Words.English Translation: → Tamil: பிரியாணி piriyani from tamil பிரியாணி piriyani dish of rice cooked with spices and meat and/or vegetables ← classical persian بریانی biryānī dish of rice cooked with spices and meat and/or vegetables ← classical persian بریان biryān roast; grilled
Words.Definition: a Singaporean and Malaysian dish which is based on the Indian biryani but has developed several differences to suit local preferences. It is typically served at Indian-Muslim eateries and stalls.

Words.English Translation: → English: brother from english brother male sibling; term of address or endearment for a male person
Words.Definition: term of address or endearment for a male person
Words.Example: Brudder, canteen pe?

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: buay tahan from singlish buay tahan unable to bear or resist ← hokkien (poj) 𫧃 𣍐 bōe not; cannot; unable to + malay tahan bear; endure; resist
Words.Definition: (transitive, of something or someone) to be unable to withstand or endure; to find intolerable or unbearable
Words.Example: Bth his videos, even more bth his face

Words.English Translation: → English: build to order from english build to order a scheme by HDB to build housing according to demand, where applicants apply for a new flat via a balloting system ← english build construct; erect + english to order as commissioned; in fulfilment of a request; bespoke
Words.Definition: a scheme by HDB to build housing according to demand, where applicants apply for a new flat via a balloting system.
Words.Example: BTO flats come with basic home design features and are an affordable and popular option for young married couples who are first-time homeowners.

Words.English Translation: → Mandarin: 变态 變態 pinyin: biàn tài + 叔叔 變態 pinyin: shū shu from mandarin (pinyin) 变态 變態 biàn tài abnormal; twisted; perverse; lecher + mandarin (pinyin) 叔叔 變態 shū shu uncle; paternal uncle
Words.Definition: abbreviation of bian tai shu shu
Words.Example: we BBFA can also become Kpop boy band. Call us btss

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 母 poj: bú from hokkien (poj) 母 bú mother; female
Words.Definition: mother; also used in phrases such as limbu and lin lao bu.
Words.Example: It doesn't matter whether it is a siam bu, or a viet bu, or ah tiong bu, as long as it is a chio bu, then it is a good bu.
Related: Siam bu for wife, Siam diu for life

Words.Word: bu hui zuo ren 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Mandarin: 不会 不會 pinyin: bù hùi + 做人 pinyin: zuò rén from mandarin (pinyin) 不会 不會 bù hùi not know how to; cannot ← mandarin (pinyin) 不 不 bù not; do not + mandarin (pinyin) 会 會 hùi know; can + mandarin (pinyin) 做人 zuò rén behave properly; conduct oneself well ← mandarin (pinyin) 做 zuò be; do + mandarin (pinyin) 人 rén person; human
Words.Definition: to not know how to behave properly; to conduct oneself poorly; to lack integrity and ethics

Words.Word: bu lang sai 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Min nan: 舞 poj: bú + 弄狮 弄獅 poj: lāng-sai from min nan (poj) 舞 bú dance + min nan (poj) 弄狮 弄獅 lāng-sai lion dance ← min nan (poj) 弄 弄 lāng play; show off + min nan (poj) 狮 獅 sai lion
Words.Definition: to perform a lion dance
Words.Example: Ladies.. You all will want to go stead with someone who knows how to boo lang sai (lion dance) or not?

Words.English Translation: → Min nan: 舞龙 舞龍 poj: bú-lêng from min nan (poj) 舞龙 舞龍 bú-lêng dragon dance ← min nan (poj) 舞 舞 bú dance + min nan (poj) 龙 龍 lêng dragon
Words.Definition: to perform a dragon dance

Words.English Translation: → Malay: buah from malay buah fruit
Words.Definition: (usually in compounds) fruit

Words.English Translation: → Malay: buah ceri from malay buah ceri Muntingia calabura ← malay buah fruit + malay ceri cherry ← english cherry small, edible, usu. red fruit ← vulgar latin ceresia cherry ← ancient greek κερᾰ́σῐον kerásion cherry; cherry tree
Words.Definition: Muntingia calabura or its edible fruit, originally native to South and Central America but now widespread in tropical regions. The fruit is a sweet red berry around 1.5cm in diameter, and vaguely resembles a cherry. The inside of the fruit contains a juicy pulp with thousands of tiny edible seeds, like a fig, and is said to taste like cotton candy.
Words.Example: Beyond the enclave was a copse of fruit trees including rambutan and guava trees. As kids, we’d routinely injure ourselves climbing these trees. Other antics include launching buah cheri (Malayan cherry) fruit at one another using slingshots.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: buah + duku from malay buah fruit + malay duku edible fruit of the Lansium domesticum tree
Words.Definition: the edible fruit of a variety of the Lansium domesticum tree, which are round and between 2.5 - 5.0 cm in diameter.[1] The fruit's flesh is segmented into large segments the length of the fruit itself. The flesh has a mild flavour and is translucent-white in colour. It is a sweeter variety of the langsat. The duku tree is shorter and wider than the langsat tree.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: buah kana from malay buah kana Chinese olive; Vatica ridleyana or its edible fruit ← malay buah fruit + malay kana Chinese olive ← hokkien (poj) 橄榄 橄欖 kaⁿ-ná Chinese olive
Words.Definition: Vatica ridleyana, a critically endangered medium-sized tree native to Singapore, or its coarse and brown fruit
Words.Example: Coat the buah kana mould with flour and knock out excess flour,place a bit of the dough in the mould and knock out slowly from the mould the dough.

Words.English Translation: → Baba malay: buah keluak from baba malay buah keluak the seeds of the Pangium edule tree ← malay / baba malay buah fruit; any small or roundish object + baba malay keluak Likely, but other possible etymologies exist (onom.) vomiting sound; nausea
Words.Definition: the edible* seeds of the Pangium edule tree, also known as kepayang in Malay, native to Southeast Asia.[1] It is famously used as one of the main ingredients in traditional Peranakan dishes like ayam buah keluak, as well as more modern creations such as buah keluak fried rice.*Buah keluak has to be boiled, buried, and soaked for up to forty days before culinary use, to draw out the toxic hydrogen cyanide naturally present in the raw nuts.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: buah + susu from malay buah fruit + malay susu breasts; milk
Words.Definition: the edible fruit of the Passiflora laurifolia L. plant, native to South America.[1] It is a milder, less tart variety of passionfruit, and is also known by water lemon, yellow granadilla, and various other names in other regions.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 抹牛油 poj: boah/boa̍h gû-iû from hokkien (poj) 抹牛油 boah/boa̍h gû-iû (fig.) criticize; scold, (lit.) spread butter ← hokkien (poj) 抹 boah/boa̍h smear; spread + hokkien (poj) 牛油 gû-iû butter; beef tallow
Words.Definition: (euphemistic, idiom) to criticize; to scold
Words.Example: After badly messing up the accounts for the third time, Andy tioh buak gu yu by his boss until damn cham.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: buang from malay buang throw away; discard
Words.Definition: to throw away; to discard
Words.Example: Buangkok cos my cat is neutered so the kok macham buang liao

Words.English Translation: → Malay: buang tabiat from malay buang tabiat behave differently than usual ← malay buang throw away; discard + malay tabiat character; behaviour; temperament ← arabic طَبِيعَة ṭabīʕa nature; character; disposition
Words.Definition: to behave unusually; to act out of character
Words.Example: These forms of conduct are called buang tebiat, which literally means “throw behaviour.” I say it’s a bad habit because our religious leaders say it’s more in line with superstition than Islam. But still we do it.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: buat + bodoh from malay buat do; make + malay bodoh stupid; idiot; fool
Words.Definition: to play dumb; to ignore the obvious; to feign ignorance

Words.English Translation: → Malay: buat malu from malay buat malu bring shame; embarrass ← malay buat do; make + malay malu shy; embarrassed
Words.Definition: to bring shame; to humiliate or embarrass
Words.Example: Some people have less common sense. Empathy 😒😒😒. Buat malu jer. I also don't eat infront of my malay friends since secondary school. This call respect.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 𫧃/袂 𣍐/袂 poj: bōe/bē from hokkien (poj) 𫧃/袂 𣍐/袂 bōe/bē cannot; not; won't ← hokkien (poj) 无 無 bô no; not + hokkien (poj) 会 會 ē can; able to; will
Words.Definition: cannot; unable to
Words.Example: steady → buay steady

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 𫧃/袂 𣍐/袂 poj: bōe/bē + 啱 poj: gam from hokkien (poj) 𫧃/袂 𣍐/袂 bōe/bē cannot; not; won't ← hokkien (poj) 无 無 bô no; not + hokkien (poj) 会 會 ē can; able to; will + hokkien (poj) 啱 gam compatible; suitable; getting along well; fit; just right ← cantonese (jyutping) 啱 ngaam1 compatible; suitable; getting along well; fit; just right
Words.Definition: incompatible; unfriendly; not getting along well
Words.Example: so lee and son buay gam each other... no wonder korea was so fragmented they were shat thruout the whole AFC tournement... the old birds buay song with the new birds and the new birds buay song with the old birds...

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 𫧃晓 𣍐曉 poj: bōe-hiáu / bē-hiáu from hokkien (poj) 𫧃晓 𣍐曉 bōe-hiáu / bē-hiáu not know how to; unable to ← hokkien (poj) 𫧃 𣍐 bōe/bē cannot; unable to + hokkien (poj) 晓 曉 hiáu understand; get; know
Words.Definition: to not know (how to); to be unable to (for lack of knowledge or having learned to do so)
Words.Example: Since many foreigners buay hiao proper Singlish, it's easy to pick them out when they try to chin chai whack one awkward 'lah' or 'leh' in their sentences.

Words.Word: buay hiao bai 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 𫧃晓䆀 𣍐曉䆀 poj: bōe-hiáu-bái from hokkien (poj) 𫧃晓䆀 𣍐曉䆀 bōe-hiáu-bái arrogant; shameless ← hokkien (poj) 𫧃晓 𣍐曉 bōe-hiáu not know how to; unable to + hokkien (poj) 䆀 䆀 bái bad; disappointing; difficult
Words.Definition: shameless; overwhelmingly arrogant; inclined to show off
Words.Example: Not all Singapore influencers are considered buay hiao bai, but aspiring ones without anything to show for it might be. Social media comments and instant messaging have made this even more apparent these days.

Words.Word: buay hiao zo lang 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 𫧃晓 𣍐曉 poj: bōe-hiáu / bē-hiáu + Min nan: 做侬 做儂 poj: chò-lâng from hokkien (poj) 𫧃晓 𣍐曉 bōe-hiáu / bē-hiáu not know how to; unable to ← hokkien (poj) 𫧃 𣍐 bōe/bē cannot; unable to + hokkien (poj) 晓 曉 hiáu understand; get; know + min nan (poj) 做侬 做儂 chò-lâng behave properly; conduct oneself well ← min nan (poj) 做 做 chò be; do + min nan (poj) 侬 儂 lâng person; human
Words.Definition: to not know how to behave properly; to conduct oneself poorly; to lack integrity and ethics
Words.Example: Buay hiao zo lang ... Or low intelligence person

Words.English Translation: → Min nan / hinghua: 𫧃赴 𣍐赴 poj: bōe-hù from min nan / hinghua (poj) 𫧃赴 𣍐赴 bōe-hù not fast enough; not in time; unable to make it on time ← min nan / hinghua (poj) 𫧃 𣍐 bōe cannot; unable to + min nan / hinghua (poj) 赴 赴 hù go to; get to
Words.Definition: to not make it on time; to be too late
Words.Example: Got this in my car. Just a press of button either inside or at the boot will activate it. But a few times people not familiar will attempt to force it close.. chiong out of the car to stop that also buay hoo.. super heart pain.

Words.Word: buay kam guan 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 𫧃甘愿 𣍐甘願 poj: bōe-kam-goān from hokkien (poj) 𫧃甘愿 𣍐甘願 bōe-kam-goān unwilling ← hokkien (poj) 𫧃 𣍐 bōe not + hokkien (poj) 甘愿 甘願 kam-goān willing
Words.Definition: unsatisfied; displeased; unwilling to accept something
Words.Example: The cake! It’s just the right texture. Fluffeh yet not light until you buay kam guan you paid $3 for it; also not too heavy until it tastes jelat. Just nice!!

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 𫧃干 𣍐幹 poj: bōe-kàn from hokkien (poj) 𫧃干 𣍐幹 bōe-kàn incompetent; useless ← hokkien (poj) 𫧃 𣍐 bōe cannot; unable to + hokkien (poj) 干 幹 kàn work; do; manage to do
Words.Definition: incompetent; useless
Words.Example: I don't believe that someone can be this buay kan... must be he buat bodoh nia.

Words.Word: buay kan tan 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 𫧃/袂 𣍐/袂 poj: bōe/bē + 简单 簡單 poj: kán-tan from hokkien (poj) 𫧃/袂 𣍐/袂 bōe/bē cannot; not; won't ← hokkien (poj) 无 無 bô no; not + hokkien (poj) 会 會 ē can; able to; will + hokkien (poj) 简单 簡單 kán-tan easy; simple
Words.Definition: not easy; not simple; complicated; difficult
Words.Example: Bros, full time job buay kan tang leh...need to use so mani mani SIM cards and hide behind VPNs....

Words.Word: buay kia lang 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Min nan: 𫧃惊侬 𣍐驚 poj: bōe-kiaⁿ-lâng from min nan (poj) 𫧃惊侬 𣍐驚 bōe-kiaⁿ-lâng not fast enough; not in time; unable to make it on time ← min nan (poj) 𫧃 𣍐 bōe not; do not + min nan (poj) 惊 驚 kiaⁿ fear; be afraid of; frighten + min nan (poj) 侬 儂 lâng person; people; human being
Words.Definition: to not be scared of what others might think; to be unafraid of backlash; to be brazen, bold, and shameless
Words.Example: HUAT AH! Ready for the chinese lunar new year // Ang Ang Buay Kia Lang 💋💅

Words.Word: buay kia lang tu lan 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 𫧃惊侬 𣍐驚 poj: bōe-kiaⁿ-lâng + 揬𡳞 poj: tu̍h-lān from hokkien (poj) 𫧃惊侬 𣍐驚 bōe-kiaⁿ-lâng not fast enough; not in time; unable to make it on time ← hokkien (poj) 𫧃 𣍐 bōe not; do not + hokkien (poj) 惊 驚 kiaⁿ fear; be afraid of; frighten + hokkien (poj) 侬 儂 lâng person; people; human being + hokkien (poj) 揬𡳞 tu̍h-lān annoying ← hokkien (poj) 揬 tu̍h poke; prod; jab + hokkien (poj) 𡳞 lān penis
Words.Definition: not scared of offending, angering, or frustrating others; unafraid of backlash; brazen, bold, and shameless
Words.Example: We hv been world number 1 in car price for at least the last 30yrs. Oni pap hv the cheek to continue increasing all sort of taxes to make it even more expensive. Beh kia lang dulan.

Words.Word: buay lin chu 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 𫧃认厝 𣍐認厝 poj: bōe-līn-chhù from hokkien (poj) 𫧃认厝 𣍐認厝 bōe-līn-chhù in a state of mental confusion; frightened; panicked ← hokkien (poj) 𫧃 𣍐 bōe cannot; unable to + hokkien (poj) 認 认 līn recognize; distinguish + hokkien (poj) 厝 厝 chhù house; building; home
Words.Definition: in a state of mental confusion; frightened; panicked

Words.English Translation: → Min nan: 𫧃歹 𣍐歹 poj: bōe-pháiⁿ from min nan (poj) 𫧃歹 𣍐歹 bōe-pháiⁿ not bad; pretty good ← min nan (poj) 𫧃 𣍐 bōe not; cannot + min nan (poj) 歹 歹 pháiⁿ bad; evil
Words.Definition: (litotes) not bad; pretty good; decent
Words.Example: That movie buay pai, quite exciting sia.

Words.Word: buay pai jiak 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Min nan: 𫧃歹食 𣍐歹食 poj: bōe-pháiⁿ-chia̍h from min nan (poj) 𫧃歹食 𣍐歹食 bōe-pháiⁿ-chia̍h not bad-tasting ← min nan (poj) 𫧃 𣍐 bōe not + min nan (poj) 歹 pháiⁿ bad; difficult; tough + min nan (poj) 食 chia̍h eat
Words.Definition: not bad-tasting; palatable
Words.Example: Actually still buay pai jiak. Standard dropped yes, but the char siew is still very shiok.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 𫧃/袂 𣍐/袂 poj: bōe/bē + 歹势 歹勢 poj: pháiⁿ-sè from hokkien (poj) 𫧃/袂 𣍐/袂 bōe/bē cannot; not; won't ← hokkien (poj) 无 無 bô no; not + hokkien (poj) 会 會 ē can; able to; will + hokkien (poj) 歹势 歹勢 pháiⁿ-sè sorry; excuse me; embarrassed
Words.Definition: shameless; unashamed
Words.Example: At first I was scared to leave work before the boss pang kang, but now that I'm a few months in I buay paĩseh leave at 6:00 sharp.

Words.English Translation: → Min nan: 𫧃使 𣍐使 poj: bōe-sái / bē-sái from min nan (poj) 𫧃使 𣍐使 bōe-sái / bē-sái cannot; may not; not allowed to
Words.Definition: cannot; may not; not allowed to
Words.Example: - Can find anyone to cover my shift next weekend?- Buay sai, it's the CNY long weekend, no one will do it lah.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 𫧃死 𣍐死 poj: bōe-sí from hokkien (poj) 𫧃死 𣍐死 bōe-sí won’t/doesn’t die ← hokkien (poj) 𫧃 𣍐 bōe won’t; doesn’t; isn’t + hokkien (poj) 死 死 sí die; dead
Words.Definition: ‘no harm trying’; ‘it won’t kill you’; ‘it’s worth a shot’; used to reassure someone that attempting something is not too risky or has manageably low consequences
Words.Example: Dun so goyang leh. Fast game, buay si one.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 𫧃爽 𣍐爽 poj: bōe-sóng from hokkien (poj) 𫧃爽 𣍐爽 bōe-sóng unhappy; dissatisfied; unwell ← hokkien (poj) 𫧃 𣍐 bōe not; cannot + hokkien (poj) 爽 爽 sóng pleased; happy; satisfied; feel good
Words.Definition: unhappy; dissatisfied
Words.Example: The more Buay See thought about it, the more he felt buay song ... "Boss," Buay See said, straightening himself, spewing his speech in a Merlion-style torrent. It was the only way to get the injustice off his chest.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 𫧃 𣍐 poj: bōe + Singlish: steady from hokkien (poj) 𫧃 𣍐 bōe not + singlish steady cool; solid; capable; ready ← english steady unwavering; firm; resolute ← hokkien (poj) 势 勢 sè power; poise & hokkien (poj) 在 在 chai steady; solid, confident, and collected under pressure
Words.Definition: spoilsport; describing a person whose behaviour sours situations for others
Words.Example: - Wee Kheng every time si peh buay steady sia. I never do homework he also must go pau toh. - Cheh, no wonder you just now tioh kan by Mdm Kuan.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 𫧃媠 𣍐媠 poj: bōe-súi from hokkien (poj) 𫧃媠 𣍐媠 bōe-súi not pretty, not nice ← hokkien (poj) 𫧃 𣍐 bōe no; not + hokkien (poj) 媠 媠 súi beautiful; good-looking; nice
Words.Definition: not nice; cruel; unkind; unfair
Words.Example: You told me to turn, I respect you, I turn and park at the loading bay. And you come over and take down my licence plate number. Buay swee lah.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 𫧃 𣍐 poj: bōe + Malay: tahan from hokkien (poj) 𫧃 𣍐 bōe not; cannot; unable to + malay tahan bear; endure; resist
Words.Definition: (transitive, of something or someone) to be unable to withstand or endure; to find intolerable or unbearable
Words.Example: I really buay tahan the heat nowadays... sometimes even aircon is not enough sia.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 𫧃/袂 𣍐/袂 poj: bōe/bē + English: tank from hokkien (poj) 𫧃/袂 𣍐/袂 bōe/bē cannot; not able ← hokkien (poj) 无 無 bô no; not + hokkien (poj) 会 會 ē can; able to; will + english tank armoured, self-propelled battle vehicle, (games) class whose role is to absorb damage ← english tank large container for storing liquids e.g. water ← portuguese tanque tank; cistern; reservoir ← general indian ṭanki tank; cistern; reservoir
Words.Definition: unable to bear, endure, or tolerate; unable to handle any longer
Words.Example: Haii. I really abit buay tank liao. Every morning i stand at the altar and pray.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 𫧃/袂 𣍐/袂 poj: bōe/bē + 当 當 poj: tong/tng from hokkien (poj) 𫧃/袂 𣍐/袂 bōe/bē cannot; not able ← hokkien (poj) 无 無 bô no; not + hokkien (poj) 会 會 ē can; able to; will + hokkien (poj) 当 當 tong/tng withstand; endure; resist
Words.Definition: to be unable to bear, endure, or tolerate
Words.Example: Even the super rich Ben Yeo buay tong coffeeshop rental, that's why he shuttered his fish soup stall?

Words.Word: buay yao kin 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 𫧃要紧 𣍐要緊 poj: bōe-iàu-kín from hokkien (poj) 𫧃要紧 𣍐要緊 bōe-iàu-kín don't worry; no problem; never mind ← hokkien (poj) 𫧃 𫧃 bōe not; do not + hokkien (poj) 要紧 要緊 iàu-kín urgent; pressing; serious
Words.Definition: 'don't worry about it'; 'no problem'; 'never mind'; 'it's alright'
Words.Example: Bro. Buay yau kin lah. U done a very good job for everyone here. Kam siah huh.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 𫧃在 𣍐在 poj: bōe-chāi from hokkien (poj) 𫧃在 𣍐在 bōe-chāi panicky; frantic; not calm or cool-headed ← hokkien (poj) 𫧃 𣍐 bōe not; cannot + hokkien (poj) 在 在 chāi steady; solid, confident, and collected under pressure
Words.Definition: panicky; frantic; not calm or cool-headed

Words.Word: buay zi dong 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 𫧃 𣍐 poj: bōe + General chinese: 自动 自動 pinyin: zì dòng from hokkien (poj) 𫧃 𣍐 bōe not + general chinese (pinyin) 自动 自動 zì dòng of one's own accord; automatically ← general chinese (pinyin) 自 自 zì own; oneself; self + general chinese (pinyin) 动 動 dòng move; act
Words.Definition: lacking initiative; not automatic; being too lazy to act on one's own accord
Words.Example: By Day 6, workers started to slacken visibly ... I was covering for the machinist's extended break time so that I could keep the machine running. In Singapore, we call this buay zi dong. I wasn't sure if Afghanis understand the meaning of such a concept. If they did, they were doing a good job being just that.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: buaya from malay buaya (lit.) crocodile, (fig.) playboy; womanizer ← malay buaya darat (lit.) land crocodile;(fig.) playboy; womanizer; bad guy ← malay buaya crocodile + malay darat land; ground
Words.Definition: crocodile

Words.English Translation: → Malay: buaya + English: biology from malay buaya (lit.) crocodile, (fig.) playboy; womanizer ← malay buaya darat (lit.) land crocodile;(fig.) playboy; womanizer; bad guy ← malay buaya crocodile + malay darat land; ground + english biology study of living things; life sciences ← new latin biologia biology ← ancient greek βίος bíos life ← ancient greek -λογία -logía the study or knowledge of
Words.Definition: (humorous) the study or science of womanizing, seduction, and flirting with women; pick-up artistry
Words.Example: Bro has PhD in buayalogy

Words.English Translation: → Malay: bubu from malay bubu fishing trap
Words.Definition: a type of primitive passive fishing trap consisting of a cone or funnel leading to a second, larger, container. These were traditionally made out of two woven bamboo or rattan baskets, but can be made from any other suitable material such as a net stretched over a frame or plastic bottles. The trap must have holes small enough for water to flow through relatively unobstructed, yet through which fish of the desired size are unable to escape. When placed into a stream of running water, fish eventually swim into the conical entrance (sometimes attracted by bait) and are unable to find their way back out. The trap is set and then collected after a period of time.
Words.Example: If we use nets to fish, we’d have to go in the evening and only come back the following morning. We’d have to spend a whole night at sea. With bubu, we don’t need to do that. We can spend our nights watching television instead ...

Words.English Translation: → Malay: bubur from malay bubur porridge; congee
Words.Definition: porridge; congee

Words.English Translation: → Malay: bubur + Possible, but not certain cacah from malay bubur porridge; congee + malay Possible, but not certain cacah chop into bits
Words.Definition: a sweet dessert soup originating in Malaysian and Peranakan cuisine, consisting of sago, coconut milk, and pandan, with cubes of a starchy vegetable such as sweet potato, yam, taro, or banana. Some variations may include additional ingredients such as gula melaka, tapioca jelly, black-eyed peas, or grated coconut. It may be served hot or cold, and was traditionally eaten by Peranakans to celebrate Chap Go Mei.[1][2]

Words.English Translation: → Malay: bubur + pulut + hitam from malay bubur porridge; congee + malay pulut glutinous rice + malay hitam black
Words.Definition: a sweet dessert, originating in Indonesian cuisine, consisting of a sticky porridge of black glutinous rice with coconut milk and either gula melaka or cane sugar. Additional ingredients, such as green beans, pandan, and salt may also be included.[1]

Words.English Translation: → English: buff + lord from english buff extremely muscular; big, fit, and strong + english lord master; a master of sth.; leader; a superior in the nobility
Words.Definition: a person who is extremely muscular or strong
Words.Example: Aiseh, buff lord sia! Look at him carrying 10 chairs at once!

Words.English Translation: → Malay: buka puasa from malay buka puasa break fast ← malay buka open + malay puasa fast; fasting ← sanskrit उपवास upavāsa fast; fasting
Words.Definition: iftar; the breaking of the day's fast during the Muslim fasting month of Ramadan
Words.Example: Breaking fast, or buka puasa, after a long day of fasting was a homely affair back in the day.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: bukit from malay bukit hill
Words.Definition: a hill
Words.Example: These hills, or bukits, of which the highest was Bukit Timah, would also be tactically important.

Words.English Translation: → English: bus + MRT + walk from english bus large vehicle for transporting many people along a road ✂ english omnibus large vehicle for transporting many people along a road ← french [voiture] omnibus [vehicle/carriage] for all ← latin omnibus for all + english MRT Singapore’s public train system ← english Mass Rapid Transit Singapore’s public train system ← english mass large group, body, or quantity + english rapid quick; fast + english transit transport; move from one place to another + english walk locomote by stepping one foot in front of the other while keeping the other planted on the ground

Words.English Translation: → Tagalog: kalamansi from tagalog kalamansi Citrus × microcarpa, or its edible fruit
Words.Definition: the plant Citrus × microcarpa, or its edible fruit. As a kumquat hybrid, the plant is sometimes sold as an ornamental, especially during the Chinese New Year season. The fruit resembles a spherical lime, and is yellow-orange in colour on the inside. It is used in many traditional dishes, often as a season or garnish, and is also popular for its juice. It is also known as limau kasturi.[1]
Words.Example: The Calamansi (Citrus microcarpa) grows to about 3 to 4 m tall, producing white to whitish-pink fragrant flowers. It grows best in moist to well-drained soil. This citrus-scented plant not only brings a fresh aroma to your garden but it is also a food source for the caterpillars of the Lime Butterfly and its small rounded fruits can be eaten when they turn from green to light orange.

Words.English Translation: → Cantonese: 茄哩啡 jyutping: ke4/ke1 le1 fe1 from cantonese (jyutping) 茄哩啡 ke4/ke1 le1 fe1 (acting) extra; background actor or player ← english carefree without worries or concern

Words.Example: I tell you, can is can. No need so kancheong like everyone else.

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: can + English: means + Singlish: can from singlish can see can for details ← english can able to; know how to; may; be possible; potentially be + english means signifies; sincerely expresses + singlish can see can for details ← english can able to; know how to; may; be possible; potentially be

Words.English Translation: → English: cannon + fairy ↻ Hokkien: 大炮仙 poj: tōa-phàu-sian from english cannon large gun used to fire ballistic projectiles ← old french canon cannon; tube ← old italian cannone cannon; tube ← latin canna reed; cane ← ancient greek κᾰ́ννᾱ kánnā reed; cane ← akkadian 𒂵𒉡𒌑𒌝 qanûm reed; cane + english fairy mythical being; immortal being in Chinese mythology ← old french faerie magical realm of the fae ← latin fāta goddess of fate; fairy; fae ↻ hokkien (poj) 大炮仙 tōa-phàu-sian braggart; bigmouth; boaster; braggadocio ← hokkien (poj) 大炮 tōa-phàu cannon, (fig.) braggart ← hokkien (poj) 仙 sian immortal; deity; fairy

Words.Example: - Mummy can I go watch Shrek 3 with my friend?- Cannot! Finish your homework first then can.

Words.English Translation: → English: capsicum from english capsicum plant of the genus Capsicum, bearing edible fruits known as pepper ← new latin Capsicum the genus Capsicum ← ancient greek καψικός kapsikós box-like ← latin capsa box; case; cylindrical container

Words.English Translation: → Malay: capteh from malay capteh Malay term for jianzi (traditional Chinese shuttlecock game)
Words.Definition: A popular traditional game which involves trying to keep a shuttlecock in the air primarily using the feet, with other parts of the leg or body except the hands often also allowed. The shuttlecock is made of a bunch of colourful rooster feathers attached at the quills to a weighted base of rubber and/or metal discs. Some modern examples may use plastic feathers or a plastic base.It is similar in concept to keepie-uppies (using a shuttlecock instead of a football), and similarly can be played by passing the shuttlecock between multiple players while keeping it airborne.The game originated in the Han dynasty of ancient China, and is known as 毽子, jiàn zi ("little shuttlecock") in Chinese.[1]

Words.Word: catch no ball 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → English: catch + no + ball ↻ Min nan: 掠无球 掠無球 poj: lia̍h-bô-kiû from english catch capture; grab; intercept + english no not any; zero + english ball roughly spherical object ↻ min nan (poj) 掠无球 掠無球 lia̍h-bô-kiû not understand ← min nan (poj) 掠 掠 lia̍h catch; capture + min nan (poj) 无 無 bô no; not; don't + min nan (poj) 球 球 kiû ball

Words.English Translation: → English: catching from english catching the act of the verb 'catch' (to capture; reach)
Words.Definition: a popular children's game, involving a 'catcher' (or for larger groups, more than one 'catcher') who chases the other players around a predefined playing area while attempting to 'catch' them (usually by touching any part of their body with either hand).While rules vary, the role of 'catcher' is usually passed on the player who is 'caught', and so the game can continue indefinitely from thereon out; most games implement an 'immunity period' where someone who has just 'caught' another player cannot immediately be 'caught' back by the same player. The variation where a 'catcher' remains a 'catcher' after being 'caught' is specifically known as 'virus', instead of 'catching'.The game is often played by groups of children during recess or after school.It is known by 'tag', 'it', 'tick', and various other names in other English-speaking countries.
Words.Example: During recess, the school is filled with the playful cries and taunts of school-kids, and the desperate, arrhythmic pattering of their Bata-clad feet, as they run amok in the quadrangle playing catching.

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: CB + English: leaf from singlish CB (vg.) abbreviation of chee bai ← singlish chee bai (vg.) cunt; general term of insult or abuse ← min nan (poj) 膣屄 chi-bai (vg.) cunt; vagina; vulva + english leaf usually green and flat organ of a plant, typically responsible for photosynthesis, transpiration, etc.
Words.Definition: (vulgar) the leaves of the Dillenia suffruticosa plant, known as simpuh air in Malay or CB plant in Singlish, which are around 12.5 - 38 by 6.5 - 25.5 cm in dimension.[1] When the leaf is split open at the base near the petiole (stalk), it resembles a vulva, hence the nickname.While soldiers are discouraged from using it as camouflage, its wide area and strength make it ideal as a dish or wrapper (bungkus) for food like nasi lemak. In the jungle, these qualities also happen to make it decent toilet paper in a pinch.
Words.Example: In case you think I’m cherry-picking, I present you with the CB leaf. ... "Gentlemen, I proudly announce that you’re no longer boys." Reminder: this screenplay was approved by MINDEF.

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: CB + English: mouth from singlish CB (vg.) abbreviation of chee bai ← singlish chee bai (vg.) cunt; general term of insult or abuse ← min nan (poj) 膣屄 chi-bai (vg.) cunt; vagina; vulva + english mouth part of the face used for speech

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: CB + English: plant from singlish CB (vg.) abbreviation of chee bai ← singlish chee bai (vg.) cunt; general term of insult or abuse ← min nan (poj) 膣屄 chi-bai (vg.) cunt; vagina; vulva + english plant member of the kingdom Plantae, (inf.) any similar vegetative or herbaceous organism ← old french planta vegetative life in general; plants; vegetation + latin plante any propagative vegetable part e.g. shoot or sprout; young tree; shrub
Words.Definition: (vulgar) the Dillenia suffruticosa plant, also known as simpuh air in Malay. It is a large shrub that grows up to 7 m tall.[1] It is well known for its large leaves, which are nicknamed CB leaves in Singlish.
Words.Example: ... the trainer shown us this plant and told us it is a no-no to use its leave as camouflage material.The trainer than proceeded to show us why it is called the CB plant: [sic]

Words.English Translation: → Malay: cempedak from malay cempedak Artocarpus integer var. integer tree, or its edible fruit
Words.Definition: the Artocarpus integer var. integer tree, or its edible fruit. The tree is native to Southeast Asia and grows up to 20 m tall, and bears large, capsule-shaped fruits around 20 - 35 cm long and 10 - 15 cm in diameter.[1] The fruit has a thick, bumpy skin resembling that of a jackfruit, and has a fragrance resembling that of a durian, albeit less pungent and offensive. It is related to breadfruit and jackfruit.[2]
Words.Example: Unlike other hawkers, the stall offers more inter-meal grub than a full meal, the highlight being their popular cempedak fritters. Despite it being of the same genus as jackfruit, this fruit was one I had yet to try.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: cepat lari from malay cepat lari run quickly ← malay cepat run + malay lari fast; quick

Words.English Translation: → English: cereal + prawn from english cereal food made from processed edible grains ← french céréale cereal ← latin Cerealis of or relating to Ceres, goddes of agriculture + english prawn crustacean in the suborder Dendrobranchiata; shrimp; meat of such an animal
Words.Definition: a dish made from frying prawns and Nestum instant cereal in a mixture of flour, butter, and spices such as curry leaves and chilli. It is believed to have been invented by zi char stalls in Singapore, and was possibly inspired by Hong Kong "typhoon shelter"-style dishes, which have similar characteristics and ingredients.
Words.Example: Singapore's culinary highlights now include favourites such as sambal seafood, crispy cereal prawns and even chicken rice as it is today.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 菜脯 poj: chhài-pó͘ from hokkien (poj) 菜脯 chhài-pó͘ (lit.) preserved / sun-dried vegetable; (fig.) dried preserved radish
Words.Definition: dried preserved radish. Used as an ingredient to add an umami or salty flavour to several dishes, such as chai tow kway and porridge. There are two main varieties available in Singapore - sweet and salty.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 菜心 poj: chhài-sim from hokkien (poj) 菜心 chhài-sim the leafy green vegetable Brassica rapa var. parachinensis
Words.Definition: the leafy green vegetable Brassica rapa var. parachinensis. It has cream- to pale-yellow-coloured flowers, and grows quickly, being ready to harvest between 1.5 - 3 months after sowing. The plant is a popular ingredient in Chinese cooking, especially its shoots and young leaves.[1]

Words.Word: chai tow kway 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Teochew: 菜头粿 菜頭粿 peng'im: cai3 tao5 guê2 from teochew (peng'im) 菜头粿 菜頭粿 cai3 tao5 guê2 chai tow kway; (lit.) radish/daikon steamed cake ← teochew (peng'im) 菜头 菜頭 cai3 tao5 radish; Chinese radish; daikon + teochew (peng'im) 粿 粿 guê2 kueh
Words.Definition: a popular dish of Teochew origin, which uses a base of steamed radish cake made from shredded Chinese radish, rice flour, and water. The radish cake is then cut approximately into cubes (in some variations, long cuboids) with a square section of around 1 cm2 (1 cm × 1 cm), and stir-fried with egg, fish sauce and/or soya sauce, chai poh, finely-diced garlic, and white pepper. It can be fried with or without chilli, usually to request. It is usually then garnished with white pepper and spring onions before serving. Some hawkers may include fresh or dried prawns in the dish. If kicap manis is added towards the end of the stir-frying process, the "black" version can be produced; if not, it is known as the "white" version. It is often possible to order a plate of half black and half white as well.
Words.Example: Later I will go downstairs and tell the chye tow kuey uncle downstairs that he is more capable than Obama because his chye tow kuey costs $3 per plate. He should really go into politics. At least he is friendly and never talks down to me. Neither does he ever claim that he sells the best chye tow kuey in Singapore.
Related: or ya peh ya som balik ah roti prata chai tow kway

Words.English Translation: → Malay: candu from malay candu opium ← tamil சாந்து cāntu cement; mortar; paste
Words.Definition: opium that has been prepared for smoking
Words.Example: Bukit Chandu, Malay for "Opium Hill", was the site of a last stand by Lieutenant Adnan Saidi and his platoon of 42 soldiers against the Japanese invaders during World War II. Their heroic sacrifice is commemorated with the museum and interpretive centre, Reflections at Bukit Chandu, located near Pasir Panjang MRT Station and just south-east of the site of the actual battle.

Words.English Translation: → English: change + parade from english change swap or replace clothing + english parade (mil.) organized procession involving soldiers marching in formation; soldiers composing the procession; general show or display of military force or drills ← french parade military display; ostentatious procession ← italian parata military parade; preparation; ostentatious display
Words.Definition: (military) a collective punishment involving a commander repeatedly sending a group of soldiers up to their bunks to change into various attires, such as full battle order or smart 4, and then fall back into formation in front of the commander within an unreasonably short time.After the soldiers inevitably fail to meet the impossible timings given, and trifling mistakes, imperfections, or anything unsatisfactory are found in the soldiers' dress, they are typically ordered to carry out some form of penalty (such as planks or push-ups). They are then ordered back up to change into a different set of attire. This procedure carries on until the commander exacting the punishment is satisfied or bored enough.Despite the sardonic name of "parade", the soldiers are forced to "march" up and down without respite, in an affair ironically lacking any pomp or dignity whatsoever. While publicly "banned" since the 1990s, change parades have persisted as a popular punishment until today.
Words.Example: I feel change parade is the most bo liao punishment. ... Failure in meeting the timing (always)would result in doing pushups (always). [sic]

Words.English Translation: → English: change + underwear from english change swap or replace clothing + english underwear undergarments or underpants, such as briefs or panties
Words.Definition: (military) to swap an old sheet of telt overlaying a map for a new one.
Words.Example: PS told me to change underwear because the telt was covered in various blotches, scratches, and marker smudges, and had become too cloudy to see any details on the map unerneath.

Words.English Translation: → Min nan: 臭 poj: chhàu + English: private from min nan (poj) 臭 chhàu smelly; repulsive; bad; detestable + english private (mil.) lowest rank in the army, besides recruit; a soldier holding that rank ← latin prīvātus not belonging to the state; personal

Words.Example: As mere chao privates, we had to take orders from the commanders, which unfortunately also involved a lot of dropping 20 and other random punishments whenever we did anything that made them buey song.

Words.English Translation: → Min nan: 臭 poj: chhàu + English: recruit from min nan (poj) 臭 chhàu smelly; repulsive; bad; detestable + english recruit (mil.) a newly enlisted soldier; the rank held by such a soldier ← french recruter to recruit

Words.Word: chap cai png 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 杂菜饭 雜菜飯 poj: cha̍p-chhài-pn̄g from hokkien (poj) 杂菜饭 雜菜飯 cha̍p-chhài-pn̄g economy rice ← hokkien (poj) 杂 雜 cha̍p mixed; assorted + hokkien (poj) 菜 菜 chhài vegetable + hokkien (poj) 饭 飯 pn̄g cooked rice; meal; food
Words.Definition: white rice with portions of assorted dishes, typically a selection or combination of vegetable dishes and meat or fish dishes chosen by the customer from a display
Words.Example: The chap cai png with wok hei stall at the coffee shop near me operates 24 hours making it easy for those working nearby factories a meal option while on graveyard shift as well as those on morning shifts to dabao their meals on the way to work.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 杂种 雜種 poj: cha̍p-chéng + 十种 十種 poj: cha̍p-chéng from hokkien (poj) 杂种 雜種 cha̍p-chéng (derog.) bastard; mongrel; half-breed ← hokkien (poj) 杂 雜 cha̍p mixed; all kinds + hokkien (poj) 种 種 chéng ethnicity; breed; kind; sort + hokkien (poj) 十种 十種 cha̍p-chéng hybrid; crossbreed, (derog.) bastard ← hokkien (poj) 十 十 cha̍p ten + hokkien (poj) 种 種 chéng ethnicity; breed; kind; sort
Words.Definition: (derogatory) bastard; a person born out of an affair, or out of wedlock; term of abuse for a bastard or mixed-race person
Words.Example: Short for Chap-cheng, probably. Hokkien for ten bloods. They call us that when we are not looking, ...

Words.Word: chap cheng kau 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 杂种 雜種 poj: cha̍p-chéng or 十种 十種 poj: cha̍p-chéng + Min nan: 狗 poj: káu from hokkien (poj) 杂种 雜種 cha̍p-chéng (derog.) bastard; mongrel; half-breed ← hokkien (poj) 杂 雜 cha̍p mixed; all kinds + hokkien (poj) 种 種 chéng ethnicity; breed; kind; sort or hokkien (poj) 十种 十種 cha̍p-chéng hybrid; crossbreed, (derog.) bastard ← hokkien (poj) 十 十 cha̍p ten + hokkien (poj) 种 種 chéng ethnicity; breed; kind; sort + min nan (poj) 狗 káu dog; (derog.) sb. or sth. detestable
Words.Definition: (derogatory) bastard; a person born out of an affair, or out of wedlock; term of abuse for a bastard or mixed-race person

Words.Word: chap cheng kia 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 杂种 雜種 poj: cha̍p-chéng + 十种 十種 poj: cha̍p-chéng + 囝 poj: kiáⁿ from hokkien (poj) 杂种 雜種 cha̍p-chéng (derog.) bastard; mongrel; half-breed ← hokkien (poj) 杂 雜 cha̍p mixed; all kinds + hokkien (poj) 种 種 chéng ethnicity; breed; kind; sort + hokkien (poj) 十种 十種 cha̍p-chéng hybrid; crossbreed, (derog.) bastard ← hokkien (poj) 十 十 cha̍p ten + hokkien (poj) 种 種 chéng ethnicity; breed; kind; sort + hokkien (poj) 囝 kiáⁿ kid; child
Words.Definition: (derogatory) bastard; a person born out of an affair, or out of wedlock; term of abuse for a bastard or mixed-race person
Words.Example: Many migrant Chinese viewed the peranakan as a community of 'culturally-bastardised Chinese'. Derogatory terms such as chap cheng kia (or bastard) were used liberally to describe the peranakan, and were flashpoints in public spaces.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 杂菜 雜菜 poj: cha̍p-chhài from hokkien (poj) 杂菜 雜菜 cha̍p-chhài mixed vegetables ← hokkien (poj) 杂 雜 cha̍p mixed; assorted + hokkien (poj) 菜 菜 chhài vegetables
Words.Definition: a stew of mixed vegetables, such as cabbage, mushrooms, and black fungus in broth, and often tossed with other ingredients such as strips of tau kee, carrot, tang hoon, and garlic.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 十五暝 poj: cha̍p-gō͘-mêe/mê/mî from hokkien (poj) 十五暝 cha̍p-gō͘-mêe/mê/mî 15th night (of Chinese New Year), also known as Lantern Festival ← hokkien (poj) 十五 cha̍p-gō͘ fifteen + hokkien (poj) 暝 mêe/mê/mî night
Words.Definition: the 15th night of Chinese New Year, also known as Lantern Festival. Some families may celebrate this with a second reunion dinner, with oranges and lanterns playing a prominent role in the celebrations. It is also known as the "Chinese Valentine's Day", and it is a chap goh mei tradition for single ladies to line up to throw oranges and other small fruits into the Singapore River (or other significant local bodies of water in other cities, such as the sea by the Esplanade in Penang) to wish for husbands.[1]
Words.Example: Chinese New Year is coming to an end, which means it’s time for single ladies to look for their Mr Right on Chap Goh Meh today.While many people still practice the centuries-old ritual to toss mandarin oranges into lakes or rivers, feng shui master Jessie Lee doesn’t really recommend it in this day and age.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 十二支 poj: cha̍p-jī-ki from hokkien (poj) 十二支 cha̍p-jī-ki gambling game played with 12 cards or game pieces ← hokkien (poj) 十二 cha̍p-jī twelve + hokkien (poj) 支 ki stick; measure word or classifier for long, thin objects
Words.Definition: an illegal gambling game played in Singapore until the late 1960s, when stricter law enforcement and mass arrests of operators from various syndicates caused a decline in its popularity. It is believed to have originated in Johor in the early 1890s.The game involves a player guessing two numbers from a set of twelve (sometimes represented using cards, but originally based on the twelve pieces in Chinese chess - hence the name).[1]
Words.Example: Because my family was not well-to-do, we patronized the two food stalls only when Mother won chap ji ki or when Father had some extra cash from working overtime.

Words.Word: chap lau chu [t͡säp̚˩ lɑʊ˩ t͡sʰuˑ˩] 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 十楼厝 十樓厝 poj: cha̍p-lâu-chhù from hokkien (poj) 十楼厝 十樓厝 cha̍p-lâu-chhù ten-storey house/building ← hokkien (poj) 十 十 cha̍p ten + hokkien (poj) 楼 樓 lâu storey; floor + hokkien (poj) 厝 厝 chhù house; building
Words.Definition: one of the original ten-storey HDB flats built by the HDB in the early 1960s.
Words.Example: Singapore's first 10-storey flats, colloquially known as "chap lau chu" in Hokkien, are seven blocks of brown and beige-coloured flats in Commonwealth Drive. Built in the early 1960s, this pioneering "mini estate" introduced Singaporeans to the concept of a self-contained "public housing precinct" with several tall housing blocks next to a food centre. Decades later, the once-bustling neighbourhood lies vacant.

Words.Word: chap sa tiam 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 十三点 十三點 poj: cha̍p-saⁿ-tiám from hokkien (poj) 十三点 十三點 cha̍p-saⁿ-tiám 13:00, (slang) half-baked; incompetent ← hokkien (poj) 十三 十三 cha̍p-saⁿ thirteen + hokkien (poj) 点 點 tiám o’clock
Words.Definition: sloppy; of poor quality; incompetent; uninterested; slipshod
Words.Example: mine is just ordinary chap sar tiam kopitiam collection only..

Words.English Translation: → Cantonese: 杂崩冷 雜崩冷 jyutping: zaap6 bang1 lang1 from cantonese (jyutping) 杂崩冷 雜崩冷 zaap6 bang1 lang1 (slang) mixed; miscellaneous; assorted; having all kinds of random things
Words.Definition: mixed; miscellaneous; assorted; having all kinds of random things
Words.Example: A mixture of ideas, beauty and craft, mostly at random, or you can say chapalang.

Words.Word: char kway teow /ˌt͡ʃɑː ˌkweɪ ˈtjaʊ/ 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Hokkien / teochew: 炒粿条 炒粿條 poj: chhá-kóe-tiâu from hokkien / teochew (poj) 炒粿条 炒粿條 chhá-kóe-tiâu char kway teow, a stir-fried noodle dish ← hokkien / teochew (poj) 炒 炒 chhá stir-fry + hokkien / teochew (poj) 粿条 粿條 kóe-tiâu kway teow, a type of flat rice noodle
Words.Definition: a stir-fried noodle dish with origins in the cuisine of southern Chinese immigrants in maritime South-East Asia, likely those with Teochew backgrounds.[1][2] It consists of kway teow (flat rice noodles) stir-fried with soya sauce, garlic, egg, lard, hum (cockles), chilli, prawns, tau geh (beansprouts), and/or other ingredients.[2]A good plate of char kway teow is, amongst other factors, judged by whether it possesses the right amount of wok hei, which imparts a delicious, smoky flavour to the noodles.[1]Char kway teow is one of the most famous dishes of the Singaporean-Malaysian culinary continuum, known in and exported to numerous countries all across the world, and is a common symbol of Singapore's hawker culture of cheap, delicious, but not necessarily healthy food.
Words.Example: If you want a taste of this shop's famous char kway teow, then be prepared to queue because patrons are aplenty and daily business hours are short. Flocked to by old gourmets, the char kway teow here comes with an intense flavour — packed with wok hey, and bursting with ingredients such as shallots, eggs, beansprouts, cockles, sausages, and more.
Related: or ya peh ya som balik ah roti prata char kway teow

Words.Word: char siew /t͡ʃɑ siu̯/ 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Cantonese: 叉烧 叉燒 jyutping: caa1 siu1 from cantonese (jyutping) 叉烧 叉燒 caa1 siu1 Cantonese barbecued pork ← hokkien / teochew (poj) 叉 叉 caa1 fork + hokkien / teochew (poj) 烧 燒 siu1 roast; grill
Words.Definition: a Cantonese barbecued pork, typically made from a slab of boneless pork shoulder, loin, belly, or some other cut. The meat is glazed with 'char siew sauce', which is a mixture of five-spice powder, honey or some other sweetener, fermented bean paste, hoisin sauce, and soya sauce, and traditionally coloured red with some form of food colouring. It is then skewered and barbecued or roasted, which is commercially done in a large rotisserie oven. The final product can be sliced and eaten on its own, or used as an ingredient or accompaniment to other foods, such as in char siew pau or char siew rice.
Words.Example: Watch Daddy Lau teach us how to make char siu! Also known as Chinese BBQ Pork, this is a classic Cantonese dish that's extremely popular. If you’re new to char siu, it’s an extremely juicy, sweet, and savory pork dish, and it’s a popular entree on its own - and a pleasant addition to many different types of noodles, rice dishes, and pastries like cha siu bao.
Related: char siew more use than you

Words.Word: char siew more use than you 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Cantonese: 生嚿叉烧好过生你 生嚿叉燒好過生你 jyutping: saang1 gau6 caa1 siu1 hou2 gwo3 saang1 nei5 from cantonese (jyutping) 生嚿叉烧好过生你 生嚿叉燒好過生你 saang1 gau6 caa1 siu1 hou2 gwo3 saang1 nei5 expression used to curse one's child as useless; good-for-nothing ← cantonese (jyutping) 生 生 saang1 give birth + cantonese (jyutping) 嚿 嚿 gau6 (classifier) piece; chunk + cantonese (jyutping) 叉烧 叉燒 caa1 siu1 char siew + cantonese (jyutping) 好过 好過 hou2 gwo3 better than; rather; might as well + cantonese (jyutping) 生 生 saang1 give birth
Words.Definition: expression used to scold one's child as useless, especially by mothers; insult for a good-for-nothing child
Words.Example: Only know how to spend my money, still say I sia suay you. Give birth to char siew more use than you!

Words.Word: char siew pau 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Cantonese: 叉烧包 叉燒包 jyutping: caa1 siu1 baau1 from cantonese (jyutping) 叉烧包 叉燒包 caa1 siu1 baau1 pau (soft bun) filled with char siew ← cantonese (jyutping) 叉烧 叉燒 caa1 siu1 char siew (Cantonese barbecued pork) + cantonese (jyutping) 包 包 baau1 pau (soft bun)
Words.Definition: a soft, fluffy steamed bun (pau) filled with char siew, popular as a snack, dim sum dish, or breakfast food. It has origins in Cantonese cuisine. It is white and roughly dome-shaped in appearance, with either an "X" mark cut into the top which opens as it steams and puffs (like a huat kueh), or a red dot made with food colouring on top to mark that it contains char siew. The filling usually is pork, but may be made of another condiment - for example, chicken char siew for a halal version.May also refer to the baked version, which is brown and has a crispy exterior, almost like a char siew soh.
Words.Example: Although I didn’t grow up in a family that made or ate chasiu, we always bought chasiubao from Chinese bakeries. ... Sweet, airy bakery-made chasiubao were a treat—we couldn’t often make it up to Chinatown from the ‘burbs.

Words.Word: char siew rice 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Cantonese: 叉烧 叉燒 jyutping: caa1 siu1 + English: rice from cantonese (jyutping) 叉烧 叉燒 caa1 siu1 Cantonese barbecued pork ← hokkien / teochew (poj) 叉 叉 caa1 fork + hokkien / teochew (poj) 烧 燒 siu1 roast; grill + english rice edible seeds, used as a food grain, of the Oryza sativa cereal crop
Words.Definition: a popular dish of Cantonese origin, consisting of slices of char siew laid over steamed rice, typically with a side vegetable and some sauce, typically based on dark soya sauce, slathered on top. It can be ordered at most roast meat stalls and some chicken rice stalls.
Words.Example: Fu Shi in Marsiling has its fair share of regular customers. They offer three types of cut: a leaner pork shoulder, fatty pork belly and a tender underarm cut. Their Char Siew Rice costs $3.50, but we heartily recommend that you top-up $1 for some roasted pork.

Words.Word: char siew soh 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Cantonese: 叉烧酥 叉燒酥 jyutping: caa1 siu1 sou1 from cantonese (jyutping) 叉烧酥 叉燒酥 caa1 siu1 sou1 Cantonese barbecued pork puff ← cantonese (jyutping) 叉烧 叉燒 caa1 siu1 char siew (Cantonese barbecued pork) + cantonese (jyutping) 酥 酥 sou1 flaky pastry; crispy
Words.Definition: a baked pastry of Cantonese origin with a buttery, flaky, and crispy crust, filled with char siew. It is a popular dish at dim sum restaurants, but can often also be found as a snack at local bakeries. It is usually somewhat tubular in shape, with flattened ends where the pastry skin is closed to seal in the contents. The top of the pastry is usually decorated with sesame seeds.
Words.Example: Ever since I first tried the Char Siew Sou at Yanting Restaurant four years ago, I’ve been on a hunt for the best in Singapore. Sadly, most places serve mediocre Baked BBQ Pork Puffs that aren’t worth the calories.

Words.English Translation: → English: Charlie Mike from english Charlie Mike (military) NATO phonetic alphabet reading of 'CM'; to continue or prolong a mission due to having received new orders or an update in the situation ← english CM abbreviation of 'continue mission' ← english continue prolong; keep going; proceed + english mission tasks; assignment; duty
Words.Definition: (military) to continue a task, mission, assignment etc., especially one perceived as unpleasant, fatiguing, or tiresome, due to having received new orders or an update in the situation; to have to perform extra duties at or very near the perceived end of a mission or assignment
Words.Example: After the defence portion, we headed back to OCS for a Charlie Mike – a 1km Casevac around OCS before ending it at the OCS parade square, where we received our green berets.

Words.English Translation: → English: cheapo from english cheapo (slang) cheapskate; miser; niggard, goods of questionable quality produced at low cost ← english cheap affordable; inexpensive, (inf.) stingy; overly frugal; niggardly + english -o colloquializing suffix
Words.Definition: a cheapskate; a miser
Words.Example: What is the right way to wear perfume? ... Technically speaking, the old-fashioned way is that you spritz the scent a few times into the air using an atomiser and then walk into the mist. The whole idea is that you are covered evenly in the heavenly scent. Of course, the cheapos among us would say the surroundings – not you – end up smelling lovely.
Related: gor jiam dua kuay gu chia leng

Words.English Translation: → Possible, but not certain English: cheater buck + cheater + Possible, but not certain balk from english Possible, but not certain cheater buck (hunting) male deer with unusual antlers ← english cheater small antler protrusions off the main branch + english buck male deer (or also some other male animals) + english cheater sb. who flouts and bends rules to attempt to gain an advantage ← english cheat flout and bend rules to attempt to gain an advantage; deceive; swindle + english -er suffix used to form a noun which performs the action of the root verb + english Possible, but not certain balk (sports and games) deceive; trick; feign; try to cheat or make an illegal move
Words.Definition: a cheater; someone who flouts and bends the rules to attempt to gain an advantage
Words.Example: Cheaterbuck Beef Pho: Yea. Shortcut and pretty quick way of making Beef Pho. However, please feel free to stew your own beef broth ... if you want to.

Words.English Translation: → English: check + clear from english check inspect; verify; confirm; control ← english check (chess) place a king under threat of capture; intj. to notify opponent of a move w. such a threat ← old french eschec (chess) check ← medieval latin scaccus (chess) check ← medieval latin scaccī chess ← arabic شَاه šāh shah; (chess) king ← persian شاه šâh king; shah; (chess) king + english clear free of sth. unwanted ← anglo-norman cler well visible; bright ← old french cler well visible; bright ← latin clārus bright; distinct
Words.Definition: (literal, military) to empty the chamber of a firearm, typically done by cocking it to eject any cartridges and visually ensuring that no ammunition remains inside
Words.Example: Before going outfield, must make sure to unload check clear, else sekali your ET gonna have to come out.

Words.Example: Cham, chi cham, because he had so many sufferings, and as a servant of God, surely you should not be so cham, you should not be so suay.

Words.Word: chee cheong fun [ˈt͡ʃʰiː˦ ˈt͡ʃʰjɔŋ˨˩ ˈfan˨˦], [- ˈt͡ʃʰɔŋ˨˩ -] 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Cantonese: 猪肠粉 豬腸粉 jyutping: zyu1 coeng4 fan2 from cantonese (jyutping) 猪肠粉 豬腸粉 zyu1 coeng4 fan2 chee cheong fun ← cantonese (jyutping) 猪肠 豬腸 zyu1 coeng4 pig intestines + cantonese (jyutping) 粉 粉 fan2 starch or flour noodles
Words.Definition: a Cantonese dish made of some condiment, such as prawn, scallop, or char siew, rolled in a thin sheet of rice noodle and cut or scored into bite-sized segments. The sheets are made from a mixture of rice flour, tapioca starch, and glutinous rice flour, giving them a desirably elastic and springy texture. It is usually served soaked in a gravy of mostly soy sauce and sesame oil, and sometimes with chilli or sambal on the side, for flavour. It can also be served with dark soy sauce and topped with sesame seeds. It is a popular breakfast food and dim sum dish in Singapore.
Words.Example: Despite its popularity as a local breakfast staple, I’ve never been a big fan of chee cheong fun. Those slick, flat rice sheets have a hard time keeping up with my gluttonous appetite and I find myself needing more food after every CCF meal.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 痴风 痴風 poj: chhi-hong from hokkien (poj) 痴风 痴風 chhi-hong lustful; thirsty; skirt-chasing ← hokkien (poj) 痴 痴 chhi crazy about; infatuated; foolish; deluded + hokkien (poj) 风 風 hong demeanor; promiscuous; lewd; dissolute; love; sexual attraction

Marine Parade or East Coast Town Council? Flood their hotline with complaints and let the relevant MPs know on their FB. Chee Liao Bee!

Words.Definition: (dated, derogatory) new Chinese immigrants that came from China to Singapore in the 19th and 20th centuries, in contrast to the much longer-established Peranakan Chinese
Words.Example: The presence of a dragon was very rare and, even then, it was understated or highly stylised or secondary to the total composition of the work. When prominent, it usually indicated marriage to a newer pure Chinese immigrant (sinkeh or Cina Gek) whose tastes were more Sinitic and conservatively Chinese with a resistance to the local influences.

Words.Example: Only then the BMW cina pek uncle came out with sombong ass face macam I kacau him. And then after some argument in his broken cinapek England and my fake ass American accent he challenged to a fight. He was a short overweight middle age cina uncle pek.

Words.English Translation: → Teochew / hokkien: 积恶 積惡 poj: chek-ak from teochew / hokkien (poj) 积恶 積惡 chek-ak commit many evil deeds; build up bad karma ← teochew / hokkien (poj) 积 積 chek amass; accumulate; store up + teochew / hokkien (poj) 恶 惡 ak evil; hostile; wicked; difficult; verbally abuse; hate
