Words.Definition: dear; dearest; darling; apple of my eye; term of endearment for a very cherished and treasured loved one
Words.Example: We, are coming to Sing to meet you. Eagerly awaiting to meet you dear ... Ok chellam, take care. See you soon.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: cendol from malay cendol cendol ← balinese ᬘᬾᬦ᭄ᬤᭀᬮ᭄ céndol drink made from sago, coconut milk and sugar or javanese ꦕꦺꦤ꧀ꦝꦺꦴꦭ꧀ jèndhol swollen; bulge
Words.Definition: a sweet dessert or drink most likely originating from Indonesia (where it is also called dawet), which has various forms all across South-East Asia. In Singapore, it usually consists of 'worm-like' pieces of green pandan rice noodles or jelly (similar to bee tai bak), shaved ice, and sweetened red beans in coconut milk. Gula melaka is added as a sweetener. The dish is often topped with additional ingredients, such as ice cream or durian.
Words.Example: There was a hawker selling iced chendol drinks in front of the former Hollywood Theatre at Tg. Katong Road. I would saved my pocket money (10 cents) at the time just to savour the delicious cup of chendol drink on a hot afternoon. It was so delicious & thirst quenching!!!

Words.Word: cheng hu kang 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 政府工 無政府 poj: chèng-hú-kang from hokkien (poj) 政府工 無政府 chèng-hú-kang government job ← hokkien (poj) 政府 無 chèng-hú government + hokkien (poj) 工 政府 kang work
Words.Definition: a government job
Words.Example: If you are just doing some JLB director post with no executive powder, no reason for your director to oppose it. The additional job will not affect your cheng hu kang.

Words.Word: cheng hu lang 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 政府 poj: chèng-hú + 侬 儂 poj: lâng from hokkien (poj) 政府 chèng-hú government + hokkien (poj) 侬 儂 lâng person; people; human being
Words.Definition: a government official or public servant

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 清汤 清湯 poj: chheng-thng from hokkien (poj) 清汤 清湯 chheng-thng sweet Chinese dessert soup ← hokkien (poj) 清 清 chheng clear; pure + hokkien (poj) 汤 湯 thng soup
Words.Definition: a sweet Chinese dessert soup consisting of pearl barley grains, longans, rock sugar, red dates, white fungus, candied winter melon, gingko nuts, crushed ice, and/or other ingredients.
Words.Example: Missing Dad plus the extreme hot weather recently, Cheng Tng seems to be a good option to combat the heat and bring me some good childhood memories. For some of you who are not familiar with this dessert, Cheng Tng literally means clear soup. It is both light and refreshing.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: cengal from malay cengal Neobalanocarpus heimii, a tree native to Singapore
Words.Definition: Neobalanocarpus heimii, a tree native to Singapore that grows up to 60 m tall. It was historically important as a good source of high quality timber and resin, for uses such as boatbuilding.[1] It is believed that Changi (the location) takes its name either from this tree, or from Hopea sangal, also known as "chengal pasir" or "chengal mata kucing".[2]

Words.English Translation: → English: teacher from english teacher sb. who teaches, esp. in a school
Words.Definition: (informal) term of address for a teacher
Words.Example: Cher, if till the end of the year still got virus means no more exams right? Yayyyy!!

Words.English Translation: → Baba malay: cherki from baba malay cherki card deck with 3 suits labelled 1-9; game played with such a deck ← hokkien (poj) 一 chi̍t one + hokkien (poj) 枝 ki long or cylindrical object e.g. a stick or branch
Words.Definition: a Chinese card deck with three suits of cards (known by various names in various languages, e.g. "Coins", "Strings", and "Myriads") numbered from 1 to 9. It was and is used to play various popular card games in South-East Asia, with one of the most popular games known as 'cherki' itself.[1][2][3]
Words.Example: Many Peranakans enhoyed gambling. Some Babas could even lose their houses in a single sitting! Nyonyas shared their husbands' love for gambling. A card game called cherki was extremely popular among them.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: cermin from malay cermin mirror
Words.Definition: the trevally, any of various species of edible marine fish in the family Carangidae, especially Alectis indica (the diamond trevally, also known as the mirror fish)
Words.Example: Word was around that the Chermins were back at their usuall hunting ground after a few years of recovery. Changi Naval Base fishing area used to be a heaven for Chermins until they dredged the entire area, presumably for the Naval ships to pass by ... The Chermins were not in their abundant schools and we had to drift in order to make the most of the time and terrain.

Words.Word: cherry cherry long chiam pas 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → English: Cherry* + Singlish: long chiam pas from english Cherry* common female given name + singlish long chiam pas scissors paper stone ← english Possible, but not certain roshambo scissors paper stone ← japanese Possible, but not certain じゃんけんぽん じゃん拳ぽん jankenpon scissors paper stone
Words.Definition: a children's rhyme chanted before playing scissors paper stone. Its lyrics have several variations, but all end in the cry "cherry cherry long chiam pas!".
Words.Example: The kids taught me a hilarious chinese rhyme recently, a popular one called Sally Sally Lom Chiam Pass. Some people know it as Cherry Cherry Lom Chiam Pass, or even Chelly Chelly Lom Chiam Pass. The husband says people didn’t have fancy names like Sally back when the rhyme started but I honestly do not know a single person called Chelly so I’m sticking with Sally.

Words.English Translation: → English: children from english children pl. of child; kids
Words.Definition: children; kids
Words.Example: Low ses have chewren will only ruin chewren life ... Dinks saving chewren from potential bad life

Words.English Translation: → Cantonese / hokkien: 𪠳 唓 jyutping: ce2 from cantonese / hokkien (jyutping) 𪠳 唓 ce2 exp. of disappointment, dismissal, or disdain at unmet expectations
Words.Definition: 'no wonder'; 'bah!'; 'pffft'; 'humph'; expression of disappointment, dismissal, or disdain at something not meeting expectations
Words.Example: Chey, that's all meh? I thought the work would be more.

Words.English Translation: → Unknown: ? from unknown ? See notes.
Words.Definition: exclamation of joy, triumph, awe, admiration, astonishment, etc.

Words.English Translation: → Unknown: ? from unknown ? See notes.
Words.Definition: exclamation of joy, triumph, awe, admiration, astonishment, marvel, etc.
Words.Example: Often enough, we hear the great saying, “Behind every successful man stands a strong woman”. That woman is me (cheydebah!) and underneath the veil of success are unseen hard work, sacrifice, dedication and persistence (that’s you!).

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 尺 poj: chhek from hokkien (poj) 尺 chhek 'Chinese foot' (traditional unit of length)
Words.Definition: an old Chinese unit of length equal to 10 chhun, standardized as 14 3⁄4 inches or 37.4650 cm.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 寸 poj: chhùn from hokkien (poj) 寸 chhùn 'Chinese inch' (traditional unit of length)
Words.Definition: an old Chinese unit of length equal to 1⁄10 chhek, standardized as 1 19⁄40 inches or 37.4650 mm.

Words.Word: chi bo eng 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 饲无用 飼無用 poj: chhī-bô-ēng from hokkien (poj) 饲无用 飼無用 chhī-bô-ēng useless; unfilial, (lit. was useless to raise) ← hokkien (poj) 饲 飼 chhī raise; rear; feed + hokkien (poj) 无用 無用 bô-ēng useless
Words.Definition: (of a child) useless; good-for-nothing; unfilial; not worth raising
Words.Example: Their estranged son wouldn't make the time to find closure and make things up to his mother, even on her deathbed. Chi bo eng.

Words.English Translation: → Mandarin: 吃饭 吃飯 pinyin: chī fàn from mandarin (pinyin) 吃饭 吃飯 chī fàn eat ← mandarin (pinyin) 吃 吃 chī eat + mandarin (pinyin) 饭 飯 fàn cooked rice
Words.Definition: to eat; to dine
Words.Example: Lai lai, chi fan. Lim peh hungry already.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 刺激 poj: chhì-kek/kiak from hokkien (poj) 刺激 chhì-kek/kiak stimulating; irritating; provoke ← hokkien (poj) 刺 chhì prick; sting + hokkien (poj) 激 kek/kiak excite; incite; irritate
Words.Definition: to excite; to stimulate; to provoke
Words.Example: Dunno why people like to exaggerate to ownself chee kek ownself.Average performer is $8-10k by mid 30? … You got see any teacher in mid 30 hit that? … Or any police officer in mid 30 hit that?

Words.Word: chi wu eng 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 饲有用 飼有用 poj: chhī-ū-ēng from hokkien (poj) 饲有用 飼有用 chhī-ū-ēng loving; filial; devoted, (lit. was worth it to raise) ← hokkien (poj) 饲 飼 chhī raise; rear; feed + hokkien (poj) 有用 有用 ū-ēng useful; have a purpose
Words.Definition: (of a child) dutiful; loving; filial; devoted; worth raising
Words.Example: Kenneth always lights up his mother's day with his bubbly antics and loving nature. Chi wu eng.

Words.Word: chiam tao roti 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 尖头罗啲 尖頭羅啲 poj: chiam-thâu-lô-ti from hokkien (poj) 尖头罗啲 尖頭羅啲 chiam-thâu-lô-ti baguette (bread) ← hokkien (poj) 尖头 尖頭 chiam-thâu pointy-headed + hokkien (poj) 罗啲 羅啲 lô-ti bread ← malay roti bread ← tamil ரொட்டி roṭṭi bread ← sanskrit रोटिका roṭikā bread
Words.Definition: baguette (a type of bread)
Words.Example: On the 10th day of Christmas my true God gave to me, 2 days mc, one PES f, and a sio sio eh jiam tau lo teeee [sic]

Words.English Translation: → English: chicken ↻ General chinese: 鸡 雞 pinyin: jī from english chicken member of the subspecies Gallus gallus domesticus ↻ general chinese (pinyin) 鸡 雞 jī chicken, (slang, f.) prostitute
Words.Definition: a female prostitute

Words.English Translation: → English: chicken + backside from english chicken member of the subspecies Gallus gallus domesticus + english backside buttocks; anatomical rear end ← english back rear; behind + english side face; flank
Words.Definition: (military) A badly-done short haircut or buzz cut.
Words.Example: Chicken backside. What SAF barbers model the backs of soldiers’ hairstyles after.

Words.English Translation: → English: chicken + business ↻ Cantonese: 做鸡 做雞 jyutping: zou6 gai1 from english chicken member of the subspecies Gallus gallus domesticus + english business trade; professional work; involvement in sth. ↻ cantonese (jyutping) 做鸡 做雞 zou6 gai1 work as a prostitute; engage in sex work ← cantonese (jyutping) 做 做 zou6 become; do + general chinese (pinyin) 鸡 雞 gai1 chicken, (fig.) prostitute; sex worker
Words.Definition: (euphemistic) prostitution; sex work
Words.Example: At Monga’s media preview, actor Chase Tan plus celeb funnymen Jack Neo, Mark Lee, Marcus Chin, Henry Thia and Jeremy Chan show up to support their friend Nono and, er, feed him fried chicken. “We’re both in the chicken business (Chinese slang for prostitution),” Nono quips to Mark, who owns chicken rice restaurant 13 Stages at Kallang Wave Mall.

Words.English Translation: → English: chicken feed from english chicken feed food (e.g. grain) given to chickens, (id.) tiny or insignificant amt. of sth.
Words.Definition: a trivially easy task; a piece of cake
Words.Example: - Any sweat?- No sweat, chicken feet! Ha ha all the way!

Words.English Translation: → English: chicken + floss from english chicken meat from a chicken (Gallus gallus domesticus) + english floss light, thread-like or fibrous material
Words.Definition: a food made by stewing chicken together with spices and sugar until soft enough to be pulled into individual fibres. It is then further beaten and broken down while being heated e.g. by frying in a large wok until it is dry and slightly crispy. The finished product has a texture similar to coarse wool.
Words.Example: There are more than 30 new items, including crispy deep-fried mango 'n' prawn rolls, steamed creamy custard buns and French toast smothered with creamy mayonnaise and a generous serving of chicken floss.

Words.Word: chicken hand duck leg 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → English: chicken + hand + duck + leg ↻ Cantonese: 鸡手鸭脚 雞手鴨腳 jyutping: gai1 sau2 aap3 goek3 from english chicken member of the subspecies Gallus gallus domesticus + english hand part of the body below the wrist including the palm and fingers + english duck any member of of several species of waterfowl in the family Anatidae + english leg (in humans) one of the lower limbs of the body, used primarily for locomotion e.g. walking ↻ cantonese (jyutping) 鸡手鸭脚 雞手鴨腳 gai1 sau2 aap3 goek3 clumsy; bumbling ← cantonese (jyutping) 鸡 雜 gai1 chicken + cantonese (jyutping) 手 手 sau2 hand + cantonese (jyutping) 鸭 鴨 aap3 duck + cantonese (jyutping) 脚 腳 goek3 leg; foot
Words.Definition: (idiom) clumsy; bumbling; lacking physical coordination
Words.Example: Mi dread exercise sia... always cannot get the actions right... chicken hand, duck leg one.. haiz..

Words.English Translation: → English: chicken + Malay / indonesian: rendang from english chicken meat from a chicken (Gallus gallus domesticus) + malay / indonesian rendang type of dry curry; rich, spicy stew- or curry-like dish with meat
Words.Definition: a variant of rendang using chicken as the meat
Words.Example: When a chicken dish eliminated a Malaysian-born woman from reality TV show MasterChef UK last week because it was just not crispy enough, a nation saw red.Judges John Torode and Gregg Wallace said Bristol-based Zaleha Kadir Olpin's chicken rendang needed "crispy" skin.

Words.English Translation: → English: chicken + rice ↻ General chinese: 鸡饭 雞飯 hts: kɔi1 ʔbui1 from english chicken member of the subspecies Gallus gallus domesticus + english rice edible seeds, used as a food grain, of the Oryza sativa cereal crop ↻ general chinese (hts) 鸡饭 雞飯 kɔi1 ʔbui1 chicken rice ← hainanese (hts) 文昌鸡 文昌雞 vun2 siɔ? kɔi1 Wenchang chicken + hainanese (hts) 饭 飯 ʔbui1 rice
Words.Definition: a national dish of Singapore, developed by Hainanese immigrants in the early 20th century from a traditional Hainanese dish called Wenchang chicken, which is the predecessor of today's "white" chicken rice. The rice is fried in chicken fat, then cooked in the leftover stock from poaching the chicken, combined with spices like salt, garlic, and spring onion. This process imparts an incredibly rich flavour into the rice; it is said that in Singaporean chicken rice, the rice is arguably more important than the chicken itself.[1]Apart from the Hainanese "white" chicken, most stalls offer roast chicken and sometimes others variations like lemon chicken as alternative choices.The dish is usually served with the chicken sliced and either laid over a bowl's worth of the rice, or on a separate dish; the chicken pieces are drenched in a dressing of light soya sauce, chicken oil, and sesame oil. It is served with a bowl of the leftover stock, garnished with chopped spring onions.Singaporeans prefer to eat chicken rice with either a special chilli, sweet dark soya sauce, or ginger-garlic sauce. So crucial is the chilli that sometimes people judge chicken rice based on the taste of the chilli alone.It is arguably the most famous dish of Singapore. Similar 'chicken rice' dishes also exist across the Hainanese diaspora, especially in South-East Asia, such as in Malaysia, Thailand, and Vietnam.
Words.Example: Hawker food prices rose by 6.1 per cent in 2023, the highest since 2008, a new study by the Singapore Department of Statistics (SingStat) found. For example, the average cost of a plate of chicken rice in 2023 was $4.15, up from $3.40 in 2019 ...

Words.Word: chicken rice ball 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → English: chicken + rice ↻ General chinese: 鸡饭 雞飯 hts: kɔi1 ʔbui1 + English: ball from english chicken member of the subspecies Gallus gallus domesticus + english rice edible seeds, used as a food grain, of the Oryza sativa cereal crop ↻ general chinese (hts) 鸡饭 雞飯 kɔi1 ʔbui1 chicken rice ← hainanese (hts) 文昌鸡 文昌雞 vun2 siɔ? kɔi1 Wenchang chicken + hainanese (hts) 饭 飯 ʔbui1 rice + english ball roughly spherical object
Words.Definition: a traditional way of serving Hainanese chicken rice, where the rice is shaped by hand into fist-sized balls. It is considered somewhat old-school in Singapore, but is still done in some places.
Words.Example: For the uninitiated, Hainan Chicken Rice Ball specialises in, well, Hainanese chicken rice balls, a traditional dish that is more commonly found in Malacca.

Words.English Translation: → English: chicken + Malay: serunding from english chicken meat from a chicken (Gallus gallus domesticus) + malay serunding spiced grated coconut condiment ← javanese ꦱꦿꦸꦤ꧀ꦢꦺꦁ srundèng spiced grated coconut condiment
Words.Definition: a highly savoury Malay and Indonesian condiment made from dried pulled chicken and grated coconut fried or toasted with a rempah (spice mixture) until it dry
Words.Example: Halal Beef and Chicken Serunding ... Mouth-watering and super tasty with rice, porridge, bread or even on its own! Enjoy the fluffy taste of cottony soft Serunding Floss!

Words.English Translation: → Spanish: chicozapote from spanish chicozapote Manilkara zapota ← nahuatl xicotzapotl Manilkara zapota ← nahuatl tzictli sticky substance; chicle (gum) + nahuatl tzapotl sapote (family of fruits)
Words.Definition: the edible fruit of the Manilkara zapota tree, a large, roundish, extremely sweet brown berry with black seeds. The gum of the tree, called chicle in English (a doublet from the same Nahuatl root) is a useful product as well.

Words.English Translation: → English: chilli from english chilli edible, usually spicy fruit of a plant in the genus Capsicum ← spanish chile edible, usually spicy fruit of a plant in the genus Capsicum ← nahuatl chīlli edible, usually spicy fruit of a plant in the genus Capsicum
Words.Definition: any sauce or condiment prepared using chilli peppers as the main ingredient, typically combined with other spices and aromatic ingredients such as garlic, lime juice, ginger, prawns, soya sauce, fish sauce, etc.
Words.Example: The chilli had a decent amount of garlic, but I found it too watery for my liking. It also didn’t pack much of a punch.

Words.English Translation: → English: chilli + crab from english chilli edible, usually spicy fruit of a plant in the genus Capsicum ← spanish chile edible, usually spicy fruit of a plant in the genus Capsicum ← nahuatl chīlli edible, usually spicy fruit of a plant in the genus Capsicum + english crab decapod crustacean of the infraorder Brachyura, characterized by having a carapace and the front two legs specialized into claws
Words.Definition: a dish of Singaporean origin, featuring crab cooked with a sauce made of chilli sauce, tomato sauce, garlic, eggs, and other ingredients, and typically using Sri Lankan mud crabs (Scylla serrata). It is usually served with fried or steamed man tou to soak up the sauce with.
Words.Example: Loved by locals and international visitors alike, chilli crab is an iconic Singaporean dish that hits the spot every time. The spicy, starchy, savoury and eggy dish was first created in the 1950s by Cher Yam Tian, who made a stir-fried crab dish with bottled chilli sauce instead of tomato ketchup – a popular delicacy at that time.

Words.English Translation: → English: chilli + Malay: padi from english chilli edible, usually spicy fruit of a plant in the genus Capsicum ← spanish chile edible, usually spicy fruit of a plant in the genus Capsicum ← nahuatl chīlli edible, usually spicy fruit of a plant in the genus Capsicum + malay padi tiny
Words.Definition: the edible fruit of a cultivar of Capsicum frutescens, also known as bird's eye chilli outside of Singapore.[1] While it is quite small (usually between 3 - 6 cm long), it is quite pungent (spicy). It is used almost universally in the various cuisines found in Singapore and the rest of South-East Asia. It changes from green to yellow to red as it ripens; while it is usually used when red and ripe, it can be and is also used from any stage.
Words.Example: When experts from Penn State University studied the relationship between personality traits and a liking for spicy food, they found that “sensation seekers” – those who enjoyed the thrills of roller coaster rides and gambling – were more likely to ask for chilli padi at mealtime.

Words.English Translation: → Min nan: 深 poj: chhim from min nan (poj) 深 chhim deep; profound; difficult
Words.Definition: deep; profound; difficult to grasp or understand
Words.Example: The novel explores such chim themes as love, loss, and the human condition.

Words.English Translation: → Min nan: 唚 poj: chim from min nan (poj) 唚 chim kiss
Words.Definition: to kiss; to pet amorously; to fondle
Words.Example: Keh Huat brought his steady to the HDB staircase to chim chim.

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: chim + English: -(ino)logy from singlish chim deep; profound; difficult to grasp or understand ← min nan (poj) 深 chhim deep; profound; difficult + english -(ino)logy a branch of learning; a study; (humorous) suffixed tongue-in-cheek to an english word to create a hypothetical subject of study ← english (term)inology* (clipping of e.g. 'terminology', "a descriptive set of nomenclature or technical jargon used in a field") ← latin -logia the study or knowledge of ← greek -λογία -logía denoting the study of something
Words.Definition: (humorous) the use of complex terminology and overly-sophisticated vocabulary
Words.Example: Critical reading and training in literature may seem, what Singaporeans would consider "cheeminology", requiring a special kind of education at the cost of the money-makers and practical pursuits. Perhaps this is so. However, I have never met a child of whichever level of education with whom I cannot discuss text and humanity.

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: chim + English: -ness from singlish chim deep; profound; difficult to grasp or understand ← min nan (poj) 深 chhim deep; profound; difficult + english -ness suffixed to an adj. to form a noun meaning "having the quality or state of (the adj.)"
Words.Definition: the quality of being chim; the character of using complex terminology and overly-sophisticated vocabulary
Words.Example: There is a stark difference in chimness between the compos of these two students. I personally prefer the more sophisticated one, as it shows a more advanced grasp of English.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 凊彩 poj: chhìn-chhái from hokkien (poj) 凊彩 chhìn-chhái anyhow; whatever; as one pleases; casual ← min nan (poj) 凊彩 chhìn-chhái casually; informally
Words.Definition: anyhow; as one pleases; 'whatever goes'
Words.Example: - What drink you want? - Chin chai lah, anything also can. - Orhhh, chin chai then chin chow lor.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 清草 poj: chhin-chháu from hokkien (poj) 清草 chhin-chháu grass jelly
Words.Definition: a jelly-like dessert originating from Hakka cuisine, which is made by boiling the leaves and shoots of the Platostoma palustre plant with sugar and agar, straining, and allowing the solution to cool and set.[1]It has almost no nutritional value, and is eaten and included in desserts and drinks mostly for its texture rather than its very faint taste. It is also traditionally believed to have medicinal and 'cooling' properties in Chinese medicine.[1]

Words.English Translation: → English: China + Singapore from english China country in Asia ← portuguese China China ← persian چین čin China ← sanskrit चीन Cīna China ← old chinese (zhengzhang) 秦 *zin Qin (state, dynasty) + english Singapore island city-state in South-East Asia, officially known as the Republic of Singapore ← malay Singapura Singapore ← sanskrit सिंहपुर siṃhá-pura Singapore ← sanskrit सिंह siṃhá lion + sanskrit पुर pura city
Words.Definition: (pejorative) epithet used to lament the observation or perception that Singapore is becoming more and more Sinicized, mainly due to the unchecked immigration of Chinese nationals who do not assimilate with the local culture, and many of whom are monolingual Mandarin speakers who expect everyone in Singapore to speak Mandarin
Words.Example: I’m not racist or against people from China but FOR GOD SAKE! Hire people who can speak English at the very least! From ordering food at a coffee shop to this, it’s getting worse by the day! We Singapore or Chinapore? What’s our first language?! ... Shame on you!

Words.English Translation: → English: China + Singaporean from english China country in Asia ← portuguese China China ← persian چین čin China ← sanskrit चीन Cīna China ← old chinese (zhengzhang) 秦 *zin Qin (state, dynasty) + english Singaporean of or relating to Singapore ← english Singapore island city-state in South-East Asia, officially known as the Republic of Singapore ← malay Singapura Singapore ← sanskrit सिंहपुर siṃhá-pura Singapore ← sanskrit सिंह siṃhá lion + sanskrit पुर pura city + english -an (suffix) adj. describing sth. of or pertaining to a n.
Words.Definition: (pejorative) of or relating to the observation or perception that Singapore is becoming more and more Sinicized, mainly due to the unchecked immigration of Chinese nationals who do not assimilate with the local culture, and many of whom are monolingual Mandarin speakers who expect everyone in Singapore to speak Mandarin
Words.Example: This is also why there are aplenty of integration woes from Singaporeans denial to accept Olympic-winning Chinaporean sports talents to a Chinaporean hanging China flag during Singapore National Day period. The ease of getting Singapore citizenship also contributed to the integration woes with Chinaporeans like Feng Tian Wei getting fast-tracked citizenship in less than 2 years. There is also no English test, no stringent interviews, no merit-based system in the awardance of citizenship in Singapore.

Words.English Translation: → English: Chinese + Indian from english Chinese of or relating to China or Chinese people, cultures, languages, ethnicities, etc. ← english China country and civilization in Asia ← portuguese China China ← persian چین čin China ← sanskrit चीन Cīna China ← old chinese (zhengzhang) 秦 *zin Qin (state, dynasty) + english -ese suffix used to form a demonym + english Indian of or related to Indian people, language, culture, ethnicity, etc. ← middle french indien Indian ← middle french Inde India ← classical persian هند hind India ← old persian 𐏃𐎡𐎯𐎢𐏁 hiⁿdūš India; river + middle french -ien suffix used to form a demonym
Words.Definition: having mixed Chinese and Indian ethnicity
Words.Example: “People always say that our family is ‘Chindian’,” said Muru. “But why? I always change it to ‘Indianese’ because I want the Indian part to come first! Traditionally speaking, it follows the father, right?”

Words.English Translation: → English: Chinese + helicopter from english Chinese of or relating to China or Chinese people, cultures, languages, ethnicities, etc. ← english China country and civilization in Asia ← portuguese China China ← persian چین čin China ← sanskrit चीन Cīna China ← old chinese (zhengzhang) 秦 *zin Qin (state, dynasty) + english -ese suffix used to form a demonym + english helicopter mispron. of 'educated', (lit.) an aircraft which flies and steers via one or more sets of rotating blades ← english Likely, but other possible etymologies exist educated be taught or instructed in; have studied in
Words.Definition: (derogatory, offensive) a person, often Mandarin-Chinese-educated, who is overly Chinese or stereotypically conservative Chinese, and cannot speak English well
Words.Example: My BMT buddy is such a Chinese helicopter! He grew up in Malaysia and can't speak a word of English.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 妆艺 妝藝 poj: Chng-gē from hokkien (poj) 妆艺 妝藝 Chng-gē the art of costume, adornment, and masquerade
Words.Definition: an annual street parade and carnival held during the second weekend of Chinese New Year, usually involving large floats and costumes and themed after the Zodiac animal for that year. Chingay processions have origins in China, but have developed into unique cultural events in their own rights in Singapore and Malaysia.[1]

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 俏 poj: chhió/chhiò from hokkien (poj) 俏 chhió/chhiò pretty; handsome; charming; lovely
Words.Definition: (usually of a young girl or woman) good-looking; attractive; pretty; charming
Words.Example: - That girl near me in lecture yesterday sibeh chio right, you think got chance?- Wait long long bro...

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 𲍸母 𪁎母 poj: chhio-bú + 俏 poj: chhió/chhiò from hokkien (poj) 𲍸母 𪁎母 chhio-bú horny or lustful woman; a female in heat ← hokkien (poj) 𲍸 𪁎 chhio in heat; horny; to rut + hokkien (poj) 母 母 bú female + hokkien (poj) 俏 chhió/chhiò pretty; handsome; charming; lovely
Words.Definition: a pretty girl; a sexy lady; an attractive young woman
Words.Example: “This bride-to-be is very chio, I can’t believe she wakes up early every morning to pack rice at the stall,” she said.A chio bu selling nasi padang? This is something.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 笑甲反 poj: chhiò kah péng from hokkien (poj) 笑甲反 chhiò kah péng ← hokkien (poj) 笑 chhiò laugh; laugh at; ridicule + hokkien (poj) 甲 kah until; to the point of; to the extent that + hokkien (poj) 反 péng flip over; turn over
Words.Definition: (lit.) to laugh until one flips over; to laugh uncontrollably; to ROFL
Words.Example: Now, join him as he melts your heart with his si bei gao lat (4896) Ge-Tai voice and make you chio ka peng at his Broadway Beng–ness.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 冲 衝 poj: chhiong from hokkien (poj) 冲 衝 chhiong charge; rush; dash
Words.Definition: to charge; to rush forward; to make a dash for
Words.Example: The MRT stops for around 30 seconds, which is plenty of time to get in. There's no need to chiong in and bash past all the people trying to alight.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 冲 衝 poj: chhiong + 山 poj: soaⁿ from hokkien (poj) 冲 衝 chhiong charge; rush; dash + hokkien (poj) 山 soaⁿ mountain; hill
Words.Definition: (lit.) to charge up a hill or mountain
Words.Example: Since Bukit Timah Hill is a rather underwhelming molehill in comparison to the mountains in our surrounding countries, the SAF sends its soldiers overseas to places like Brunei to chiong sua.

Words.Word: chiong sua unit 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Singlish: chiong sua + English: unit from singlish chiong sua involving tough, strenuous physical activity ← hokkien (poj) 冲 衝 chhiong charge; rush; dash + hokkien (poj) 山 山 soaⁿ mountain; hill + english unit organized group ← latin ūnītus united
Words.Definition: (military) a unit or vocation which frequently partakes in extremely tough, strenuous, and high-paced training and physical activity, with relatively little time to relax
Words.Example: PES A and B all the same one lar. You can find any chiong sua unit with like only 10% PES A, and the rest is B.

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: chiong + English: -ster from singlish chiong to charge; to rush; to make a dash for ← hokkien (poj) 冲 衝 chhiong charge; rush; dash + english -ster sb. who does or is associated with sth.
Words.Definition: someone who parties, clubs, and drinks all the time; a reveller
Words.Example: Many of those who live the chiongster life soon have their empty wallets or their waistlines catch up with them.

Words.English Translation: → English: chetty + Malay: melaka from english chetty a member of a South Indian caste of merchants, traders, money-lenders, etc. ← tamil செட்டி sheṭṭi title for member of a mercantile class ← sanskrit श्रेष्ठ śreṣṭha most splendid or sanskrit श्रेष्ठिन् śreṣṭhin head of a mercantile guild + malay melaka Melaka (state in Malaysia)
Words.Definition: a Tamil people, also known as "Indian Peranakans", who assimilated with the local culture (such as Malay language and culture) while syncretizing it with their Hindu religion and traditions.

Words.Word: chiu kana kha, kha kana lam pa

Words.English Translation: → English: chocolate bar from english chocolate bar a piece of chocolate in the shape of a roughly flat or long cuboid, sometimes segmented so smaller pieces may be easily broken off for consumption ← spanish chocolate chocolate ← nahuatl chocolatl a drink made of cacao beans + english bar a roughly cuboid piece of any solid substance ← old french barre bar
Words.Definition: (military) a small, black, bar-shaped sensor worn by a soldier during training exercises, which indicates when they have been hit by a 'round' fired from a firearm fitted with an emitter, in a similar manner to laser tag.Misplacing any of these sensors is a serious offence, which is unfortunate as they have a tendency to become loose and detach in the field.
Words.Example: If you’ve participated in the Army Training Evaluation Centre (ATEC) evaluation, the ‘chocolate bars’ will not be foreign to you.Soldiers will be fitted with ‘chocolate bars’ — which are like sensors to identify whether you’ve been hit.

Words.English Translation: → Cantonese: 啋 jyutping: coi1 from cantonese (jyutping) 啋 coi1 'touch wood'; exp. used to ward off bad luck in response to sth. inauspicious said
Words.Definition: (apotropaic) expression used to ward off bad luck when another person says something inauspicious; 'touch wood!' (but said by an opposite party)
Words.Example: Choi, choi! Alamak, don't say such things during CNY!

Words.English Translation: → General chinese: 充公 pinyin: chōng gōng from general chinese (pinyin) 充公 chōng gōng confiscate; seize; expropriate

Words.Word: chop carrot head 简 繁

Words.English Translation: → Chinese pidgin english: 速速 *see notes: chop-chop* from chinese pidgin english (*see notes) 速速 chop-chop* quick; quickly; 'hurry up' ← cantonese (jyutping) 速速 cuk1 cuk1 quick; rapid; quickly
Words.Definition: quickly; hurriedly

Words.Definition: 'hurry up'; 'quickly'; expression urging someone to make haste, or referring to hastiness and hurriedness

Words.English Translation: → Malay: cup / chup from malay cup / chup excl. requesting a stop or halt; excl. to hush or call for silence ← hindi Possible, but not certain चुप cup 'shut up'; 'shush'; 'quiet!'
Words.Definition: to reserve; to 'call dibs' on, especially a table or seat. It is usually customary accompany this by leaving a small personal object behind as a marker of reservation, such as a packet of tissue paper.
Words.Example: Can help me chope my space, I go toilet quickly.

Words.English Translation: → English: chopsticks from english chopsticks plural of 'chopstick' ← english chopstick East Asian eating utensil consisting of two sticks ← chinese pidgin english (pinyin) 速 chop* quickly; fast ↻ general chinese (pinyin) 筷子 kuài zi chopsticks, (lit.) 'little quick ones' ← general chinese (pinyin) 快 kuài quick; fast + english stick long, thin, roughly cylindrical piece of material, esp. wood
Words.Definition: a finger game played with the goal of knocking both the opponent's hands out of play. It is commonly played by children. Each player starts with one outstretched finger on each hand, and by striking any other hand with one of their hands, adds the striking hand's number of fingers to the stuck hand. A hand is eliminated when the number of fingers would equal or exceed 5. Various other rules are included, such as a "clap" or "split" where a player can "revive" their own previously-eliminated hand by clapping if their other hand has two or more fingers raised, thereby distributing the count across both hands in any way they desire.It is a mathematically solved game, meaning that any outcome can be achieved with perfect play.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 粗米粉 poj: chho͘-bí-hún from hokkien (poj) 粗米粉 chho͘-bí-hún rice noodles ← hokkien (poj) 粗 chho͘ (of cylindrical objects) thick; coarse + hokkien (poj) 米粉 bí-hún rice vermicelli; rice flour ← hokkien (poj) 米 bí rice + hokkien (poj) 粉 hún flour; powder
Words.Definition: rice noodles around the same thickness as spaghetti, commonly used in dishes such as laksa, Hokkien mee, and sliced fish soup
Words.Example: The slippery fresh rice noodles (chor bee hoon) were slicked with a coconut-rich laksa sauce perfumed with dried shrimps and grassy laksa leaves.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 粗鲁 粗魯 poj: chho͘-ló͘ from hokkien (poj) 粗鲁 粗魯 chho͘-ló͘ vulgar; crass; coarse; rude; uncouth ← hokkien (poj) 粗 粗 chho͘ crude; vulgar; rude + hokkien (poj) 鲁 魯 ló͘ vulgar; rough; unrefined
Words.Definition: vulgar; crass; coarse; rude; uncouth
Words.Example: Most would expect him to be more chor lor, given his Ah Seng fashion sense and mannerisms, but he was actually quite a polite and eloquent young man.

Words.English Translation: → Mandarin: 臭臭 pinyin: chòu chou from mandarin (pinyin) 臭臭 chòu chou old unwashed childhood comfort item e.g. a bolster or soft toy ⇇ mandarin (pinyin) 臭 chòu smelly
Words.Definition: an old, unwashed, usually huggable item from one's childhood, such as a bolster, pillow, blanket, soft toy, or towel, used for comfort and emotional support
Words.Example: It’s no surprise that one may get angry at the thought of having to, or someone washing their Chou Chou ... it’s precisely this stinky smell that makes it the most intimate and ‘personalized’ possession to you.

Words.Word: chui kong lam pa song 简 繁

Words.Definition: (vulgar) used to describe someone who talks a lot, as if they love the sound of their own voice, or listening to their own rhetoric gives them pleasure and satisfaction. Usually connotes that what they say is empty or idle nonsense.
Words.Example: Preach, but not practiced. Otherwise known as chui kong, lam pa song.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 插 poj: chhap from hokkien (poj) 插 chhap stick in; poke; interfere; meddle; pay attention or heed to; take notice of

Words.Word: chup jit kha 简 繁

Words.English Translation: → English: Chinese + yuppie from english Chinese of or relating to China or Chinese people, cultures, languages, ethnicities, etc. ← english China country and civilization in Asia ← portuguese China China ← persian چین čin China ← sanskrit चीन Cīna China ← old chinese (zhengzhang) 秦 *zin Qin (state, dynasty) + english -ese suffix used to form a demonym + english yuppie young professional with disposable income and an extravagant lifestyle ← english young upwardly mobile / urban professional young professional with disposable income + english -ie colloq. suffix
Words.Definition: a young Chinese urban professional with a high, disposable income and an extravagant lifestyle
Words.Example: Call him chuppie to his face and he might just crown you with his golf club. But call him a yuppie and he might ask you to his wine-tasting sessions.

Words.Definition: to come out or up with; to produce; to appear

Words.English Translation: → Min nan / cantonese / hakka: 出 poj: chhut + Singlish: pattern from min nan / cantonese / hakka (poj) 出 chhut come out with; appear; go out; outside + singlish pattern wont or habit to cause an annoyance or bother; antics; trouble, or characteristically troublesome behaviour ← english pattern characteristic sequence, arrangement, method, or set of behaviours
Words.Definition: to cause an annoyance or bother; to be full of antics; to create trouble, or exhibit troublesome behaviour

Words.English Translation: → Min nan / cantonese / hakka: 出 poj: chhut + English: stun from min nan / cantonese / hakka (poj) 出 chhut come up with; appear; arise + english stun dumbfound; daze; shock; render unable to act or move

Words.English Translation: → Cantonese: 啜啜 jyutping: zyut3 zyut3 from cantonese (jyutping) 啜啜 zyut3 zyut3 kiss; suck (reduplicated), (onomatopoeic) kissing or sucking noise ← cantonese (jyutping) 啜 zyut3 kiss; suck
Words.Definition: Cerithidea obtusa (a.k.a. red chut-chut), or the closely related species C. quadrata or C. quoyii (a.k.a. black chut-chut), an edible marine snail with a cone-shaped shell popular in Malay cuisine. It is typically prepared in a sambal or coconut milk-based curry gravy, and is eaten by slurping or sucking the meat out of the shell (hence the Malay name). The tip of the shell is usually snipped off to facilitate this.
Words.Example: We sequenced the complete mitogenome of the red chut-chut snail Cerithidea obtusa, from the Cần Giờ mangrove in Vietnam. The mitogenome is 15,708 bp long.

Words.English Translation: → Teochew: 水粿 peng'im: zui2 guê2 from teochew (peng'im) 水粿 zui2 guê2 steamed rice cake with chye por ← teochew (peng'im) 水 zui2 water + teochew (peng'im) 粿 guê2 steamed cake made from rice flour or glutinous rice flour
Words.Definition: a steamed rice cake dish originating in Teochew cuisine. The cakes are usually inverted conic frustums around 5cm in diameter, and come topped with chye por and served with chilli (as they would be tasteless otherwise).

Words.English Translation: → Malay: cicak from malay cicak lizard; house lizard
Words.Definition: lizard; any lizard smaller than a monitor lizard, particularly the common house gecko (Hemidactylus frenatus)
Words.Example: The darling creature, which we have owned for less than a year, loves to hunt, and I don't mean just popping a cicak into her darling mouth every now and then, but tree lizards of reasonable size, grass snakes, rats, bats, and birds.

Words.Definition: a pontianak; the vampiric ghost of a woman who died while pregnant or in childbirth
Words.Example: All this while I was pretty cool as I didn’t think that the screaming is of a cik pon ... The next morning, one of my cousins told me about the screaming too and then only I realised that it has to be a cik pon.

Until I remember all the times I had to go the extra mile to clarify minor details in the middle of a thousand and one more important things just because some idiot insisted on mixing things together for no reason other than their own overweening sense of entitlement to Xtreme CKLPS.

Words.English Translation: → Singlish / english: char kway teow from singlish / english char kway teow stir-fried noodle dish ← hokkien / teochew (poj) 炒粿条 炒粿條 chhá-kóe-tiâu char kway teow, a stir-fried noodle dish ← hokkien / teochew (poj) 炒 炒 chhá stir-fry + hokkien / teochew (poj) 粿条 粿條 kóe-tiâu kway teow, a type of flat rice noodle

Words.English Translation: → English: clay + pot ↻ General chinese: 砂锅 砂鍋 pinyin: shā guō from english clay fine earth + english pot open vessel used to contain food ↻ general chinese (pinyin) 砂锅 砂鍋 shā guō earthenware cooking pot ← general chinese (pinyin) 砂 砂 shā sand; granular material + general chinese (pinyin) 锅 鍋 guō pot

Words.Definition: (euphemistic) to torrent; to download through a peer-to-peer file sharing network, especially BitTorrent

Words.English Translation: → English: coffee shop from english coffee shop type of local food centre with multiple stalls selling various foods and drinks ↻ hokkien (poj) 咖啡店 ko-pi-tiàm type of local food centre with multiple stalls selling various foods and drinks ← hokkien (poj) 咖啡 ko-pi coffee ← malay kopi coffee ← dutch koffie coffee ← italian caffè coffee ← ottoman turkish قهوه kahve coffee ← arabic قَهْوَة qahwa coffee + hokkien (poj) 店 tiàm shop; store
Words.Definition: a type of local food centre with multiple stalls selling various foods and drinks, commonly found in Singapore and Malaysia. Distinct from a hawker centre in that it is usually privately owned and smaller, with only around 3 - 12 stalls in a single L- or U-shaped arrangement. However, the term is sometimes extended to refer to much larger establishments, such as food courts.
Words.Example: Two key coffee shop associations have backed the “siu dai by default” movement, which encourages food and beverage (F&B) operators here to make in-house beverages with less sugar the norm.

Words.Example: Actually, scratch the cinnamon roll comparison. After tasting, the buttery-sweet flavour and the multi-layered crisp flakiness reminded me of something else – if a regular prata and a Danish pastry had a crispy-fried love child, it would be coin prata.

Words.English Translation: → English: coolie from english coolie manual labourer, usu. Chinese or Indian, imported from their countries to work as indentured labourers ← hindustani क़ुली qulī slave; porter; servant ← old turkish قل qul slave
Words.Definition: manual labourers, usually ethnically Chinese, who emigrated from China to Singapore in three waves between 1823 - 1927 in hope for a better life — though most would only find work as indentured labourers. They were usually associated with a guild corresponding to their native language or hometown on arrival. Coolies formed an essential part of early Singapore’s labour force. Their work was difficult and backbreaking, and they often faced additional hardships such as exploitation, mistreatment, and abuse by their managers and brokers.[1]
Words.Example: In the 1930s, coolie quarters were a common sight in Chinatown. The coolies lived in deplorable and unsanitary conditions with little light and poor ventilation.

Words.English Translation: → English: crocodile from english crocodile amphibious reptile of the family Crocodylidae ← old french cocodril crocodile ← latin cocodril crocodile ← ancient greek κροκόδειλος lizard; crocodile
Words.Definition: a playground game where a player (the 'crocodile') chases the other players around a predefined playing area while attempting to 'catch' them (usually by touching any part of their body with either hand). The crocodile may only stay on the ground (the 'water'), while the other players must jump and move about on various structures (the 'islands') without touching the floor (such as on the playground structures, benches, or fitness corner equipment) to avoid them.Depending on rules, a player who is 'caught' may become the new crocodile, be 'eaten' and have to sit out the rest of the round, etc.It is one of several variations of catching.
Words.Example: Sometimes may also modify the rules to make it similar to "Ice and Water", where the eaten player will stand at the edge of the (1st) benches, and crocodile will continue catching all the remaining players. Players can then save "eaten" players by going over to the first bench and tag them.

Words.Definition: a fried pastry snack likely ultimately originating in the Spanish and Portuguese empanada, the Cornish pasty, or the Indian samosa. It usually consists of a pastry shell filled with a dry curry (such that curry sauce does not spill out when the pastry is bitten into), which may be made from potatoes, meat, fish, egg, and curry spices.Despite the name, some variations may not actually include curry or even curry powder, and the shell is more often (though not always) made of a more shortcrust-like pastry or a hard, flaky pastry instead of puff pastry.

Words.Example: Although many people were looking forward to the company’s annual D&D, and many weeks had been put in by the event committee in planning it months ahead, the whole affair unfortunately had to be given the no-go because of COVID.

Words.English Translation: → Mandarin: 打小人 pinyin: dǎ xiǎo rén from mandarin (pinyin) 打小人 dǎ xiǎo rén villain hitting ← cantonese (jyutping) 打小人 daa2 siu2 jan4-2 villain hitting ← cantonese (jyutping) 打 daa2 hit; beat + cantonese (jyutping) 小人 siu2 jan4-2 villain; scoundrel

Words.English Translation: → Cantonese: 锄大弟 鋤大弟 jyutping: co4 daai6 di2 from cantonese (jyutping) 锄大弟 鋤大弟 co4 daai6 di2 shedding card game extremely popular in East Asia ← cantonese (jyutping) 锄 鋤 co4 discard; remove; get rid of + cantonese (jyutping) 大 大 daai6 big; elder; great + cantonese (jyutping) 弟 弟 dai6 younger brother
Words.Definition: a card game extremely popular in East Asia, played using a standard 52-card deck. In Singapore, the game typically may be played between 2-5 players, but the optimal number is four. The objective of the game is to be the first to get rid of all of one's cards, by depositing sequences of poker-like hands (such as ones, twos, five-card combinations, etc.) of increasing value in turn.The suits are ranked with Diamonds being the lowest, followed by Clubs, Hearts, then Spades. Within each suit, 2 is the highest card (hence the name of the game in English, "Big Two"), followed by the ace, then the cards in usual order. However, the ace and 2 may play the roles of the values 1 and 2 in certain situations, such as in a straight.To start, each player is dealt a hand made by dealing all the cards until the remainder is no longer divisible by the number of players. If there are any leftover cards, the players with the lowest-ranked cards (3 of diamonds, then 3 of clubs, etc.) take a corresponding card from the remainder, to give them an advantage in forming combinations.The player with the 3 of diamonds goes first, discarding the three of diamonds in some combination of 1, 2, or 5 cards. All players then have to make a play of higher value by discarding the same number of cards as the round started with in turn (with some rare exceptions, such as when a player has a "dragon" straight), or skip their turn if they are unable or unwilling to do so. Once play has gone a full round without anyone matching a player's play, they win that round and get to start a new round with any combination they please. The game may end when one player has discarded all their cards, or keep going until there is one loser left.While the game is popular throughout East and South-East Asia and within the diasporas of these regions, it originated somewhere in China, likely in Hong Kong.

Words.English Translation: → Cantonese: 大佬 jyutping: daai6 lou2 from cantonese (jyutping) 大佬 daai6 lou2 triad boss; boss; big brother ← cantonese (jyutping) 大 daai6 big; great; elder + cantonese (jyutping) 佬 lou2 brother; guy

Words.English Translation: → Tamil: தீபாவளி tīpāvaḷi + Malay: hari raya from tamil தீபாவளி tīpāvaḷi Deepavali, the Hindu 'festival of light' ← sanskrit दीपावलि dīpāvali row of lights + malay hari raya holiday or festival; Eid ← malay hari day + malay raya big; great
Words.Definition: The name given to the occasional period when the Hindu festival of Deepavali and the Muslim festival of Hari Raya Puasa coincide or occur very close to one another, leading to an extended period of festivities and holidays in Singapore and Malaysia. This happens because their dates are determined by the Hindu and Muslim calendars respectively, which do not line up with one another.

Words.English Translation: → Tamil: தீபாவளி tīpāvaḷi from tamil தீபாவளி tīpāvaḷi Deepavali, the Hindu 'festival of light' ← sanskrit दीपावलि dīpāvali row of lights
Words.Definition: the Hindu 'festival of lights', celebrated from around mid-October to mid-November, depending on the Tamil calendar; it is a public holiday for one assigned day a year in Singapore. Celebrations usually involve traditions such as decorating with lights and candles, the wearing of new clothes, eating traditional food and snacks such as muruku and athi resam, and decorating the entrance of homes with rangoli (colourful patterns made from coloured rice).

Words.Example: Senkottan is an unusual word among the urban readership for it is the name of a seed used to etch dhoby marks in bygone days.

It is a popular snack that can be found at most local bakeries, especially during the Mooncake Festival season.

Words.English Translation: → English: don't + Singlish: play play from english don't do not ← english do perform; execute; syntactic marker + english not adverb used to negate sth. + singlish play play mess around; play a fool; be unserious ← malay main-main playful; unserious; play a fool
Words.Definition: don't play around; don't play a fool; be serious. Popularized by the titular character Phua Chu Kang, played by local actor Gurmit Singh.

Words.English Translation: → English: don’t + say + I + say + Singlish: one from english don’t contraction of 'do not' ← english do aux. syntactic marker + english not used to negate a verb + english say tell; speak sth. + english I 1p. sing. pron. + english say tell; speak sth. + singlish one used to highlight an origin or emphasize sth. ← english one pro-form (used as a substitute word for a noun or pronoun understood in context)
Words.Definition: used when one is giving dubious advice, but doesn’t want to be blamed or held responsible for the potential consequences, or named as the one who gave that dubious idea
Words.Example: By right you have to submit all the required forms, but by left you call customer service to complain they will still give you. But don't say I say one hor.

Words.English Translation: → English: don't from english don't do not ← english do perform; execute; syntactic marker + english not adverb used to negate sth.
Words.Definition: don't; do not; doesn't; does not
Words.Example: Singlish-speaking character Phua Chu Kang who popularised the catchphrases “use your blain” and “donch pray pray” was also reprimanded by then-Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong in 1999 for being a bad linguistic example, and had to learn proper English in the show’s third season.

Words.English Translation: → English: done + -(d)ed from english done finished; completed + english -(d)ed suffix used to form past tense of a verb

Words.English Translation: → General chinese: 咚锵 咚鏘 pinyin: dōng qiāng from general chinese (pinyin) 咚锵 咚鏘 dōng qiāng (onom.) sound of hitting drums, cymbals, gongs, etc. ← general chinese (pinyin) 咚 dōng (onom.) thump; sound of drums + general chinese (pinyin) 锵 鏘 qiāng (onom.) clang; sound of cymbals or gongs

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: dowan + English: done ↻ Hokkien: 莫 莫 poj: mài + 煞 poj: soah from singlish dowan not want ← english don't do not ← english do perform; execute; syntactic marker + english not adverb used to negate sth. + english want desire; wish for + english done finished; settled ↻ hokkien (poj) 莫 莫 mài not want; contraction of 毋愛 ← hokkien (poj) 毋爱 毋愛 m̄-ài not want + hokkien (poj) 煞 soah give up; stop; let things be; leave it

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: drama + English / translingual: mama from singlish drama acting in a manner to exaggerate or attract attention; making an excessively big deal out of something ← english drama a play, prose, movie, etc. which is acted out and tells a story; situation of intrigue or gossip + english dramatic over-acted or exaggerated, usu. to attract attention ← ancient greek δρᾶμα drâma drama; play + english / translingual mama mother

Words.English Translation: → Malay: duku from malay duku edible fruit of the Lansium domesticum tree
Words.Definition: the edible fruit of a variety of the Lansium domesticum tree, which are round and between 2.5 - 5.0 cm in diameter.[1] The fruit's flesh is segmented into large segments the length of the fruit itself. The flesh has a mild flavour and is translucent-white in colour. It is a sweeter variety of the langsat. The duku tree is shorter and wider than the langsat tree.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: duku + langsat from malay duku edible fruit of the Lansium domesticum tree + malay langsat edible fruit of the Lansium domesticum tree
Words.Definition: the edible fruit of a hybrid of two varieties of the Lansium domesticum tree, the duku and langsat, which is round and between 2.5 - 5.0 cm in diameter.[1] It inherits properties of both varieties.

Words.English Translation: → Hindi: दम dam + Tamil: பிரியாணி piriyani from hindi दम dam stew over a slow fire; breath ← classical persian دم dam seam; breath + tamil பிரியாணி piriyani dish of rice cooked with spices and meat and/or vegetables ← classical persian بریانی biryānī dish of rice cooked with spices and meat and/or vegetables ← classical persian بریان biryān roast; grilled
Words.Definition: a style of briyani cooked over a low fire while covering and sealing the cooking vessel with dough, which causes the contents to be slowly steamed while retaining all its aromas. It is traditionally said to have developed in the Mughal Empire.

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: dun + liddat from singlish dun don't; do not ← english don't do not ← english do perform; execute; syntactic marker + english not adverb used to negate sth. + singlish liddat that way; like so ← english like just as; such as; similar to + english that used to indicate sth. further from the speaker than 'this'

Words.English Translation: → Malay: durian from malay durian the edible fruit of several trees of the genus Durio
Words.Definition: the edible fruit of several trees of the genus Durio, which grow up to 40 m tall and sport leaves with a scaly, coppery underside. It is related to similar trees like the nangka (jackfruit) and cempedak, and has a highly-recognizable large, spiky appearance. However, it is also infamous for its pungent, 'overripe fruit' smell, which many find repulsive, and which has earned it a ban from most public enclosed spaces such as trains and taxis. Despite the off-putting smell, the flesh is prized by many as a delicacy across the region.

Words.Definition: a hard, mildly savoury biscuit with a cupped or shell-like shape made from wheat and/or soya bean flour, often with a spiral pattern, said to resemble an ear

Words.English Translation: → English: entire + Malay: kampung ↻ Possible, but not certain Cantonese: 成/全村人 jyutping: seng4/cyun4 cyun1 jan4 from english entire whole ← anglo-norman entier whole; entire ← latin integer whole; entire; complete + malay kampung village; community; hometown ↻ cantonese (jyutping) Possible, but not certain 成/全村人 seng4/cyun4 cyun1 jan4 large group of people; everyone ← cantonese (jyutping) 成 seng4 entire; whole; all or cantonese (jyutping) 全 cyun4 entire; whole; all + cantonese (jyutping) 村 cyun1 village + cantonese (jyutping) 人 jan4 people

Words.English Translation: → Malay: epok-epok from malay epok-epok Malay variant of a curry puff ← malay Dubious or unconfirmed epok pouch woven from leaves and used to hold betel nuts; hug; hold; fold
Words.Definition: a Malay snack food similar to a curry puff, but with a more blistered and crispy skin. It often also does not include curry, with other popular fillings including sardine, rendang, and black pepper chicken. It may be derived directly from the Portuguese empanada, unlike the curry puff which likely was influenced by the Cornish pasty.[2]

Words.Word: er duo bing 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Mandarin: 耳朵饼 耳朵餅 pinyin: ěr duo bǐng from mandarin (pinyin) 耳朵饼 耳朵餅 ěr duo bǐng hard, mildly savoury biscuit ← mandarin (pinyin) 耳朵 耳朵 ěr duo ear + mandarin (pinyin) 饼 餅 bǐng biscuit; cookie
Words.Definition: a hard, mildly savoury biscuit with a cupped or shell-like shape made from wheat and/or soya bean flour, often with a spiral pattern, said to resemble an ear
Words.Example: Ever wondered why this snack is known as Er Duo Bing (also known as 'Ear' Biscuits)? Because it looks exactly like an ear! Surprise your grandparents with this irresistible savoury snack!

Words.English Translation: → English: entrenching tool from english entrenching tool (mil.) adze, spade, or hoe-like tool used for digging, usu. collapsible or modular ← english entrenching used to create a trench; excavating ← english en- used to form a verb which means 'to make or cause' the modified word + english trench narrow, excavated pit or ditch ← old french trenche trench + english tool implement or equipment for performing a specific task
Words.Definition: (military) an adze hoe (cangkul) used for digging, which is assembled from an ET blade (the digging head) and ET stick (the shaft), and disassembled into its components for ease of transport when not in use.
Words.Example: The recruits swung their ETs at the hard ground for hours trying to eke out a semblance of a shell scrape, only for their efforts to be washed away by a sudden, merciless downpour.

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: ET + English: blade from singlish ET (mil.) modular adze hoe used for digging ← english entrenching tool (mil.) adze, spade, or hoe-like tool used for digging, usu. collapsible or modular ← english entrenching used to create a trench; excavating ← english en- used to form a verb which means 'to make or cause' the modified word + old french trench narrow, excavated pit or ditch ← english trenche trench + english blade flat, sometimes sharp functional end of a weapon, tool, or other piece of equipment
Words.Definition: (military) the digging adze head of an ET, which may be assembled together with an ET stick (the shaft) to form the full tool, and detached therefrom and stored in a sheathing pouch for ease of transport when not in use.
Words.Example: Even the sharpest, shiniest ET blade gets dulled and sullied when it strikes its first pebble.

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: ET + English: stick from singlish ET (mil.) modular adze hoe used for digging ← english entrenching tool (mil.) adze, spade, or hoe-like tool used for digging, usu. collapsible or modular ← english entrenching used to create a trench; excavating ← english en- used to form a verb which means 'to make or cause' the modified word + old french trench narrow, excavated pit or ditch ← english trenche trench + english stick long piece of wood or other material
Words.Definition: (military) a wooden stick, around 6 cm in diameter and 40 cm long, which serves as the shaft and handle of an ET. It may be assembled together with an ET blade (the digging head) to form the full tool, and detached therefrom for ease of transport when not in use.
Words.Example: The encik scolded the privates for play-fighting while using their ET sticks as makeshift batons.

Words.English Translation: → English: ever + Singlish: never from english ever at some point in time; always; all the time + singlish never did not; have not; do not; negative particle ← english never not ever

Words.Definition: expression of exasperation or displeasure at a tendency for everything and anything to be politicized, especially in an unpleasant or excessive manner

Words.English Translation: → English: expensive from english expensive costly; highly-priced ← latin expens- paid out ← latin expendō weigh out; pay ← latin ex- out + latin pendō weigh out; pay

Words.Example: $12 for 2 curry puffs? So ex, no wonder this shop like bo lang ai.

Words.English Translation: → English: example from english example sth. given to illustrate ← old french example example ← latin exemplum example

Words.Example: Eee! Your bag smell like example, shit! Hehehehe…

Words.English Translation: → English: extra from english extra extraordinary; beyond; additional ← latin extrā beyond; outside of
Words.Definition: over the top; above and beyond; doing far more than necessary, often to make oneself look better, be dramatic, or show off

Words.English Translation: → Mandarin: 发菜 髮菜 pinyin: fǎ cài from mandarin (pinyin) 发菜 髮菜 fǎ cài the edible cyanobacterium Nostoc flagelliforme ← mandarin (pinyin) 发 髮 fǎ/fà hair ← mandarin (pinyin) 菜 菜 cài vegetable

Words.English Translation: → English: fall in from english fall in gather in an orderly rank arrangement ← english fall drop; collapse + english in to or within some point

Words.English Translation: → Cantonese / hakka: 饭菜 飯菜 jyutping: faan6 coi3 from cantonese / hakka (jyutping) 饭菜 飯菜 faan6 coi3 (lit.) food; rice and vegetables, (Singapore) Cantonese dish of rice, char siew, egg, etc.
Words.Definition: a Singaporean Cantonese dish of rice (sometimes glutinous rice) seasoned with soya sauce and steamed with char siew. The dish is often topped with a hard-boiled egg (usually sliced in half lengthwise), and may include other condiments such as mushrooms. It is a popular breakfast food in Singapore. Similar in concept to lor mai gai.
Words.Example: At first glance, this dish appears to be like a giant fan choy. But instead of traditionally using char siew, this hawker stall opts for chopped chicken drumsticks instead.

Words.English Translation: → English: Fancy Gems from english Fancy Gems small round biscuit with a hard icing topping ← english fancy decorative; elaborate ✂ english fantasy sth. imagined ← old french fantasie fantasy ← latin phantasia fantasy; imagination ← ancient greek φᾰντᾰσῐ́ᾱ phantasía apparition; appearance + english gem precious stone ← latin gemma bud; jewel; gem
Words.Definition: small, airy, round biscuits in the shape of an oblate spheroid or scallop about 1.5 cm in diameter, topped with a hard piped icing that comes in one of various bright colours. They are often considered to be a very nostalgic and traditional Singaporean snack, and ultimately originate from the UK.
Words.Example: This photograph is a close-up of the Fancy Gem biscuits, also commonly known as Iced Gem biscuits or 'belly button' biscuits. The little round biscuits are topped with pink, white, yellow or green icing. This is a snack that was commonly eaten in the 1970s and 1980s.

Words.Example: Despite having secured a prestigious PSC scholarship, he decided his true calling was serving in the military, and so he left it all behind to sign up a farmer in the army.

Words.English Translation: → English: finger + splitting + game from english finger one of the digits on the human hand + english splitting dividing; separating + english game activity played for amusement or competition
Words.Definition: a children's game played between two players, who each clasp their hands with both index fingers extended and pressed together, then take turns holding out their hands in this position while the other smashes their own index fingers into their opponent's using a downward overhead swing. The first person to cause the other's fingers to split (such that the index fingertips are no longer touching each other) is deemed the winner, irrespective of whether they were the one hitting or were bracing against their opponent's hit.

Words.Definition: gone; used up; completely spent; having none left
Words.Example: Sorry ah boy, fish curry finish already - I give you chicken curry can anot?

Words.English Translation: → English: fish tank ↻ Cantonese: 鱼缸 魚缸 jyutping: jyu4 gong1 from english fish tank aquarium; usu. transparent vessel containing water and fish or other marine life ← english fish animal which lives in water + english tank large container for storing liquids e.g. water ← portuguese tanque tank; cistern; reservoir ← general indian ṭanki tank; cistern; reservoir ↻ cantonese (jyutping) 鱼缸 魚缸 jyu4 gong1 fish tank; aquarium, (slang) brothel with prostitutes displayed behind glass panels ← cantonese (jyutping) 鱼 魚 jyu4 fish + cantonese (jyutping) 缸 缸 gong1 jar; tank; vat
Words.Definition: a type of brothel featuring prostitutes displayed behind glass panels

Words.English Translation: → English: fish + ball ↻ General chinese: 鱼圆 魚圓 pinyin: yú yuán from english fish animal which lives in water, or meat thereof + english ball roughly spherical object ↻ general chinese (pinyin) 鱼圆 魚圓 yú yuán fishball ← min nan (poj) 鱼圆 魚圓 hîr-îⁿ fishball ← min nan (poj) 鱼 魚 hîr fish + min nan (poj) 圆 圓 îⁿ round; circular
Words.Definition: a food item made from a paste of pulverized fish mixed with a binder, such as starch, and seasoning (resulting in a form of surimi), which is then squeezed into round ball-shaped pieces around 3 - 4 cm in diameter. By beating the fish meat to uncoil the protein strands, and setting the formed balls in iced, salted water, a desirably firm yet bouncy (QQ) texture is produced, similar to other Chinese meatball products like beef and pork balls. The paste produced is essentially the same as that used for fishcake.Fishballs are a popular ingredient in many dishes, such as fishball soup, bak chor mee, and fishball noodles, and are also enjoyed on their own as a snack. They likely originated in Fujianese and Teochew cuisine.
Words.Example: This was in the 1980s, and Tan’s stall was one of several selling fishball noodles at Kovan 209 Market & Food Centre. Competition was stiff, and they often had the fewest customers.

Words.English Translation: → English: fishball + noodles from english fishball food item made from a paste of pulverized fish mixed with a binder, squeezed into round ball-shaped pieces ↻ general chinese (pinyin) 鱼圆 魚圓 yú yuán fishball ← min nan (poj) 鱼圆 魚圓 hîr-îⁿ fishball ← min nan (poj) 鱼 魚 hîr fish + min nan (poj) 圆 圓 îⁿ round; circular + english noodles long, thin strings of cooked dough ← german Nudel pasta; noodle
Words.Definition: a food item of Teochew origin, which in its most basic form is made from fishballs (which may come served in a clear soup) and typically mee pok noodles tossed in a seasoning sauce of soy sauce, stock, vinegar, and other ingredients. It is usually topped with various additional condiments, such as fishcake, fried shallots, chilli, ikan bilis, pork liver, ground pork (bak chor), sliced pork, meatballs, etc. May come in soup or dry variants.
Words.Example: Now run by the third generation, this family-run stall is famous for its fish ball noodle soup topped with ground pork, pork liver, seaweed and pork rinds. Pork ribs are simmered for hours resulting in a broth rich in gutsy flavours.

Words.English Translation: → English: fishcake from english fishcake fried patty made from flaked fish, potato, and seasoning ← english fish animal which lives in water, or meat thereof + english cake mass of food made from cooking a dough, batter, paste, etc.
Words.Definition: a food item made from a paste of pulverized fish mixed with a binder, such as starch, and seasoning (resulting in a form of surimi), which is then shaped into cuboid or cylindrical blocks. By beating the fish meat to uncoil the protein strands, and setting the formed balls in iced, salted water, a desirably firm yet bouncy (QQ) texture is produced, similar to other Chinese meatball products like beef and pork balls. The paste produced is essentially the same as that used for fishballs.Fishcakes are a popular ingredient in many dishes, such as laksa or bak chor mee, where they are often sliced, and can also be enjoyed on their own as a snack. They likely originated in Fujianese and Teochew cuisine.
Words.Example: It was an epic mess of slurp-worthy flat noodles tossed in dark soya sauce, topped with generous amounts of lap cheong (Chinese sausage) and fishcake.

Words.English Translation: → English: five stones from english five stones traditional ancient game played using 5 stones or other small items ← english five the number 5 + english stones small rocks
Words.Definition: a traditional game involving sets of variously throwing, catching, and picking up five pebble-sized stones according to a set of game rules. The stones may be substituted for any other small, weighted items, such as beanbags or small bones. It is known in other countries as jacks, jackstones, knucklebones, chackstones, and many other names, and has been played by humans since antiquity.

Words.English Translation: → English: five + foot + way from english five the number 5 + english foot unit of measure equal to 12" or 0.305 m + english way road; path
Words.Definition: a continuous ground-floor walkway featuring a overhanging second storey to provide cover from the tropical sun, a common colonial architectural feature in buildings from that era in Singapore, Malaysia, Indonesia, and other countries such as Taiwan and parts of Thailand. Despite the name, the walkway is not necessarily exactly five feet wide.
Words.Example: Visitors will also be able to sign up for Conserved Buildings in Chinatown, a walking trail by Do it SG to explore the conservation of heritage buildings in Singapore, its history and the activities that were held at the Five Footways.

Words.English Translation: → English: fried rice from english fried rice Chinese dish of rice stir-fried with various ingredients ↻ general chinese (pinyin) 炒饭 炒飯 chǎo fàn Chinese dish of rice stir-fried with various ingredients ← general chinese (pinyin) 炒 炒 chǎo stir-fry; stir-fried + general chinese (pinyin) 饭 飯 fàn cooked rice
Words.Definition: fried rice, a Chinese dish of rice stir-fried with any of various ingredients.

Words.English Translation: → English: film from english film movie; thin pellicle used for capturing images
Words.Definition: a film; a movie
Words.Example: I am looking for old "CANON" brand camera. Spoilt or "flim-type" ones also can. Does anyone has 1 for sale? Budget is $15.

Words.English Translation: → English: flip + Singlish: prata from english flip rotate sth. end over end + singlish prata type of local flatbread with influence from Indian paratha ← tamil பரோட்டா parōṭṭā paratha; type of Indian flatbread
Words.Definition: to vacillate; to keep changing one's mind, instructions, directions, etc.; to be fickle
Related: or ya peh ya som balik ah
or ya peh ya som balik ah roti prata char kway teow
or ya peh ya som balik ah roti prata chai tow kway

Words.English Translation: → English: flustered + frustrated from english flustered confused; panicky; agitated + english frustrated annoyed; vexed; disappointed; stressed ← latin frūstrātus deception
Words.Definition: flustered and frustrated; stressed; vexed; agitated; confused; in a state of panic

Words.English Translation: → English: fly + aeroplane ↻ Cantonese: 放飞机 放飛機 jyutping: fong3 fei1 gei1 from english fly cause to go airborne; guide or control in the air + english aeroplane fixed-wing, heavier-than-air aircraft ← french aéroplane fixed-wing, heavier-than-air aircraft ← ancient greek ἀερόπλανος aeróplanos air-wanderer ↻ cantonese (jyutping) 放飞机 放飛機 fong3 fei1 gei1 stand sb. up; miss an appointment ← cantonese (jyutping) 放 放 fong3 put; release + cantonese (jyutping) 飞机 飛機 fei1 gei1 aeroplane
Words.Definition: to stand someone up
Words.Example: I had a movie date with this girl but she fly me aeroplane. Since I go the cinema already, might as well watch alone lor.

Words.Word: fly me kite 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → English: fly + me + kite ↻ Cantonese: 放飞机 放飛機 jyutping: fong3 fei1 gei1 from english fly cause to go airborne; guide or control in the air + english me 1p. sing. obj. pron. + english kite toy held on a tether and carried aloft by the wind ↻ cantonese (jyutping) 放飞机 放飛機 fong3 fei1 gei1 stand sb. up; miss an appointment ← cantonese (jyutping) 放 放 fong3 put; release + cantonese (jyutping) 飞机 飛機 fei1 gei1 aeroplane
Words.Definition: to stand someone up
Words.Example: I also got a lot of wedding conflict too and also ppls fly me kite during wedding saying that they sure will attend but...

Words.Word: fong fei gei 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Cantonese: 放飞机 放飛機 jyutping: fong3 fei1 gei1 from cantonese (jyutping) 放飞机 放飛機 fong3 fei1 gei1 stand sb. up; miss an appointment ← cantonese (jyutping) 放 放 fong3 put; release + cantonese (jyutping) 飞机 飛機 fei1 gei1 aeroplane
Words.Definition: to stand someone up
Words.Example: Wake up 5:30am to go to the airport. Bye bye Bali. Unless we want to “fong fei gei” and extend the trip? hehe.

Words.English Translation: → English: for + fuck from english for in order that/to + english fuck expn. of dismay, anger, etc.
Words.Definition: (vulgar, rude) 'for what?'; used to ask for a reason or justification for something, especially when one feels it is likely a ridiculous, annoying, or unreasonable purpose
Words.Example: Chao sinkie no innovative what! Like that how to pass in engineering courses?! Can pass & get the certification only become paper engineers for F.U.C.K ?!

Words.English Translation: → English: fork + spoon from english fork tined utensil used for eating + english spoon utensil used to scoop food
Words.Definition: (military, dated) the symbol of the Infantry of the SAF, which used to be a pair of rifles crossed at the barrel, and is now a pair of daggers with crossing blades. The name is due to the passing similarity between the logo and a pair of crossed eating utensils.

Words.English Translation: → English: freeze + and + melt from english freeze (of a liquid) turn solid + english and conj. used to connect two elements together + english melt (of a solid) turn liquid
Words.Definition: a playground game that is a variation of police and thief, with one team playing as the 'ice' players and one team as the 'water' players. The ice players pursue the water players, tapping them to freeze them (after which they must stand in place); they may be unfrozen by getting tapped by another water player.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 米粉 poj: bí-hún + English: fried from hokkien (poj) 米粉 bí-hún rice vermicelli; rice flour ← hokkien (poj) 米 bí rice + hokkien (poj) 粉 hún flour; powder + english fried cooked in oil or fat ← old french frire fry ← latin frīgō fry; roast
Words.Definition: any dish using bee hoon noodles stir-fried together with other ingredients, such as soya sauce, chilli, sambal, vegetables, egg, meat, prawns, seasoning powder, tomato ketchup, etc.

Words.English Translation: → English: friend from english friend a person (other than a family member) who one is affectionate with and enjoys the company of; (archaic) befriend; make friends with
Words.Definition: (transitive) to befriend; to be friends with
Words.Example: Why you go and pau toh me? I don't friend you anymore!

Words.English Translation: → English: friend from english friend a person (other than a family member) who one is affectionate with and enjoys the company of
Words.Definition: to befriend
Words.Example: Come friend-friend me. I'll try to send Daily Gifts. & I don't have any more Lucky Eggs...so you can time the landmark friendship status levels to your needs.

Words.English Translation: → English: frog + in + a + well ↻ General chinese: 井底之蛙 pinyin: jǐng dǐ zhī wā from english frog amphibian of the order Anura + english in within; inside + english a indef. article + english well hole dug in the ground to access groundwater ↻ general chinese (pinyin) 井底之蛙 jǐng dǐ zhī wā someone w. a very limited outlook and knowledge of the world ← general chinese (pinyin) 井 jǐng well + general chinese (pinyin) 底 dǐ bottom + general chinese (pinyin) 之 zhī 's; genitive marker + general chinese (pinyin) 蛙 wā frog

Words.English Translation: → Cantonese: 腐竹 jyutping: fu6 zuk1 from cantonese (jyutping) 腐竹 fu6 zuk1 dried tofu skin ← cantonese (jyutping) 豆腐 dau6 fu6 tofu + cantonese (jyutping) 竹 zuk1 bamboo
