Words.Definition: (vulgar) exclamation of intense frustration or annoyance

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: fuck + English: upside down from singlish fuck (vulgar) scold; severely reprimand ← english fuck (vulgar) have sex with; screw over; contemptible person; expn. of surprise, dismay, anger, etc.; intensifier + english upside down inverted; oriented such that the top is at the bottom ← english up so down oriented such that the 'up' is 'down'; (lit.) 'up as down'
Words.Definition: (vulgar) to scold; to severely reprimand
Words.Example: Office xmm makes mistake, just given casual reminders. BBFA at work makes tiny mistake, kenna fk upside down.

Words.English Translation: → English: fuck you + Singlish: understand from english fuck you (vg.) expn. of anger, frustration, contempt, etc. ← english fuck (vg.) have sex with; screw; expn. of surprise, dismay, anger, etc.; intensifier + english you 2p. s. & p. pronoun + singlish understand used to emphasise and reinforce the preceding statement ← english understand comprehend; grasp the meaning of
Words.Definition: (military, vulgar) expression of annoyance, anger, frustration, incredulity, contempt, etc.

Words.English Translation: → English: field pack from english field pack (mil.) backpack used to carry essential items for a soldier ← english field (mil.) place where a battle or other mil. operation happens + english pack bundle of items to be carried
Words.Definition: (military) a large backpack used by soldiers to carry essential items needed in an outfield situation, such as a change of clothes, water, rations, armour, etc. It is also carried during some other training activities, such as route marches.
Words.Example: Incredibly, they covered almost 100 km every day, each carrying a 20-kg fullpack of supplies.

Words.English Translation: → Cantonese / hokkien: 加 jyutping / poj: gaa1 / ka + Singlish: C from cantonese / hokkien (jyutping / poj) 加 gaa1 / ka add + singlish C (drink ordering) w. evaporated milk ← hainanese (hrs) Possible, but not certain 鲜 鮮 si1 fresh; raw, (of milk) pasteurized but not otherwise treated or english Possible, but not certain Carnation brand name of Carnation evaporated milk ← english Carnation brand name of Carnation cigars (or image of carnation on cigar box) ← english carnation flowers of the Dianthus genus and its hybrids ← middle french carnation skin- or flesh-coloured ← italian Possible, but not certain carnagione skin- or flesh-coloured ← late latin carnātiōnem fleshiness
Words.Definition: (drink ordering) with more evaporated milk

Words.Definition: (drink ordering) more sweet; with extra sugar or condensed milk

Words.English Translation: → Malay: gelabah from malay gelabah confused; uncertain; frantic; panicked; anxious
Words.Definition: (of a person) confused; uncertain; frantic; panicked
Words.Example: Barbara would always panic whenever she was put into any decision-making position, leading to her colleagues giving her the unfortunate nickname "Barbara the Gabra".

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: gabra + king from singlish gabra confused; uncertain; frantic; panicked; chaotic; disorderly ← malay gelabah confused; uncertain; frantic; panicked; anxious + singlish king (suffix, usu. sarcastic or pejorative) the epitome of sth. ← english king (usu. male) the ruler of a monarchy; a powerful or preeminent person
Words.Definition: a person who is always confused, uncertain, frantic, and panicked
Words.Example: Just our luck, we got the gabra king sergeant as our sec comm. We're all gonna die...

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: gabra + English: like + zebra from singlish gabra confused; uncertain; frantic; panicked; chaotic; disorderly ← malay gelabah confused; uncertain; frantic; panicked; anxious + english like just as; such as; similar to + english zebra zebra (Hippotigris spp.) ← italian zebra zebra ← old portuguese ezebrario wild ass ← vulgar latin eciferus wild horse
Words.Definition: (simile, of a person) extremely confused; uncertain; frantic; panicked; anxious; flustered
Words.Example: Aiyah, when this happens, both drivers will gabra like zebra. Then all the goldfish will start to point and stare, very traumatizing for accident victims.

Words.English Translation: → English: government from english government the body ruling or controlling a state, including its people, land, resources, etc., and with the power to enact, pass, and enforce its laws ← old french governement government
Words.Definition: a government (usually the Singaporean government)
Words.Example: Walao eh, the bloody gahmen raising GST again. Jin buay tahan.

Words.English Translation: → Cantonese: 街街 jyutping: gaai1 gaai1 from cantonese (jyutping) 街街 gaai1 gaai1 (lit.) 'street street'; (fig.) 'walk-walk' ← cantonese (jyutping) 出街 ceot1 gaai1 go out (e.g. to town); go out for a walk ← cantonese (jyutping) 出 ceot1 leave; go out + cantonese (jyutping) 街 gaai1 street
Words.Definition: to go out for a walk
Words.Example: My ah ma always bring me go Tampines Mall gai gai when I was small.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: gajah from malay gajah elephant; giant ← sanskrit गज gaja elephant
Words.Definition: (drink ordering) giant; upsized; bigger
Words.Example: Facebook user Raymond Seow had shared photos of his Milo drink and the accompanying receipt in a post on Dec 15, along with the caption: "Damn expensive nowadays!" ... However, the stall assistant revealed that this was actually 'Milo Gajah' and explained how it came in a bigger cup.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 啱 poj: gam from hokkien (poj) 啱 gam compatible; suitable; getting along well; fit; just right ← cantonese (jyutping) 啱 ngaam1 compatible; suitable; getting along well; fit; just right
Words.Definition: compatible; chummy; getting along well
Words.Example: I would go to JB and I grew so gam [chummy] with the people who sold the pirated DVDs that they would give me package deals.

Words.English Translation: → Mandarin: 干 乾 pinyin: gān + 弟 pinyin: dì from mandarin (pinyin) 干 乾 gān foster; adoptive; nominal + mandarin (pinyin) 弟 dì younger brother
Words.Definition: someone who is not related by blood or by law to another, but is considered a little brother to them based on social, cultural, or other ties, such as a close male friend, godbrother, or blood brother; term of address for such a person

Words.Definition: someone who is not related by blood or by law to another, but is considered an elder brother to them based on social, cultural, or other ties, such as a close male friend, godbrother, or blood brother; term of address for such a person

Words.Definition: someone who is not related by blood or by law to another, but is considered a little sister to them based on social, cultural, or other ties, such as a close female friend, godsister, or sworn sister; term of address for such a person

Words.English Translation: → Cantonese: 碱水 鹼水 jyutping: gaan2 seoi2 from cantonese (jyutping) 碱水 鹼水 gaan2 seoi2 alkaline water; lye water ← cantonese (jyutping) 碱 鹼 gaan2 sodium carbonate; alkali; soap + cantonese (jyutping) 水 水 seoi2 water
Words.Definition: alkaline water; lye water, a solution of sodium carbonate and potassium carbonate (and sometimes smaller amounts of other bases such as sodium hydroxide or sodium phosphates), used in Chinese cuisine to make foods such as alkaline noodles

Words.English Translation: → Cantonese: 韭菜 jyutping: gau2 coi3 from cantonese (jyutping) 韭菜 gau2 coi3 Allium tuberosum, a.k.a. garlic chives ← cantonese (jyutping) 韭 gau2 Allium tuberosum; leek + cantonese (jyutping) 菜 coi3 vegetable
Words.Definition: Allium tuberosum (also known as garlic chives), a plant in the same family as garlic, chives, and onions whose long, green leaves and flower buds are commonly used as a vegetable in Chinese cuisine
Words.Example: The former comes bathed in a thickened brown sauce topped with fresh, boiled medium-sized prawns, braised chicken, deep fried shallots and boiled "kau choy" ...

Words.English Translation: → Cantonese: 搞掂/搅掂 搞掂/攪掂 jyutping: gaau2 dim6 from cantonese (jyutping) 搞掂/搅掂 搞掂/攪掂 gaau2 dim6 complete a task; get sth. done; settle a matter ← cantonese (jyutping) 搞 搞 gaau2 do; make or cantonese (jyutping) 搅 攪 gaau2 disturb; stir + cantonese (jyutping) 掂 掂 dim6 straight; stable; settled; smooth
Words.Definition: to complete a task; to get something done; to finish
Words.Example: The faster you gao dim your homework, the faster you can play with your friends!

Words.English Translation: → Cantonese: 觉觉 覺覺 jyutping: gaau3-4 gaau3-2 from cantonese (jyutping) 觉觉 覺覺 gaau3-4 gaau3-2 (childish, dimin.) sleep ⇇ cantonese (jyutping) 觉 覺 gaau3 sleep
Words.Definition: (childish) sleep
Words.Example: Good.. fine the tee kee gao gao best.. keep doubling the fine if continue to tee kee..

Words.English Translation: → Cantonese: 枸杞 jyutping: gau2 gei2 from cantonese (jyutping) 枸杞 gau2 gei2 Lycium chinense or L. barbarum, both a.k.a. goji berry or wolfberry ← persian Possible, but not certain گوجه gowje plum
Words.Definition: the edible fruits of Lycium chinense or Lycium barbarum, which are both also known as the goji berry or wolfberry. They are orange to red in colour, and are often dried (resembling raisins) and used in soups, herbal dishes, and traditional Chinese medicine.

Words.English Translation: → Cantonese: 枸杞 jyutping: gau2 gei2 + 菜 jyutping: coi3 from cantonese (jyutping) 枸杞 gau2 gei2 Lycium chinense or L. barbarum, both a.k.a. goji berry or wolfberry ← persian Possible, but not certain گوجه gowje plum + cantonese (jyutping) 菜 coi3 vegetable
Words.Definition: the soft, edible leaves of Lycium chinense or Lycium barbarum, used in Chinese cuisine as a vegetable for soups and herbal dishes

Words.English Translation: → Cantonese: 枸杞 jyutping: gau2 gei2 + 子 jyutping: zi2 from cantonese (jyutping) 枸杞 gau2 gei2 Lycium chinense or L. barbarum, both a.k.a. goji berry or wolfberry ← persian Possible, but not certain گوجه gowje plum + cantonese (jyutping) 子 zi2 seed; child; small round obj.
Words.Definition: the edible fruits of Lycium chinense or Lycium barbarum, which are both also known as the goji berry or wolfberry. They are orange to red in colour, and are often dried (resembling raisins) and used in soups, herbal dishes, and traditional Chinese medicine.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: garang from malay garang fierce; ferocious; strong
Words.Definition: fearless; brave; daring; gung ho
Words.Example: The commandos and NDU boys always bantered about whose unit was the most garang.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: gasak from malay gasak hit; beat; whack
Words.Definition: tackle a task without necessarily having the requisite knowledge or skills to do so
Words.Example: Don't just gasak, take your time to savour its delicate flavours.

Words.English Translation: → English: gassy + drink from english gassy (of drinks) containing gas; carbonated; bubbly ← english gas state of matter between a liquid and plasma ← dutch gas gas ← ancient greek χᾰ́ος khắos void; chaos; space + english -y (suffix) having the quality of + english drink beverage; edible liquid
Words.Definition: a carbonated drink; a fizzy drink
Words.Example: The citrus-flavoured gassy drink is based on the same drink from the American comic strip L'il Abner, about fictional hillbillies living in a village called Dogpatch.

Words.English Translation: → English: good + class + bungalow from english good great; pleasant; favourable; positive; of worth, etc. + english class category; set; grouping + english bungalow large, detached one-storey house ← hindi बंगला baṅglā Bengali
Words.Definition: a type of landed property in Singapore which fulfils certain requirements, such as having a minimum of 1,400 square metres of land area and being located in specified Good-Class Bungalow Areas. They are only allowed to be purchased and owned by Singaporean citizens, and are often seen as a prestigious status symbol of the richest of the rich in Singapore. Some may have historical and cultural significance in and of themselves, such as the preserved colonial black-and-white houses that are mostly owned by the state.[1][2]

Words.English Translation: → English: good + Christian + girl from english good great; pleasant; favourable; positive; well-behaved, etc. + english Christian follower of Christianity and Jesus Christ ← old french chrestien Christian ← latin Chrīstiānus Christian ← ancient greek Χρῑστιᾱνός Khrīstiānós Christian + english girl young female person
Words.Definition: (slightly derogatory) a young woman or girl who (at least in public presentation) is a staunch Christian, stays away from vices, dresses modestly, often listens to gospel music or Christian rock, and enjoys broadcasting their faithfulness and devoutness on social media such as by regularly posting Bible verses. Often includes several negative stereotypes, such as a tendency to moralize and evangelize without social or self-awareness, having a very narrow worldview, and being oblivious to the extent of their own unintentional or intentional racism, prejudices, condescension, etc.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: gelek from malay gelek dance; twist; roll; dodge; prance
Words.Definition: to dance, especially with rolling or twisting movements; to sashay
Words.Example: The late Dollah [Kassim] earned the nickname "Gelek King" for his superior ball control and dribbling skills which made him look as if he was dancing past opposing defenders.

Words.English Translation: → English: gem biscuits from english gem biscuits small round biscuit with a hard icing topping ← english gem precious stone + english biscuit small baked item; cookie ← old french bescuit twice-baked bread ← latin biscoctus twice-cooked ← latin bis twice; two times + latin coctus cook
Words.Definition: small, airy, round biscuits in the shape of an oblate spheroid or scallop about 1.5 cm in diameter, topped with a hard piped icing that comes in one of various bright colours. They are often considered to be a very nostalgic and traditional Singaporean snack, and ultimately originate from the UK.
Words.Example: Some of the gifts for babies born next year as part of the SG50Baby Jubilee Gift will be printed with a "Gem Baby" character, whose design is inspired by Gem biscuits. The small biscuits topped with pink, yellow, white or green icing have been a hit with children here for several generations.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: gemuk from malay gemuk fat
Words.Definition: fat; overweight; obese

Words.English Translation: → Malay: geng from malay geng gang; (slang) group of buddies ← english gang group or company of people; (pej.) criminal or delinquent group
Words.Definition: a group of close buddies or friends

Words.English Translation: → English: gentlemen from english gentlemen polite term for a man; well-mannered, couth man ← english gentle high-born; of a respectable family ← old french gentil high-born; noble ← latin gentilis of or belonging to the same clan or family + english man adult male human
Words.Definition: (military) gentlemen (or gentleman); term of address for any man or group of men
Words.Example: Gennermen! Today I will be teach you about how to build basha.

Words.English Translation: → English: GEP + -er from english GEP initialism of 'Gifted Education Programme' ← english Gifted Education Programme MOE programme for intellectually gifted students who score in the top 1% of their cohorts in a special selection test ← english gifted talented; of special or exceptional abilities + english education schooling; teaching; imparting of knowledge, values, skills, etc. ← middle french éducation education; upbringing ← latin ēducātiō bringing up; rearing + english programme organized set of courses, classes, activities, etc. ← french program program ← late latin programma proclamation; notice ← ancient greek πρόγραμμα prógramma proclamation; notice; program + english -er suffix used to form a demonym
Words.Definition: (derogatory) a student in the GEP (Gifted Education Programme)

Words.English Translation: → English: girl from english girl a young female person; a female person younger than the speaker
Words.Definition: girl; a young female person
Words.Example: Boy ah, who is that ger ger I see you with yesterday?

Words.English Translation: → Malay: gerek from malay gerek bore; drill a hole, (slang) cool; awesome
Words.Definition: cool; awesome; stylish
Words.Example: The least gerek you can feel is when you forget to zip your fly.

Words.Word: get eaten by 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → English: get [verb] by + eaten ↻ Singlish: tioh makan & kena makan from english get [verb] by (passive) be on the receiving end of an action + english eaten consumed; past participle of 'eat' ↻ singlish tioh makan be taken advantage of; be overwhelmed or overtaken; be eaten ← hokkien (poj) 着 著 tio̍h get; receive ← malay makan eat; consume & singlish kena makan be taken advantage of; be overwhelmed or overtaken; be eaten ← malay kena get; incur; receive ← malay makan eat; consume
Words.Definition: to be taken advantage of; to be swindled

Words.English Translation: → Mandarin: 歌台 歌臺 pinyin: gē tái from mandarin (pinyin) 歌台 歌臺 gē tái song stage; type of popular live stage performance ← mandarin (pinyin) 歌 歌 gē song + mandarin (pinyin) 台 臺 tái stage; platform
Words.Definition: a type of live stage performance featuring song, dance, plays, stand-up, and other forms of entertainment. They are often loud, gaudy, and garishly colourful, and are popular among the primarily Chinese-language-speaking, elderly-to-middle-aged demographic in Singapore. They are especially held during festivals such as the Hungry Ghost Festival and Chinese New Year.[1]
Words.Example: The format of getai was modernised in the 2000s. Stage structures became more elaborate with complex lighting systems, laser effects, pyrotechnics, digital sound systems, and screen displays.

Words.English Translation: → English: gg from english gg (gaming slang) init. of good game; (fig.) game over; it's over; expression of defeat, hopelessness, or loss ← english good game expression used to sportingly congratulate one's opponent after a match or game ← english good enjoyable; worthy; pleasant + english game match; round of a sport or game
Words.Definition: expression of defeat, hopelessness, resignation, or loss; 'game over'; 'it's over'
Related: you die, I die, everybody die

Words.English Translation: → English: gg + dot com / .com from english gg (gaming slang) init. of good game; (fig.) game over; it's over; expression of defeat, hopelessness, or loss ← english good game expression used to sportingly congratulate one's opponent after a match or game ← english good enjoyable; worthy; pleasant + english game match; round of a sport or game + english dot com / .com DNS suffix for commercial (or other) websites ← english dot small round point; (punct. mark) period; full stop + english com abbr. of 'commercial' ✂ english commercial of or relating to commerce ← french commercial commercial ← latin commercium commerce; trade
Words.Definition: expression of defeat, hopelessness, resignation, or loss; 'game over'; 'it's over'
Words.Example: I got an offer now, should I wait or resign? Later really 2 digit then gg dot com
Related: you die, I die, everybody die

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 金毛 poj: kim-mô͘ from hokkien (poj) 金毛 kim-mô͘ golden hair ← hokkien (poj) 金 kim gold; golden + hokkien (poj) 毛 mô͘ hair
Words.Definition: a neighbourhood in the west-central region of Singapore (in Queenstown, or politically the Holland - Bukit Timah GRC), along the Ulu Pandan River.

Words.Word: giah lam pa chut lai tom toh teng 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 𫽥𡳞脬出来丼桌顶 攑𡳞脬出來丼桌頂 poj: gia̍h lām-pha chhut-lâi tôm toh-téng from hokkien (poj) 𫽥𡳞脬出来丼桌顶 攑𡳞脬出來丼桌頂 gia̍h lām-pha chhut-lâi tôm toh-téng (fig.) harshly self-criticize or self-flagellate over a mistake, (lit.) take one's testicles out and bang them on the table ← hokkien (poj) 𫽥 攑 gia̍h take; hold + hokkien (poj) 𡳞脬 𡳞脬 lām-pha (vulgar) scrotum; ballsack; balls + hokkien (poj) 出来 出來 chhut-lâi come out + hokkien (poj) 丼 丼 tôm (onom.) sound of sth. dropping into a well; deep, hollow sound of an impact + hokkien (poj) 桌顶 桌頂 toh-téng on top of a table
Words.Definition: (idiom) to harshly criticize oneself or self-flagellate over a mistake, especially one particularly stupid, embarrassing, or causing one to lose face
Words.Example: I blur blur daydreaming and called the teacher 'mummy' on accident… want to giah lam pa chut lai tom toh teng right there and then.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 瘾饭 癮飯 poj: giàn-pn̄g or 悭饭 慳飯 poj: kian-pn̄g from hokkien (poj) 瘾饭 癮飯 giàn-pn̄g greedy; craving ← hokkien (poj) 瘾 癮 giàn addicted; craving + hokkien (poj) 饭 飯 pn̄g cooked rice or hokkien (poj) 悭饭 慳飯 kian-pn̄g greedy; craving ← hokkien (poj) 悭 慳 kian greedy; covetous; stingy + hokkien (poj) 饭 飯 pn̄g cooked rice
Words.Definition: greedy; covetous; always on the lookout for free goodies and cheap deals
Words.Example: Can’t think of any benefits for sg other than for kiam png sinkies to go jb shopping and blue wave

Words.English Translation: → Malay: gila from malay gila crazy; mad; insane; mentally ill
Words.Definition: crazy; mad; insane
Words.Example: In a viral video uploaded on social media, a lone macaque had stolen a cup of Pedas Giler or Crazy Spicy Maggi noodles and proceeded to eat it nonchalantly.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 囡仔 poj: gín/kín-á from hokkien (poj) 囡仔 gín/kín-á kid; child
Words.Definition: a child; a kid
Words.Example: Eh halo dis one whose ginna ah? Belong to Salakau or Semakau?

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 囡仔疕 poj: gín/kín-á-phí from hokkien (poj) 囡仔疕 gín/kín-á-phí kid; child ← hokkien (poj) 囡仔 gín/kín-á kid; child + hokkien (poj) 疕 phí headache; sore; scab
Words.Definition: (sometimes derogatory) a child; a kid; silly kiddo
Words.Example: slay means that ? everytime hear ginna pis say for every probable response until it becomes a no head no tail reply, macam like oh.....

Words.English Translation: → English: give ↻ Mandarin: 给 給 pinyin: gěi from english give transfer to; provide; grant ← old norse gefa give ↻ mandarin (pinyin) 给 給 gěi give; to; for; by
Words.Definition: to; towards
Words.Example: How can you do like this? Give him say sorry!

Words.English Translation: → English: give + chance from english give allow; confer; grant + english chance opportunity ← old french cheance chance; fate; luck; fall ← latin cadēns falling
Words.Definition: to give a chance
Words.Example: In the mid-1990s, audiences here had more of a 'give chance' attitude towards local films. Then, in the early 2000s, this attitude became a 'let's be extra critical because this is a local film'.

Words.English Translation: → Cantonese: 畀面 jyutping: bei2 min6-2 from cantonese (jyutping) 畀面 bei2 min6-2 show respect out of pity or to preserve another's dignity; do something nice or respectful for somebody els even if one is reluctant to do so
Words.Definition: to show respect or be respectful to somebody, often just as a favour, out of pity, or to preserve another's dignity
Words.Example: Give her some face lah. At least show up for the meeting.

Words.English Translation: → English: glamorous from english glamorous stylish; glittering; elegant
Words.Definition: glamorous; stylish; glittering; elegant
Words.Example: I'm not glam enough to be in that friend group. All they do is hop around the most Instagrammable cafes in the city centre... I'd rather do something sporty or relax at home.

Words.English Translation: → English: glass + heart ↻ Mandarin: 玻璃心 pinyin: bō li/lí xīn from english glass amorphous solid material, usu. transparent, made of silica and certain additives + english heart organ which pumps blood through the body ↻ mandarin (pinyin) 玻璃心 bō li/lí xīn oversensitive; easily offended; sb. who is oversensitive ← mandarin (pinyin) 玻璃 bō li/lí glass ← prakrit फालिअ phālia crystal ← sanskrit स्फटिक sphaṭika crystal; quartz + mandarin (pinyin) 心 xīn heart
Words.Definition: (derogatory) oversensitive; easily offended; having feelings that are easily hurt

Words.English Translation: → English: go fly a kite from english go fly a kite used to tell sb. being annoying to go away; 'get lost'; 'stop being such a bother'; 'go to hell' ← english go move; leave; leave to + english fly cause to go airborne; guide or control in the air + english a indef. article + english kite toy held on a tether and carried aloft by the wind
Words.Definition: (idiom, rude) used to tell someone who is being annoying to go away; 'get lost'; 'go to hell'
Words.Example: - You know ah, you'd be less stressed if you actually did something about your problems instead of whining to us about them.- Eh, go fly kite lah!

Words.English Translation: → English: go steady from english go steady date someone exclusively
Words.Definition: to begin an exclusive and committed relationship

Words.English Translation: → English: go + visiting from english go move; travel out for sth. + english visiting gerund of 'visit' ← english visit go meet with sb. at their place of residence ← old french visiter visit ← latin vīsitō visit; see
Words.Definition: to visit one's various relatives during certain festivals, particularly Chinese New Year, Hari Raya (either Puasa or Haji), and/or Deepavali (depending on one's cultural and community background)

Words.English Translation: → Malay: goblok from malay goblok dumbass; extremely idiotic ← javanese goblog extremely idiotic
Words.Definition: (offensive) dumbass; moron; cretin
Words.Example: Bloody goblok, don't know how to drive isit?

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: got + English: God + in + Heaven from singlish got have; exists; has happened; completive aspect marker (action has been done) ← english got received; obtained, (with have) possess + english God single deity of the Abrahamic religions; chief male deity of a religion + english in within; at; inside + english Heaven sky; paradisical location said to be the dwelling place of God or gods and other beings in various religions
Words.Definition: (sarcastic, humorous) used in response to 'where got?' or any other phrase with 'got'. It may be used to make fun of the overuse of the phrase, or the lack of elaboration or useful information it provides, etc.
Words.Example: - Oei! You got bring the money anot?- Uh… got ah… got…- God in Heaven! The money where lah?

Words.English Translation: → English: Godzilla from english Godzilla kaiju from Godzilla (1954) and the following film series ← japanese ゴジラ gojira Godzilla, a kaiju from Godzilla (1954) and the following film series ← japanese ゴリラ gorira gorilla ← english gorilla gorilla ← ancient greek Γόριλλαι Górillai tribe of hairy women + japanese 鯨 クジラ kujira whale
Words.Definition: (drink ordering) iced, with a scoop of ice cream or dollop of whipped cream, and topped with a scoop of the drink’s (usually Milo or Horlicks) powder. Equivalent to a dinosaur with the addition of the cream or ice cream.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: guli from malay guli marbles ← sanskrit गोलिका golikā small ball for playing with; marble
Words.Definition: a marble; a small, often ornamented sphere of glass or other hard material used as a toy
Words.Example: Things like goli/marbles, kuti kuti or flag erasers were favourites of students, not to forget bottle cap soccer and the rubber band game where you jump over the rope without touching it.

Words.English Translation: → English: gonna from english gonna modal used to indicate a future action or intention, or that something is likely to happen ← english going to used to indicate a future action or intention, or that something is likely to happen
Words.Definition: (auxiliary) going to; gonna; modal used to indicate a future action or intention
Words.Example: I gon' go home after work, got some tai chi I need to settle.

Words.English Translation: → English: gone + case from english gone having passed; doomed + english case situation; condition; task to work on
Words.Definition: somebody or something irredeemable, hopeless, beyond help; futile, or doomed
Words.Example: "At first, I thought there was nothing wrong. When I saw my fillings and looked at my teeth, gone case. Twenty over years and they just cracked like that."

Words.English Translation: → English: gone + fuck from english gone dead; done for; doomed + english fuck (vg.) expn. of dismay, anger, etc.; intensifier
Words.Definition: (vulgar) expression conveying a sense of finality and a situation going terribly wrong; ‘it’s done for’; ‘it’s doomed’

Words.English Translation: → Min nan: 戆 戇 poj: gōng from min nan (poj) 戆 戇 gōng stupid; dull; dumb; simple-minded; stubborn; foolish
Words.Definition: stupid; dull; dumb; simple-minded; foolish
Words.Example: Sally felt so gong gong when she realised she had been waiting at the wrong bus stop for 25 minutes.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 降头 poj: kōng-thâu from hokkien (poj) 降头 kōng-thâu a Southeast Asian form of black magic or witchcraft used to curse people
Words.Definition: a Southeast Asian form of black magic or witchcraft, involving spirits and incantations, used to curse, enthrall, deceive, or cause hurt to others.
Words.Example: What to do if a friend kena gong tao? ... How do I tell if kena gong tao? And if he did, what can I do about it?

Words.English Translation: → Mandarin: 恭喜 pinyin: gōng xǐ from mandarin (pinyin) 恭喜 gōng xǐ congratulate; congratulations
Words.Definition: 'congratulations!'
Words.Example: Dun horse back cannon lah. I can tell you that it is going to correct to 3.3 soon before going back up. But still gxgx that u huat.

Words.Word: gong zai beng 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Cantonese: 公仔饼 公仔餅 jyutping: gung1 zai2 beng2 from cantonese (jyutping) 公仔饼 公仔餅 gung1 zai2 beng2 pastry made from mooncake skin ← cantonese (jyutping) 公仔 公仔 gung1 zai2 doll; figurine; symbol + cantonese (jyutping) 饼 餅 beng2 pastry; cookie; biscuit
Words.Definition: a pastry made from the same ingredients as the outer skin of a traditional mooncake, or effectively a mooncake without any fillings. It traditionally comes in interesting shapes such as a pig/piglet, generic fish, koi, crab, the zodiac animal of the year, etc., but can feasibly be made in any shape. It is a popular snack that can be found at most local bakeries, especially during the Mooncake Festival season.

Words.English Translation: → English: goggles + Google from english goggles eyewear made to fit over and around and protect the eyes + english Google search engine & Internet company ← english googol 10100
Words.Definition: goggles

Words.English Translation: → Tamil: குண்டு kuṇṭu from tamil குண்டு kuṇṭu fat; fat person
Words.Definition: a dummy; a moron; a stupid or silly person
Words.Example: Can you tell that goondu to keep it down? I cannot sleep lah.

Words.English Translation: → English: good from english good great; pleasant; favourable; positive; competent etc.
Words.Definition: good
Words.Example: This dictionary sibeh goot sia. Who write ah?
Related: orbi good, ang moh jiak cerut

Words.Word: gor jiam dua kuay gu chia leng 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Hokkien / teochew: 五占大过牛车辇 五占大過牛車輦 poj / peng'im: gō͘-chiam tōa-kòe gû-chhia-lêng2 from hokkien / teochew (poj / peng'im) 五占大过牛车辇 五占大過牛車輦 gō͘-chiam tōa-kòe gû-chhia-lêng2 (lit.) five cents bigger than a bullock cart's wheel, (fig.) think one's money is worth more than it is ← hokkien (poj) 五 五 gō͘ five + min nan (poj) 占 占 chiam cent + min nan (poj) 大过 大過 tōa-kòe bigger than; more than + min nan (poj) 牛车 牛車 gû-chhia bullock cart; oxcart + min nan (peng'im) 辇 輦 lêng2 wheel
Words.Definition: (idiom) thinking one's money is worth more than it is; describing someone who lowballs or offers to pay a laughably low amount for something
Words.Example: One youth in Singapore is carrying out a coin-collecting campaign to prove that five cents is indeed bigger than a bullock cart's wheel (i.e. gor chiam tua kuay gu chia leng).

Words.Word: gor kee chiu 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 五枝须 五枝鬚 poj: gō͘-ki-chhiu from hokkien (poj) 五枝须 五枝鬚 gō͘-ki-chhiu (lit.) five-string beard/moustache, (fig.) lecherous; lewd; pervert; dirty old man, (slang) catfish
Words.Definition: a pervert; a dirty old man; a lecher
Words.Example: I had a gor kee chiu follow me all the way through the MRT station - luckily I managed to get in a train just before the doors closed and get out of there.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: goreng from malay goreng fry; fried, (slang) flatter
Words.Definition: to fry; to deep-fry
Words.Example: He's been getting gorenged in there for an hour now. Just how badly did he screw up?

Words.English Translation: → English: go astern from english go astern (nautical) reverse; go backwards ← english go move; head towards + english astern (nautical) toward the rear of a vessel
Words.Definition: (invariable) to go backwards; to reverse
Words.Example: Alamak, I turn salah liao. Need to gostan.

Words.English Translation: → English: got from english got received; obtained, (with have) possess ↻ general chinese (pinyin) 有 yǒu have; exists; has happened; there is; possess; completive aspect marker (action has been done) & malay ada have; exists; there is
Words.Definition: to have; to possess; to own
Words.Example: I got car, but I prefer to cycle to work.

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: got + aircon from singlish got have; exists ← english got received; obtained, (with have) possess + singlish aircon air conditioner; air conditioning ← english air-con abbreviation of air-conditioner ← english air conditioner a system used alongside a remote to control the temperature and humidity of a room or space
Words.Definition: (usually sarcastic) air-conditioned; having air-conditioning
Words.Example: Anyone who has gone through national service will have surely heard the phrase, "Your helmet got aircon ah?" being belted out by an irate sergeant towards soldiers who keep their helmets on when they don't need it.

Words.Word: got dragon got phoenix 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Singlish: got + English: dragon + Singlish: got + English: phoenix ↻ Hokkien: 有龙有凤 有龍有鳳 poj: ū-lêng-ū-hōng from singlish got have; exists; has happened ← english got received; obtained, (with have) possess + english dragon mythical, scaled animal ← old french dragon dragon ← latin dracō dragon ← ancient greek δρᾰ́κων drákōn dragon + singlish got have; exists; has happened ← english got received; obtained, (with have) possess + english phoenix mythical Chinese chimera; mythical fiery bird ← latin phoenīx phoenix ← ancient greek φοῖνῐξ phoînix phoenix ← egyptian 𓃀𓈖𓏌𓅱𓅣 bnw grey heron; the Bennu; phoenix ↻ hokkien (poj) 有龙有凤 有龍有鳳 ū-lêng-ū-hōng (lit.) have dragon(s), have phoenix(es) ← hokkien (poj) 有 有 ū have; has got; there is + hokkien (poj) 龙 龍 lêng dragon + hokkien (poj) 有 有 ū have; has got; there is + hokkien (poj) 凤 鳳 hōng Chinese phoenix; fenghuang; hōō
Words.Definition: (idiom) a story, speech, written work etc. told with elaborate, flowery language and heavy embellishments
Words.Example: anyone encounter "experts" before who can say until like dragon got phoenix, but when ask them to show example...... they will say the example is too simple and obvious and no need to show.

Words.Word: got dragon got tiger 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Singlish: got + English: dragon + Singlish: got + English: tiger ↻ Hokkien: 有龙有虎 有龍有虎 poj: ū-lêng-ū-hó͘ from singlish got have; exists; has happened ← english got received; obtained, (with have) possess + english dragon mythical, scaled animal ← old french dragon dragon ← latin dracō dragon ← ancient greek δρᾰ́κων drákōn dragon + singlish got have; exists; has happened ← english got received; obtained, (with have) possess + english tiger Panthera tigris, a large predatory feline ← latin tigris tiger ← ancient greek τῐ́γρῐς tĭ́grĭs tiger ↻ hokkien (poj) 有龙有虎 有龍有虎 ū-lêng-ū-hó͘ (lit.) have dragon(s), have tiger(s) ← hokkien (poj) 有 有 ū have; has got; there is + hokkien (poj) 龙 龍 lêng dragon + hokkien (poj) 有 有 ū have; has got; there is + hokkien (poj) 虎 虎 hó͘ tiger
Words.Definition: (idiom) a story, speech, written work etc. told with elaborate, flowery language and heavy embellishments
Words.Example: Wen Wei writes until “Got dragon got tiger”… No wonder his teacher make special mention to his essay.

Words.Word: got eyes also don't know Mount Taishan 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Singlish: got + English: eyes + Singlish: also + English: don't + know + Mount ↻ Mandarin: 有眼不识泰山 有眼不識泰山 pinyin: yǒu yǎn bù shí tài shān from singlish got have; exists; possess ← english got received; obtained + english eyes organs used to see + singlish also as well; too; used for emphasis; even; still ← english also in addition; too; besides + english don't do not ← english do perform; execute; syntactic marker + english not adverb used to negate sth. + english know understand; be cognizant of; comprehend + english Mount mountain; used as a title in proper names of mountains ← latin mōns mountain ↻ mandarin (pinyin) 有眼不识泰山 有眼不識泰山 yǒu yǎn bù shí tài shān not recognize excellence, talent, someone important, etc.; be blind to greatness ← mandarin (pinyin) 有 有 yǒu have; possess + mandarin (pinyin) 眼 眼 yǎn eye; eyes + mandarin (pinyin) 不 不 bù don't; not + mandarin (pinyin) 识 識 shí recognize; know + mandarin (pinyin) 泰山 泰山 tài shān Taishan (mountain or folklore character); (fig.) sth. important or significant
Words.Definition: (idiom) to not recognize excellence, outstanding talent, someone important, etc. even when it is right in front of one's face; to be blind to someone's greatness
Words.Example: Apparently Harvard rejected Jack Ma over 10 times before he gave up trying. Probably cos he Chinese, plus got no sob story and CCAs all. Talk about got eyes also don't know Mount Taishan.

Words.Word: got eyes also don't know orh ee orh 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Singlish: got + English: eyes + Singlish: also + English: don't + know + Mount ↻ Mandarin: 有眼不识泰山 有眼不識泰山 pinyin: yǒu yǎn bù shí Tài shān + General chinese: 泰山 pinyin: tài shān + Singlish: orh ee orh from singlish got have; exists; possess ← english got received; obtained + english eyes organs used to see + singlish also as well; too; used for emphasis; even; still ← english also in addition; too; besides + english don't do not ← english do perform; execute; syntactic marker + english not adverb used to negate sth. + english know understand; be cognizant of; comprehend + english Mount mountain; used as a title in proper names of mountains ← latin mōns mountain ↻ mandarin (pinyin) 有眼不识泰山 有眼不識泰山 yǒu yǎn bù shí Tài shān not recognize excellence, talent, someone important, etc.; be blind to greatness ← mandarin (pinyin) 有 有 yǒu have; possess + mandarin (pinyin) 眼 眼 yǎn eye; eyes + mandarin (pinyin) 不 不 bù don't; not + mandarin (pinyin) 识 識 shí recognize; know + mandarin (pinyin) 泰山 泰山 Tài shān Taishan (mountain or folklore character); (fig.) sth. important or significant; Tarzan + general chinese (pinyin) 泰山 tài shān Tarzan (fictional character) ← english Tarzan fictional character raised in the jungle by apes + singlish orh ee orh Singlish phonetic approximation of the "Tarzan yell" ← fictional ape language [ululating yell] Tarzan's iconic cry from the movie Tarzan the Ape Man (1932) and subsequent media
Words.Definition: (idiom, metonym, humorous) to not recognize excellence, outstanding talent, someone important, etc. even when it is right in front of one's face; to be blind to someone's greatness
Words.Example: Jialat lah, today someone come by while I was working, ask so many questions and make me pek chek until I tell him go fly kite. Sekali is the CEO sia. Macam Undercover Boss liddat, I really got eyes also don't know orh ee orh.

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: got + English: licence from singlish got have; exists; has happened; possess ← english got received; obtained, (with have) possess + english licence legal permission to do sth.; freedom to do sth, esp. when it is not normal practice
Words.Definition: to have permission to do something, especially when against social obligations or norms
Words.Example: Don't worry, today I got licence from towkay to pang kang early.

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: got + standard from singlish got have; exists; has happened; possess ← english got received; obtained, (with have) possess + singlish standard great or outstanding quality ← english standard acceptable quality or grade; recognized benchmark of quality
Words.Definition: impressive; well competent; having a high ability or aptitude
Words.Example: Wah! The char kway teow here really got standard man!

Words.English Translation: → Malay: gotong royong from malay gotong royong cooperation
Words.Definition: cooperation; mutual help; sharing of burdens; neighbourly care for one another within a community
Words.Example: Bring on "gotong royong", but let us also remember the Malay proverb, "seperti katak di bawah tempurung": Let us not be like a frog under a shell that thinks the shell is the world.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: goyang from malay goyang shake; sway, (slang) scared; cowardly
Words.Definition: to shake; to sway
Words.Example: Last car damn goyang sia, need drive so slow.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: goyang kaki from malay goyang kaki relax; take things easy while others do the work ← malay goyang sway; swing; shake + malay kaki leg; foot
Words.Definition: (idiom) to sit around doing nothing; to while away the time; to skive around; to idle and relax while watching others do the work

Words.English Translation: → Kristang: gragoh from kristang gragoh shrimp; prawn ← malay [udang] geragau small dried shrimp, used as an ingredient for making belacan etc.
Words.Definition: (possibly derogatory) a person of Eurasian descent
Words.Example: ... or as a condiment such as in cincalok which has its origins from the geragok (or krill) fishermen of Malacca (relatively darker skinned descendants of Portuguese who intermarried with the local population and who are often referred to as "Geragok").

Words.English Translation: → English: grandfather + story from english grandfather male grandparent + english story tale; account of events ← anglo-norman estorie history; story ← latin historia history; story ← ancient greek ῐ̔στορῐ́ᾱ historíā history; written account; inquiry
Words.Definition: (idiom) an unnecessarily long-winded account of an event that happened in the past, which is often boring, confusingly non-linear, moralizing, and/or uncalled-for
Words.Example: All I wanted to know was where the box went; I never asked for his whole grandfather story!

Words.English Translation: → English: grandfather’s from english grandfather’s of or belonging to one’s male grandparent
Words.Definition: (possessive, attributive, sarcastic) used to qualify that something is of or belongs to one’s grandfather. Used to imply that someone is treating said thing or place as if they or their family has owned it for generations, permitting them to do whatever they please and acting as if they were the most important person there
Words.Example: Eh! Your grandfather’s hotel ah? You trash the room until so jialat you confirm tio charged lah!

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: grandfather's + English: army from singlish grandfather's of or belonging to one’s grandfather; implies permission to do whatever one pleases ← english grandfather's of or belonging to one’s male grandparent + english army armed land forces, sometimes also including the entire military e.g. air force and navy
Words.Definition: (sarcastic) used to imply that a soldier is acting as if they were permitted to do whatever they please in the army, that rules do not apply to them, and that they are the most important person there
Words.Example: Chao recruit! I say 7:30 first parade means 7:34 you can happy happy jalan in ah? Your grandfather army isit?

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: grandfather's + English: road from singlish grandfather's of or belonging to one’s grandfather; implies permission to do whatever one pleases ← english grandfather's of or belonging to one’s male grandparent + english road street; paved way for vehicles or pedestrians
Words.Definition: (sarcastic) a road or street which one treats as if it belongs to one’s grandfather. Used to imply that someone is acting as if they were permitted to do whatever they please and that they are the most important person on the road
Words.Example: This goondu park like it’s his grandfather road. Somehow managed to take up 3 spots with one car!

Words.English Translation: → English: grandmother + story from english grandmother female grandparent + english story tale; account of events ← anglo-norman estorie history; story ← latin historia history; story ← ancient greek ῐ̔στορῐ́ᾱ historíā history; written account; inquiry
Words.Definition: (idiom) an unnecessarily long-winded account of an event that happened in the past, which is often boring, confusingly non-linear, moralizing, and/or uncalled-for

Words.English Translation: → English: green + bean ↻ General chinese: 绿豆 綠豆 pinyin: lǜ dòu & Malay: kacang hijau from english green colour between yellow and blue on the visible light spectrum + english bean plant of the family Fabaceae producing edible seeds, or the seeds thereof ↻ general chinese (pinyin) 绿豆 綠豆 lǜ dòu Vigna radiata and its edible bean ← general chinese (pinyin) 绿 綠 lǜ green + general chinese (pinyin) 豆 豆 dòu bean & malay kacang hijau Vigna radiata and its edible bean ← malay kacang bean + malay hijau green
Words.Definition: the bean plant Vigna radiata and its edible green-coloured beans, which are used in several local dishes in Singapore

Words.Word: green bean soup 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Singlish: green bean + English: soup from singlish green bean Vigna radiata and its edible bean ← english green colour between yellow and blue on the visible light spectrum + english bean plant of the family Fabaceae producing edible seeds, or the seeds thereof ↻ general chinese (pinyin) 绿豆 綠豆 lǜ dòu Vigna radiata and its edible bean ← general chinese (pinyin) 绿 綠 lǜ green + general chinese (pinyin) 豆 豆 dòu bean & malay kacang hijau bean ← malay kacang green + malay hijau + english soup liquid-based dish with other ingredients ↻ general chinese (pinyin) 汤 湯 tāng soup
Words.Definition: a soup made by boiling green beans (Vigna radiata) and other optional ingredients in water, usually sweetened (traditionally with rock sugar or gula melaka) and served as a cold or warm dessert.
Words.Example: Do you like green bean soup with a thicker consistency or a more watery texture? For a thicker soup, mash up some of the softened beans with the back of a spoon against a sieve.

Words.Word: gu lou yok 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Cantonese: 咕噜肉 咕嚕肉 jyutping: gu1 lou1 juk6 from cantonese (jyutping) 咕噜肉 咕嚕肉 gu1 lou1 juk6 sweet and sour pork ← cantonese (jyutping) 咕噜 咕嚕 gu1 lou1 (onom.) rolling; bubbling; gurgling; rumbling + cantonese (jyutping) 肉 肉 juk6 meat; pork
Words.Definition: sweet and sour pork, a Cantonese dish of deep-fried diced pork stir-fried in a sweet and sour tomato-based sauce with vegetables such as capsicum and onions

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 牛奶 poj: gû-ni from hokkien (poj) 牛奶 gû-ni cow’s milk; milk ← hokkien (poj) 牛 gû cow + hokkien (poj) 奶 ni milk; breast
Words.Definition: milk; cow’s milk
Words.Example: You use what kind of gu ni to make your yogurt?

Words.English Translation: → Mandarin: 姑娘 pinyin: gū niáng from mandarin (pinyin) 姑娘 gū niáng young maiden; young unmarried woman
Words.Definition: (derogatory) an effeminate man
Words.Example: Shovelling hard-packed snow is no easy task. It’s a bit like trench-digging during NS, except in the cold and without some sergeant calling you a “gu niang” every few minutes.

Words.Word: gu wak zai 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Cantonese: 古惑仔 古惑仔 jyutping: gu2 waak6 zai2 from cantonese (jyutping) 古惑仔 古惑仔 gu2 waak6 zai2 gangster; triad member; hooligan ← cantonese (jyutping) 蛊惑仔 蠱惑仔 gu2 waak6 zai2 gangster; triad member; hooligan ← cantonese (jyutping) 蛊惑 蠱惑 gu2 waak6 sly; cunning; trick; poison; bad influence + cantonese (jyutping) 仔 仔 zai2 son; child; dimin. suffix
Words.Definition: a Cantonese gangster, ruffian, or hooligan, especially one from Hong Kong or associated with the Hong Kong triads
Words.Example: You all heard of the news? Few days ago liao, sinkie family go hk then eat roadside stall go complain neighbouring table the gu wak zai smoking..ended up tio walloped causeway bay style

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 牛油 poj: gû-iû from hokkien (poj) 牛油 gû-iû butter; beef tallow ← hokkien (poj) 牛 gû cow + hokkien (poj) 油 iû oil
Words.Definition: butter
Words.Example: All I had for breakfast was some leftover chiam tao lo ti with gu yu.

Words.English Translation: → General chinese: 乖 pinyin: guāi from general chinese (pinyin) 乖 guāi well-behaved; good; obedient
Words.Definition: well-behaved; good; obedient
Words.Example: Ming Lee was always seen as the guai kid sitting quietly in the back of the class. Who would have guessed she’d grow up into the Lianest of Ah Lians?

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 怪𡳞 poj: koài-lān from hokkien (poj) 怪𡳞 koài-lān (lit.) weird dick; strange penis, (fig, vg.) hard to please or get along with; annoying; contemptible ← hokkien (poj) 怪 koài weird; strange; queer + hokkien (poj) 𡳞 lān (vg.) penis; dick; male genitalia
Words.Definition: (vulgar, of a person) hard to please or get along with; being difficult; annoying; contemptible
Words.Example: I seemed to please everyone at the interview except the director, who was just showing the most guai lan face the entire time.

Words.English Translation: → English: guarantee + Singlish: got + chop from english guarantee additionally; on top of sth. ← french guarantie assure; guarantee; promise + singlish got have; there is; completive aspect marker (action has been done) + singlish chop stamp or seal; mark indicating e.g. origin, brand, or authenticity ← hindi छाप chāp stamp; mark; impression
Words.Definition: for sure; definitely; absolutely

Words.English Translation: → Malay: gula melaka from malay gula melaka palm sugar; palm jaggery ← malay gula sugar ← sanskrit गुल gula unrefined sugar; raw sugar; molasses + malay Melaka a state in Malaysia (aka Malacca) or its capital city ← sanskrit आमलकी āmalakī Phyllanthus emblica, aka the Indian gooseberry tree, whose fruits can be eaten, or used in cooking and Ayurvedic medicine
Words.Definition: a palm sugar made from the sap of coconut palms (although it may be made from a mixture of saps from other palms as well), named after Melaka in Malaysia. It has a complex and rich flavour, and is an integral ingredient in Singaporean and other Asian cuisines. It is usually sold in large, solid, caramel-brown cakes or blocks.

Words.Word: guo da li 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Mandarin: 过大礼 過大禮 pinyin: guò dà lǐ from mandarin (pinyin) 过大礼 過大禮 guò dà lǐ betrothal ceremony ← mandarin (pinyin) 过 過 guò cross over + mandarin (pinyin) 大 大 dà great; big + mandarin (pinyin) 礼 禮 lǐ ceremony; ritual; gift
Words.Definition: a traditional Chinese betrothal ceremony practiced by the various Southern Chinese cultures in Singapore before a wedding, usually involving a presentation of various gifts such as gold, a suckling pig, a bridal basket, etc. from the groom’s family to the bride’s family (or vice versa)
Words.Example: I had to plead with the cake shop to rush my orders for the Guo Da Li (betrothal) cakes because we were so late.

Words.English Translation: → Mandarin: 锅贴 鍋貼 pinyin: guō tiē from mandarin (pinyin) 锅贴 鍋貼 guō tiē potstickers, a type of sail-shaped Chinese dumpling ← mandarin (pinyin) 锅 鍋 guō pot + mandarin (pinyin) 贴 貼 tiē stick; paste
Words.Definition: potstickers, a type of distinctly sail-shaped Chinese dumpling usually stuffed with a ground meat like pork or beef, and vegetables such as chives. It has a vaguely triangular cross-section, with a flat base that is often intentionally burnt slightly when pan-frying to produce a crispy texture.
Words.Example: ... the dumplings were crunchy, and pan-fried fresh. And that chive goodness truly did not hold back. The flavour was vibrant and the guo tie skin had that perfect springy kick.

Words.English Translation: → English: garter from english garter band, usu. elastic, worn on the leg to fasten a sock or stocking ← old norman gartier garter ← old french garet calf; hock; shank; bend of the knee
Words.Definition: (military) an elastic band worn around the leg near the ankle, into which the excess length of the trouser leg of a soldier's uniform is tucked

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 哈 poj: hâⁿ + English: huh from hokkien (poj) 哈 hâⁿ expression of confusion, doubt, surprise, amusement, questioning, sarcasm, etc.; particle used to form a question + english huh expression of confusion, doubt, surprise, amusement, questioning, sarcasm, etc.; particle used to form a question
Words.Definition: expression of confusion, curiosity, doubt etc.
Words.Example: Hãr? Really got such thing meh?

Words.English Translation: → Malay: habis from malay habis finish; complete
Words.Definition: to finish; to complete
Words.Example: The nasi padang at this stall used to be so popular that after 12:30 it usually habis already.
Related: you die, I die, everybody die

Words.English Translation: → Min nan: 虾米 蝦米 poj: hê-bí from min nan (poj) 虾米 蝦米 hê-bí small, dried shrimp
Words.Definition: small, dried shrimp used as an ingredient in many dishes
Words.Example: There is only one way I always cook my ‘petai’, that is with pounded chili, dried shrimps (hae bee) and assam water. This dish makes my guests come scrambling for more.

Words.Word: hae bee hiam 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Min nan: 虾米莶 蝦米薟 poj: hê-bí-hiam from min nan (poj) 虾米莶 蝦米薟 hê-bí-hiam dry spiced sambal composed of small dried shrimp, desiccated coconut shavings, chilli, lemongrass, peppercorns, shallots, garlic, turmeric, galangal, and various other spices, traditionally combined by roughly pounding in a mortar and pestle before frying ← min nan (poj) 虾米 蝦米 hê-bí small, dried shrimp + min nan (poj) 莶 薟 hiam spicy; pungent
Words.Definition: a dry spiced sambal composed of small dried shrimp, desiccated coconut shavings, chilli, lemongrass, peppercorns, shallots, garlic, turmeric, galangal, and various other spices, traditionally combined by roughly pounding in a mortar and pestle before frying.It is often used as a condiment or ingredient; for example as the filling in rempah udang. It has origins in Peranakan cuisine.
Words.Example: Hae Bee Hiam (or as my chat group calls it: HBH) is an age old favourite amongst Singaporeans and Malaysians. ... All Peranakan families have their own versions with some having more ingredients and some less.

Words.English Translation: → Min nan: 虾枣 蝦棗 poj: hê-chó from min nan (poj) 虾枣 蝦棗 hê-chó fried rolls with a filling of seasoned prawn, pork, water chestnuts etc. wrapped in beancurd skin and a coating of egg ← min nan (poj) 虾 蝦 hê prawn; shrimp + min nan (poj) 枣 棗 chó edible fruit of the Ziziphus jujuba tree, a.k.a. Chinese date or jujube
Words.Definition: a roll with a filling of seasoned prawn, pork, water chestnuts, and other ingredients wrapped in beancurd skin and deep-fried with a coating of egg. The rolls are usually seasoned with ngoh hiang (five-spice) powder, and served with a sweet plum or chilli sauce and dark soya sauce as a dip. The name means 'prawn date', as originally the rolls were shaped more like shorter, oblong capsules resembling Chinese dates, but modern versions often come as a long roll sliced into smaller pieces as it takes less effort to prepare. Likely originated in Teochew or Hokkien cuisine.
Words.Example: If it’s crispy, typically Teochew snacks you crave, they have it all – Hae Cho (Prawn Rolls) and the Liver Rolls too.

Words.English Translation: → Min nan: 虾膏 蝦膏 poj: hê-chó from min nan (poj) 虾膏 蝦膏 hê-chó fermented shrimp paste ← min nan (poj) 虾 蝦 hê prawn; shrimp + min nan (poj) 膏 膏 chó paste; cream; fat
Words.Definition: a prawn paste used as a condiment in cooking, such as as a primary ingredient in rojak sauce. It may be fermented or non-fermented. It sometimes has a thick, molasses-like consistency and black colour, due to the molasses and/or sugar that is often added to it.
Words.Example: This black/brownish dressing dominantly contains a black shrimp paste called petis udang or hae ko ...

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 虾面 蝦麵 poj: hê-mī from hokkien (poj) 虾面 蝦麵 hê-mī prawn noodles ← hokkien (poj) 虾 蝦 hê prawn; shrimp + hokkien (poj) 面 麵 mī wheat noodles
Words.Definition: a soup noodle dish of Hokkien origin, featuring prawns and pork (usually ribs or slices of meat) and yellow noodles in a spicy, savoury bowl of soup. The soup is made from fried prawn shells and heads boiled, simmered, and strained into an intensely flavourful stock, together with other ingredients such as pork stock, fried shallots, and chilli.
Words.Example: ... known simply as prawn mee in Singapore, but as hae mee or har mee in Penang. This noodle dish is all about the broth. Rich and heady with deep depths of prawn flavour, shimmering orange from the prawn oil.

Words.English Translation: → Mandarin: 海南 pinyin: hǎi nán + English: -ese from mandarin (pinyin) 海南 hǎi nán island and province off the coast of mainland China, (lit.) 'south of the sea' + english -ese used to form a demonym or other word for something of a place, country, culture, etc.
Words.Definition: of or relating to Hainan or its people, ethnicity, culture, background, etc.

Words.English Translation: → English: Hainanese + pork chop from english Hainanese of or relating to Hainan or its people, ethnicity, culture, background, etc. ← mandarin (pinyin) 海南 hǎi nán island and province off the coast of mainland China, (lit.) 'south of the sea' + english -ese used to form a demonym or other word for something of a place, country, culture, etc. + english pork chop cut of meat taken from a section perpendicular to a pig's spine, such as a rib ← english pork pig meat ← old french porc pig; pork ← latin porcus domestic pig; pig + english chop cut of meat, often from a rib
Words.Definition: a dish featuring a deep-fried, usually boneless cut of pork pounded flat, marinated and seasoned with a mix of Asian and Western condiments such as soya sauce and Worcestershire sauce, then breaded (traditionally with British cream cracker crumbs) and deep-fried. It is usually drizzled with a tomato-based gravy with mixed vegetables and served with a helping of white rice.It was developed by Hainanese chefs serving in British colonial households for the Western palate, and is similar to Western dishes such as the German schnitzel. The pork may sometimes be substituted for chicken, in which case it is known as a Hainanese chicken chop.
Words.Example: Hainanese pork chop is definitely an East meets West food. The pork chop is crispy on the outside and tender inside and the lightly tangy, sweet sauce to go with the pork chop is just heavenly.

Words.English Translation: → English: Hainanese + Singlish: steamboat from english Hainanese of or relating to Hainan or its people, ethnicity, culture, background, etc. ← mandarin (pinyin) 海南 hǎi nán island and province off the coast of mainland China, (lit.) 'south of the sea' + english -ese used to form a demonym or other word for something of a place, country, culture, etc. + singlish steamboat style of hot pot with a thin, less oily broth ← english steamboat ship or vessel propelled with steam power; steamer ← english steam gaseous form of water + english boat vessel used on water for transport
Words.Definition: a style of steamboat invented by Hainansese immigrants to Singapore, using a clear chicken stock and often featuring plenty of seafood
Words.Example: We were there to eat mookata one night and after eating, a friend commented that there was another yummy hainanese steamboat place at Golden Mile Tower ... it is one of those eating place where a lot of Hainanese goes to because the flavour of the food there can provide that Hainanese nostalgia. [sic]

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 害矣 poj: hāi--ah from hokkien (poj) 害矣 hāi--ah exclamation of distress, grief, horror, disappointment, etc.; 'it's done for'; 'oh no'; 'alas'; 'how awful!'
Words.Definition: exclamation of distress, grief, horror, disappointment, etc.; 'it's done for'; 'oh no'; 'alas'; 'how awful!'
Words.Example: Haiya is the MSG of word. All the flavour inside. Your bus come late? Haiya. You run out of milk? Haiya. Your baby born with three arm? Haiya.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 害矣 poj: hāi--ah + Tamil: ஐயோ aiyō + General chinese: 哎哟 哎喲 pinyin: āiyō from hokkien (poj) 害矣 hāi--ah exclamation of distress, grief, horror, disappointment, etc.; 'it's done for'; 'oh no'; 'alas'; 'how awful!' + tamil ஐயோ aiyō alas; woe; oh no + general chinese (pinyin) 哎哟 哎喲 āiyō ouch; oh dear
Words.Definition: exclamation of distress, grief, horror, disappointment, etc.; 'it's done for'; 'oh no'; 'alas'; 'how awful!'

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: haiya from singlish haiya exclamation of distress, grief, horror, disappointment, etc.; 'it's done for'; 'oh no'; 'alas'; 'how awful!' ← hokkien (poj) 害矣 hāi--ah exclamation of distress, grief, horror, disappointment etc.; 'it's done for'; 'oh no'; 'alas'; 'how awful!'
Words.Definition: expression of disappointment, annoyance, weariness, etc.
Words.Example: Haiz... this week I OT every day until like 8 plus. Si beh shag sia.

Words.English Translation: → Hakka: 客家 hag5 ga1 from hakka 客家 hag5 ga1 (lit.) 'guest families'; subgroup of Chinese people with a wide historical dispersion, and their language, culture, etc.
Words.Definition: of or relating to the Hakka, a subgroup of Chinese people with a wide historical dispersion (now concentrated in and around Guangdong, Fujian, and Jiangxi in China, as well as in a diaspora all over the world), and their language, culture, background, etc.
Words.Example: Of all Singaporean Hakkas, the most famous is almost certainly the founding father, Lee Kuan Yew.

Words.Word: Hakka yong tau foo 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Hakka: 客家 hag5 ga1 + Min nan / cantonese: 酿豆腐 釀豆腐 poj / jyutping: iōng-tāu-fū / joeng6 dau6 fu6 from hakka 客家 hag5 ga1 (lit.) 'guest families'; subgroup of Chinese people with a wide historical dispersion, and their language, culture, etc. + min nan / cantonese (poj / jyutping) 酿豆腐 釀豆腐 iōng-tāu-fū / joeng6 dau6 fu6 originally Hakka dish of tofu, vegetables, mushrooms, etc. stuffed with a mixture of ground pork and/or fish paste ← hakka (pinfa) 酿豆腐 釀豆腐 ngiong4 têu4 fu4 Hakka dish of tofu stuffed with ground pork and fried or braised ← hakka (pinfa) 酿 釀 ngiong4 stuff a filling into sth. and cook; ferment + hakka (pinfa) 豆腐 豆腐 têu4 fu4 tofu
Words.Definition: a dish of Hakka origin, traditionally consisting of tofu stuffed with a paste of ground pork which is then pan-fried or braised. In Singapore, the dish often includes a number of other items, especially the "Hakka Three Treasures" of brinjal, bitter melon, and chilli peppers, which are also stuffed with the same paste.
Words.Example: This Hakka Yong Tau Foo (YTF) recipe was my granny’s who migrated from China to Singapore many many years ago. ... My granny used to cook this dish for us without fail every time we go to her place for Lunar New Year reunion dinner and I used to dislike it a lot. But now that I’m all grown up and she is no longer with us, I’m starting to appreciate and even crave for her YTF every now and then.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: halal from malay halal permissible or lawful according to Muslim religious beliefs ← arabic حَلَال ḥalāl permissible; legal; allowed
Words.Definition: permissible or lawful according to Muslim religious beliefs, such as regarding consumption of food

Words.English Translation: → English: half + ball ↻ Hokkien: 半粒 poj: pòaⁿ-lia̍p from english half 0.5 + english ball roughly spherical object ↻ hokkien (poj) 半粒 pòaⁿ-lia̍p type of handicap in sports betting, (lit.) 'half a granule / ball' ← hokkien (poj) 半 pòaⁿ half + hokkien (poj) 粒 lia̍p (measure word) granules; round objects; grains; balls; pieces
Words.Definition: a popular type of handicap in sports betting where 0.5 of a goal is given, such that the possibility of a draw is eliminated and punters need only choose between a win or a loss. Also known as 'Asian handicap' in English.
Words.Example: Matches featuring the half-ball handicap often attract a large audience due to their high level of excitement.

Words.English Translation: → English: half + fuck from english half 1/2; partial + english fuck (vg.) expn. of dismay, anger, etc.; intensifier
Words.Definition: half-assed; sloppily and poorly done; halfhearted; careless; unserious
Words.Example: Everyone know half fuck measures lead to half fuck results. We see it when we are in school, work, life and now we are watching this play out in a national scale

Words.English Translation: → English: half past six from english half past six 6:30 (am or pm)
Words.Definition: sloppy; careless; slipshod; of poor quality; incompetent; uninterested
Words.Example: We can talk about half-past-six attitude, mentality or character to describe persons or individuals. We can talk about “half-past-six” products and quality and after-sales services. There are also “half-past-six” marriages, relationships and quality of life.

Words.Word: ham chim peng 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Cantonese: 咸煎饼 鹹煎餅 jyutping: haam4 zin1 beng2 from cantonese (jyutping) 咸煎饼 鹹煎餅 haam4 zin1 beng2 Chinese deep-fried dough snack topped with sesame seeds ← cantonese (jyutping) 咸 鹹 haam4 salty + cantonese (jyutping) 煎饼 煎餅 zin1 beng2 fried pancake or flatbread
Words.Definition: a Southern Chinese deep-fried dough snack topped with sesame seeds. It has a hollow centre, which is sometimes filled with a filling such as tau sar or five spice powder.
Words.Example: The distinctive look and flavor of Ham Chim Peng comes from the key ingredient: the red-colored Chinese fermented bean curd (南腐乳), or “bean cheese.”

Words.Word: ham ga chan 简 繁

Words.English Translation: → Min nan: 含巴拢 含巴攏 poj: hâm-pa-láng + Cantonese: 冚唪唥 jyutping: ham6 baa6 laang6 from min nan (poj) 含巴拢 含巴攏 hâm-pa-láng total; all; sum ← min nan (poj) 含 含 hâm contain; enclose; include + min nan (poj) 巴 巴 pa clumped; stick; cling + min nan (poj) 拢 攏 láng/lóng everything; all; total; together + cantonese (jyutping) 冚唪唥 ham6 baa6 laang6 everything; all; entire; everyone

Words.English Translation: → English: handsome from english handsome handsome
Words.Definition: (of a person) handsome
Words.Example: Despite his modesty, his friends always teased him by calling him 'hamsum' due to his striking features.

Words.English Translation: → English: hand + phone + Mandarin: 手机 手機 pinyin: shǒu jī from english hand part of the body below the wrist including the palm and fingers + english phone device used to make calls, send messages, run applications, etc. ✂ english telephone device used to make calls, send messages etc. ← french téléphone telephone ← ancient greek τῆλε têle far away; far + ancient greek φωνή phōnḗ sound; voice; speech + mandarin (pinyin) 手机 手機 shǒu jī mobile phone ← mandarin (pinyin) 手 手 shǒu hand; machine; device + mandarin (pinyin) 机 機 jī
Words.Definition: a mobile phone or smartphone

Words.English Translation: → English: hang + flower ↻ Mandarin: 吊花 pinyin: diào huā from english hang suspend; drape + english flower usu. colourful reproductive structure in angiosperms ← anglo-norman flur flower ← altin flōrem flower ↻ mandarin (pinyin) 吊花 diào huā hang flowers ← mandarin (pinyin) 吊 diào hang + mandarin (pinyin) 花 huā flower
Words.Definition: variation of diao hua

Words.English Translation: → Malay: hangus from malay hangus burnt black; scorched; charred; consumed by fire
Words.Definition: burnt black; scorched; charred; consumed by fire

Words.English Translation: → Possible, but not certain Hokkien: 闲唠/啰 閒嘮/囉 poj: hân lô͘ or Possible, but not certain 哈哪 poj: hâⁿ--ná from hokkien (poj) Possible, but not certain 闲唠/啰 閒嘮/囉 hân lô͘ idle drivel; unimportant chatter ← hokkien (poj) 闲 閒 hân idle; unimportant; trivial; unrelated + hokkien (poj) 唠/啰 嘮/囉 lô͘ nag; prattle; yap; chatter; annoying; noisy or hokkien (poj) Possible, but not certain 哈哪 hâⁿ--ná (imitative) 'blah blah'; 'yada yada'
Words.Definition: 'yeah, yeah'; 'alright, enough'; 'OK, whatever'; 'yada yada yada'; 'blah, blah'; used to indicate disinterest, impatience, irritation, or dismissal with someone else's prattling, nagging, drivel, behaviour, pattern, etc.
Words.Example: My mom keeps insisting they are just lying and selling normal coke as Coke Zero - then is like 'ha nah ha nah' when I try explaining to her.

Words.English Translation: → Teochew / hokkien: 好脸 好臉 poj: hàu-lián from teochew / hokkien (poj) 好脸 好臉 hàu-lián boast; brag; be arrogant

Words.Word: happy can already 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 欢喜着好 歡喜著好 poj: hoaⁿ-hí tio̍h hó ↻ English: happy + Singlish: can + already from hokkien (poj) 欢喜着好 歡喜著好 hoaⁿ-hí tio̍h hó (proverb) being happy is good enough ← hokkien (poj) 欢喜 歡喜 hoaⁿ-hí happy; joyful + hokkien (poj) 着 著 tio̍h already; then + hokkien (poj) 好 好 hó good; great ↻ english happy joyful; contented + singlish can affirmative particle; able to; permitted to ← english can able to; may; be possible; permitted + singlish already particle indicating perfective aspect or change of state ← english already completed or happened by the present or specified time ↻ min nan (poj) 了 liáu particle indicating perfective aspect or change of state; already; (approximately) past tense marker
Words.Definition: (proverb) being joyful and content with life is good enough; used to remind one that finding joy and happiness are more important in life than e.g. material goods, wealth, social standing and reputation, etc.
Words.Example: - Wah she damn weird sia, I never before see people eat prata with kicap manis... - Aiyah, happy can already.

Words.Word: happy can liao 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 欢喜着好 歡喜著好 poj: hoaⁿ-hí tio̍h hó ↻ English: happy + Singlish: can + liao from hokkien (poj) 欢喜着好 歡喜著好 hoaⁿ-hí tio̍h hó (proverb) being happy is good enough ← hokkien (poj) 欢喜 歡喜 hoaⁿ-hí happy; joyful + hokkien (poj) 着 著 tio̍h already; then + hokkien (poj) 好 好 hó good; great ↻ english happy joyful; contented + singlish can affirmative particle; able to; permitted to ← english can able to; may; be possible; permitted + singlish liao particle indicating perfective aspect or change of state; already; (approximately) past tense marker ← min nan (poj) 了 liáu particle indicating perfective aspect or change of state; already; (approximately) past tense marker

Words.Example: You got see her new puppy? She happy like bird, play whole day never stop.

Words.Definition: (simile) very happy; ecstatic; overjoyed; jumping with joy

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: suka-suka ↻ English: happy from singlish suka-suka as one wishes; according to one’s desires ← malay sesuka-suka as one wishes; according to one’s desires ← malay suka like; happiness ← sanskrit सुख sukhá prosperous; pleasant; joyful; happy ↻ english happy pleased; contented
