Words.English Translation: → Cantonese: 虾 蝦 jyutping: haa1 from cantonese (jyutping) 虾 蝦 haa1 prawn; shrimp
Words.Definition: prawn; shrimp
Words.Example: Hãr? Really got such thing meh?

Words.English Translation: → Cantonese: 虾酱 蝦醬 jyutping: haa1 zoeng3 from cantonese (jyutping) 虾酱 蝦醬 haa1 zoeng3 fermented shrimp paste
Words.Definition: a Chinese fermented shrimp paste, used as a condiment in dishes such as har cheong gai.
Words.Example: There’re many types of fermented prawn paste. I could smell this one once the bottle was open.OMG, this is potent stuff!It wasn’t belachan ... Nor was it Penang hae ko ... What I had was har cheong, a liquid prawn paste made in Hong Kong. It was a very appetizing grey – oh yum! ...

Words.Word: har cheong gai 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Cantonese: 虾酱鸡 蝦醬雞 jyutping: haa1 zoeng3 gai1 from cantonese (jyutping) 虾酱鸡 蝦醬雞 haa1 zoeng3 gai1 prawn paste chicken ← cantonese (jyutping) 虾酱 蝦醬 haa1 zoeng3 prawn paste; shrimp paste + cantonese (jyutping) 鸡 雞 gai1 chicken
Words.Definition: a fried chicken dish originating in Singaporean Cantonese cuisine. It usually consists of chicken wings, marinated overnight in Cantonese prawn paste (har cheong) and a seasoned batter before being deep-fried, resulting in a fried chicken that is far more intensely flavourful and bursting with umami than is found in any other cuisine. It is a very popular dish at most zi chars in Singapore, Malaysia, and beyond.
Words.Example: She told me that to make really good Har Cheong Gai, you have to get a specific brand of shrimp sauce from Hong Kong.

Words.English Translation: → Cantonese: 虾饺 蝦餃 jyutping: haa1 gaau2 from cantonese (jyutping) 虾饺 蝦餃 haa1 gaau2 Cantonese prawn dumpling
Words.Definition: a traditional Cantonese prawn dumpling, served as a dim sum dish. It consists of prawn meat wrapped in a dumpling skin, which is pleated in a characteristic sail-like shape. When steamed, the skin turns translucent. It is often served with a dumpling soya sauce or chilli oil for dipping.
Words.Example: I’ll even dare to stick my neck out and claim that har gow might be the #1 dim sum item of all time. At least, I wouldn’t be surprised if they were.

Words.English Translation: → Cantonese: 虾碌 蝦碌 jyutping: haa1 luk1 + 烙 jyutping: lok3 from cantonese (jyutping) 虾碌 蝦碌 haa1 luk1 dish of fried shell-on prawns in a tomato and soy sauce; prawns with the shell on ← cantonese (jyutping) 虾碌 蝦碌 haa1 luk1 mistake; bungle; blunder ← english hard luck misfortune; difficulty; adversity & cantonese (jyutping) 虾 蝦 haa1 prawn; shrimp + cantonese (jyutping) 碌 碌 luk1 round object; roll ← cantonese (jyutping) 辘 轆 luk1 round object; roll; wheel + cantonese (jyutping) 烙 lok3 pan-fry
Words.Definition: a Cantonese dish of large, pan-fried or seared, shell-on prawns pan-fried in a tomato- and soy-based sauce
Words.Example: The key to Har Loke prawns is to really give the shells a really good char so that the sauce is infused with a smoky flavour.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: haram from malay haram forbidden or unlawful according to Muslim religious beliefs ← arabic حَرَام ḥarām forbidden; illegal; taboo
Words.Definition: forbidden, unlawful, or sinful according to Muslim religious beliefs, such as regarding consumption of food

Words.English Translation: → Malay: Hari Raya from malay Hari Raya holiday or festival; Eid ← malay hari day + malay raya big; great
Words.Definition: Hari Raya Puasa, also known as Hari Raya Aidilfitri, the Muslim festival day marking the end of the fasting month of Ramadan. It is a public holiday in Singapore.
Words.Example: You'll see pockets of families rocking the traditional Malay outfits in the same colour again this Hari Raya. It’s a cultural tradition observed by families to symbolise unity.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: Hari Raya + Aidiladha from malay Hari Raya holiday or festival; Eid ← malay hari day + malay raya big; great + malay Aidiladha Muslim festival celebrating Ibrahim's willingness to sacrifice his son Ismail ← arabic عِيد الْأَضْحَى ʕīd al-ʔaḍḥā Muslim festival celebrating Ibrahim's willingness to sacrifice his son Ismail ← arabic عِيد ʕīd festival; holiday + arabic الْأَضْحَى al-ʔaḍḥā [the] sacrifice; victim
Words.Definition: the Muslim festival day celebrating the haj, as well as the story of Ibrahim and Ismail in the Quran. It is a public holiday in Singapore.
Words.Example: On this morning, festivities beign with a prayer service held in an open place, which is generally well-attended. Hari Raya Aidilahda is a time of sacrifice, ...

Words.English Translation: → Malay: Hari Raya + Aidilfitri from malay Hari Raya holiday or festival; Eid ← malay hari day + malay raya big; great + malay Aidilfitri Muslim festival celebrating Ibrahim's willingness to sacrifice his son Ismail ← arabic عِيد اَلْفِطْر ʕīd al-fiṭr Muslim festival celebrating the end of the fasting month of Ramadan ← arabic عِيد ʕīd festival; holiday + arabic اَلْفِطْر al-fiṭr [the] breaking of a fast
Words.Definition: the Muslim festival day celebrating the end of the fasting month of Ramadan. It is a public holiday in Singapore.
Words.Example: On this morning, festivities beign with a prayer service held in an open place, which is generally well-attended. Hari Raya Aidilahda is a time of sacrifice, ...

Words.English Translation: → Malay: Hari Raya + haji from malay Hari Raya holiday or festival; Eid ← malay hari day + malay raya big; great + malay haji pilgrimage to Mecca, or sb. who has completed the pilgrimage ← arabic حَجِّيّ ḥajjiyy pilgrimage to Mecca & arabic حَجّ ḥajj one who has completed the pilgrimage to Mecca
Words.Definition: the Muslim festival day celebrating the haj, as well as the story of Ibrahim and Ismail in the Quran. It is a public holiday in Singapore.
Words.Example: Muslims sacrifice a suitable animal and distribute the meat ... In Malaysia, there are no celebrations as such for Hari Raya Haji, which is thus a much quieter festival than Hari Raya Puasa even though, in religious or spiritual terms, Hari Raya Haji is a far greater festival.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: Hari Raya + puasa from malay Hari Raya holiday or festival; Eid ← malay hari day + malay raya big; great + malay puasa fast; fasting ← sanskrit उपवास upavāsa fast; fasting
Words.Definition: the Muslim festival day celebrating the end of the fasting month of Ramadan. It is a public holiday in Singapore.
Words.Example: On the morning of Hari Raya Puasa, Muslims will attend mosque for the traditional Hari Raya prayers. Afterwards they will say to each other "Selamat Hari Raya! Maaf zahir batin!", which means "Happy Hari Raya! I seek forgiveness from you!"

Words.English Translation: → Baba malay: hati babi from baba malay hati babi traditional Peranakan pork meatball dish, (lit.) 'pig's liver' ← malay hati liver + malay babi pig; pork
Words.Definition: a traditional Peranakan pork meatball dish made from a mixture of ground pork and pig's liver (sometimes substituted with liver from other animals, such as chicken) with soya sauce, coriander, shallots, etc., which is shaped into bite-sized balls, stuffed into pieces of pig's caul (intestinal lining), and pan-fried.
Words.Example: Hati Babi Bungkus is one of the most traditional peranakan dish, served with mustard green salad. Only when we can get stocks of the pig caul lining(pig stomach lining) can we then prepare this delicacy. [sic]

Words.English Translation: → English: have from english have possess; exist; own
Words.Definition: to exist; to be; to be able to be found; there is
Words.Example: Actually this word have in Chinese, but we just say it in English with a Chinese tone most of the time.

Words.English Translation: → English: havoc from english havoc mayhem; disorder; confusion; destruction ← old french havot pillaging; looting
Words.Definition: rambunctious; rowdy; undisciplined
Words.Example: The ginnas in the playground damn havoc, always make so much noise.

Words.English Translation: → English: hawker from english hawker peripatetic merchant or peddler of goods ← middle low german hoker peddler; hawker; market-man
Words.Definition: someone who sells food, drinks, or more rarely other goods in general, especially from a hawker stall in a hawker centre
Words.Example: Many of us who live in Singapore take our hawker centres almost for granted. We use them regularly, love the good food, and even go out of our way for our favourite dish by a special hawker.

Words.English Translation: → English: hawker + centre from english hawker peripatetic merchant or peddler of goods ← middle low german hoker peddler; hawker; market-man + english centre location or complex designated for a particular purpose or activity ← middle french centre centre ← latin centrum centre ← ancient greek κέντρον kéntron stab; poke; sting; sharp pointed object; centre of a circle
Words.Definition: a large complex, usually sheltered but outdoors, housing several stalls that sell a variety of food and drinks, with tables and seating provided for patrons. In most estates, it is often located within, nearby, or is connected to a larger market area, containing e.g. sundry shops, a wet market, bakeries, coffee shops, etc. A hawker centre usually forms the core of any given Singaporean town, both physically and culturally.
Words.Example: If you want the real food in Singapore, get yourself to a hawker center.

Words.English Translation: → English: hawker + stall from english hawker peripatetic merchant or peddler of goods ← middle low german hoker peddler; hawker; market-man + english stall small shop where goods are sold
Words.Definition: a small, open-fronted shop in a hawker centre from which a hawker sells food or drinks
Words.Example: Sometimes, I sit and watch the hawker stall operators and see how hard they work in sweaty conditions.

Words.English Translation: → English: Housing and Development Board from english Housing and Development Board Singaporean statutory board in charge of public housing
Words.Definition: (metonym) a HDB flat, a type of multi-storey public housing building built by the Housing and Development Board in Singapore

Words.English Translation: → General chinese: 听讲 聽講 poj: thiaⁿ-kóng from general chinese (poj) 听讲 聽講 thiaⁿ-kóng hear it said of something; hear stories or rumours of ← general chinese (pinyin) 听 聽 thiaⁿ hear; listen + general chinese (pinyin) 讲 講 kóng say; speak; talk
Words.Definition: to hear it said of something; to hear stories or rumours of
Words.Example: Hear say they gonna have a sale in a few months. Better don't rush to buy now unless you really need.

Words.English Translation: → English: heart attack from english heart attack acute myocardial infarction; big scare ← english heart organ which pumps blood through the body + english attack onset or episode of an illness or medical condition
Words.Definition: a game where two or more players sit in a circle playing scissors paper stone, except saying 'Heart-A-ttack!' before throwing their hand rather than 'scissors paper stone!'. Once a player (or players) has lost a round of scissors paper stone, they put a free hand on the table; subsequent losers of rounds then stack their hands on top of the already placed stack of hands.Play continues so long as no one player is the only player with two hands free at the same time the others have both hands in the stack. If the player whose hand is at the bottom of the stack wins a round of scissors-paper-stone, or there is only one other player left with a free hand but that player still has a hand in the stack, the bottommost player gets to remove their hand from the bottom (making the stack more technically a queue of hands) and keep playing.Once a player manages to free both hands while the others all have both hands in the stack, they can then begin counting down by saying 'Heart... A... ttack!', slapping a hand down upon the pile of hands on the last syllable. All other players must scramble to snatch their hands away from the oncoming slap, lest they be stung by the painful blow — though they are not allowed to begin doing so before the last syllable has been uttered.
Words.Example: Heart Attack was definitely a thrilling and exciting game, but were the red, swollen hands and anxiety it gave us really worth it?

Words.English Translation: → English: heart + pain ↻ General chinese: 心痛 pinyin: xīn tòng from english heart organ which pumps blood through the body + english pain hurt; aching; suffering ← old french peine pain; suffering ← latin poena punishment; torment ← ancient greek ποινή poinḗ blood money; penalty ↻ general chinese (pinyin) 心痛 xīn tòng sad; sad to the point of heartache ← general chinese (pinyin) 心 xīn heart + general chinese (pinyin) 痛 tòng pain; hurt; painful
Words.Definition: (hyperbole) expression of sadness or disappointment in response to an unfortunate or pitiable situation
Words.Example: Wah, see my bank account balance go down really heart pain one.

Words.English Translation: → English: heartlands + -er from english heartlands (Sg.) residential districts or towns, esp. those populated by the low- to middle-class and away from touristy regions ← english heartland interior parts of a country or region ← english heart (fig.) core; essence; centre + english land region; country; place + english -er suffix used to form a demonym
Words.Definition: a Singaporean citizen or resident that lives or works in the heartlands, who is stereotypically low- to middle-class, less sophisticated, politically and socially conservative, and culturally typically Singaporean; an ordinary Singaporean person

Words.English Translation: → English: heartland from english heartland interior parts of a country or region ← english heart (fig.) core; essence; centre + english land region; country; place
Words.Definition: the residential districts or towns of Singapore as a collective whole, especially those overwhelmingly populated by ordinary, low- to middle-class Singaporean citizens, and away from the city centre and touristy regions

Words.English Translation: → English: heart + hardware from english heart organ which pumps blood through the body + english hardware equipment; tools; physical parts of a computer
Words.Definition: social, intellectual, emotional, spiritual, and cultural needs and sensitivities (especially as opposed to 'hardware' such as infrastructure and other physical things); feelings of affection, charity, love for one's country, loyalty, etc.
Words.Example: While her sister social service agencies focus their efforts on the ground, MSF focuses on building the “heartware” for the social service ... putting forth policies, community infrastructure, programmes and services, which have a focus on families, social services and social safety nets.

Words.English Translation: → English: heat + -y + General chinese: 热 熱 pinyin: rè + Hokkien: 燥 poj: sò from english heat hotness; thermal energy + english -y suffix used to form an adjective from a noun + general chinese (pinyin) 热 熱 rè (TCM) serving to warm, stimulate, or energize the body + hokkien (poj) 燥 sò (TCM) serving to warm, stimulate, or energize the body
Words.Definition: (TCM) serving to warm, stimulate, or energize the body

Words.English Translation: → English: heck from english heck (euphemistic, slightly vulgar) minced oath of hell ← english hell (slightly vulgar) intensifier; general swear word; place of eternal suffering and torment
Words.Definition: (slightly vulgar) negating intensifier, implying an absolute lack of something, wantonness, and a lack of concern

Words.English Translation: → English: heck + care from english heck (euphemistic, slightly vulgar) minced oath of hell ← english hell (slightly vulgar) intensifier; general swear word; place of eternal suffering and torment + english care bother about; be concerned with; mind; worry about
Words.Definition: (slightly vulgar) to not care in the slightest about; to not give a damn
Words.Example: Heck care the script, we can just anyhowly wing it on the day lah.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 鱼鳔 魚鰾 poj: hî/hîr-piō from hokkien (poj) 鱼鳔 魚鰾 hî/hîr-piō (fish) swim bladder
Words.Definition: the swim bladder of a fish, also known as fish maw when used in a culinary context, where it is often sold dried and used for its spongy texture
Words.Example: Unlike other simpler soups like Pong Tauhu or Bakwan Kepiting which are deemed more “daily meal”- like, Hee Pio Soup is much more laborious to prepare as everything is usually made from scratch.

Words.English Translation: → English: education from english education schooling; teaching; imparting of knowledge, values, skills, etc. ← middle french éducation education; upbringing ← latin ēducātiō bringing up; rearing
Words.Definition: education

Words.English Translation: → General chinese: 冥币 冥幣 pinyin: míng bì from general chinese (pinyin) 冥币 冥幣 míng bì joss paper money; Hell banknotes ← general chinese (pinyin) 冥 冥 míng dark; deep; the underworld; the nether realm + general chinese (pinyin) 币 幣 bì money; currency
Words.Definition: joss paper made to resemble banknotes issued by some 'bank of Hell', burnt during ancestor worship or festivals like the Hungry Ghost Festival, Chinese New Year, and Qing Ming, with the idea that the money can be used by spirits or the dead in the afterlife, making them wealthy and appeased.
Words.Example: Just below the basin where Ma would have stood, we burnt some "hell money". They said that this would be the first time that the soul would wake up, still unaware of her death. The burning of hell money would show her that she was indeed there. We cleared away the ashes of the hell money and, oddly, we could see Ma's footprints on the floor.

Words.English Translation: → English: hello + Malay: polis & English: police from english hello general greeting or call for attention + malay polis government department in charge of maintaining public order and law enforcement ← english police government department in charge of maintaining public order and law enforcement & english police government department in charge of maintaining public order and law enforcement ← middle french police governing; management ← latin polītīa government; management; state ← ancient greek πολῑτείᾱ polīteíā citizenship; government of a state
Words.Definition: (jocular) expression of faux alarm, used in response to witnessing a petty transgression, someone saying or doing something politically incorrect or against social norms, unintentionally giving the impression that they are well-versed in an illegal act, etc.
Words.Example: Hello polis, please catch my wife!! Who eats prata like that?!!

Words.English Translation: → English: help from english help cry for assistance; assist
Words.Definition: exclamation of exasperation, frustration, incredulity, etc., especially at a situation or at somebody else's incompetence, insufferability, behaviour, cluelessness, etc.
Words.Example: Help lah! You 15 years old already still dunno how to send email?

Words.English Translation: → Min nan: 幸 poj: hēng from min nan (poj) 幸 hēng lucky; fortunate; luckily; rejoice
Words.Definition: 'how fortunate'; 'thank goodness'; expression of relief at something lucky happening, or something unlucky being avoided
Words.Example: Heng ah! Lucky I zao early from the office today. Heard got some big cock-up situation happen soon after I left... not my tai chi anymore.

Words.Word: heng ong huat 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 兴旺发 興旺發 poj: heng ōng hoat from hokkien (poj) 兴旺发 興旺發 heng ōng hoat auspicious blessing ← hokkien (poj) 兴 興 heng prosper; succeed; flourish + hokkien (poj) 旺 旺 ōng prosperous; flourishing + hokkien (poj) 发 發 hoat prosper; become wealthy; expand; rise
Words.Definition: used to wish or express auspicious tidings of wealth, fortune, prosperity, etc.
Words.Example: Heng! Ong! Huat ah! Who said common culture can't be classy? These atas cupcakes follow a black-white-gold palette and look super intense and impressive — an auspicious fit for royalty. For large winnings and awesome celebrations.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 兴衰 興衰 poj: heng-soe from hokkien (poj) 兴衰 興衰 heng-soe ups and downs; rise and fall; prosperity and decline ← hokkien (poj) 兴 興 heng arise; prosper; succeed; excitement + hokkien (poj) 衰 衰 soe bad luck; unlucky; awful
Words.Definition: having its ups and downs; sometimes good and sometimes bad
Words.Example: The mee soto here is quite heng suay; some days got standard, other days damn rabak.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: hentak + kaki from malay hentak stomp; stamp (a foot) + malay kaki foot; leg
Words.Definition: (military command, imperative) to march on the spot
Words.Example: We were forced to hentak kaki on the parade square until the perpetrator who tried to sneak out of camp the previous night confessed.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: hentam from malay hentam hit; beat; do sth. flagrantly with no regard for consequences
Words.Definition: hit; beat up
Words.Example: Oei... Better get me my tau huay chui, or else I hentam you, understand?!

Words.English Translation: → Malay: hentam + bola from malay hentam hit; beat; collide with + malay bola ball ← portuguese bola ball; sphere ← old occitan bola ball; sphere ← latin bulla bubble; bubble-shaped object
Words.Definition: a children's game where a chosen player has to chase and try to throw a ball to hit the other players, while they attempt to run away; a player who gets hit then becomes the next thrower, and so on. It is similar in concept to catching, except using a ranged projectile instead of one's hand to 'tag' another player.
Words.Example: Playing hantam bola in the rain would send one rolling into muddy puddles but the fun would end immediately when your mother saw your dirty state; she would hantam (whack) you instead!

Words.English Translation: → Possible, but not certain English: hex from english Possible, but not certain hex clipping of 'hexadecimal' ✂ english hexadecimal base 16 ← english hexadeca- sixteen ← ancient greek ἑξα- hexa- six + ancient greek δέκᾰ déka ten + latin decimālis decimal
Words.Definition: the symbol #, also known variously as the number sign, hash, octothorpe, etc.

Words.English Translation: → Min nan: 耳聋 耳聾 poj: hī-lâng from min nan (poj) 耳聋 耳聾 hī-lâng deaf; deaf person
Words.Definition: deaf; hard of hearing
Words.Example: Aiyo.. say already.. the HP costume is NOT for me!!! U all cheh meh or hee lang??

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien / teochew: 莶 薟 poj: hiam from hokkien / teochew (poj) 莶 薟 hiam spicy
Words.Definition: spicy; pungent
Words.Example: Last time I 2k salary,gf hiam me earn 2k so go for 5k de..now I 10k salary,gf hiam me earn 10k nia so go for 20k guy..means what ah?

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 娆 嬈 poj: hiâu from hokkien (poj) 娆 嬈 hiâu promiscuous; lewd; slutty; indecent; beautiful
Words.Definition: (of a woman) sexy; attractive; beautiful
Words.Example: Her mother would say "Aiyah. Girls, these days. So hiau ... Men don't even have to touch them. One look at them and they are already behaving like prostitutes ..."

Words.English Translation: → English: high + SES from english high elevated; great + english SES initialism of 'socioeconomic status' ← english socioeconomic status social and economic standing of an individual, group, class, etc. ← english socioeconomic of or relating to both social and economic factors ← english socio- relating to society and social factors ← middle french social allied; social ← latin sociālis of or relating to allies, companionship etc; social + english economic of or relating to an economy; the study of money ← middle french œconomique household management; of or relating to household management ← latin oeconomicus economic; household management ← ancient greek οἰκονομικός oikonomikós of or relating to household management + english status standing; position ← latin status position; rank; standing
Words.Definition: of or having an elevated or prestigious social and economic standing, such as in terms of educational background and access to education, wealth, family and occupational prestige, and other economic and subjective social factors which may lead to different experiences and social perceptions.[1]

Words.English Translation: → Malay: hilang from malay hilang lose; lost; vanished; missing; dead
Words.Definition: lost; missing; vanished
Words.Example: Wait we kena hilang our heritage then after a few years then gahmen say Singapore got no culture one.

Words.English Translation: → Hinghua: 兴化 興化 buc: hing-hua̍ from hinghua (buc) 兴化 興化 hing-hua̍ county or region in Putian, Fujian, China and its people, language, culture, etc.
Words.Definition: a county and region in Putian, Fujian, China
Words.Example: The Henghua people dominated industries and services related to bicycles, automobiles, tram parts, and land transportation ... the rickshaw industry provided the incoming Henghua immigrants with job opportunities under the principle of “picking up what others discard”.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 凶 poj: hiong from hokkien (poj) 凶 hiong fierce; aggressive; ferocious
Words.Definition: fierce; aggressive; ferocious
Words.Example: In my experience, the most hiong of chiongsters are secretly the GCGs.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 香饼 香餅 poj: hiong-piáⁿ from hokkien (poj) 香饼 香餅 hiong-piáⁿ hiong piah; a small, round, and hollow pastry with a dense, flaky, and crispy crust, filled with a sweet and sticky filling made of scallion oil and malt ← hokkien (poj) 香 香 hiong fragrant; savoury + hokkien (poj) 饼 餅 piáⁿ pastry; cookie; biscuit
Words.Definition: a small, round, and hollow pastry with a dense, flaky, and crispy crust, filled with a sweet and sticky filling made of scallion oil and malt. The top of the pastry is usually decorated with a red stamp or sesame seeds.Similar to pong piãh, which mostly differs in that it is around twice the size of hiong piãh and has a less crispy crust.

Words.English Translation: → English: hit + aeroplane ↻ Cantonese: 打飞机 打飛機 jyutping: daa2 fei1 gei1 from english hit strike; beat + english aeroplane fixed-wing, heavier-than-air aircraft ← french aéroplane fixed-wing, heavier-than-air aircraft ← ancient greek ἀερόπλανος aeróplanos air-wanderer ↻ cantonese (jyutping) 打飞机 打飛機 daa2 fei1 gei1 (lit.) fight/beat aeroplane; (slang, of a male) jerk off; wank ← cantonese (jyutping) 打 打 daa2 hit; fight; beat + cantonese (jyutping) 飞机 飛機 fei1 gei1 aeroplane
Words.Definition: (of a male) to masturbate; to jerk off; to wank

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 无𫝺/甩 無𫝺/甩 poj: bô-hiù from hokkien (poj) 无𫝺/甩 無𫝺/甩 bô-hiù indifferent; pay no heed; ignore ← hokkien (poj) 无 無 bô no; not; don't + hokkien (poj) 𫝺/甩 𫝺/甩 hiù (vulgar) pay attention or heed to; take notice of

Words.English Translation: → Singlish / english: Hokkien mee from singlish / english Hokkien mee stir-fried noodle dish ← hokkien (poj) 福建面 福建麵 Hok-kiàn-mī stir-fried noodle dish ← hokkien (poj) 福建 福建 Hok-kiàn Fujian, a province in China; of or relating to the Hokkien ethnolinguistic community + hokkien (poj) 面 麵 mī wheat noodles
Words.Definition: abbreviation of Hokkien mee.
Words.Example: I have an impression like nowadays it's quite hard to find bee hoon in HKM, most of them use thick 粗米粉 liao.

Words.English Translation: → Min nan: 好命 poj: hó-miā from min nan (poj) 好命 hó-miā having a fortunate and comfortable life ← min nan (poj) 好 hó good; great; well + min nan (poj) 命 miā life; fate; luck
Words.Definition: having a fortunate and comfortable life
Words.Example: I'm glad it's a cha bor. And I hope she’ll be a blur sotong – that’s the most ho mia a cha bor can be in this world, a gong gong, jambu little sotong.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 好势 好勢 poj: hó-sè from hokkien (poj) 好势 好勢 hó-sè well; successfully; good (intj.) 'alright!'; expn. of satisfaction, agreement, etc. ← hokkien (poj) 好 好 hó good; great; well + hokkien (poj) 势 勢 sè power; poise; situation
Words.Definition: 'alright!'; 'yeah!'; used to express satisfaction, agreement, permission, etc.
Words.Example: Ho seh! Win again!

Words.Word: ho seh bo 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 好势无 好勢無 poj: hó-sè--bô from hokkien (poj) 好势无 好勢無 hó-sè--bô 'how are you?'; 'are you alright?'; 'how is it?' ← hokkien (poj) 好势 好勢 hó-sè well; successfully; good (intj.) 'alright!'; expn. of satisfaction, agreement, etc. + hokkien (poj) 无 無 bô or not; no; not have
Words.Definition: 'how are you?'; 'are you alright?'; used as a greeting or question about someone's condition, situation, etc.
Words.Example: Auntie, ho seh bo? Business today good anot?

Words.English Translation: → Min nan: 好心 poj: hó-sim from min nan (poj) 好心 hó-sim good-hearted; kind ← min nan (poj) 好 hó good + min nan (poj) 心 sim heart
Words.Definition: good-hearted; kind
Words.Example: wah the abang jin ho sim stop the fight … hero la

Words.English Translation: → Hockchew: 福州 buc: Hók-ciŭ from hockchew (buc) 福州 Hók-ciŭ capital city of Fujian, China
Words.Definition: the capital city of Fujian, China
Words.Example: The Hockchews share the Fujian love for soups. But, like the Guangdong people, the Hockchews prefer stir-frying to stewing and steaming.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 福建 poj: Hok-kiàn from hokkien (poj) 福建 Hok-kiàn Fujian, a province in China ← hokkien (poj) 福州 Hok-chiu prefecture in ancient China + hokkien (poj) 建州 Kiàn-chiu prefecture in ancient China
Words.Definition: a widely-spoken Southern Min (Min Nan) language (or family of related languages / dialects) spoken by people from parts of Fujian including Quanzhou, Zhangzhou, Amoy, etc. and its diaspora, especially in maritime South-East Asia (where it used to be the lingua franca amongst Chinese communities) and Taiwan (where it is an official language).
Words.Example: Hokkien songs are for the man-in-the-street. Patrons feel that Hokkien lyrics relate more to their lives, and love, happiness and sadness are described explicitly.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 福建面 福建麵 poj: Hok-kiàn-mī from hokkien (poj) 福建面 福建麵 Hok-kiàn-mī stir-fried noodle dish ← hokkien (poj) 福建 福建 Hok-kiàn Fujian, a province in China; of or relating to the Hokkien ethnolinguistic community + hokkien (poj) 面 麵 mī wheat noodles
Words.Definition: a dry noodle dish of Singaporean Hokkien origin, usually using a mixture of yellow noodles and rice noodles stir-fried with prawns, squid, pork slices, fish cake, lard, eggs, spring onions, and other ingredients, together with a savoury sauce made of prawn stock. It is usually served with a sliced calamansi or other lime and a dollop of sambal chilli.
Words.Example: The long queues at my favourite fried hokkien mee stall in Serangoon Gardens prompted me to cook my own one day.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 福建面 福建麵 poj: Hok-kiàn-mī + English: noodles from hokkien (poj) 福建面 福建麵 Hok-kiàn-mī Fujian, a province in China ← hokkien (poj) 福建 福建 Hok-kiàn Fujian, a province in China; of or relating to the Hokkien ethnolinguistic community + hokkien (poj) 面 麵 mī wheat noodles + english noodles long, thin strings of cooked dough ← german Nudel pasta; noodle
Words.Definition: yellow alkaline egg noodles slightly thicker than spaghetti, often used in Hokkien cuisine but also now common in other local and regional cuisines. They are usually sold fresh, rather than dried. The use of a carbonate salt (typically sodium or potassium carbonate) gives the noodles a unique taste and springy texture, as well as causing their distinctive bright yellow colour.
Words.Example: The modern version of the dish is made using a mixture of Hokkien noodles and thick rice vermicelli (chor bee hoon) or laksa noodles, cooked and simmered together in the stock.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 福建 poj: Hok-kiàn + 兵 poj: peng from hokkien (poj) 福建 Hok-kiàn Fujian, a province in China ← hokkien (poj) 福州 Hok-chiu prefecture in ancient China + hokkien (poj) 建州 Kiàn-chiu prefecture in ancient China + hokkien (poj) 兵 peng soldier; army
Words.Definition: (military, slightly derogatory) a soldier whose primary language is Hokkien, and behaves according to and follows the cultural stereotypes associated with a Hokkien person
Words.Example: His newfound suave was occasionally betrayed by a veneer of "hokkien peng" brusqueness.

Words.English Translation: → Possible, but not certain Hokkien: 仾 仾 poj: hōng + 奸 姦 poj: kàn from hokkien (poj) Possible, but not certain 仾 仾 hōng (passive) to get (by someone) ← hokkien (poj) 予侬 予儂 hō͘-lâng by someone + hokkien (poj) 奸 姦 kàn fuck
Words.Definition: (vulgar) 'I'm/we're screwed'; exclamation of despair or frustration at an unfortunate or terrible situation
Words.Example: My blank attachment where sia?? Hong kan liao!
Related: you die, I die, everybody die
kan ni na bu chao chee bai
kan ni na chao chee bai

Words.English Translation: → English: Hong Kong + -ie from english Hong Kong a city and SAR in China ← cantonese (jyutping) 香港 hoeng1 gong2 Hong Kong; Hong Kong Island ← cantonese (jyutping) 香 hoeng1 fragrant; aromatic + cantonese (jyutping) 港 gong2 port; harbour + english -ie dimin. suffix; (sometimes derog.) used to form a noun for a person associated with sth.
Words.Definition: (derogatory, offensive) a Hong Konger; someone from Hong Kong or of Hongkongese descent
Words.Example: Two things never to say to a Hongkonger: (1) Call him a Hongkie. (2) Insult his new $32-billion airport.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 风 風 poj: hong + English: -ster from hokkien (poj) 风 風 hong demeanor; promiscuous; lewd; dissolute; love; sexual attraction + english -ster sb. who does or is associated with sth.

Words.Word: hongster never die, tiong sim is a lie 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Singlish: hongster + never + English: die + Hokkien: 忠心 poj: tiong-sim + English: is a lie from singlish hongster flirt; coquette; womanizer; playboy; promiscuous person ← hokkien (poj) 风 風 hong demeanor; promiscuous; lewd; dissolute; love; sexual attraction ← english -ster sb. who does or is associated with sth. + singlish never will not; did not; have not ← english never not ever + english die stop living; become dead; fade off or away + hokkien (poj) 忠心 tiong-sim loyalty; faithfulness; devotion + english is a lie be untrue; be misleading; be deceiving
Words.Definition: faithfulness and loyalty is overrated, and will result in heartbreak and betrayal, while cheaters and those who flirt and sleep around will never get their hearts broken

Words.English Translation: → Min nan: 粉粿 poj: hún-kóe from min nan (poj) 粉粿 hún-kóe steamed green bean flour cake ← min nan (poj) 粉 hún flour; powder + min nan (poj) 粿 kóe steamed cake made from rice flour or glutinous rice flour
Words.Definition: a steamed kueh with a jelly-like texture made from green bean starch or flour, water, and sugar, often flavoured with e.g. pandan or coconut milk
Words.Example: Hoon Kueh is one of my favourite Nonya Kueh and I would occasionally buy it from Bengawan Solo to enjoy. These are either filled with bananas or corn - both of which I love.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 乎 poj: hohⁿ / hô͘ⁿ / hōⁿ + Cantonese: 嗬 jyutping: ho2 from hokkien (poj) 乎 hohⁿ / hô͘ⁿ / hōⁿ particle used to emphasize, ask for confirmation, indicate imperative, etc. + cantonese (jyutping) 嗬 ho2 particle used to form interrog. or ask for confirmation
Words.Definition: used to emphasize a preceding statement, especially in terms of its validity, as well as await the listener's acknowledgement or comprehension of it; '..., OK?'
Words.Example: That one not I say, is Nabil say one.→ That one not I say hor, is Nabil say one.

Words.English Translation: → Cantonese: 河粉 jyutping: ho4 fan2 from cantonese (jyutping) 河粉 ho4 fan2 flat rice noodle used in Cantonese cuisine; Cantonese equivalent of kway teow ← cantonese (jyutping) 沙河粉 saa1 ho4 fan2 flat rice noodle used in Cantonese cuisine; Cantonese equivalent of kway teow ← cantonese (jyutping) 沙河 saa1 ho4 town in Guangdong, China believed to be where hor fun originated from, (lit.) 'sandy river' + cantonese (jyutping) 粉 fan2 flour; powder; noodles
Words.Definition: a flat rice noodle used in Cantonese cuisine; the Cantonese equivalent of kway teow
Words.Example: ... many local noodle dishes in these countries are made using hor fun noodles. The Indonesian Kwetiau Siram, Thai Pad See Ew and our own Char Kway Teow and Beef and Seafood Hor Fun are just a few examples.

Words.Word: hor ka sai 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 虎咬狮 虎咬獅 poj: hó͘-kā-sai from hokkien (poj) 虎咬狮 虎咬獅 hó͘-kā-sai drink made from Milo and coffee ← hokkien (poj) 虎 虎 hó͘ tiger + hokkien (poj) 咬 咬 kā bite + hokkien (poj) 狮 獅 sai lion
Words.Definition: a drink made from mixing Milo and coffee, originating from Taiping, Perak, Malaysia and popularized in the region sometime between the 1950s to 60s. It is similar to Neslo, but slightly different in that it uses local traditional coffee (kopi) rather than Nescafe-branded coffee.

Words.English Translation: → English: horrible + terrible + vegetable from english horrible terrible; extremely bad; awful; terrifying ← old french horrible terrifying ← latin horribilis terrifying; terrible; dreadful ← latin horreō tremble; fear; dread + latin -ibilis -able; able to be + english terrible horrible; extremely bad; awful; dreadful ← old french terrible terrible; terrifying ← latin terribilis terrifying; terrible; dreadful ← latin terreō fear; frighten; terrify + latin -ibilis -able; able to be + english vegetable edible plant used as a culinary item ← old french vegetable plant; vegetable ← latin vegetābilis able to grow; enlivening
