Words.Example: Can’t promise any more stories after this, but I was looking through my old conversations with people I met on dating apps and was reminded of this horrible terrible vegetable sorry excuse of a man.

Words.English Translation: → English: horrible + incorrigible from english horrible terrible; extremely bad; awful; terrifying ← old french horrible terrifying ← latin horribilis terrifying; terrible; dreadful ← latin horreō tremble; fear; dread + latin -ibilis -able; able to be + english incorrigible unable to be corrected or reformed; ← middle french incorrigible unpunished; not correctable ← latin incorrigibilis unable to be corrected ← latin in- un-; not + latin corrigere correct; reform; improve ← latin con- with; used to indicate completeness + latin regō control; govern; straighten + latin -ibilis -able; able to be
Words.Definition: terrible; extremely bad; awful; beyond correction; hopeless
Words.Example: Lexie Bean has tested and approved the cooling mats by @ohpopdog ! Keep your dogs cool during this Horrigible Heatwave.

Words.Word: horse back cannon 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → English: horse + back + cannon ↻ General chinese: 马后炮/砲 馬後炮/砲 pinyin: mǎ hòu pào from english horse Equus ferus, a domesticated hoofed animal used for work, riding, transport, racing, etc. + english back to the rear; behind + english cannon large gun used to fire ballistic projectiles ← old french canon cannon; tube ← old italian cannone cannon; tube ← latin canna reed; cane ← ancient greek κᾰ́ννᾱ kánnā reed; cane ← akkadian 𒂵𒉡𒌑𒌝 qanûm reed; cane ↻ general chinese (pinyin) 马后炮/砲 馬後炮/砲 mǎ hòu pào checkmating pattern in xiangqi; (idiom) 20/20 hindsight ← general chinese (pinyin) 马 馬 mǎ horse; (xiangqi) knight; horse + general chinese (pinyin) 后 後 hòu back; behind + general chinese (pinyin) 炮/砲 炮/砲 pào cannon; (xiangqi) cannon
Words.Definition: (xiangqi) a checkmating pattern in Chinese chess (xiangqi) where the horse/knight is two squares in a straight line from the opponent's general, with the cannon lined up behind it; in this configuration, the general has no legal moves and is in check, thus resulting in checkmate
Words.Example: horse back cannon most powder moves

Words.English Translation: → English: handover, takeover from english handover, takeover process of transfer of responsibilities, items, knowledge, data, etc. from one party to another ← english handover transfer of possession or control of sth. from one party to another ← english hand over transfer possession or control of sth. to another party ← english hand give; pass + english over from one to another + english takeover reception of responsibilities, items, knowledge, data, etc. from another party ← english take over receive possession or control of sth. from another party ← english take get; receive + english over from one to another
Words.Definition: a transfer of something, such as responsibilities, items, knowledge, data, etc. from one party to another
Words.Example: Right now, Minister all doing HOTO. Where got time to tackle this problem?

Words.English Translation: → English: how from english how what way, degree, manner, extent, etc.
Words.Definition: used at the end of a sentence as a question or interrogative marker asking about feasibility or acceptability of a presented option; 'how is that for you'; 'would that work'
Words.Example: I can meet you after I end work — maybe 6:30 outside Clem Mall. For you is how?

Words.English Translation: → English: how + Singlish: can ↻ Hokkien: mana poj: ma-na + 会使 會使 poj: ē-sái from english how in what way + singlish can affirmative particle; able to; permitted to ← english can able to; may; be possible; permitted ↻ hokkien (poj) mana ma-na where; (rhet.) how ← malay mana where + hokkien (poj) 会使 會使 ē-sái can; may; be allowed to
Words.Definition: why is it allowed; why is it possible; in what sense would this do or suffice; in what way is this fair
Words.Example: I tapau with my own container I still must pay the 50 cents? How can?!

Words.English Translation: → English: how + can + this + be + allowed from english how in what way + english can able to; may; be possible; permitted + english this used to indicate sth. closer to the speaker than 'that' + english be auxiliary verb + english allowed permitted; authorized ← anglo-norman allouer allot; allow ← medieval latin allaudāre laud; praise + medieval latin allocō allot; assign
Words.Definition: 'why is it allowed'; 'in what way is this fair'; used to complain about something that one takes umbrage at, feels is unfair, or ought to be illegal
Words.Example: What is most ironic is how netizens react strongest to posts or tweets they abhor most. They may be trolls or may sincerely mean their comments, but never a day passes when we don't appreciate this gift that keeps on giving. It makes us ask in turn: How can dis b allow?

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 发 發 poj: hoat from hokkien (poj) 发 發 hoat prosper; produce; become wealthy; expand; rise
Words.Definition: to prosper; to become wealthy; to gain a fortune
Words.Example: May your business huat this year! Gong xi fa cai!

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 发 發 poj: hoat + 啊 pinyin: a from hokkien (poj) 发 發 hoat prosper; produce; become wealthy; expand; rise + hokkien (pinyin) 啊 a general particle or interjection
Words.Definition: used to celebrate, wish, or express auspicious tidings of wealth, fortune, prosperity, etc.
Words.Example: I'm going to be a white bunny in 2011. My feng shui master mentioned that white will be my lucky colour this year. Huat, ah!

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 发菜 髮菜 poj: hoat-chhài from hokkien (poj) 发菜 髮菜 hoat-chhài the edible cyanobacterium Nostoc flagelliforme
Words.Definition: the Hokkien name for the edible cyanobacterium Nostoc flagelliforme, used as an ingredient in Chinese cuisine. It is popular due to its near-homophony with the popular auspicious phrase 发财/發財, hoat-châi ("to prosper; to become wealthy").

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 发粿 發粿 poj: hoat-kóe from hokkien (poj) 发粿 發粿 hoat-kóe a traditional steamed rice cake, (slang) the heck; what on earth ← hokkien (poj) 发 發 hoat expand; rise; prosper; produce; become wealthy + hokkien (poj) 粿 粿 kóe kueh
Words.Definition: a traditional Hokkien steamed rice or wheat flour cupcake, which is soft, fluffy, and sweet. It is traditionally leavened with baking soda or toddy instead of yeast. The cakes are usually brown (due to the addition of gula melaka as a sweetener) or bright orange (as an auspicious colour), and are often used as offerings at traditional Chinese religious altars. Very similar to ma lai gao and wã ko kueh, the latter of which is often just used as a synonym, though they are often differentiated as being somewhat smaller and more colourful than huat kueh.
Words.Example: Rice flour huat kueh was actually the kind of huat kueh I grew up eating. Mom usually bought the iconic pink rice flour huat kueh from the market and use them as an offering for praying.

Words.English Translation: → Min nan / cantonese: 蚶 poj: ham from min nan / cantonese (poj) 蚶 ham ark clam, any marine bivalve mollusc in the family Arcidae
Words.Definition: Tegillarca granosa, also known as the blood cockle or simply cockle, a species of edible marine clam with red flesh that is a common ingredient in Singaporean cuisine
Words.Example: Tuck into char hum (fried half-shell cockles with garlic, chilli and ground peanuts) ...

Words.English Translation: → Likely, but other possible etymologies exist Hokkien: 陷子 poj: hām-chí from hokkien (poj) Likely, but other possible etymologies exist 陷子 hām-chí cowardly; no balls ← hokkien (poj) 陷 hām missing; defective; deficient + hokkien (poj) 子 chí testicle ✂ hokkien (poj) 𡳞脬子 lān-pha-chí testicle
Words.Definition: (vulgar, of males) cowardly; lacking courage; scared
Words.Example: Seem like most people are also humji. If the two males smoking are school kids wearing school uniform, I am sure some hero wannabe will scold them. But the two males are tattoo beng. No one dare tell them off
Related: hum ji bo ji attap chee

Words.Word: hum ji bo ji attap chee 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Likely, but other possible etymologies exist Hokkien: 陷子 poj: hām-chí + 无子 無子 poj: bô-chí + Singlish: attap chee from hokkien (poj) Likely, but other possible etymologies exist 陷子 hām-chí cowardly; no balls ← hokkien (poj) 陷 hām missing; defective; deficient + hokkien (poj) 子 chí testicle ✂ hokkien (poj) 𡳞脬子 lān-pha-chí testicle + hokkien (poj) 无子 無子 bô-chí (vulgar, lit.) lack testicles; (vulgar, fig.) cowardly ← hokkien (poj) 无 無 bô no; not have + hokkien (poj) 子 子 chí testicle ✂ hokkien (poj) 𡳞脬子 𡳞脬子 lān-pha-chí testicle + singlish attap chee edible immature fruits of the nipa palm ← malay atap Nypa fruticans, a.k.a. nipa palm ← malay atap roof + hokkien (poj) 子 chí child; son; seed
Words.Definition: (vulgar, of males) cowardly; lacking courage; scared
Words.Example: He so spineless, hum chee boh chee attap chee he don't dare de la.

Words.English Translation: → Likely, but other possible etymologies exist Hokkien: 陷子 poj: hām-chí + English: dog from hokkien (poj) Likely, but other possible etymologies exist 陷子 hām-chí cowardly; no balls ← hokkien (poj) 陷 hām missing; defective; deficient + hokkien (poj) 子 chí testicle ✂ hokkien (poj) 𡳞脬子 lān-pha-chí testicle + english dog Canis lupus familiaris
Words.Definition: (vulgar) a coward; someone who lacks courage
Words.Example: Don't compare me with those humji dog who name drop others while being anonymous
Related: hum ji bo ji attap chee

Words.Word: Hungry Ghost Festival 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → English: hungry + ghost ↻ Min / hakka: 枵鬼 poj: iau-kúi & Cantonese / mandarin: 饿鬼 餓鬼 pinyin: è guǐ + English: festival from english hungry needing food + english ghost ghoul; spirit of the dead ↻ min / hakka (poj) 枵鬼 iau-kúi gluttonous; stingy; (Budd.) preta; hungry ghost ← min / hakka (poj) 枵 iau hungry; starving + min / hakka (poj) 鬼 kúi ghost; demon; evil spirit & cantonese / mandarin (pinyin) 饿鬼 餓鬼 è guǐ glutton; (Budd.) preta; hungry ghost ← cantonese / mandarin (pinyin) 饿 餓 è hungry; starving + cantonese / mandarin (pinyin) 鬼 鬼 guǐ ghost; demon; evil spirit + english festival celebration or special event ← old french festival festive ← latin fēstīvus festive; merry
Words.Definition: a religious and cultural festival observed during the seventh month of the lunar calendar, when it is believed that hungry ghosts escape the underworld and roam about the human realm looking for food. Adherents of Taoism, Buddhism, and Chinese folk religion traditionally make offerings to appease these spirits, leaving food, lighting candles and joss sticks, and burning Hell money and paper effigies of expensive items.The large amounts of smoke, unsightly littering, and pollution caused by these offerings is often a contentious point against the practise of this tradition.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 拂 poj: hut + 刜 poj: hut/phut from hokkien (poj) 拂 hut act recklessly; disregard everything; do without care for the consequences + hokkien (poj) 刜 hut/phut strike forcefully; hit; do recklessly without care for the consequences
Words.Definition: to act recklessly; to disregard everything; to do without care for the consequences
Words.Example: If not then lose already what! Just anyhow hoot also can!

Words.English Translation: → Malay: hutang/utang from malay hutang/utang debt
Words.Definition: debt
Words.Example: I once asked a friend how he was able to own a thousand-dollar instrument meant for astronauts and space-shuttlers. The simple answer: "Hutang lor!" Or, to guise it more sophisticatedly: "I'm on a two-year plan."

Words.Word: I tell you 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → English: I + tell + you ↻ Hokkien: 我共汝讲 我共汝講 poj: oá kā lí kóng from english I 1p. sing. subj. pronoun + english tell say; inform + english you 2p. sing. & pl. pronoun ↻ hokkien (poj) 我共汝讲 我共汝講 oá kā lí kóng [let] me tell you; 'listen here' ← hokkien (poj) 我 我 oá I; me; 1p. sing. pronoun + hokkien (poj) 共 共 kā to; with; at + hokkien (poj) 汝 汝 lí you; 2p. sing. pronoun + hokkien (poj) 讲 講 kóng speak; talk; say
Words.Definition: used at the start of a sentence to call attention to something one is about to say; used to indicate one is about to give their opinion, give advice, explain something, share their thoughts etc.; 'look here'; 'listen here'
Words.Example: I tell you ah, every day eat ice kacang not good for you.

Words.English Translation: → English: I + thought + what from english I 1p. sing. pron. + english thought simple past of ‘think’ + english what which thing
Words.Definition: used when one realizes that something one thought was important, serious, or significant turns out to be less of a big deal than one was led to believe
Words.Example: Chey I thought what. I thought big hoo ha because she sounds like Ris Low or that other sg woman who voiced some video game (now, that was AWFUL)or something. At least Kelly is natural and enunciates quite well.

Words.English Translation: → English: i.e. + that is to say from english i.e. that is to say; in other words ← latin id est that is + english that is to say in other words; namely; used to introduce an explanation, clarification, etc.
Words.Definition: (conjunctive) in other words; namely; used to introduce an explanation, clarification, etc.
Words.Example: And we are comparing apple with apple here. i.e. to say, similar GPA, same degree awarded, class of honors, years of experience, etc.

Words.English Translation: → English: immediate + action from english immediate at once; right away; instant ← french immediat immediate ← late latin immediātus immediate + english action performing or doing of sth. ← old french aucion action ← latin āctiō action
Words.Definition: (military) an issue encountered with a weapon in the course of its operation which interferes with its normal functioning, such as a jammed round, double feeding, no feeding, etc.

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: Internet Brigade from singlish Internet Brigade grp. of netizens who try to influence public opinion on sth. ← english Internet global communicational and informational computer network ✂ english internetwork network of and between multiple networks ← english inter- between; connecting ← latin inter between + english network system of interconnected devices ← english net mesh of connected lines or cords + english work sth. made or produced + english brigade coordinated group of people with a common purpose, view, etc. ← french brigade (mil.) large unit comprising several battalions ← italian brigata group; party, (mil.) brigade
Words.Definition: (pejorative) a group of netizens who vehemently support and praise a particular party, organization, or cause in online spaces such as forums and social media, and try to positively influence public sentiment towards it. According to various accounts, they may either be genuinely zealous and earnest supporters, or paid off to favourably influence the public’s views on said party.
Words.Example: IB is not just political....many commercial companies have their own IBs too to "create the hype" for their products.. I'm sure you met them once awhile within your FB page where friends tell you to like a certain group or page that you don't give a damn... I'm sure big companies like Apple would have their own IB...

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: IB + English: dog from singlish IB init. of 'Internet brigade' ← singlish Internet Brigade grp. of netizens who try to influence public opinion on sth. ← english Internet global communicational and informational computer network ✂ english internetwork network of and between multiple networks ← english inter- between; connecting ← latin inter between + english network system of interconnected devices ← english net mesh of connected lines or cords + english work sth. made or produced + english brigade coordinated group of people with a common purpose, view, etc. ← french brigade (mil.) large unit comprising several battalions ← italian brigata group; party, (mil.) brigade + english dog Canis lupus familiaris
Words.Definition: (pejorative) someone who vehemently supports and praises a particular party, organization, or cause in online spaces such as forums and social media, and tries to positively influence public sentiment towards it. According to various accounts, they may either be genuinely zealous and earnest supporters, or paid off to favourably influence the public’s views on said party.
Words.Example: Everyone's caught up in the election fever I guess. Compared to the mudslinging at TRS/yahoo/facebook/TOC etc, at least you won't be labelled an "IB dog" if you state your views.

Words.English Translation: → English: in charge from english in charge leading; commanding; responsible for
Words.Definition: a person responsible for leading, commanding, supervising, delegating etc.; a person-in-charge
Words.Example: Irfan was appointed as the cookhouse IC, which made him feel like he was a big shot with a burden of responsibility, but really his job was just to make sure people scanned their 11Bs when they queued up.

Words.English Translation: → English: ice + and + freeze from english ice solid form of water; H2O(s) + english and conj. used to connect two elements together + english freeze (of a liquid) turn solid
Words.Definition: a playground game that is a variation of police and thief, with one team playing as the 'ice' players and one team as the 'water' players. The ice players pursue the water players, tapping them to freeze them (after which they must stand in place); they may be unfrozen by getting tapped by another water player.
Words.Example: omg finally someone who calls it ice and freeze! growing up everyone corrected me saying it should be ice and water or freeze and melt which made me doubt my own memory LOL.

Words.English Translation: → English: ice + and + melt from english ice solid form of water; H2O(s) + english and conj. used to connect two elements together + english melt (of a solid) turn liquid
Words.Definition: a playground game that is a variation of police and thief, with one team playing as the 'ice' players and one team as the 'water' players. The ice players pursue the water players, tapping them to freeze them (after which they must stand in place); they may be unfrozen by getting tapped by another water player.

Words.English Translation: → English: ice + and + water from english ice solid form of water; H2O(s) + english and conj. used to connect two elements together + english water clear liquid (at room temperature and pressure) with the chemical formula H2O
Words.Definition: a playground game that is a variation of police and thief, with one team playing as the 'ice' players and one team as the 'water' players. The ice players pursue the water players, tapping them to freeze them (after which they must stand in place); they may be unfrozen by getting tapped by another water player.

Words.English Translation: → English: ice + ball from english ice solid form of water; H2O(s) + english ball roughly spherical object
Words.Definition: a traditional dessert consisting of shaved ice packed into a roughly fist-sized ball, drenched with colourful, sweet syrup. Historically, the ball was then held in the hands and eaten before it melted. Due to reasons including hygiene concerns, it has largely been displaced in Singapore by ice kacang, which probably arose around the same time.[1] Still, it can still be found elsewhere in the region, such as in Malaysia (albeit served in bowls for hygiene).
Words.Example: The vendor would shape the shavings into an ice ball using his bare hands, and make a depression in the ice ball with an index finger to make space for the fillings. … To save money, children would sometimes request the vendor to halve the ice ball for sharing. They would hold the ice ball in their hands and slurp it, leaving a sticky mess of melted ice and syrup and staining their clothes.

Words.English Translation: → English: ice cream + Hokkien: 阿伯 poj: a-peh from english ice cream sweet frozen dairy dessert + hokkien (poj) 阿伯 a-peh father's elder brother; old man
Words.Definition: an itinerant hawker, usually an older man, who traditionally sells potong ice cream out of a mobile stand attached to a motorcycle, cart, or some other wheeled vehicle
Words.Example: I love otah with bread too. Ditto for ice cream (I always take red bean and chocolate ice cream with the roti). Over here in Italy they sell gelato with Foccacia bread, but not as cheap as the ice cream ah pek in Orchard Rd.

Words.English Translation: → English: ice cream + Singlish: auntie from english ice cream sweet frozen dairy dessert + singlish auntie term of address for a woman of an older generation than the speaker, regardless of relation ← english auntie dimin. of aunt (female relative of the same generation as one's parent) ↻ asian languages "auntie" equivalent of "auntie" in various languages and cultures; woman of older generation than oneself
Words.Definition: an itinerant hawker, usually an older woman, who traditionally sells potong ice cream out of a mobile stand attached to a motorcycle, cart, or some other wheeled vehicle
Words.Example: Check out how Jenny, the Teck Whye ice-cream auntie, and her cold treats have warmed the hearts of fellow residents.

Words.English Translation: → English: ice cream + Singlish: uncle from english ice cream sweet frozen dairy dessert + singlish uncle term of address for a man of an older generation than the speaker, regardless of relation ← english uncle male relative of the same generation as one's parent ↻ asian languages "uncle" equivalent of "uncle" in various languages and cultures; man of older generation than oneself
Words.Definition: an itinerant hawker, usually an older man, who traditionally sells potong ice cream out of a mobile stand attached to a motorcycle, cart, or some other wheeled vehicle
Words.Example: For many Singaporeans, these traditional ice creams are an affordable, nostalgic treat. Buying one from one of Singapore's "ice cream uncles" is almost a right of passage.

Words.English Translation: → English: iced gems from english iced gems small round biscuit with a hard icing topping ← english iced topped with icing + english gem precious stone ← latin gemma bud; jewel; gem
Words.Definition: small, airy, round biscuits in the shape of an oblate spheroid or scallop about 1.5 cm in diameter, topped with a hard piped icing that comes in one of various bright colours. They are often considered to be a very nostalgic and traditional Singaporean snack, and ultimately originate from the UK.
Words.Example: Do you know that for every paying dine-in customer, you are entitled to a complimentary scoop of the old-school ice gems biscuit? Who loves them, ki chew!

Words.English Translation: → English: ice + jelly from english ice the solid form of water; H2O(s) + english jelly dessert made with a solution of gelatine or another gelling agent and flavouring, which is allowed to set
Words.Definition: a sweet dessert consisting of pieces of aiyu jelly in a syrup of shaved ice and lime, sometimes also flavoured with other ingredients such as honey or fruit.
Words.Example: One of the draws here is its new unlimited self-service ice jelly bar, which means you can gorge yourself silly on the refreshing dessert.

Words.English Translation: → English: ice + Malay: kacang from english ice the solid form of water; H2O(s) + malay kacang bean; nut
Words.Definition: a traditional dessert consisting of a mountain of shaved ice over various sweet condiments, such as sweetened red beans (the eponymous kacang), jelly, sweetcorn, attap chee, etc., all drenched in colourful, sweet syrup. It may also include additional toppings over the ice, with popular ingredients including durian and ice cream. Traditionally, the shaved ice is produced using a hand-crunk machine into which a large block of ice is loaded. It was usually sold by the same vendor selling ice balls.[1]
Words.Example: We’ve seen ice kacang topped with durian, even peanuts — but chocolate syrup and sprinkles are new to us.

Words.English Translation: → English: icebox + Malay: bergerak from english icebox insulated box for containing ice and keeping items cool; refrigerator ← english ice solid form of water; H2O(s) + english box cuboid container or compartment for containing items + malay bergerak move; moving ← malay ber- -ing; continuous tense + malay gerak move; movement; motion
Words.Definition: (derogatory, humorous) a fat, overweight, or obese person

Words.English Translation: → English: in + camp + training from english in within; inside + english camp military compound or base + english training process of acquiring, imparting, refreshing, or improving skills
Words.Definition: (military) a mandatory military call-up and training of between one to two weeks which all NSMen have to attend annually until their ROD, which is usually after ten (or more) cycles of call-ups. Due to these obligations, Singaporean males are not permitted to leave the country for more than 6 months without an exit permit until they are released from this duty.
Words.Example: No one says it out loud, but it’s an open secret that many bosses discriminate against hiring male Singaporeans because of their ICT obligations.

Words.English Translation: → Tamil: இடியப்பம் iṭiyappam from tamil இடியப்பம் iṭiyappam South Indian rice vermicelli; string hoppers ← tamil இடி iṭi flour + tamil அப்பம் appam rice flour cake; appam; bread
Words.Definition: a South Indian type of steamed rice vermicelli; string hoppers. It may be eaten with curry, sugar, grated coconut, gula melaka, etc.

Words.English Translation: → English: idle + Singlish: king from english idle unoccupied; lazy; do nth. + singlish king (suffix, usu. sarcastic or pejorative) the epitome of sth. ← english king (usu. male) the ruler of a monarchy; a powerful or preeminent person
Words.Definition: (military) a soldier who is extremely lazy and always skiving

Words.English Translation: → Malay: ikan from malay ikan fish
Words.Definition: fish

Words.English Translation: → Malay: ikan bilis from malay ikan bilis anchovies; (culinary) archived that are dried and usually fried or used to make stock ← malay ikan fish + malay bilis small; delicate; bleary-eyed
Words.Definition: a very small marine fish of the family Engraulidae (anchovies)
Words.Example: Researchers from the Singapore Institute of Clinical Sciences (SICS) said that whole ikan bilis found at hawker stalls, like nasi lemak vendors, are healthier than the “cleaned” anchovies ― where the head and bones are removed ― sold at supermarkets and upscale eateries.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: ikan kicap from malay ikan kicap fish fried with soya sauce ← malay ikan fish + malay kicap soya sauce ← hokkien (poj) 膎汁 kôe/kê-chiap/chap fish sauce ← hokkien (poj) 膎 kôe/kê preserved fish or seafood + hokkien (poj) 汁 chiap/chap sauce; juice
Words.Definition: a Malay dish of fried fish topped with a gravy based on kicap manis (sweet soya sauce) and soya sauce

Words.English Translation: → Malay: ikan kuning from malay ikan kuning yellowstripe scad (Selaroides leptolepis) ← malay ikan fish + malay kuning yellow
Words.Definition: the yellowstripe scad (Selaroides leptolepsis), an inshore tropical schooling fish in the horse mackerel family. It is often fried and served with nasi lemak.
Words.Example: Unsustainable species include the Indian threadfin, also known as the ngoh hur, used in fish porridge; silver pomfret, commonly used in Chinese dishes; and yellowbanded scad, or ikan kuning, a key ingredient in nasi lemak.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: ikan merah from malay ikan merah mangrove red snapper (Lutjanus argentimaculatus) ← malay ikan fish + malay merah red
Words.Definition: the mangrove red snapper (Lutjanus argentimaculatus), a tropical fish which is popular as a food species

Words.English Translation: → Malay: ikan todak from malay ikan todak swordfish, needlefish, or similar-looking species ← malay ikan fish + malay todak swordfish, needlefish, or similar-looking species
Words.Definition: a swordfish, needlefish, or any similar-looking fish species, characterized by their long, slender, sword- or needle-like bill. Ikan todak are eaten as a food species. They also feature prominently in local mythology, most famously in the tale of their attack on Singapore - from which many well-known places in Singapore got their names, including Tanjong Pagar and Bukit Merah.

Words.English Translation: → English: Indian + chief from english Indian of or relating to indigenous Americans ← english Indian of or related to Indian people, language, culture, ethnicity, etc. ← middle french indien Indian ← middle french Inde India ← classical persian هند hind India ← old persian 𐏃𐎡𐎯𐎢𐏁 hiⁿdūš India; river + middle french -ien suffix used to form a demonym + english chief leader; head; boss ← old french chef/chief leader; head; boss ← latin capus/caput head; leader
Words.Definition: (military, dated) an appointed leader of a group of soldiers, such as a section commander.

Words.English Translation: → English: Indian + Malay: rojak from english Indian of or related to Indian people, language, culture, ethnicity, etc. ← middle french indien Indian ← middle french Inde India ← classical persian هند hind India ← old persian 𐏃𐎡𐎯𐎢𐏁 hiⁿdūš India; river + middle french -ien suffix used to form a demonym + malay rojak salad dish of bite-sized pieces of fruit, vegetables, and fritters with a sweet, tangy dressing ← javanese ꦫꦸꦗꦏ꧀ rujak salad dish of bite-sized pieces of fruit, vegetables, and fritters with a sweet, tangy dressing; mix; blend
Words.Definition: a variety of rojak invented in the 1950s in local Indian-Muslim (mamak) cuisine, consisting of bite-sized pieces of potato, fried dough fritters, hard-boiled eggs, fried tofu etc., which are often dyed a bright red. It is served with a sweet, tangy dipping sauce made of chilli, peanuts, and other ingredients. Customers usually choose the items they want from a selection in front of the stall, similarly to yong tau foo. It is also known as pasembur in Malaysia.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: macam + ini from malay macam just like; similar to + malay ini this
Words.Definition: 'like this'; carries a degree of certainty

Words.English Translation: → English: inside from english inside inner face or part; interior
Words.Definition: inside; within
Words.Example: During my time...got this joker pcc insai store room. Kana catch by OC, whole lots of the coy jitao pump 100 ... Thanks to this joker we pcc him insai toilet.

Words.English Translation: → English: interested from english interested showing interest; enthusiastic ← old french interesse interest ← latin interesse lie between; take part in
Words.Definition: enthusiastic about; motivated; eager

Words.English Translation: → English: Internet + brigade from english Internet global communicational and informational computer network ✂ english internetwork network of and between multiple networks ← english inter- between; connecting ← latin inter between + english network system of interconnected devices ← english net mesh of connected lines or cords + english work sth. made or produced + english brigade coordinated group of people with a common purpose, view, etc. ← french brigade (mil.) large unit comprising several battalions ← italian brigata group; party, (mil.) brigade
Words.Definition: (pejorative) a group of netizens who vehemently support and praise a particular party, organization, or cause in online spaces such as forums and social media, and try to positively influence public sentiment towards it. According to various accounts, they may either be genuinely zealous and earnest supporters, or paid off to favourably influence the public’s views on said party.
Words.Example: I saw many instances of people who made malicious or dishonest comments on my Facebook page and found that they had locked their profile. I suspect that they are members of the Internet Brigade and now operate under their new SOP (standard operating procedure). There are probably about 100 members under this gang ... I suspect that the members of this malicious gang are paid to vandalize and terrorize other people on social media.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: Ipoh + Cantonese: 河粉 jyutping: ho4 fan2 from malay Ipoh state capital of Perak, Malaysia ← malay ipuh the tree Antiaris toxicaria or the plant family Strychnos, or their poisonous saps; poison prepared from the sap of these plants + cantonese (jyutping) 河粉 ho4 fan2 flat rice noodle used in Cantonese cuisine; Cantonese equivalent of kway teow ← cantonese (jyutping) 沙河粉 saa1 ho4 fan2 flat rice noodle used in Cantonese cuisine; Cantonese equivalent of kway teow ← cantonese (jyutping) 沙河 saa1 ho4 town in Guangdong, China believed to be where hor fun originated from, (lit.) 'sandy river' + cantonese (jyutping) 粉 fan2 flour; powder; noodles
Words.Definition: a style of hor fun from Ipoh, Malaysia, especially noted for its silky smooth mouthfeel. It has a clear chicken- or prawn- based gravy, and typically uses shredded chicken and sometimes prawns as the main protein.

Words.English Translation: → English: individual + physical + proficiency + test from english individual relating to one person alone ← latin indīviduālis indivisible + english physical of or related to the body ← late latin physicālis of or related to the natural sciences + english proficiency ability; aptitude; skill ← latin prōficiēns advance; benefit + english -ency used to form an abstract noun denoting a quality ← latin -entia used to form an abstract noun + english test trial or examination to determine or measure sth.
Words.Definition: a test of physical fitness involving three stations: push-ups, sit-ups, and a 2.4 km run, which all NS-liable Singaporean males have to complete yearly starting from the age of 16.5 years old. Older iterations of the test included other exercises, such as pull-ups and the standing broad jump.
Words.Example: Andy failed his IPPT, so he has to stay back for RT.

Words.Word: iron rice bowl 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → English: iron + rice + bowl ↻ Mandarin: 铁饭碗 鐵飯碗 pinyin: tiě fàn wǎn from english iron metal, element Fe with atomic number 26 + english rice edible seeds, used as a food grain, of the Oryza sativa cereal crop + english bowl roughly hemispherical container ↻ mandarin (pinyin) 铁饭碗 鐵飯碗 tiě fàn wǎn (lit.) iron rice bowl, (fig.) highly stable and secure job, often w. the government ← mandarin (pinyin) 铁 鐵 tiě iron + general chinese (pinyin) 饭碗 飯碗 fàn wǎn (lit.) rice bowl, (fig.) livelihood; living; job; career ← general chinese (pinyin) 饭 飯 fàn cooked rice + general chinese (pinyin) 碗 碗 wǎn bowl
Words.Definition: (metaphor) a highly stable and secure job, often with the government
Words.Example: It's like an iron rice bowl for us as everyone needs accounting services ... I'm pretty comfortable where I am in my job ...

Words.English Translation: → English: is it from english is it 'really?'; particle used to form a question ← english is be + english it 3rd person sing. neuter pron.
Words.Definition: 'is that so?'; 'really?'; used to question the veracity of a statement, or ask for affirmation
Words.Example: - You know, even if you bring your own container, a lot of stalls will still charge you 50 cents to da bao?- Isit? Wah how come ah?

Words.English Translation: → English: itchy from english itchy sensation of needing to be scratched; having a niggling desire to do sth.; jittery; eager; on edge
Words.Definition: jittery; restless; constantly having the desire to do something
Words.Example: Were his hands itchy? Did he have a bad day? An incident at Tanjong Pagar Plaza’s carpark yesterday (June 21) has left netizens confused.

Words.English Translation: → English: itchy + backside from english itchy sensation of needing to be scratched; having a niggling desire to do sth.; jittery; eager; on edge + english backside buttocks; anatomical rear end ← english back rear; behind + english side face; flank
Words.Definition: (idiom) unable to sit still; listless; restless; constantly having the desire to move about; hyperactive
Words.Example: “It was an itchy backside situation,” quips actor Adam Chen. He is explaining to 8days.sg why he has opened a new cafe, after toughing out the recent Covid-19 pandemic where he saw business for his eateries fall by as much as 90 per cent.

Words.English Translation: → Baba malay: itek + sio from baba malay itek duck ← malay itik duck + baba malay sio roasted; grilled ← hokkien (poj) 烧 燒 sio roasted; grilled; hot
Words.Definition: a Peranakan dish of dry-roasted duck braised in a soy-based sauce flavoured with coriander and assam. Peranakan recipes are infamous for their extremely long preparation times, it is usually marinated and and itek sio is no different - it is usually marinated and seasoned for at least 6 hours beforehand or if not overnight, before a multi-step cooking process of braising, deep-frying or dry roasting, and braising again.
Words.Example: On the origins of itek sio, she says: “Some Peranakan families are Taoists, so they cooked items such as a whole chicken, duck and pork belly after they have been used as prayer offerings in the temple.”

Words.English Translation: → Baba malay: itek + tim from baba malay itek duck ← malay itik duck + baba malay tim roasted; grilled ← hokkien (poj) 𤆤/𬊈 𤆤/燖 tīm simmer; boil in water; braise; stew; heat up in hot water; steam
Words.Definition: a sour and savoury soup of Peranakan origin, made from boiling duck, kiam chye, chilli, assam, ginger, brandy, and other ingredients. It was often eaten during special occasions such as Chinese New Year.[1]
Words.Example: … known as Itek Tim, this cosy weather soup is being slow-boiled for hours, with hearty duck meat and addictively sour vegetables infused in making a light, savoury broth. Just a sip of it will confirm leave you craving more!

Words.English Translation: → Malay: jadi from malay jadi become ← sanskrit जाति jātí birth; production; character; assigned position
Words.Definition: to become; to be; to assume

Words.English Translation: → Malay: jaga from malay jaga awake; watch over; be on guard ← pali jagga awake; watch over; be attentive ← sanskrit जागर्ति jāgarti awake; watch over; be attentive
Words.Definition: to guard; to watch over; to keep vigil at
Words.Example: I go toilet first, can jaga my barang-barang?

Words.English Translation: → Malay: jagung from malay jagung corn; maize ← javanese ꦗꦮ ꦲꦒꦸꦁ jawa agung corn; maize ← javanese ꦗꦮ jawa grain + javanese ꦲꦒꦸꦁ agung big; great; large
Words.Definition: maize; corn (the plant Zea mays and its edible grain)

Words.English Translation: → Malay: Jakun from malay Jakun ethnic group, one of the Orang Asli in Malaysia, (slang) slave; unsophisticated or uncivilized person
Words.Definition: (derogatory) easily fascinated by ordinary things

Words.English Translation: → Malay: jalan from malay jalan road; way; walk; street; path
Words.Definition: (used in place names) road; way; walk; street; path
Words.Example: The author grew up in Jalan Limau Nipis, a short walk away from Tanah Merah MRT station.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: berjalan-jalan from malay berjalan-jalan go for a walk; take a stroll
Words.Definition: to go for a walk; to take a stroll
Words.Example: Many people could benefit from the simplicity of a day's jalan-jalan around their neighbourhood to appreciate the vibrant heritage right at their doorsteps.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: jambu from malay jambu any plant of the genus Syzygium or its edible fruit, (slang) cute; adorable; pretty; beautiful ← javanese / old javanese ꦗꦩ꧀ꦧꦸ jambu any plant of the genus Syzygium or its edible fruit ← sanskrit जम्बु jambu Syzygium cumini or its edible fruit
Words.Definition: any plant of the genus Syzygium or its edible fruit, but most commonly Syzygium aqueum,[1] which bears pear-shaped fruits around 5 - 8 cm in length which transition from pale green to red as they ripen. The fruits have a tart, mild taste, and are commonly eaten as they are or as an ingredient in rojak.
Words.Example: Frankly, without the jambu Jolie, that fine body that's to die for and those lips so luscious, there was nothing else to watch.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: jangan from malay jangan do not; don’t
Words.Definition: don't; do not

Words.English Translation: → Malay: jangan + main-main from malay jangan don't + malay main-main playful; unserious; play a fool
Words.Definition: don't play around; don't play a fool; be serious
Words.Example: When it comes to safety rules, jangan main-main.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: jangan tension from malay jangan tension 'relax'; 'don't stress over it' ← malay jangan don't + malay tension tension ← english tension feeling of unease, nervousness, anxiety, mentail or emotional discomfort, stress, etc. ← middle french tension tension; stretching; extension ← latin tēnsiō tension; stretching; extension
Words.Definition: 'relax'; 'don't stress over it'; used to encourage a person to calm down and stop worrying, overthinking, or feeling anxious
Words.Example: ... we've been invited to "tok-kok and freak out like terror1" at the book's launch at Bibi's in Peranakan Place on Wednesday, where it is hoped that guests will be able to jangan tension lah!

Words.English Translation: → English: junior college from english junior college (SG) post-secondary educational institute offering A-levels or IB; type of tertiary-level educational institute ← english junior younger; lower in level ← latin jūnior younger + english college tertiary-level educational institute ← middle french college institution; university ← latin collēgium college; school; company
Words.Definition: (initialism) junior college

Words.English Translation: → Malay: Jepun from malay Jepun Japan; Japanese ← hokkien (poj) 日本 Ji̍t-pún Japan; Japanese ← middle chinese (baxter) 日本 nyit pwonX Japan & japanese 日本 nippon Japan ← japanese 日 nichi sun + japanese 本 pon origin
Words.Definition: Japan
Words.Example: So long ago...body prob eaten by many fishes wch are then got caught and become sashimi..so is inside many jitpuns now...

Words.English Translation: → Malay: jelak from malay jelak bored; tired, (from food) full; satisfied; satiated
Words.Definition: (of food) overwhelmingly rich; intensely fatty or sweet
Words.Example: My friends don't normally like to eat tempura because they feel it's too jelak; but this one, they can sit through the whole menu and still have room for dessert.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: jeling from malay jeling side-eye; give a side glance
Words.Definition: to side-eye; to give a glance out the corner of one's eye; to snatch a look
Words.Example: And then there were two other very Bruneian ladies (outfit, the typical high end bags). I smiled and they just jeling jeling.

Words.English Translation: → English: Jew from english Jew Jewish person, (derog.) cheapskate; miser; money-minded person ← old french juiu/giu Jew ← latin iūdaeus Jew; Judaean; Jewish ← ancient greek Ῐ̓ουδαῖος Ioudaîos Jew; Judaean ← ancient greek Ἰούδᾱς Ioúdās Judah; Judas ← hebrew יְהוּדָה y'hudá Judah (male given name); Judea ← hebrew יָדָה yadá worship; praise; revere
Words.Definition: (transitive, racist, offensive) to freeload; to greedily take without asking permission
Words.Example: Can don't always jew my chalk? Your hands so sweaty, get your own lah!

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: jiu hu bu from singlish jiu hu bu female Malaysian person ← hokkien (poj) 州府 chiu-hú (lit.) subnational division e.g. a state, (met.) archaic term for Malaysia ('Federated Settlements') + hokkien (poj) 母 bú mother; female
Words.Definition: a Malaysian; someone from Malaysia
Words.Example: Alot of Singaporeans fall into the misconception that JHK are very kelian. But once you see the property they live back in Malaysia, you will see just how pathetic our pigeon holes are in comparison to theirs.

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: jiu hu kia from singlish jiu hu kia Malaysian person ← hokkien (poj) 州府 chiu-hú (lit.) subnational division e.g. a state, (met.) archaic term for Malaysia ('Federated Settlements') + hokkien (poj) 囝 kiáⁿ son; child; dimin. suffix
Words.Definition: a Malaysian; someone from Malaysia
Words.Example: Alot of Singaporeans fall into the misconception that JHK are very kelian. But once you see the property they live back in Malaysia, you will see just how pathetic our pigeon holes are in comparison to theirs.

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: ji ba boom from singlish ji ba boom (onom.) sound of a large explosion
Words.Definition: (onomatopoeic) the sound of a large explosion
Words.Example: Babi Kia lay wondering what happened. At first he thought whole world jibaboom liao. The he thought maybe just the forest part jibaboom. Then he thought maybe he ownself jibaboom and now one person on the moon or somewhere and would neh see again Christopher Lobin lah, Pooh lah, Hee-haw lah.

Words.English Translation: → Japanese: チョキ choki + グー gū + パー pā from japanese チョキ choki scissors (in jankenpon) + japanese グー gū stone; rock (in jankenpon) + japanese パー pā paper (in jankenpon)
Words.Definition: a turn-based finger game played between two (or sometimes more) players. Players may choose between three different symbols made with the hands, which are the same as the symbols in scissors paper stone, though 'scissors' is called 'ji', 'stone' is 'gu', and 'paper' is 'pa'.The players first play e.g. scissors paper stone to decide who goes first. The players then hold up their hands and shout 'ji gu pa!', commencing the game. On their turn, a player displays any combination of the three symbols with their hands while shouting out their names, such as 'ji gu!', while the opponent quickly reacts and displays their own. If any of the player's symbols matches any of the opponent's, the opponent's corresponding hand is 'knocked out' for the rest of the game. The winner is the player who 'knocks out' both their opponent's hands first.

Words.English Translation: → Likely, but other possible etymologies exist Hokkien: 挐潲 poj: jî/lî/jû-siàu from hokkien (poj) Likely, but other possible etymologies exist 挐潲 jî/lî/jû-siàu (vg.) stir trouble for no reason; reckless; chaotic
Words.Definition: (slightly vulgar) to prank; to make trouble and mischief for no reason; to play a trick on; to purposely annoy or disturb; to make a fool of; to bully
Words.Example: Easy for bike to fit. When I drive and see this, I always feel like filtering in nicely just to ji siao them. One day my intrusive thoughts might take over for real.

Words.English Translation: → Mandarin: 加饭 加飯 pinyin: jiā fàn from mandarin (pinyin) 加饭 加飯 jiā fàn add rice ← mandarin (pinyin) 加 加 jiā add; more; increase + mandarin (pinyin) 饭 飯 fàn (cooked) rice
Words.Definition: (food ordering) 'add rice'; used to order a larger portion of rice than normal
Words.Example: Uncle, kui png da bao, jia fan.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 食 poj: chia̍h from hokkien (poj) 食 chia̍h eat
Words.Definition: to eat

Words.Word: jiak bo liao 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 食 poj: chia̍h + 无 無 poj: bô + 了 poj: liáu from hokkien (poj) 食 chia̍h eat + hokkien (poj) 无 無 bô no; not; don't + hokkien (poj) 了 liáu finish; complete
Words.Definition: to be unable to finish some food or meal
Words.Example: Wah still got dessert ah? I jiak bo liao already.

Words.Word: jiak buay liao 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 食 poj: chia̍h + 𫧃 𣍐 poj: bōe/bē + 了 poj: liáu from hokkien (poj) 食 chia̍h eat + hokkien (poj) 𫧃 𣍐 bōe/bē not; cannot; unable to + hokkien (poj) 了 liáu finish; complete
Words.Definition: to be unable to finish some food or meal
Words.Example: Wah still got dessert ah? I jiak buay liao already.

Words.Word: jiak buay lok 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 食 poj: chia̍h + 𫧃 𣍐 poj: bōe/bē + 落 poj: lo̍k from hokkien (poj) 食 chia̍h eat + hokkien (poj) 𫧃 𣍐 bōe/bē not; cannot; unable to + hokkien (poj) 落 lo̍k down
Words.Definition: to be unable to finish some food or meal
Words.Example: Just now you say dinner chiah buay lok, then so soon already want chendol.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 食 poj: chia̍h + 草 poj: chháu from hokkien (poj) 食 chia̍h eat + hokkien (poj) 草 chháu grass; weeds
Words.Definition: (idiom) to be or to go broke; to be unable to afford even food or daily necessities
Words.Example: Lim Seng went into severe debt when his businesses all failed in one fell swoop due to Covid. He was only spared from having to jiak chao because of the help and support of his old friends and neighbours.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 食 poj: chia̍h + 鱼 魚 poj: hî/hîr from hokkien (poj) 食 chia̍h eat + hokkien (poj) 鱼 魚 hî/hîr fish
Words.Definition: (of a person) extremely strict
Words.Example: My boss is so jiak hi. He needs to jiak a chill pill and let us jiak zua every once in a while.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 食风 食風 poj: chia̍h-hong from hokkien (poj) 食风 食風 chia̍h-hong go on holiday; gallivant; go for a joyride; live in luxury ↻ malay makan angin (lit.) eat wind; (fig.) take a walk to get some fresh air; sit around silently passing the time or cantonese (jyutping) 食风 食風 sik6 fung1 (lit.) eat wind; (fig.) go on holiday; gallivant; go for a joyride; live in luxury
Words.Definition: (idiom) to go on holiday; to gallivant; to go for a joyride
Words.Example: She felt the need to clear her mind that night, so she went to {jiak hong} in her new convertible along the coastal expressway.

Words.Word: jiak hong chu 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 食风 食風 poj: chia̍h-hong + 厝 poj: chhù from hokkien (poj) 食风 食風 chia̍h-hong eat wind ← malay makan angin (lit.) eat wind; (fig.) take a walk to get some fresh air; sit around silently passing the time or cantonese (jyutping) 食风 食風 sik6 fung1 (lit.) eat wind; (fig.) go on holiday; gallivant; go for a joyride; live in luxury + hokkien (poj) 厝 chhù house; building
Words.Definition: a holiday home or bungalow by the seaside; a beachfront villa
Words.Example: The friends decided to go rent a jiak hong chu to jiak hong and celebrate their graduation.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 食 poj: chia̍h + Malay: kentang from hokkien (poj) 食 chia̍h eat + malay kentang potato ← javanese ꦏꦼꦤ꧀ꦛꦁ kenthang potato
Words.Definition: (pejorative) to act or behave like a Westerner; to be westernized
Words.Example: And 我知，你想我是红毛派逐日食蕳砃 (jiak kantang), burger makan apple pieBut now you know 我的福建真的袂歹I can fly to Taiwan, 共查某倾偈(tr.: And I know, you think I'm an ang moh pai / chiah kantang every day, burger makan apple pie / But now you know my Hokkien is really buay pai / I can fly to Taiwan, and chat up the cha bors)

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 食 poj: chia̍h + 球 poj: kiû from hokkien (poj) 食 chia̍h eat, (fig.) take + hokkien (poj) 球 kiû ball
Words.Definition: (betting) to accept a handicap of a specified number of goals when betting on a weaker team, especially in football
Words.Example: - These odds you take Netherlands and I take Wales, fair meh?- You chiak kiu loh. I pang chit liap give you.

Words.English Translation: → Min nan: 食侬 食儂 poj: chia̍h-lâng from min nan (poj) 食侬 食儂 chia̍h-lâng oppress; bully; domineer ← min nan (poj) 食 食 chia̍h eat; consume + min nan (poj) 侬 儂 lâng person; human
Words.Definition: to oppress; to exploit; to domineer
Words.Example: Jiak lang gao gao-attitude is not exactly worth championing, but spare a thought for your neighbours while you exercise your creativity, i think still can lah. Just don't spend all the efforts in penny pinching, that's like missing the forest for the tree.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 食了米 poj: chia̍h-liâu-bí from hokkien (poj) 食了米 chia̍h-liâu-bí to be a loafer; to live an idle and aimless life ← hokkien (poj) 食 chia̍h eat + hokkien (poj) 了 liâu waste + hokkien (poj) 米 bí rice
Words.Definition: to be a loafer; to live an idle and aimless life; to be useless
Words.Example: The job market is in a terrible freeze right now, and there is an overwhelming number of fake job ads put online by scummy companies trying to fill a local application quota. Many highly-qualified fresh graduates are being forced to loaf about for months and jiak liau bi while getting ghosted by every company they apply to.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 食 poj: chia̍h + 镭 鐳 poj: lui from hokkien (poj) 食 chia̍h eat; consume + hokkien (poj) 镭 鐳 lui money; coins ← malay duit money; a doit ← dutch duit doit, a Dutch copper coin historically worth 1/8 of a stiver or 1/160 of a guilder; (inf.) money
Words.Definition: to con; to cheat of money; to swindle
Words.Example: - gg liao lor............... bookie jiak lui- Kelong season man city jiak most lui then lvp lose to Plymouth jiak one more round

Words.Word: jiak pa bo sai pang 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 食饱 食飽 poj: chia̍h-pá + 无 無 poj: bô + 屎 poj: sái + 放 poj: pàng from hokkien (poj) 食饱 食飽 chia̍h-pá eat until one is full; be full + hokkien (poj) 无 無 bô no; not have + hokkien (poj) 屎 sái faeces; poop; excrement; bodily secretion; (vg.) shit; lousy; useless + hokkien (poj) 放 pàng release; let out; lay down; emit ← hokkien (poj) 放屎 pàng-sái defecate; excrete faeces; poop
Words.Definition: (idiom) having nothing better to do; having too much time on one's hands
Words.Example: Some people jiak pa bo sai pang, want to make one whole dictionary for Singlish.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 食补 食補 poj: chia̍h-pó͘ from hokkien (poj) 食补 食補 chia̍h-pó͘ take nutritional supplements; drink herbal tonic ← hokkien (poj) 食 食 chia̍h eat; consume + hokkien (poj) 补 補 pó͘ nourish; augment
Words.Definition: to eat healthy and nutritious food to nourish the body
Words.Example: Felt like I deserved to "chiak por", and claypot rice with soup seemed a good choice.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 食 poj: chia̍h + 屎 poj: sái from hokkien (poj) 食 chia̍h eat + hokkien (poj) 屎 sái faeces; poop; excrement; bodily secretion; (vg.) shit

Words.Word: jiu hu char 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 𬶧鱼 鰇魚 poj: jiû-hû/hîr + 炒 poj: chhá from hokkien (poj) 𬶧鱼 鰇魚 jiû-hû/hîr squid; cuttlefish + hokkien (poj) 炒 chhá stir-fried

Words.Example: Growing up, Jiu Hu Char was a dish that I watched Mum prepare and would help when I could, slicing the ingredients for this dish. Coming from a large family, Mum has to cook up a storm to feed the family.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 州府 poj: chiu-hú + 囝 poj: kiáⁿ from hokkien (poj) 州府 chiu-hú (lit.) subnational division e.g. a state, (met.) archaic term for Malaysia ('Federated Settlements') + hokkien (poj) 囝 kiáⁿ son; child; dimin. suffix
Words.Definition: a Malaysian; someone from Malaysia
Words.Example: i see those sinkie who work under jihu kia/mei sure tio bully until jialat jialat by them ... but they in malaysia also kena bully by the bumi they should know bullying is not a nice feeling wat ... why they come here must treat sinkie like that?

Words.Example: Instead of growing guts to fire the real JLBs, the weak government chose to offer no job security

Words.English Translation: → Baba malay: joget + Malay: joget from baba malay joget dance; dancing ← malay joget type of traditional Javanese song and dance performance; dance + malay joget type of traditional Javanese song and dance performance; dance ← javanese ꦗꦺꦴꦒꦺꦠ꧀ jogèt type of traditional Javanese song and dance performance
Words.Definition: a dance (in general)
Words.Example: Also known as Chakunchak, Joget can be performed without singing too. Practiced by the Peranakan community, this dance form is usually performed by couples who appear to be playfully teasing each other. The beauty of the dance lies in the fact that the couple does not touch each other as they make rhythmic hand and foot movements.

Words.English Translation: → English: jolly well from english jolly well had better; certainly; used for emphasis ← english jolly extremely; very; merry; joyful ← old french joli pretty; cute; merry; joyful + english well good; very; satisfactorily; as desired
Words.Definition: had better; ought to; should; certainly
Words.Example: You jolly well behave, or your parents will be getting a call!

Words.English Translation: → Malay: jom from malay jom let's go; let's
Words.Definition: let's go; let's

Words.English Translation: → Possible, but not certain Cantonese: 啜 jyutping: zyut3 from cantonese (jyutping) Possible, but not certain 啜 zyut3 kiss; suck, (onomatopoeic) kissing or sucking noise
Words.Definition: (usually of a young girl or woman) good-looking; attractive; pretty; sexy
Words.Example: Ooi Ah Seng!! Look there!! You see that girl walking across the Atrium. Wah-lau damn jude man!!!!

Words.English Translation: → English: junior college from english junior college tertiary-level educational institute that awards a degree below a bachelor's degree ← english junior younger; lower in level ← latin jūnior younger + english college tertiary-level educational institute ← middle french college institution; university ← latin collēgium college; school; company
Words.Definition: a post-secondary educational institute, usually for students between the ages of 17 to 18, offering either the Singapore-Cambridge GCE A-level or International Baccalaureate Diploma at the end of a two-year course. Equivalent to sixth form or the final two years of high school in other countries.

Words.English Translation: → English: just + nice from english just simply; only; merely ← old french juste fair; righteous; proper ← latin iūstus fair; righteous; lawful; proper + english nice satisfactory; pleasing; good ← old french nice naive; ignorant; unknowing ← latin nescius ignorant; not knowing; unaware
Words.Definition: coincidentally; perfectly; conveniently; incidentally
Words.Example: Just nice Pritam busy with his own trial, not in Parliament this time to query regarding Income-Allianz ... So coincidental in the timing sia

Words.English Translation: → English: just now from english just now a moment ago; recently ← english just only; merely ← old french juste fair; righteous; proper ← latin iūstus fair; righteous; lawful; proper + english now at present; current
Words.Definition: a moment ago; recently
Words.Example: Just now I tell you no need already what.

Words.English Translation: → English: just + Singlish: whack from english just simply; only; merely ← old french juste fair; righteous; proper ← latin iūstus fair; righteous; lawful; proper + singlish whack do without necessarily having the requisite knowledge or skills ← english whack hit; beat; smack ↻ hokkien (poj) 拍 phah (lit.) hit; (generally) do or perform an action; used to verbify a noun & hokkien (poj) 拂 hut act recklessly; disregard everything; do without care for the consequences & hokkien (poj) 刜 hut/phut strike forcefully; hit; do recklessly without care for the consequences & malay gasak hit; beat; whack & malay hentam hit; beat; do sth. flagrantly with no regard for consequences
Words.Definition: to tackle a task spontaneously and unsystematically, without necessarily having the requisite knowledge, planning, or skills to do so
Words.Example: We didn't have a schedule in mind. It was just, "Let's just do this" ... and we just whack.

Words.Word: ka ki kong, ka ki song 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Min nan: 家己 poj: ka-kī + 讲 講 poj: kóng + 家己 poj: ka-kī + 爽 poj: sóng from min nan (poj) 家己 ka-kī self; oneself + min nan (poj) 讲 講 kóng talk; speak + min nan (poj) 家己 ka-kī self; oneself + min nan (poj) 爽 sóng happy; satisfied; pleased; feel good; enjoyable
Words.Definition: used to describe someone who talks a lot, as if they love the sound of their own voice, or listening to their own rhetoric gives them pleasure and satisfaction. Usually connotes that what they say is empty or idle nonsense.
Words.Example: -Can anybody explain how they get this number?- i think its a common singapore practice called "ka ki kong ka ki song"

Words.Word: ka ki nang 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Teochew / hainanese / min nan: 家己侬 家己儂 peng'im: ga1 gi7 nang5 from teochew / hainanese / min nan (peng'im) 家己侬 家己儂 ga1 gi7 nang5 one of us; one of our own; close companions; sb. in one's circle
Words.Definition: one of us; one of our own; people in one's circle; close companions; friends and family
Words.Example: He got lucky and made a fortune. His sense of ka-ki nang ... was very strong. He would send remittances home to China to his family, relatives, and close friends. He also recruited one of his relatives in Singapore to help out in his shop and paid him a monthly salary of $1,000, a hefty sum at that time.
Related: ka ki kong, ka ki song

Words.Word: ka li kong 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 共汝讲 共汝講 poj: kā lí kóng from hokkien (poj) 共汝讲 共汝講 kā lí kóng tell you; speak to you; 'listen here' ← hokkien (poj) 共 共 kā to; with; at + hokkien (poj) 汝 汝 lí you; 2p. sing. pronoun + hokkien (poj) 讲 講 kóng speak; talk; say

Words.Example: Eh ka li kong ah, next time better get me my tau huay chui else I hentam your kha chng.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 敢若 poj: káⁿ-ná + 屎 poj: sái from hokkien (poj) 敢若 káⁿ-ná like; as if + hokkien (poj) 屎 sái faeces; poop; excrement; bodily secretion; (vg.) shit; lousy; useless

Related: kan ni na bu chao chee bai
kan ni na chao chee bai

Words.English Translation: → Min: 虼蚻 poj: ka-choa̍h from min (poj) 虼蚻 ka-choa̍h cockroach
Words.Definition: a cockroach
Words.Example: In her own colourful words, she was confronted by a “MF huge-ass ka zhua”.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: kacang from malay kacang bean; nut, (slang) easy-peasy; simple; easy
Words.Definition: a bean; a nut; a legume
Words.Example: he ... lived in a rented room in Serangoon Road, where he cooked and prepared his own kacang. This is unlike older vendors nowadays, who buy their goods ready-cooked. Mr Mannan picked up the kacang cooking skills in his hometown in Orthanadu, South India ...

Words.English Translation: → Malay: kacang + ڤول pul from malay kacang bean; nut + malay ڤول pul Vicia faba, a.k.a. fava bean or broad bean ← arabic فُول fūl Vicia faba, a.k.a. fava bean or broad bean ← aramaic פול/פֹּולא pūl/pūlā bean
Words.Definition: a thick stew or dip of mashed fava beans, mixed with various spices and usually topped with sliced red onions, sliced green chillies, and an egg. It is typically served with bread for dipping. It is derived from the Egyptian (and Middle Eastern / North African) breakfast dish ful mudammas, but has diverged significantly from it (e.g. using only fully-mashed or blended beans, being spicy, and using more local spices).
Words.Example: The kacang pool was a hearty and wholesome dish designed for maximum impact – it filled me up with everything I needed to start my day and was a cutlery-optional pleasure to eat.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: kacang + putih from malay kacang bean; nut + malay putih white
Words.Definition: assorted nuts, beans, or legumes and other tidbits like murukku or fried crackers traditionally sold as snacks by South Indian immigrants, with each serving usually given in a rolled cone of paper
Words.Example: Big factories now have the market cornered. The kacang putih man has all but disappeared.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: kacang + rebus from malay kacang bean; nut + malay rebus boil; boiled
Words.Definition: peanuts boiled in their shells until soft
Words.Example: I could hear his voice from afar calling for customers and normally he would shout.."kacang puteh, kacang rebus". I would then run to the front stairs waiting for him.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: kacau from malay kacau confused; chaotic
Words.Definition: to disturb; to agitate; to bother; to annoy
Words.Example: Whenever I am trying to have a relaxing cooking session on my own, my dog always comes to the kitchen to kacau me in the hope of getting some off-cuts or scraps.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: kaci from malay kaci sweetlips (fish)
Words.Definition: the sweetlips, any of various of edible marine fish in the subfamily Plectorhinchinae, such as Plectorhincus lineatus (the yellowbanded sweetlips) or Diagramma pictum (the painted sweetlips)
Words.Example: Caught a Painted Sweetlips (Kaci) and decided to cook some fish curry!

Words.English Translation: → Cantonese: 芥兰 芥蘭 jyutping: gaai3 laan4-2 from cantonese (jyutping) 芥兰 芥蘭 gaai3 laan4-2 Brassica oleracea var. alboglabra
Words.Definition: Brassica oleracea var. alboglabra, a leafy green vegetable commonly eaten in Chinese and South-East Asian cuisine, such as in stir-fries
Words.Example: Kai Lan is a versatile vegetable that has tender leaves and a thick, crunchy stem. It can be eaten blanched, steamed, or stir-fried.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: kak from malay kak older sister; term of address for a female person slightly older than oneself; older sibling; older brother ✂ malay kakak older sister; term of address for a female person slightly older than oneself; older sibling; older brother
Words.Definition: older sister; term of address or endearment for an older sister

Words.English Translation: → Malay: kakak from malay kakak older sister; term of address for a female person slightly older than oneself; older sibling; older brother
Words.Definition: older sister; term of address or endearment for an older sister
Words.Example: They say that you can’t utter the word pontianak in full while in the dark, which is why I once heard my aunt refer to one as cik pon, or kakak.

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: ka ki nang &/or Malay: kaki from singlish ka ki nang one of us; one of our own; people in one's circle; friends and family ← teochew / hainanese / min nan (peng'im) 家己侬 家己儂 ga1 gi7 nang5 one of us; one of our own; close companions; sb. in one's circle &/or malay kaki sb. who is fond of or good at sth.; lover of sth.; leg; foot ↻ cantonese (jyutping) Possible, but not certain 脚 腳 goek3 sb. who joins in an activity; leg; foot
Words.Definition: a friend; a close companion; a buddy
Words.Example: Many Singaporeans still have fond memories of these past experiences, and continue to enjoy occasions to hang out with their 'kakis'.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: kaki bangku from malay kaki bangku clumsy; bumbling ← malay kaki leg; foot + malay bangku bench; stool ← portuguese banco bench ← italian banco bench; desk ← old high german bank bench
Words.Definition: (idiom) clumsy; bumbling; having two left feet, especially when playing sports
Words.Example: Especially if he turns out to have what Malaysian soccer fans rudely call "kaki bangku" ... the kind that cannot begin to kick a football right.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: kaki lima from malay kaki lima five-foot way ← malay kaki foot (unit of measure); foot; leg + malay lima five
Words.Definition: Malay term for a five-foot way.
Words.Example: Kaki lima are found all over the country, but they are blocked by fences, motorbikes, goods and clutter.Keeping them clear of obstructions is a struggle for council enforcers.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 咖喱卜 poj: ka-lí-pok from hokkien (poj) 咖喱卜 ka-lí-pok curry puff ← hokkien (poj) 咖喱 ka-lí curry ← english curry type of Indian dish typically featuring various ingredients in a spiced gravy ← tamil கறி kaṟi curry; thick sauce; meat; pepper + hokkien (poj) 卜 pok to divine; (arch.) pop; crack; burst or malay epok-epok epok-epok (a Malay variant of curry puff)
Words.Definition: a curry puff, a fried pastry snack likely ultimately originating in the Spanish and Portuguese empanada, the Cornish pasty, or the Indian samosa.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 含 poj: kâm + 𡳞 poj: lān from hokkien (poj) 含 kâm hold or keep in one's mouth + hokkien (poj) 𡳞 lān (vulgar) penis; the hell
Words.Definition: (vulgar) get lost; go away; piss off

Words.English Translation: → Min nan: 感谢 感謝 poj: kám-siā from min nan (poj) 感谢 感謝 kám-siā thank you
Words.Definition: thank you; expression of gratitude or appreciation
Words.Example: Remember to ‘kam-sia’ our bus captains for their hard work in bringing us to our destinations safely.

Words.English Translation: → Baba malay: kamcheng from baba malay kamcheng elaborately decorated lidded pot ← hokkien (poj) 崁钟 崁鍾 khàm-cheng covered jar ← hokkien (poj) 崁 崁 khàm lid; cover + hokkien (poj) 钟 鍾 cheng vessel
Words.Definition: a traditional Peranakan ceramic pot or jar with a lid. It is usually elaborately decorated, especially so for those used for special occasions. Depending on factors like size and cost, it may be used for storing food, holding soups or stews, pickling, etc.
Words.Example: A 'camcheng' could be used as a container for water, pickles and other types of food. China exported a large number of these ceramics to the Straits Settlements communities in Penang, Malacca and Singapore in the 1800s ...

Words.English Translation: → Malay: kampung from malay kampung village; community; hometown
Words.Definition: a traditional village
Words.Example: At least five disused kampung houses on the island will be restored to their former glory as part of years-long restoration efforts ...

Words.English Translation: → Malay: ayam kampung + English: chicken from malay ayam kampung free-range village chicken ← malay ayam chicken + malay kampung village; community; hometown + english chicken domesticated bird of the subspecies Gallus gallus domesticus
Words.Definition: a breed of free-range chicken, typically slightly smaller and less productive than most farmed chicken breeds. Their meat is considered a culinary delicacy and valued at a higher price than that of normal chickens, and their skin usually also has a yellower hue.
Words.Example: A kampung chicken has just set a local record. Ten thousand first-edition copies of the novel Kampung Chicken by Ravi Veloo are now on sale at book stores ... The novel is an allegorical tale about Sui, a kampung chicken who tries to fly the coop.

Words.English Translation: → English: kampung + spirit from english kampung traditional village; hometown ← malay kampung village; community; hometown + english spirit soul; enthusiasm; energy ← old french esprit spirit; soul; essence ← latin spīritus breath; air; spirit; energy
Words.Definition: a sense of care, cooperation, and togetherness among neighbours and the general community, like that of a warm and homely village
Words.Example: While many of us speak of the kampung spirit, it has not carried over to actions to have good neighbourly relationships.

Words.English Translation: → Min nan: 感谢 感謝 poj: kám-siā + Korean: 감사합니다 gamsahamnida from min nan (poj) 感谢 感謝 kám-siā thank you; thanks + korean 감사합니다 gamsahamnida thank you ← korean 감사 感謝 gamsa thanks; gratitude + sino-korean / middle chinese (pinyin) 感谢 感謝 komX zjaeH thanks; gratitude ← korean 합니다 -hamnida do; say; render
Words.Definition: (humorous) thank you; thanks

Words.Definition: a rag-and-bone man; a person who collects scraps and unwanted items (especially old newspapers, but also old clothes, radios, television sets, etc.) from households, then sells them for a profit in order to make a living
Words.Example: In what appeared to be a freak mishap, a mini-fridge being carried by a karung guni man fell three storeys, landed on an awning and then rolled off and hit a woman on a scooter.

Words.English Translation: → Tamil: காவடி kaavadi from tamil காவடி kaavadi burden; Kavadi (large ceremonial metal frame)
Words.Definition: a large, often well-decorated metal frame carried by Tamil Hindus during the festival of Thaipusam, which is lined with a hundred or so spears and needles which pierce the carrier’s skin
Words.Example: Each kavadi-bearer’s journey is unique. Murali Raj, who has been carrying kavadi for over a decade, shares his experience: “[I carried my] first kavadi 15 years ago – it was the spike kavadi. It’s not those small arch kavadis, it’s the one where you carry the whole figure, which is supported using the belt.”

Words.English Translation: → Malay: kaya from malay kaya sweet jam made of coconut, eggs, and sugar ✂ malay seri kaya sweet jam made of coconut, eggs, and sugar ← malay seri alteration of 'sari' ← malay sari essence; extract ← old javanese ꦱꦫꦶ sāri essence; extract; nectar ← sanskrit सार sā́ra essence; quintessence; nectar + malay kaya rich; wealthy; great
Words.Definition: a sweet jam made of coconut, eggs, and sugar, and usually flavoured with pandan. Several variations can be found, such as the greener, creamier Nyonya kaya and the dark brown, caramelized Hainanese kaya.
Words.Example: Enjoy 20 per cent discounts on any two of the following ... Pandan Kaya Fudge Loaf, Pandan Kaya with Gula Melaka Roll, Baby Pandan Chiffon and Pandan Golden Bahulu.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: kaya + English: toast from malay kaya sweet jam made of coconut, eggs, and sugar ✂ malay seri kaya sweet jam made of coconut, eggs, and sugar ← malay seri alteration of 'sari' ← malay sari essence; extract ← old javanese ꦱꦫꦶ sāri essence; extract; nectar ← sanskrit सार sā́ra essence; quintessence; nectar + malay kaya rich; wealthy; great + english toast slice of toasted bread ← old french toster toast bread ← latin tō̆stus scorched; roasted; toasted
Words.Definition: a traditional sandwich of kaya paired with thick slabs of butter between slices of toasted bread. Local chains often use traditional local sliced white bread without the crusts, which is much lighter and airier than commercial sliced bread, though this is not a necessary defining feature of the dish. It is often eaten with soft-boiled eggs and a cup of kopi or teh. The dish was created by Hainanese immigrants and popularized in coffee shops and kopitiams. It can be seen as a variation of roti bakar or roti kahwin, a genre of Malay sandwiches of toast with various spreads (usually consisting of kaya and another spread).
Words.Example: Yes, Vitamin D can be found in eggs, butter, and fortified foods ... So a breakfast of half-boiled eggs, kaya toast with butter and a glass of milk will start your day with a good helping of Vitamin D.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 家婆 poj: ke-pô from hokkien (poj) 家婆 ke-pô busybody; nosy; meddle; be nosy ← hokkien (poj) 家 ke home; family; house + hokkien (poj) 婆 pô grandmother
Words.Definition: to nose about; to be a busybody; to stick one's nose in others' business; to pry

Words.English Translation: → Malay: kayu from malay kayu wood

Mr Govindaswamy told the story of a traffic policeman who called a motorist a "kayu" after booking him ... Mr Chua had replied that if he was really innocent and preferred to pay the fine, he "must be really kayu"."How can the Minister use the word 'kayu'," Mr Govindaswamy retorted yesterday. "Is it a Parliamentary word?"
Related: char siew more use than you

Words.Example: Fortnightly visits slowly become weekly then daily. :( ... Very bad for the heart and wallet to fall into KC trap. :(

Words.English Translation: → Malay: ke belakang pusing from malay ke belakang pusing (mil. command, imp.) about turn; turn around 180 degrees ← malay ke to; towards + malay belakang back; rear + malay pusing spin; turn; pivot
Words.Definition: (military command, imperative) to turn around 180 degrees on the spot to face the rear; 'about turn'
Words.Example: Have you ever attempted a ke-belakang pusing (about-turn) on the move with your feet apart? That day, my knee caps stabbed two soldiers in their kidneys.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: ke kanan pusing from malay ke kanan pusing (mil. command, imp.) right turn; turn right 90 degrees ← malay ke to; towards + malay kanan right + malay pusing spin; turn; pivot
Words.Definition: (military command, imperative) to turn right 90 degrees on the spot; 'right turn'
Words.Example: Shanghai-born Wang Fang, 32, does not speak a word of Bahasa Indonesia. But shout the commands "kiri pusing" and "ke kanan pusing" ... and she will promptly turn left and right.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: ke kiri pusing from malay ke kiri pusing (mil. command, imp.) left turn; turn left 90 degrees ← malay ke to; towards + malay kiri left + malay pusing spin; turn; pivot

Words.Example: Here, commands in Malay like "Ke kiri pusing" (left turn) and "Ke kanan pusing" .(right turn) are the orders of the day. Students don't go from one class to another — they march.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: kebaya from malay kebaya traditional light blouse ← arabic قَبَايَة/قَبَاء qabāya/qabāʔ type of long-sleeved garment; gown ← middle persian kabāh cloak; gown; garment
Words.Definition: a light blouse traditionally worn by women in the Malay and Peranakan communities, usually well-decorated with embroidery or sequins and made of a lightweight or sheer fabric. It was held together with buttons or special ornate pins known as kerosang, and traditionally worn together with a sarong to form an outfit known as the sarong kebaya.
Words.Example: Mr Wong, who has been making Peranakan attire for more than a decade, declined to reveal the price of the shawl. He said it usually takes two to three months, for example, to make a custom kebaya ...

Words.English Translation: → Malay: buah kedondong from malay buah kedondong fruit of the tree Spondias dulcis or related Spondias spp.
Words.Definition: the edible fruit of Spondias dulcis, a tree native to Southeast Asia and the Pacific region. The fruits are egg-shaped and around 6 - 9 cm in length, and come in bunches of a dozen or more on a single stalk. They are good source of vitamins A, B, and C. They may be eaten raw, but are also commonly processed by pressing into a juice. The tree's leaves are sometimes used culinarily to impart a sour taste to dishes.[1][2][3]
Words.Example: Other kinds of fruits will be planted next year, including avocado, duku, langsat, rambai and kedondong.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 碱粽 鹼粽 poj: kiⁿ-chàng from hokkien (poj) 碱粽 鹼粽 kiⁿ-chàng alkaline glutinous rice dumplings ← hokkien (poj) 碱 鹼 kiⁿ sodium carbonate; alkali + hokkien (poj) 粽 粽 chàng glutinous rice dumpling wrapped in flat leaves
Words.Definition: a tetrahedral dumpling of glutinous rice wrapped in flat leaves (usually bamboo), usually plain, filled with a sweet paste such as tau sar, or stuffed with some other simple ingredients. The rice has a characteristic yellow colour due to the alkaline water used in its preparation, similar to e.g. yellow noodles. While it contains no meat, it is usually considered a type of bak chang.
Words.Example: ... traditionally popular picks — from the humble kee chang with chestnuts and salted egg yolk to the popular Nonya, Amoy and even Hong Kong varieties — continue to command long queues during the Dragon Boat Festival ...
