Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 假痟 poj: ké-siáu from hokkien (poj) 假痟 ké-siáu act crazy; pretend to be insane ← hokkien (poj) 假 ké fake; false; pretend; act + hokkien (poj) 痟 siáu crazy; mad; insane
Words.Definition: to act; to pretend; to feign

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 过瘾 過癮 poj: kè-giàn + Cantonese: 有瘾 有癮 jyutping: jau5 jan5 from hokkien (poj) 过瘾 過癮 kè-giàn satisfy a craving; enjoy oneself fully; get a kick out of sth. + cantonese (jyutping) 有瘾 有癮 jau5 jan5 satisfy a craving; enjoy oneself fully; get a kick out of sth.
Words.Definition: very interesting; to have a kick

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien / teochew: 激心 poj: kek-sim from hokkien / teochew (poj) 激心 kek-sim worried; distressed; heartbroken
Words.Definition: worried; anxious
Words.Example: "I don't need these, Por Por.""Aiyah, I kek sim only. Worry for you. You see shark, then how? Call me ah?"

Words.English Translation: → Malay: kelam-kabut from malay kelam-kabut chaotic; frantic; disorderly; confused
Words.Definition: (of a situation) chaotic; messy; disorderly; confused
Words.Example: The outdoor rave descended into a kelam-kabut-fest as a sudden downpour opened up upon the partygoers.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: Keling from malay Keling (derog., offensive) Indian; person of Indian descent ← sanskrit कलिङ्ग kaliṅga country or region in ancient India and its people
Words.Definition: (derogatory, offensive) ethnic slur for a person of Indian descent

Words.English Translation: → Malay: Keling + Min nan: 囝 poj: kiáⁿ from malay Keling (derog., offensive) Indian; person of Indian descent ← sanskrit कलिङ्ग kaliṅga country or region in ancient India and its people + min nan (poj) 囝 kiáⁿ son; child; dimin. suffix
Words.Definition: (derogatory, offensive) ethnic slur for a person of Indian descent

Words.English Translation: → Malay: kelong from malay kelong wooden offshore fishing platform; offshore fish trap; (slang) cheats; tricks
Words.Definition: a type of wooden offshore fishing platform common among the maritime cultures of South-East Asia, which may function as fisheries or even homes
Words.Example: For most of us, the image of a kelong ... is often associated with the region's past ... The reality of locally farmed seafood, sadly, is not something widely celebrated.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: kena from malay kena get; incur; receive; hit by; affected by
Words.Definition: (transitive) to get; to receive; to incur; to be hit by
Words.Example: But all that makes little difference to her real life: A working mum of three who drives an SUV, frets about whether she'll kena a parking ticket and fields phone calls from her hubby about who's going to pick up the kid from Kumon.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: kena + English: butter ↻ Hokkien: 抹牛油 poj: boah/boa̍h gû-iû from malay kena get; incur; receive; hit by; affected by + english butter condiment made from churning milk; to spread this condiment ← latin būtȳrum butter ← ancient greek βούτῡρον boútūron butter, (lit.) cow cheese ↻ hokkien (poj) 抹牛油 boah/boa̍h gû-iû (fig.) criticize; scold, (lit.) spread butter ← hokkien (poj) 抹 boah/boa̍h smear; spread + hokkien (poj) 牛油 gû-iû butter; beef tallow
Words.Definition: (euphemistic, idiom) to get scolded; to be criticized
Words.Example: But he himself also face pressure from his own superior becuz if system enhancement, new features, bugfixes cannot be rolled out he kena butter the butt. Then he no happy vent his anger on vendor. So depend you want to be in which position all kena buttered as well. Maybe some position buttered less some position buttered more.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: kena + makan from malay kena get; incur; receive + malay makan eat; consume
Words.Definition: to be taken advantage of; to be swindled
Words.Example: Cheese pies, who says buy more win more arh ?Knn, kena makan gao gao...Now must eat Cai peng - white rice lum lor with one veg only..... for whole month .

Words.English Translation: → Malay: kena + Hokkien: 屎 poj: sái from malay kena get; incur; receive; hit by; affected by + hokkien (poj) 屎 sái faeces; poop; excrement; bodily secretion; (vg.) shit; lousy; useless
Words.Definition: (vulgar) to be afflicted or affected by something unpleasant
Words.Example: But the ring, hor, acherly can make people very powderful. But then, hor, if you wear too long will also kena sai. Si beh hiong one, so better faster go and destroy it, lor.
Related: you die, I die, everybody die

Words.English Translation: → Teochew: 经 經 peng'im: gêng1 from teochew (peng'im) 经 經 gêng1 evade; shift responsibility; shirk
Words.Definition: to malinger; to feign sickness or injury
Words.Example: All you need to do is look to Reddit and forum threads, where many seek advice on how to "chao keng" or "down-PES" without having an actual medical condition. These guys only worsen the problem.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 弓蕉囝 poj: keng-chio-kiáⁿ from hokkien (poj) 弓蕉囝 keng-chio-kiáⁿ (pej.) Chinese person who is overly Westernized ← hokkien (poj) 弓蕉 keng-chio banana + hokkien (poj) 囝 kiáⁿ kid; child; fella
Words.Definition: (pejorative) a person of Chinese descent who speaks English well but has poor skills in Chinese languages, is only in touch with Western culture, and lives a Western lifestyle with Western tastes and values
Words.Example: I was your quintessential Anglo-Chinese School Chiak Kantang Kengchio Kia (potato-eating banana child)...

Words.Word: keng ka liao 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Singlish: keng + Hokkien: 甲 poj: kah + 了 poj: liáu from singlish keng malinger; feign sickness or injury; shirk responsibility ← teochew (peng'im) 经 經 gêng1 evade; shift responsibility; shirk + hokkien (poj) 甲 kah until; to the point of; to the extent that + hokkien (poj) 了 liáu finished; completed; to the end
Words.Definition: malingering at every opportunity; feigning sickness or injury to no end
Words.Example: There's this guy in my reservists battalion who everyone calls Mr. Keng Ka Liao. I don't even know his real name, but it can't possibly fit him better than that.

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: keng + king from singlish keng malinger; feign sickness or injury; shirk responsibility ← teochew (peng'im) 经 經 gêng1 evade; shift responsibility; shirk + singlish king (suffix, usu. sarcastic or pejorative) the epitome of sth. ← english king (usu. male) the ruler of a monarchy; a powerful or preeminent person
Words.Definition: someone who is always feigning sickness or injury; a serial malingerer
Words.Example: Within two weeks, the camp MO had already identified the keng kings of the batch and caught on to their antics.

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: keng + English: -ster from singlish keng malinger; feign sickness or injury; shirk responsibility ← teochew (peng'im) 经 經 gêng1 evade; shift responsibility; shirk + english -ster sb. who does or is associated with sth.
Words.Definition: someone who is always feigning sickness or injury; a serial malingerer
Words.Example: Within two weeks, the camp MO had already identified the keng kings of the batch and caught on to their antics.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: kentang from malay kentang potato ← javanese ꦏꦼꦤ꧀ꦛꦁ kenthang potato
Words.Definition: potato, the edible tuber of the Solanum tuberosum plant

Words.English Translation: → Malay: kena + Singlish: -z from malay kena get; incur; receive; hit by; affected by + singlish -z colloquializing suffix; used to add a quirky, silly, cool, or cute twang ← english -z (urban slang) suffix used to add a quirky, silly, cool, or cute twang
Words.Definition: (transitive) to get; to receive; to incur; to be hit by

Words.English Translation: → Malay: kepala + butuh from malay kepala head ← sanskrit कपाल kapā́la skull; cranium + malay butuh (vulgar) penis; (general insult)
Words.Definition: (vulgar) dickhead; idiot; general term of insult or abuse
Words.Example: Left toe, right toe, kepala butoh!

Words.English Translation: → Malay: kepala otak kau from malay kepala otak kau 'my ass'; 'my foot'; 'as if' ← malay kepala otak (derog.) head; brain ← malay kepala head ← sanskrit कपाल kapā́la skull; cranium + malay otak brain + malay kau (familiar) 2p. sing. pron.
Words.Definition: (rude) 'my ass'; 'my foot'; 'as if'; expression of disbelief, disagreement, disdain, disapproval, doubt, etc., used as a retort to something one thinks is highly exaggerated, unlikely, or untrue

Words.English Translation: → Malay: kerja keras from malay kerja keras work hard; hard work ← malay kerja work ← sanskrit कार्य kāryà work; act; business + malay keras hard; difficult; tough
Words.Definition: hard work
Words.Example: I am so proud of her, of how hard she works. I always tell her, this life is rewarding only for those who ‘kerja keras’. To fulfil dreams, hard and endless work is pertinent. No one will do your job for you. Hard work matters. They help you succeed in life.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: keropok from malay keropok fried crackers ← javanese ꦏꦿꦸꦥꦸꦏ꧀ krupuk fried crackers; crunchy flakes
Words.Definition: fried crackers eaten as snacks, appetizers, or as sides with meals. They may come in a wide variety of shapes, colours, sizes, ingredients, and flavours, such as belinjo nut, prawn, or fish.
Words.Example: Wang's current obsession for on-air chow-downs: A "random medley of snacks" like fish keropok and chunks of watermelon and papaya.

Words.English Translation: → Baba malay / malay: kerosang / kerongsang from baba malay / malay kerosang / kerongsang set of decorative brooches for fastening a kebaya ← portuguese coração heart
Words.Definition: a set of ornate, decorative brooches, often in a chain of three or five, used for fastening a kebaya
Words.Example: The best part about these modern kebayas is that you don't have to wear them with a kerosang ... because they come with buttons and pins.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: kesian from malay kesian pitiful; take pity ← malay kasihan pitiful; take pity
Words.Definition: pitiful; pitiable
Words.Example: Walao kesian sia the uncle his food got flipped.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: ketapang from malay ketapang Terminalia catappa
Words.Definition: Terminalia catappa (sometimes also known as Indian almond, beach almond, etc.), a tall tree with a wide crown that grows near bodies of water. Its leaves, when dried, are popular in the aquarium hobby, as they release tannins when steeped in water that have a calming and medicinal effect on Betta fish and some other species.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: ketuk from malay ketuk tap; rap; knock
Words.Definition: to convince or coax someone to pay for something, especially a meal

Words.English Translation: → Malay: ketupat from malay ketupat compressed rice wrapped and cooked in a pouch of woven palm leaves
Words.Definition: a traditional Malay dumpling of compressed rice wrapped and cooked in a square, pillow-shaped pouch of woven palm leaves (though modern versions may use plastic pouches instead). It is usually served by unwrapping the resulting dumpling and then cubing it into bite-sized pieces. It is eaten as an accompaniment to or ingredient of other dishes, such as satay or lontong, and is also associated with Malay cultural festivals, especially Hari Raya Puasa.
Words.Example: There will also be one-site workshop sessions to learn ketupat weaving, Jawi calligaphy as well as cooking demonstrations.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien / teochew: 敲 poj: khà from hokkien / teochew (poj) 敲 khà call (by phone, pager, etc.); knock; hit
Words.Definition: to call (by phone, pager, etc.); to telephone
Words.Example: Eh? Who kha me so many times ah? Must be scam call lah, I block the bugger.
Related: chiu kãna kha, kha kãna lam pa
kha kãna chiu, chiu kãna kha
chiu kana kha, kha kana lam pa
kha kana chiu, chiu kana kha

Words.English Translation: → Min nan: 尻川 poj: kha-chhng from min nan (poj) 尻川 kha-chhng butt; buttocks; anus ← min nan (poj) 尻 kha end of spine; coccyx or sacrum; buttocks + min nan (poj) 川 chhng creek; river
Words.Definition: butt; buttocks; backside
Words.Example: Depends on how many strokes bah. 1-3 strokes can still fully recover. those kena 24 strokes one... can change a new kar chng liao.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 跤 poj: kha + 敢若 poj: káⁿ-ná + 手 poj: chhiú from hokkien (poj) 跤 kha leg; foot + hokkien (poj) 敢若 káⁿ-ná like; be like; as if + hokkien (poj) 手 chhiú hand
Words.Definition: (idiom) clumsy; bumbling; lacking physical coordination

Words.Word: kha kana chiu, chiu kana kha
Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 跤 poj: kha + 敢若 poj: káⁿ-ná + 手 poj: chhiú from hokkien (poj) 跤 kha leg; foot + hokkien (poj) 敢若 káⁿ-ná like; be like; as if + hokkien (poj) 手 chhiú hand
Words.Definition: (idiom) lacking physical coordination; clumsy; bumbling

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 敲 poj: khà + English: pager from hokkien (poj) 敲 khà call (by phone, pager, etc.); knock; hit + english pager wireless electronic device used to receive and display messages ← english page call; contact; summon; young servant or attendant ← old french page young attendant ← late latin pagius servant + english -er suffix used to form a noun which performs the action of the root verb
Words.Definition: (dated) to page; to contact or leave a message by pager (or some other telecommunications device)
Words.Example: It is true. The handphone companies are getting Singaporeans to talk.And what are they saying on their handphones?... "Allo, who kah pager?"

Words.English Translation: → Min nan: 歁戆 歁戇 poj: gōng from min nan (poj) 歁戆 歁戇 gōng stupid; dull; dumb; simple-minded; stubborn; foolish
Words.Definition: stupid; dull; dumb; simple-minded; foolish
Words.Example: Why are you so cum gong? You clearly knew this wasn't the right path.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 孔 poj: kháng + 头 頭 poj: thâu from hokkien (poj) 孔 kháng hole; opening + hokkien (poj) 头 頭 thâu head
Words.Definition: an opportunity; a good deal; a source; a tip; an opening

Words.English Translation: → Min nan: 哭爸 poj: khàu-pē from min nan (poj) 哭爸 khàu-pē (vg.) complain (as if to one's father) ← min nan (poj) 哭 khàu cry; wail + min nan (poj) 爸 pē father
Words.Definition: to complain (as if a petulant child crying to one's father, or as if one's father has just died); to whine

Words.English Translation: → Min nan: 哭爸哭母 poj: khàu-pē-khàu-bú from min nan (poj) 哭爸哭母 khàu-pē-khàu-bú (vg.) complain (as if to one's father and mother) ← min nan (poj) 哭 khàu cry; wail + min nan (poj) 爸 pē father + min nan (poj) 哭 khàu cry; wail + min nan (poj / peng'im) 母 bú/bho2 mother
Words.Definition: (idiom) to complain (as if a petulant child crying to one's father and mother, or as if one's parents have just died); to whine; to complain to high heaven
Words.Example: Joo Chiat PAP activist Khartini Abdul Khalid had commented that Singaporeans "kao peh kao bu" ... because it shows they ultimately have faith that the PAP Government can solve problems and is trusted to do so responsibly.

Words.English Translation: → Min nan: 客 poj: kheh/khek from min nan (poj) 客 kheh/khek (lit.) 'guest'; subgroup of Chinese people with a wide historical dispersion, and their language, culture, etc.
Words.Definition: of or relating to the Hakka, a subgroup of Chinese people with a wide historical dispersion (now concentrated in and around Guangdong, Fujian, and Jiangxi in China, as well as in a diaspora all over the world), and their language, culture, background, etc.
Words.Example: Last Sunday at the World Book Fair 1997, the nanyang Khek Community Guild launched a CD-ROM titled The Hakkas: A Cultural And Historical Annotation Of The Guest People.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 起车 起車 poj: khí-chhia from hokkien (poj) 起车 起車 khí-chhia (euph.) die, (lit.) go up a car ← hokkien (poj) 起 起 khí go up; raise + hokkien (poj) 车 車 chhia car; land vehicle
Words.Definition: (euphemistic) to die; to pass away

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 起手 poj: khí-chhiú from hokkien (poj) 起手 khí-chhiú raise one's hand ← hokkien (poj) 起 khí go up; raise + hokkien (poj) 手 chhiú hand
Words.Definition: to raise one's hand; to put one's hand up
Words.Example: Who thinks that Singapore will be around for five more years? Khi chiu!

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 起痟 poj: khí-siáu from hokkien (poj) 起痟 khí-siáu go crazy; go mad ← hokkien (poj) 起 khí go up; raise + hokkien (poj) 痟 siáu crazy; go crazy
Words.Definition: to go crazy; to go mad

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 欠 poj: khiàm from hokkien (poj) 欠 khiàm owe; ask for; deserve
Words.Definition: to ask for; to deserve
Words.Example: it goes both ways, sometimes gotch cockanathan customers who really must kiam gan then they can seng mok. if is auntie really impatient type, then next time dun go buy from that stall lor.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 欠拍 poj: khiàm-phah from hokkien (poj) 欠拍 khiàm-phah need a beating ← hokkien (poj) 欠 khiàm owe; ask for; deserve ← hokkien (poj) 拍 phah hit; beat; whack
Words.Definition: (intransitive) to need a beating; to deserve to be hit
Words.Example: This cockanathan always act cute buay cute. Really khiam phah; someone needs to make him wake up his idea.

Words.Word: khiang tioh ho, mai keh khiang 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 勥着好, 莫假勥 勰著好, 莫假勰 poj: khiàng tio̍h hó, mài ké-khiàng from hokkien (poj) 勥着好, 莫假勥 勰著好, 莫假勰 khiàng tio̍h hó, mài ké-khiàng it is alright if one is clever and capable, but don't pretend to be when one is not ← hokkien (poj) 勥 勰 khiàng clever; capable; good at + hokkien (poj) 着 著 tio̍h then; followingly; once; as soon as + hokkien (poj) 好 好 hó good; alright; OK; well + hokkien (poj) 莫 莫 mài not want; don't; contraction of 毋愛 ← hokkien (poj) 毋爱 毋爱 m̄-ài not want; don't + hokkien (poj) 假勥 假勰 ké-khiàng act smart; be a smartass ← hokkien (poj) 假 假 ké fake; pretend; false + hokkien (poj) 勥 勰 khiàng clever; capable; good at
Words.Definition: (proverb) it is alright if one is clever and capable, but don't pretend to be when one is not; don't misplace your confidence
Words.Example: Just now I tell you turn left you got turn, good. But now I never say then you ownself turn, end up go the wrong way, must gostan. Listen what I say lah. Khiang tioh ho, mai keh khiang.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 跷跤 蹺跤 poj: khiau-kha from hokkien (poj) 跷跤 蹺跤 khiau-kha sit on a chair with one leg raised and the foot resting on the chair, or the leg resting on the other thigh to form a triangle shape ← hokkien (poj) 跷 蹺 khiau to raise or lift one's foot + hokkien (poj) 跤 跤 kha leg; foot
Words.Definition: to sit on a chair with one leg raised and the foot resting on the chair, or the leg resting on the other thigh to form a triangle shape
Words.Example: I always khiao kha at the kopitiam while I lim my morning teh cos liddat lagi song.

Words.Word: khiao kha yo lam pa 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 跷跤摇𡳞脬 蹺跤搖𡳞脬 poj: khiau-kha iô lām-pha from hokkien (poj) 跷跤摇𡳞脬 蹺跤搖𡳞脬 khiau-kha iô lām-pha (fig.) loaf about; have nothing to do, (lit.) sit with a leg up or with one leg resting on the other, shaking one's ballsack. ← hokkien (poj) 跷跤 蹺跤 khiau-kha sit on a chair with one leg raised and the foot resting on the chair, or the leg resting on the other thigh to form a triangle shape + hokkien (poj) 摇 搖 iô shake; swing; wiggle + hokkien (poj) 𡳞脬 𡳞脬 lām-pha (vulgar) scrotum; ballsack; balls
Words.Definition: (idiom) to have nothing better to do; to while away the time; to be idle; to sit around having too much free time on one's hands
Words.Example: I tried to be relatively productive while I was unemployed, going to the gym and such, but most days I just khiao kha yo lam pa.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 抾着 抾著 poj: khioh-tio̍h from hokkien (poj) 抾着 抾著 khioh-tio̍h grab; catch
Words.Definition: to grab or catch, especially a good opportunity or opening

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 扩 擴 poj: khok from hokkien (poj) 扩 擴 khok expand; protuberance; convex
Words.Definition: the distinctive forehead protuberance of the flowerhorn cichlid (luo han fish), properly known as its nuchal hump
Words.Example: Don't expect these females to grow a kok because females don't normally carry giant kok.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 炕肉 poj: khòng-bah from hokkien (poj) 炕肉 khòng-bah soya sauce braised pork belly ← hokkien (poj) 炕 khòng slow-cook or stew + hokkien (poj) 肉 bah meat
Words.Definition: a Hokkien dish of pork belly braised in a soya-sauce-based gravy, which is popularly eaten with rice or in buns
Words.Example: In well-prepared khong bak, the fat should be stewed until it literally melts in the mouth, but this was not the case with ours that day.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 炕肉包 poj: khòng-bah-pau from hokkien (poj) 炕肉包 khòng-bah-pau open steamed bun sandwich with a slice of braised pork belly ← hokkien (poj) 炕肉 khòng-bah soya sauce braised pork belly ← hokkien (poj) 炕 khòng slow-cook or stew + hokkien (poj) 肉 bah meat + hokkien (poj) 包 pau soft Chinese bun or bread, often with filling
Words.Definition: a Hokkien dish consisting of a slice of khong bak (pork belly braised in a soya-sauce-based gravy) sandwiched in an open steamed bun, sometimes with other ingredients such as vegetables or tau kwa
Words.Example: Bunz, another new concept, gives the traditional kong bak pau a modern twist. In place of fatty pork is low-fat chicken, which is guaranteed to melt in your mouth. And it's healthier too.

Words.Word: khong kha khiao 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 吭跤翘 吭跤翹 poj: khōng-kha-khiàu from hokkien (poj) 吭跤翘 吭跤翹 khōng-kha-khiàu fall over on one's back with one's legs in the air; (slang) die
Words.Definition: (euphemistic) to die; to pass away
Words.Example: The thought is scary. To perform for 50,000 people per night. To prepare for such an event, even Michael Jackson kong ka kiao. Not stress meh?

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 看 poj: khoàⁿ from hokkien (poj) 看 khoàⁿ look; see
Words.Definition: to look; to see
Words.Example: Eh, over there what thing ah? We go kaypoh khua khua a bit.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 看 poj: khoàⁿ + 侬 儂 poj: lâng from hokkien (poj) 看 khoàⁿ look; see + hokkien (poj) 侬 儂 lâng person; people; human being
Words.Definition: to judge or assess a person based on outward appearances or presentation, to determine e.g. their social standing, class, status, authority, wealth, character, etc.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 看 poj: khoàⁿ + English: midnight from hokkien (poj) 看 khoàⁿ see; look; watch + english midnight 00:00; the middle of the night
Words.Definition: to watch a midnight screening of a movie, show, play, etc.
Words.Example: Come all the way here kua midnight.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 看什物 poj: khoàⁿ sím-mi̍h from hokkien (poj) 看什物 khoàⁿ sím-mi̍h what [the hell] are you looking at; what are you staring at, (lit.) 'see what' ← hokkien (poj) 看 khoàⁿ see; look + hokkien (poj) 什物 sím-mi̍h what
Words.Definition: (rude) what [the hell] are you looking at; what are you staring for
Words.Example: Le kua si mi? My car more swee.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 看什物看 poj: khoàⁿ sím-mi̍h khoàⁿ from hokkien (poj) 看什物看 khoàⁿ sím-mi̍h khoàⁿ what [the hell] are you looking at; what are you staring for, (lit.) 'see what see' ← hokkien (poj) 看 khoàⁿ see; look + hokkien (poj) 什物 sím-mi̍h what + hokkien (poj) 看 khoàⁿ see; look
Words.Definition: (rude) what [the hell] are you looking at; what are you staring for; what's so nice to look at
Words.Example: Khoa si mi khoa? Kan ni na, stare some more I bloody come over hentam you.

Words.Word: khua si mi lan jiao 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 看 poj: khoàⁿ + 什物 poj: sím-mi̍h + 𡳞鸟 𡳞鳥 poj: lān-chiáu from hokkien (poj) 看 khoàⁿ look; see + hokkien (poj) 什物 sím-mi̍h what + hokkien (poj) 𡳞鸟 𡳞鳥 lān-chiáu penis
Words.Definition: (vulgar, rude) 'what the hell are you looking at'

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 款 poj: khóan from hokkien (poj) 款 khóan type; sort; kind
Words.Definition: type; sort; kind; ilk
Words.Example: Dunno…but their kuan like to ask until your ancestor name that kind.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 困 睏 poj: khùn from hokkien (poj) 困 睏 khùn sleep; nap
Words.Definition: to sleep
Words.Example: Some nights ... I fall asleep drooling on the keyboard. I wake up the next morning only to find a friend had left a message at 12:47am, saying, "brown? brown? Guess you koon liao. Bye."

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 吱吱咯咯 poj: ki-ki-ko̍k-ko̍k from hokkien (poj) 吱吱咯咯 ki-ki-ko̍k-ko̍k (onom.) sound of clattering, rattling, chattering, squeaking, etc.
Words.Definition: (onomatopoeic) a clattering, rattling, knocking, or other similar sound or action
Words.Example: My car left one year. I also changed mounting n front suspension … I want comfort. Don't like to hear ki ki Kok Kok sound.

Words.English Translation: → Min nan: 囝 poj: kiáⁿ from min nan (poj) 囝 kiáⁿ son; child; dimin. suffix
Words.Definition: child; kid
Words.Example: Don't be such a blur kia and anyhow follow people lah.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 行行 poj: kiâⁿ-kiâⁿ from hokkien (poj) 行行 kiâⁿ-kiâⁿ go for a walk; (lit.) 'walk-walk' ← hokkien (poj) 行 kiâⁿ walk
Words.Definition: to go out for a walk or stroll
Words.Example: On Sunday I go East Coast Park kiã kiã with my steady2.

Words.Word: kia lai kia khir 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Min nan: 行来行去 行來行去 poj: kiâⁿ-lâi-kiâⁿ-khì/khìr from min nan (poj) 行来行去 行來行去 kiâⁿ-lâi-kiâⁿ-khì/khìr walk to and fro; pace back and forth; move aimlessly around ← hokkien (poj) 行 行 kiâⁿ walk + hokkien (poj) 来 來 lâi come + hokkien (poj) 行 行 kiâⁿ walk + hokkien (poj) 去 去 khì/khìr go
Words.Definition: to walk to and fro; to pace back and forth; to move aimlessly around

Words.English Translation: → Min nan: 惊 驚 poj: kiaⁿ + 侬 儂 poj: lâng from min nan (poj) 惊 驚 kiaⁿ frighten; scare + min nan (poj) 侬 儂 lâng person
Words.Definition: scary; frightening; shocking
Words.Example: Sibei Kia Lang! If you guys go Malaysia, better only eat whole big fish and not fillets.

Words.Word: kia si lang 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Min nan: 惊 驚 poj: kiaⁿ + 死 poj: sí + 侬 儂 poj: lâng from min nan (poj) 惊 驚 kiaⁿ frighten; scare + min nan (poj) 死 sí death; die; to the death of + min nan (poj) 侬 儂 lâng person
Words.Definition: extremely scary; very very frightening
Words.Example: If the way you drive your Singapore-registered car is a rojak mix of kiasu, kiasi and kia si lang, with the ratio depending on individual competence and consideration behind the wheel, then you are truly a homegrown motorist.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 行 poj: kiâⁿ + Singlish: stead from hokkien (poj) 行 kiâⁿ walk + singlish stead go steady ← english go steady (inf; dated) date someone exclusively
Words.Definition: to begin an exclusive and committed relationship; to go steady
Words.Example: After paktoring for several months, they decided to kiã stead and commit to a more serious relationship.

Words.English Translation: → Min nan: 咸 鹹 poj: kiâm from min nan (poj) 咸 鹹 kiâm salty; stingy; miserly
Words.Definition: stingy; miserly; overly frugal
Words.Example: it goes both ways, sometimes gotch cockanathan customers who really must kiam gan then they can seng mok. if is auntie really impatient type, then next time dun go buy from that stall lor.

Words.English Translation: → Min nan: 咸菜 鹹菜 poj: kiâm-chhài from min nan (poj) 咸菜 鹹菜 kiâm-chhài pickled or salted vegetables; (fig.) crumpled; creased ← min nan (poj) 咸 鹹 kiâm salty + min nan (poj) 菜 菜 chhài vegetables
Words.Definition: a type of salted or pickled vegetable, especially (but not necessarily) made from Brassica juncea (mustard greens), used as an ingredient in many Chinese dishes such as soups or toppings to impart a salty, sour, and umami flavour
Words.Example: For most Singaporeans, mustard greens exist in the form of pickled vegetables or kiam chye, as it is known locally.

Words.English Translation: → Min nan: 咸鱼 鹹魚 poj: kiâm-hîr from min nan (poj) 咸鱼 鹹魚 kiâm-hîr salted dried fish ← min nan (poj) 咸 鹹 kiâm salty + min nan (poj) 鱼 魚 hîr fish
Words.Definition: salted dried fish, used as an ingredient in cooking
Words.Example: It has been steamed, curried, fried, grilled, given away and all but minced and made into kiam her, and I still have half a head in my freezer. Best fish we ever had.

Words.English Translation: → Min nan: 咸涩 鹹澀 poj: kiâm-siap from min nan (poj) 咸涩 鹹澀 kiâm-siap salty and astringent; stingy; miserly ← min nan (poj) 咸 鹹 kiâm salty; stingy; miserly + min nan (poj) 涩 澀 siap astringent; tart; stingy; miserly
Words.Definition: stingy; miserly; overly frugal
Words.Example: My friend Alex has become kiam siap following the currency crisis, and it's rubbing off on me.
Related: gor jiam dua kuay gu chia leng

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 悭 慳 poj: kian &/or 瘾 癮 poj: giàn from hokkien (poj) 悭 慳 kian greedy; covetous; stingy &/or hokkien (poj) 瘾 癮 giàn addicted; craving
Words.Definition: greedy; covetous

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 挠涂 撓塗 poj: kiáu-thô͘ from hokkien (poj) 挠涂 撓塗 kiáu-thô͘ dig mud, (derog.) Malay ← hokkien (poj) 挠 撓 kiáu dig + hokkien (poj) 涂 塗 thô͘ mud
Words.Definition: (derogatory, racist) a person of Malay ethnicity

Words.English Translation: → Min nan: 夹 夾 poj: kiap from min nan (poj) 夹 夾 kiap pinch; clamp; clip
Words.Definition: tongs; tweezers; any other tong-like tool used to grip or clamp objects
Words.Example: ... what better way to flaunt your command of the force than wielding a pair of these glowing LED chopsticks? ... Now you can slay the competition to kiap the plumpest piece of chicken on the dining table — almost as satisfying in our opinion.

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: kiap from singlish kiap pinch; clamp; clip; tongs ← min nan (poj) 夹 夾 kiap pinch; clamp; clip
Words.Definition: tongs; tweezers; any other tong-like tool used to grip or clamp objects

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: kiap + English: -er from singlish kiap pinch; clamp; clip; tongs ← min nan (poj) 夹 夾 kiap pinch; clamp; clip + english -er suffix used to form a noun which performs the action of the root verb
Words.Definition: tongs; tweezers; any other tong-like tool used to grip or clamp objects

Words.English Translation: → Min nan: 惊死 驚死 poj: kiaⁿ-sí from min nan (poj) 惊死 驚死 kiaⁿ-sí fear death; scared; cowardly ← min nan (poj) 惊 驚 kiaⁿ fear; be afraid of; frighten + min nan (poj) 死 死 sí die; death
Words.Definition: cowardly; scared; afraid of taking risks
Words.Example: People who know me know that I am quite kiasi. If I have a small symptom, I consult a doctor immediately, rather than rely on home remedies or off-the-shelf medicines.

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: kiasi + English: -ism from singlish kiasi fearing death; cowardly; sb. who fears death, is cowardly, or is risk-averse ← min nan (poj) 惊死 驚死 kiaⁿ-sí fear death; scared; cowardly ← min nan (poj) 惊 驚 kiaⁿ fear; be afraid of; frighten + min nan (poj) 死 死 sí die; death + english -ism suffix used to form a noun describing a tendency, ideology, behaviour, principle, etc. ← ancient greek ισμός -ismós suffix used to form abstract nouns
Words.Definition: a stereotypically Singaporean mindset of cowardliness, risk-aversion, fear of death, and a reluctance to take action when there may be perceived negative consequences
Words.Example: Singaporeans, chose to take it a step further — by imbibing our children with the virtues of the three Ks: kiasuism, kiasiism and caning.
Related: Sinkie pwn Sinkie, can sleep good tonight

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: kiasi + English: -ness from singlish kiasi fearing death; cowardly; sb. who fears death, is cowardly, or is risk-averse ← min nan (poj) 惊死 驚死 kiaⁿ-sí fear death; scared; cowardly ← min nan (poj) 惊 驚 kiaⁿ fear; be afraid of; frighten + min nan (poj) 死 死 sí die; death + english -ness suffixed to an adj. to form a noun meaning "having the quality or state of (the adj.)"
Words.Definition: the stereotypically Singaporean quality of cowardliness, risk-aversion, fear of death, and a reluctance to take action when there may be perceived negative consequences

Words.English Translation: → Min nan: 惊输 驚輸 poj: kiaⁿ-su from min nan (poj) 惊输 驚輸 kiaⁿ-su fear losing; scared of losing out ← min nan (poj) 惊 驚 kiaⁿ fear; be afraid of; frighten + min nan (poj) 输 輸 su lose; be defeated
Words.Definition: scared of losing out and being uncompetitive with others; selfish; overly-competitive to the point of stepping over others
Words.Example: She will go back to Malaysia to continue pre-university instead of going to a JC in Singapore. Well, at least she won't be in a kiasu environment anymore ... Actually, I think I would probably be less kiasu if I wasn't living and studying in this kiasu environment. It's hard not to be kiasu when everyone around you is ... maybe I'm not truly kiasu but just ambitious!

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: kiasu + English: -ism from singlish kiasu afraid to lose out; over-competitive ← min nan (poj) 惊输 驚輸 kiaⁿ-su fear losing; scared of losing out ← min nan (poj) 惊 驚 kiaⁿ fear; be afraid of; frighten + min nan (poj) 输 輸 su lose; be defeated + english -ism suffix used to form a noun describing a tendency, ideology, behaviour, principle, etc. ← ancient greek ισμός -ismós suffix used to form abstract nouns
Words.Definition: a stereotypically Singaporean mindset of overcompetitiveness, fear of losing out to others, selfishness, and wanting to get ahead of others at any cost
Words.Example: Kiasuism is not unique to Singapore; rather, it is a unique manifestation of any competitive society to excel economically.
Related: Sinkie pwn Sinkie, can sleep good tonight

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: kiasu + English: -ness from singlish kiasu afraid to lose out; over-competitive ← min nan (poj) 惊输 驚輸 kiaⁿ-su fear losing; scared of losing out ← min nan (poj) 惊 驚 kiaⁿ fear; be afraid of; frighten + min nan (poj) 输 輸 su lose; be defeated + english -ness suffixed to an adj. to form a noun meaning "having the quality or state of (the adj.)"
Words.Definition: the stereotypically Singaporean quality of overcompetitiveness, fear of losing out to others, selfishness, and wanting to get ahead of others at any cost
Words.Example: Hesitations about Singapore's "kiasuness" also were prevalent in the accounts of several women who did not want to educate their children in Singapore.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: kicap from malay kicap soya sauce ← hokkien (poj) 膎汁 kôe/kê-chiap/chap fish sauce ← hokkien (poj) 膎 kôe/kê preserved fish or seafood + hokkien (poj) 汁 chiap/chap sauce; juice

Words.English Translation: → Malay: kicap manis from malay kicap manis sweet dark soya sauce ← malay kicap soya sauce ← hokkien (poj) 膎汁 kôe/kê-chiap/chap fish sauce ← hokkien (poj) 膎 kôe/kê preserved fish or seafood + hokkien (poj) 汁 chiap/chap sauce; juice + malay manis sweet
Words.Definition: a type of thick, sweet soya sauce, usually made by mixing dark soya sauce with caramel, gula melaka, or brown sugar
Words.Example: The kicap manis-rubbed Cape Grim Angus (S$35) ... has lovely inflections of familiar Malay flavours with that perfect balance of lime, chillies and kicap manis to keep you diving in till the last slice.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: kilat from malay kilat lightning; quick as lightning, (slang) excellent; amazing; awesome
Words.Definition: excellent; amazing; awesome

Words.English Translation: → English: killer + litter from english killer sth. which kills + english litter rubbish; waste, esp. thrown or strewn around ← anglo-norman litere bedding; bed ← old french litiere bedding; bed ← latin lectuāria bedding; blanket

Words.English Translation: → Min nan: 金 poj: kim from min nan (poj) 金 kim gold; golden; money

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 金蕉囝 poj: kim-chio-kiáⁿ from hokkien (poj) 金蕉囝 kim-chio-kiáⁿ (pej.) Chinese person who is overly Westernized ← hokkien (poj) 金蕉 kim-chio banana + hokkien (poj) 囝 kiáⁿ kid; child; fella
Words.Definition: (pejorative) a person of Chinese descent who speaks English well but has poor skills in Chinese languages, is only in touch with Western culture, and lives a Western lifestyle with Western tastes and values

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 金纸 金紙 poj: kim-chóa from hokkien (poj) 金纸 金紙 kim-chóa hell money; joss paper ← hokkien (poj) 金 金 kim money; gold + hokkien (poj) 纸 紙 chóa paper
Words.Definition: hell money; joss paper; paper burned as offerings to ancestors or deities in traditional Chinese folk religion
Words.Example: The leftover traces of itinerant altars are not always visible, but when noticed, still juxtapose themselves strongly against their surroundings. In Figure 4.8A, we see a single sheet of kim zua resting on the grass, no doubt blown aside when its brethren were burnt.

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: kim from singlish kim gold; golden ← min nan (poj) 金 kim gold; golden; money
Words.Definition: gold; golden
Words.Example: And, if he is laughing, if his hair keem-keem, if he neh answers any questions, you will know who liao.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: kimak from malay kimak (vg.) mother’s vagina; motherfucker ✂ malay pukimak (vg.) mother’s vagina; motherfucker ← malay puki (vg.) vulva; vagina + malay mak mother

Words.Definition: (usually sarcastic or pejorative) someone that is the epitome of something; someone unbelievably outrageous
Words.Example: Wah, so relak ah, come to work in FBT and slipper. Really king sia you.

Words.English Translation: → English: King Kong from english King Kong eponymous character in the 1933 film King Kong and resulting media series ← english King title given to a male monarch; ruler + english Kong name coined for the 1933 movie King Kong
Words.Definition: (drink ordering) iced, with two scoops of ice cream or dollops of whipped cream, and topped with a scoop of the drink’s (usually Milo or Horlicks) powder. Equivalent to a Godzilla or dinosaur with the addition of the one or two scoops of cream or ice cream respectively.

Words.English Translation: → Min nan: 叫 poj: kiò from min nan (poj) 叫 kiò call; be called
Words.Definition: to be called; to be named

Words.English Translation: → English: keep + in + view from english keep maintain; hold on to + english in within; inside + english view sight ← anglo-norman vewe sight; seeing ← old french veue sight; seeing ← latin vidēre see; look out for
Words.Definition: to set aside for the time being; to table for future consideration

Words.English Translation: → English: Kiwi from english Kiwi Australian brand of shoe polish ← english kiwi flightless bird in the genus Apteryx endemic to New Zealand ← māori kiwi (likely onom.) flightless bird in the genus Apteryx endemic to New Zealand

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: kiã lai kiã khir from singlish kiã lai kiã khir walk to and fro; pace back and forth; walk around; explore ← min nan (poj) 行来行去 行來行去 kiâⁿ-lâi-kiâⁿ-khì/khìr walk to and fro; pace back and forth; move aimlessly around ← min nan (poj) 行 行 kiâⁿ walk + min nan (poj) 来 來 lâi come + min nan (poj) 行 行 kiâⁿ walk + min nan (poj) 去 去 khì/khìr go

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: kan ni na chao chee bai from singlish kan ni na chao chee bai (vg.) fuck your mother; excl. of anger, displeasure, frustration, contempt, etc. ← hokkien (poj) 奸恁娘母 姦恁娘母 kàn-ní-nâ-bú (vg.) fuck your mother ← hokkien (poj) 奸 姦 kàn (vg.) fuck + hokkien (poj) 恁 恁 lín you (pl.); y'all; your (sing. and pl.) ← hokkien (poj) 汝侬 汝儂 lí-nâng/lâng you people; y'all + hokkien (poj) 娘 娘 niâ mother; lady ← min nan (poj) 臭膣屄 臭膣屄 chhàu-chi-bai (vg., offensive) smelly cunt + min nan (poj) 臭 臭 chhàu smelly; repulsive; bad; detestable
