Related: kan ni na chao chee bai
kan ni na bu chao chee bai

Words.English Translation: → English: knock down + it from english knock down hit, such as to cause to fall ← english knock hit sharply + english down towards a lower position + english it 3p. neut. pron.; dummy pron.
Words.Definition: (NS, usually imperative) to get into a push-up position
Words.Example: "... Tomorrow morning, we're waking up early for some physical training! ... You need to be strong if you want to be a police officer! Now, knock it down!"

Words.English Translation: → English: you know from english you know filler or pause word; used to confirm understanding or agreement; used to imply sth. from context;
Words.Definition: used at the end of a sentence or statement for emphasis
Words.Example: Eh, don't sell now. Hear say the gahmen gonna increase the price again next year, know!

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: ka na sai from singlish ka na sai shitty; awful; shit ← hokkien (poj) 敢若 káⁿ-ná like; as if + hokkien (poj) 屎 sái faeces; poop; excrement; bodily secretion; (vg.) shit; lousy; useless
Words.Definition: (vulgar) abbreviation of ka na sai

Words.English Translation: → English: koi + biscuit from english koi ornamental breeds of Cyprinus rubrofuscus, the Amur carp ← japanese 鯉 コイ/こい koi carp + english biscuit small baked item; cookie ← old french bescuit twice-baked bread ← latin biscoctus twice-cooked ← latin bis twice; two times + latin coctus cook
Words.Definition: a pastry made from the same ingredients as the outer skin of a traditional mooncake, or effectively a mooncake without any fillings, which is molded into the shape of a koi. It is a popular snack that can be found at most local bakeries, especially during the Mooncake Festival season.

Words.English Translation: → English: koi + mooncake from english koi ornamental breeds of Cyprinus rubrofuscus, the Amur carp ← japanese 鯉 コイ/こい koi carp + english mooncake Chinese pastry with a sweet lotus paste or other filling, traditionally eaten during the Mid-Autumn Festival ↻ mandarin (pinyin) 月饼 月餅 yuè bǐng pastry with a sweet lotus paste or other filling, traditionally eaten during the Mid-Autumn Festival ← mandarin (pinyin) 月 月 yuè moon + mandarin (pinyin) 饼 餅 bǐng pastry; cookie; biscuit
Words.Definition: a pastry made from the same ingredients as the outer skin of a traditional mooncake, or effectively a mooncake without any fillings, which is molded into the shape of a koi. It is a popular snack that can be found at most local bakeries, especially during the Mooncake Festival season.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 啯 嘓 poj: kho̍k/ko̍k/kok from hokkien (poj) 啯 嘓 kho̍k/ko̍k/kok (onom.) knocking sound; hit; knock
Words.Definition: (onomatopoeic) a knocking sound
Words.Example: Walao eh. My new buddy is such a cock. He always forget this forget that, end up getting both of us in trouble.

Words.English Translation: → Tamil: கொலைவெறி kolaiveṟi from tamil கொலைவெறி kolaiveṟi savage anger; murderous rage; bloodthirstiness; fury ← tamil கொலை kolai murder; killing; tormenting + tamil வெறி veṟi anger; fury; intoxication; frenzy; madness; savagery
Words.Definition: anger; rage; fury; madness

Words.English Translation: → Cantonese / hakka: 干捞面 乾撈麵 jyutping: gon1 lou1 min6 from cantonese / hakka (jyutping) 干捞面 乾撈麵 gon1 lou1 min6 Sarawakian noodle dish ← cantonese / hakka (jyutping) 干 乾 gon1 dry + cantonese / hakka (jyutping) 捞 撈 lou1 mix; stir + cantonese / hakka (jyutping) 面 麵 min6 wheat noodles
Words.Definition: a Sarawakian dish of egg noodles tossed in lard or shallot oil, usually topped with minced pork, sliced char siew, fried shallots, garlic, white pepper, fish and soya sauce, served with a bowl of soup on the side. It often includes other ingredients depending on who is preparing the dish, and may also be made in a halal version. It is said to derive from a similar Hakka noodle dish known as yam mian.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: konek from malay konek (vg.) penis; child's penis
Words.Definition: (vulgar) penis

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 讲 講 poj: kóng from hokkien (poj) 讲 講 kóng speak; talk; say
Words.Definition: to speak; to talk; to say
Words.Example: Eh, kong simple English lah. Don't try to throw smoke at me by using all these cheemologies.

Words.Word: kong jiao wei 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 讲鸟话 講鳥話 poj: kóng chiáu ōe from hokkien (poj) 讲鸟话 講鳥話 kóng chiáu ōe talk rubbish; spout nonsense ✂ hokkien (poj) 讲𡳞鸟话 講𡳞鳥話 kóng lān-chiáu ōe (vg.) talk rubbish; spout nonsense ← hokkien (poj) 讲 講 kóng speak; say; talk + hokkien (poj) 𡳞鸟 𡳞鳥 lān-chiáu (vg.) penis; cock + hokkien (poj) 话 話 ōe speech; words; language
Words.Definition: to talk rubbish; to spout nonsense
Words.Example: They kong jiao wei one ... u ever wonder why they lunchtime jiak salad and fish soup but still dino size?
Related: talk cock sing song play ping pong
ka ki kong, ka ki song

Words.English Translation: → Likely, but other possible etymologies exist Min nan: 公馆 公館 poj: kong-koán from min nan (poj) Likely, but other possible etymologies exist 公馆 公館 kong-koán public hall; Chinese club or association ← min nan (poj) 公 kong grand; great + min nan (poj) 馆 館 koán building; office
Words.Definition: a type of Teochew and Hokkien percussion band consisting of instruments such as gongs and drums, which traditionally plays at cultural, religious, and other important events such as funerals, Chinese New Year, etc.
Words.Example: Although the local funeral industry has continued to evolve and modernise, traditional rituals remain common. Pictured here is one such ceremony led by a “gong guan” troupe, and it involves the loud banging of cymbals and drums.

Words.Word: kong lan jiao wei 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 讲𡳞鸟话 講𡳞鳥話 poj: kóng lān-chiáu ōe from hokkien (poj) 讲𡳞鸟话 講𡳞鳥話 kóng lān-chiáu ōe (vg.) talk rubbish; spout nonsense ← hokkien (poj) 讲 講 kóng speak; say; talk + hokkien (poj) 𡳞鸟 𡳞鳥 lān-chiáu (vg.) penis; cock + hokkien (poj) 话 話 ōe speech; words; language
Words.Definition: (vulgar) to talk rubbish; to spout nonsense
Words.Example: kong lan wei lah, do a proper 2 yr full time + 3+7 cycle NS + mob & IPPT then come back and talk to me

Words.Word: kong si mi 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 讲 講 poj: kóng + 什物 poj: sím-mi̍h from hokkien (poj) 讲 講 kóng speak; talk; say + hokkien (poj) 什物 sím-mi̍h what
Words.Definition: expression of confusion, doubt, incredulity, disagreement, etc., especially in response to someone saying something confusing, nonsensical, ridiculous, irrelevant, or untrue; 'what are you saying?'; 'what are you talking about?'
Words.Example: The boy stared back at him, nonplussed, with a huh, le kong si mi or huh, what you talking look. His jaw hung a little lower and his eyebrows were raised a little higher.

Words.Word: kong si mi lan jiao 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 讲 講 poj: kóng + 什物 poj: sím-mi̍h + 𡳞鸟 𡳞鳥 poj: lān-chiáu from hokkien (poj) 讲 講 kóng speak; talk; say + hokkien (poj) 什物 sím-mi̍h what + hokkien (poj) 𡳞鸟 𡳞鳥 lān-chiáu penis
Words.Definition: expression of confusion, doubt, incredulity, disagreement, etc., especially in response to someone saying something confusing, nonsensical, ridiculous, irrelevant, or untrue; 'what are you saying?'; 'what are you talking about?'
Words.Example: you kong si mi lan jiao? I'm here askin for help and you say what guy got caught for f?

Words.Word: kong wu kong bo 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 讲有讲无 講有講無 poj: kóng-ū-kóng-bô from hokkien (poj) 讲有讲无 講有講無 kóng-ū-kóng-bô speak nonsense; keep contradicting oneself; beat around the bush ← hokkien (poj) 讲 講 kóng say; talk; speak + hokkien (poj) 有 有 ū have; exists; there is + hokkien (poj) 讲 講 kóng say; talk; speak + hokkien (poj) 无 無 bô no; not have; don't
Words.Definition: to speak vaguely, unclearly, and in nonsensical circles; to keep contradicting oneself; to be ridiculous, argumentative, and difficult; to beat around the bush
Words.Example: knn kong wu kong bo but didn't address why is there no chair for the mak cik

Words.English Translation: → Likely, but other possible etymologies exist English: cop from english Likely, but other possible etymologies exist cop take; steal
Words.Definition: to steal; to take without asking permission

Words.English Translation: → Malay: kopi + Hokkien / teochew: 咖啡 poj: ko-pi from malay kopi coffee ← dutch koffie coffee ← italian caffè coffee ← ottoman turkish قهوه kahve coffee ← arabic قَهْوَة qahwa coffee + hokkien / teochew (poj) 咖啡 ko-pi coffee ← malay kopi coffee
Words.Definition: coffee (in general)
Words.Example: ... the initiative includes messages such as "Remember to take a kopi (coffee) break whenever you feel sleepy".

Words.English Translation: → Malay: kopi + Hokkien / teochew: 咖啡 poj: ko-pi + Min nan / cantonese: 搀/掺 攙/摻 poj: chham from malay kopi coffee ← dutch koffie coffee ← italian caffè coffee ← ottoman turkish قهوه kahve coffee ← arabic قَهْوَة qahwa coffee + hokkien / teochew (poj) 咖啡 ko-pi coffee ← malay kopi coffee + min nan / cantonese (poj) 搀/掺 攙/摻 chham mix; blend; add impurities
Words.Definition: kopi (Nanyang-style coffee) mixed with teh
Words.Example: Kopi Cham is a beloved beverage that perfectly embodies the multicultural essence of Singapore and Malaysia ... Originally created by innovative kopitiam (coffee shop) owners in the mid-20th century, Kopi Cham quickly became a staple in the local coffee culture.

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: kopi + kaki from singlish kopi coffee ← hokkien / teochew (poj) 咖啡 ko-pi coffee ← malay kopi coffee & malay kopi coffee ← dutch koffie coffee ← italian caffè coffee ← ottoman turkish قهوه kahve coffee ← arabic قَهْوَة qahwa coffee + singlish kaki friend; buddy; close companion who one does a shared activity together with; buddy with a common interest or passion ← malay kaki sb. who is fond of or good at sth.; lover of sth.; leg; foot & singlish ka ki nang one of us; one of our own; people in one's circle; friends and family ← teochew / hainanese / min nan (peng'im) 家己侬 家己儂 ga1 gi7 nang5 one of us; one of our own; close companions; sb. in one's circle
Words.Definition: a close buddy or companion who one regularly drinks coffee (or other common kopitiam drinks) with

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien / teochew: 咖啡 poj: ko-pi + 囝 poj: kiáⁿ from hokkien / teochew (poj) 咖啡 ko-pi coffee ← malay kopi coffee ← dutch koffie coffee ← italian caffè coffee ← ottoman turkish قهوه kahve coffee ← arabic قَهْوَة qahwa coffee + hokkien / teochew (poj) 囝 kiáⁿ son; child; dimin. suffix
Words.Definition: a coffee boy; a child or young person who serves coffee, other drinks, and food items to patrons at a kopitiam
Words.Example: Mr Lim Bee Huat is the "kopi kia" (coffee boy) who had big dreams. At nine, he worked at a coffee shop after school, learning the secrets of the trade ... Now reagrded as the "Kopitiam King", Mr Lim is the managing director of Kopitiam Investment Pte Ltd.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien / teochew: 咖啡 poj: ko-pi + 镭 鐳 poj: lui ↻ Malay: duit kopi from hokkien / teochew (poj) 咖啡 ko-pi coffee ← malay kopi coffee ← dutch koffie coffee ← italian caffè coffee ← ottoman turkish قهوه kahve coffee ← arabic قَهْوَة qahwa coffee + hokkien / teochew (poj) 镭 鐳 lui money; coins ← malay duit money; a doit ← dutch duit doit, a Dutch copper coin historically worth 1/8 of a stiver or 1/160 of a guilder; (inf.) money ↻ malay duit kopi monetary bribe ← malay duit money; a doit ← dutch duit doit, a Dutch copper coin historically worth 1/8 of a stiver or 1/160 of a guilder; (inf.) money + malay kopi coffee ← english coffee drink made by infusing beans of the genus Coffea in water
Words.Definition: (euphemism) a monetary bribe, usually paid to a corrupt official or authority, said to be enough for the receiving party to buy a cup of kopi with
Words.Example: M'sia police investigating alleged 'kopi lui' case involving 2 S'pore cars & S$170

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: kopi + English: money ↻ Malay: duit kopi from singlish kopi coffee ← hokkien / teochew (poj) 咖啡 ko-pi coffee ← malay kopi coffee & malay kopi coffee ← dutch koffie coffee ← italian caffè coffee ← ottoman turkish قهوه kahve coffee ← arabic قَهْوَة qahwa coffee + english money cash; currency; legally accepted means of quantifying and exchanging wealth ← anglo-norman muneie money; coins ← latin monēta mint; money; coins ← latin Monēta Italian goddess of the mint ↻ malay duit kopi monetary bribe ← malay duit money; a doit ← dutch duit doit, a Dutch copper coin historically worth 1/8 of a stiver or 1/160 of a guilder; (inf.) money + malay kopi coffee ← english coffee drink made by infusing beans of the genus Coffea in water
Words.Definition: (euphemism) a monetary bribe, usually paid to a corrupt official or authority, said to be enough for the receiving party to buy a cup of kopi with
Words.Example: Nearer home, it is known as kopi money. Whatever word is used, it means the same thing: Money that oils the palm to get a deal through, whether it is to get something through customs or to climch a multi-million dollar contract.

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: kopi + Malay: susu from singlish kopi coffee ← hokkien / teochew (poj) 咖啡 ko-pi coffee ← malay kopi coffee & malay kopi coffee ← dutch koffie coffee ← italian caffè coffee ← ottoman turkish قهوه kahve coffee ← arabic قَهْوَة qahwa coffee + malay susu milk; breast
Words.Definition: (metaphor) a homogeneous and harmonious mixture of various different elements
Words.Example: Although the different races here have grown closer over time, Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong does not think Singapore will ever become a kopi susu nation. As with the world, there are different races and religions here, so people must not pretend they are not there, ... ‘We can make progress but to make it one country, completely homogenised, stirred together like kopi susu, I don't think that's going to happen.’ ...

Words.English Translation: → Malay: kopi & Hokkien / teochew: 咖啡 poj: ko-pi + English: toast from malay kopi coffee ← dutch koffie coffee ← italian caffè coffee ← ottoman turkish قهوه kahve coffee ← arabic قَهْوَة qahwa coffee & hokkien / teochew (poj) 咖啡 ko-pi coffee ← malay kopi coffee + english toast slice of toasted bread ← old french toster toast bread ← latin tō̆stus scorched; roasted; toasted
Words.Definition: the classic Singaporean breakfast combination of a cup of Nanyang coffee (kopi) paired with kaya toast, also known as a Nanyang breakfast
Words.Example: a hidden gem located at Boon Lay industrial area is an American-styled café serving a variety range of fabulous western cuisine , local curry rice / noodles , kopi toast set and unique desserts at affordable prices ...

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: kopi + -cino from singlish kopi coffee ← hokkien / teochew (poj) 咖啡 ko-pi coffee ← malay kopi coffee & malay kopi coffee ← dutch koffie coffee ← italian caffè coffee ← ottoman turkish قهوه kahve coffee ← arabic قَهْوَة qahwa coffee + singlish -cino made w. a base of milk, or condensed milk and water, w. the preceding drink layered on top ✂ italian cappuccino espresso coffee with steamed or frothed milk, so named due to dark brown colour resembling Capuchin monks' habits ← german Kapuziner Capuchin (monk of the Capuchin order) ← italian [frate] cappuccino Capuchin (monk of the Capuchin order) ← italian cappuccio hood; monk's cowl ← italian -ino suffix used to indicate a profession or form a diminutive
Words.Definition: a base of frothed milk, or frothed condensed milk and water, with sweetened black coffee layered on top in a milk-coffee ratio of around 1:1. The drink is served with the layers of milk and coffee not fully mixed. It may be seen as a local variant of the Italian cappuccino.

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: kopi + O + English: licence from singlish kopi coffee ← hokkien / teochew (poj) 咖啡 ko-pi coffee ← malay kopi coffee & malay kopi coffee ← dutch koffie coffee ← italian caffè coffee ← ottoman turkish قهوه kahve coffee ← arabic قَهْوَة qahwa coffee + singlish O (drink ordering) black ← hokkien / teochew (poj/peng'im) 乌 烏 o͘/ou1 black; dark + english licence legal permission to do sth.; freedom to do sth, esp. when it is not normal practice
Words.Definition: a driving licence obtained by bribing the driving examiner with money, said to be enough for them to buy a cup of kopi-O with
Words.Example: Driving schools have been warned not to participate in illegal 'kopi-O' driving licence issuance, or face instant revocation of their licences if caught.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 咖啡店 poj: ko-pi-tiàm from hokkien (poj) 咖啡店 ko-pi-tiàm type of local food centre with multiple stalls selling various foods and drinks ← hokkien (poj) 咖啡 ko-pi coffee ← malay kopi coffee ← dutch koffie coffee ← italian caffè coffee ← ottoman turkish قهوه kahve coffee ← arabic قَهْوَة qahwa coffee + hokkien (poj) 店 tiàm shop; store
Words.Definition: a type of local food centre with multiple stalls selling various foods and drinks, commonly found in Singapore and Malaysia. It is distinct from a hawker centre in that it is usually privately owned and smaller, with only around 3 - 12 stalls in a single L- or U-shaped arrangement. However, the term is sometimes extended to refer to much larger establishments, such as food courts.
Words.Example: Drop by the Repair Kopitiam, and you won't see coffee shop uncles indulging in their daily kopi and kaya toast. In fact, the kopitiam isn't even located in a coffee shop.

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: kopi + English: copium from singlish kopi coffee ← hokkien / teochew (poj) 咖啡 ko-pi coffee ← malay kopi coffee & malay kopi coffee ← dutch koffie coffee ← italian caffè coffee ← ottoman turkish قهوه kahve coffee ← arabic قَهْوَة qahwa coffee + english copium metaphorical narcotic taken to delude oneself into denying or coping with an undesirable situation ← english cope deal with sth. ← french couper cut; chop off + english opium narcotic made from poppy ← latin opium opium; poppy juice ← ancient greek ὄπῐον ópĭon opium; poppy juice
Words.Definition: a metaphorical narcotic taken to delude oneself into denying, coping with, or detaching oneself from the reality of an undesirable situation
Words.Example: - Can buy kopi with exposure?- Kopium certainly

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 哥 poj: ko͘ from hokkien (poj) 哥 ko͘ elder brother
Words.Definition: elder brother; a term of address or endearment for an elder brother or male cousin

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 哥哥 poj: ko͘-ko͘ from hokkien (poj) 哥哥 ko͘-ko͘ elder brother
Words.Definition: elder brother; a term of address or endearment for an elder brother
Words.Example: Natalie flung herself into her mother and wailed. "Kor Kor is tweatening me! Kor Kor hit me."

Words.English Translation: → Min nan: 孤独 孤獨 poj: ko͘-ta̍k from min nan (poj) 孤独 孤獨 ko͘-ta̍k unfriendly; unsociable; selfish; stingy; petty; weird
Words.Definition: (pejorative) unfriendly; unsociable; selfish; unneighbourly; individualistic
Words.Example: i think yx can be considered gor tak. haha! She is not one of those who will naturally go to others to play. Unlike CE, who is ever friendly.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: korban from malay korban ritual sacrifice, esp. of an animal on Eid al-Adha; sacrificial victim ← arabic قُرْبَان qurbān sacrifice; sacrificial victim ← aramaic קורבנא qurbānā offering; sacrifice
Words.Definition: the ritual sacrifice of an animal by Muslims during Hari Raya Haji (Hari Raya Aidiladha)
Words.Example: Meanwhile, efforts were being made to ensure that the Korban carried on as scheduled, even though 121 sheep imported from Ireland for the rites died on the way to Singapore, due to heat stress.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: kosong from malay kosong empty; zero; vacant
Words.Definition: (of food) plain; without any additional ingredients or toppings
Words.Example: My coffee shop aunty has her own jargon, which the patrons understand. She would shout "kopi C, kopi sua, tak kiu kosong" across the tables when she takes orders.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: konek from malay konek tail; (vg.) penis
Words.Definition: (vulgar) penis

Words.English Translation: → Malay: koyak from malay koyak tear; ripped apart
Words.Definition: spoilt; broken; out of order; damaged
Words.Example: I think Indonesia must be smiling now ... Because of this haze, all the Malaysian and Singaporean athletes might go to Jakarta with 'koyak' lungs ... !

Words.English Translation: → Malay: koyok from malay koyok medicinal patch; nonsense; drivel ← min nan / hakka (poj) 膏药 膏藥 ko-io̍h medicinal patch; poultice ← min nan / hakka (poj) 膏 膏 ko oil; ointment; cream; paste + min nan / hakka (poj) 药 藥 io̍h medicine
Words.Definition: a fake or fraudulent item; something falsely presented as authentic or of high quality
Words.Example: What I want to tell him is that if our proposal is koyok, it's because the PAP's policies have given the people aches and pains ...

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: khao peh from singlish khao peh (vg.) complain (as if to one's father) ← min nan (poj) 哭爸 khàu-pē (vg.) complain (as if to one's father) ← min nan (poj) 哭 khàu cry; wail + min nan (poj) 爸 pē father
Words.Definition: Initialism of khao peh.

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: khao peh khao bu from singlish khao peh khao bu (vg.) complain (as if to one's father and mother) ← min nan (poj) 哭爸哭母 khàu-pē-khàu-bú (vg.) complain (as if to one's father and mother) ← min nan (poj) 哭 khàu cry; wail + min nan (poj) 爸 pē father + min nan (poj / peng'im) 哭 khàu cry; wail + min nan (poj) 母 bú/bho2 mother
Words.Definition: Initialism of khao peh khao bu.

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: kaypoh from singlish kaypoh busybody; nosy; meddle; be nosy ← hokkien (poj) 家婆 ke-pô busybody; nosy; meddle; be nosy ← hokkien (poj) 家 ke home; family; house + hokkien (poj) 婆 pô grandmother
Words.Definition: abbreviation of kaypoh
Words.Example: Aiyoh why the couple so kpo? What’s wrong with eating alone even on Xmas?

Words.English Translation: → Min nan: 韭菜 poj: gau2 coi3 from min nan (poj) 韭菜 gau2 coi3 Allium tuberosum, a.k.a. garlic chives ← min nan (poj) 韭 gau2 Allium tuberosum + min nan (poj) 菜 coi3 a.k.a. garlic chives; leek
Words.Definition: Allium tuberosum (also known as garlic chives), a plant in the same family as garlic, chives, and onions whose long, green leaves and flower buds are commonly used as a vegetable in Chinese cuisine
Words.Example: Appetisers include snails ku chye ($12++ for half dozen), snails wrapped in wanton skin, laced with ku chye ...

Words.Word: ku ku bird /ku˨ ku˧ t͡sjɑʊ˦˨/, [t͡ɕjɑʊ˦˨] 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 咕咕鸟 咕咕鳥 poj: ku-kú-chiáu + English: bird from hokkien (poj) 咕咕鸟 咕咕鳥 ku-kú-chiáu (childish) penis, especially that of a young boy ← hokkien (poj) 咕咕 咕咕 ku-ku (onom.) dove or other bird's cry; (fig., childish) penis, especially that of a young boy + hokkien (poj) 鸟 鳥 chiáu bird + english bird (slang) penis
Words.Definition: (childish, vulgar) a penis, especially that of a young boy

Words.Word: ku ku jiao 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 咕咕鸟 咕咕鳥 poj: ku-kú-chiáu from hokkien (poj) 咕咕鸟 咕咕鳥 ku-kú-chiáu (childish) penis, especially that of a young boy ← hokkien (poj) 咕咕 咕咕 ku-ku (onom.) dove or other bird's cry; (fig., childish) penis, especially that of a young boy + hokkien (poj) 鸟 鳥 chiáu bird
Words.Definition: (childish, vulgar) a penis, especially that of a young boy

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 瓜子 poj: koa/koe-chí from hokkien (poj) 瓜子 koa/koe-chí melon seed; edible seed eaten as a snack ← hokkien (poj) 瓜 koa/koe melon; gourd + hokkien (poj) 子 chí seed
Words.Definition: any edible dried seed (usually from a melon such as a watermelon, but also pumpkin, sunflower, etc.) consumed as a snack
Words.Example: My mother would buy red kuachi for Chinese New Year because of the auspicious colour ... I was not fond of kuachi. Besides, nibbling kuachi is a girl's thing like embroidering patterns on pillowcases.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: kuah from malay kuah sauce; gravy; broth; dressing
Words.Definition: (in general) sauce; gravy; broth; dressing; any liquid condiment which is eaten with food

Words.English Translation: → Min nan: 乖囝 poj: koai-kiáⁿ from min nan (poj) 乖囝 koai-kiáⁿ good kid ← min nan (poj) 乖 koai well-behaved; obedient + min nan (poj) 囝 kiáⁿ kid; child
Words.Definition: a good kid; a well-behaved child
Words.Example: You know lah, Orchard Plaza is clueless to me cos I kuai kia don't go there chiong one. And I didn't know there's a legendary Nasi Lemak stall there, opened since 1986.

Words.English Translation: → Likely, but other possible etymologies exist Hokkien: kua-sa poj: kua-sa from hokkien (poj) Likely, but other possible etymologies exist kua-sa kua-sa bequeath; will; transfer of assets ← malay kuasa power; authority ← sanskrit वश váśa power; authority ✂ malay / indonesian [surat] kuasa [letter of] attorney or authority ↻ dutch volmacht [brief] [letter of] attorney or authority
Words.Definition: a will; a last testament
Words.Example: Had she not been ignorant of wills and trust, Grandma Tan would not have resorted to the practice of kuasa and lose control of her house as well as her wish as to who would be rightful beneficiary of her most precious asset.

Words.English Translation: → Tamil: குச்சி kucci from tamil குச்சி kucci stick; sprig
Words.Definition: tiny; small; insignificant

Words.English Translation: → Malay: kucing kurap from malay kucing kurap mangy, unwanted stray cat ← malay kucing cat + malay kurap ringworm
Words.Definition: (metaphor, derogatory) unwanted; useless; worthless; looked down upon
Words.Example: S-League is kucing kurap stuff, who wants to bet? The standard is so unpredictable ...

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 粿 poj: kóe + Malay: kuih from hokkien (poj) 粿 kóe steamed cake made from rice flour or glutinous rice flour + malay kuih small snack cakes, biscuits, confectioneries etc. ← hokkien (poj) 粿 kóe steamed cake made from rice flour or glutinous rice flour
Words.Definition: any of various small traditional snack cakes, biscuits, confectioneries etc., often (but not always) sweet and brightly coloured, which are found in various forms in Chinese, Peranakan, Malay, Tamil, and almost all other Singaporean and surrounding regional cuisines
Words.Example: Meet Nick Soon, a kueh evangelist whose tiny stall in Berseh Food Centre has transformed the humble soon kueh, gu chye kueh (chive dumpling) and png kueh (rice dumpling).

Words.English Translation: → Malay: kuih + Indonesian / malay: Ambon from malay kuih small snack cakes, biscuits, confectioneries etc. ← hokkien (poj) 粿 kóe steamed cake made from rice flour or glutinous rice flour + indonesian / malay Ambon island and city in Maluku, Indonesia ← ambonese malay ombong dew[1]
Words.Definition: variant of kueh bingka ambon

Words.English Translation: → Malay: kuih + baulu/bahulu from malay kuih small snack cakes, biscuits, confectioneries etc. ← hokkien (poj) 粿 kóe steamed cake made from rice flour or glutinous rice flour + malay baulu/bahulu type of small, soft or crumbly snack cake ← kristang bolu cake ← portuguese bolo cake ← portuguese bola ball; sphere ← old occitan bola ball; sphere ← latin bulla bubble; bubble-shaped object
Words.Definition: a type of small snack cake made of flour, eggs, sugar, and a leavening agent, popularly eaten during festive seasons such as Hari Raya Puasa and Chinese New Year. They are similar in size to a madeleine, and may come in various shapes, with the most common being that of a fluted dome (i.e. the classic jelly dome shape). They may be crumbly and stiff, or soft and spongy, depending on preparation.
Words.Example: When we were young, the grown-ups would sit around a stove with a fan in one hand and a towel in the other for the sweat to bake the toothsome kueh bahulu. Once the freshly baked kueh bahulu were ready, the kids would immediately stop whatever games they were playing and rush forward to pop a piece in their mouths.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: kuih + bangkit from malay kuih small snack cakes, biscuits, confectioneries etc. ← hokkien (poj) 粿 kóe steamed cake made from rice flour or glutinous rice flour + malay bangkit rise; rise up; get up
Words.Definition: a small, light, airy, brittle, very dry biscuit made from sago starch (or sometimes tapioca starch), coconut milk or cream, eggs, sugar, salt, and pandan, traditionally eaten during festive seasons such as Hari Raya and Chinese New Year. Because they are so dry (from the lack of water in the ingredients) and airy (from expansion, bangkit, after baking), they tend to have a melt-in-the-mouth texture. They are often made in attractive shapes such as flowers, hearts, butterflies, other animals, etc.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: kuih + bingka from malay kuih small snack cakes, biscuits, confectioneries etc. ← hokkien (poj) 粿 kóe steamed cake made from rice flour or glutinous rice flour + malay bingka type of cake made with rice flour, coconut milk, and sugar
Words.Definition: a soft, moist, cake traditionally made from grated tapioca (cassava), sugar, coconut milk, and optional flavourings or ingredients such as pandan or yellow food colouring. It is often rectangular in shape, and is cut into small cuboid pieces for serving.
Words.Example: When baked, the tapioca kuih exudes a nutty caramelized fragrance. Kuih Bingka is never too sweet, so it goes really well for tea. In fact, we enjoy it for breakfast too!

Words.English Translation: → Malay: kuih + bingka + Indonesian / malay: Ambon from malay kuih small snack cakes, biscuits, confectioneries etc. ← hokkien (poj) 粿 kóe steamed cake made from rice flour or glutinous rice flour + malay bingka type of cake made with rice flour, coconut milk, and sugar + indonesian / malay Ambon island and city in Maluku, Indonesia ← ambonese malay ombong dew[2]
Words.Definition: a soft, moist, spongy cake traditionally made from sago or tapioca flour (but often also rice flour), which is mixed with sugar, coconut milk, eggs, and an optional flavouring such as pandan or banana, then fermented with yeast (traditionally palm wine) before baking. Due to the fermentation process, the cake has characteristic long bubbles stretching from the top to the bottom. Despite the name, it is likely to have originated in Medan, Indonesia.
Words.Example: Up till then I haven’t even eaten the original Kuih Bingka Ambon from Medan, but I knew that what I baked was no where close to the real thing.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: kuih + bingka + ubi kayu from malay kuih small snack cakes, biscuits, confectioneries etc. ← hokkien (poj) 粿 kóe steamed cake made from rice flour or glutinous rice flour + malay bingka type of cake made with rice flour, coconut milk, and sugar + malay ubi kayu Manihot esculenta, a.k.a. cassava; tapioca ← malay ubi yam + malay kayu wood ↻ general chinese (pinyin) 木薯 mù shǔ Manihot esculenta, a.k.a. cassava; tapioca ← general chinese (pinyin) 木 mù wood + general chinese (pinyin) 薯 shǔ yam; yam-like tuber
Words.Definition: a soft, moist, cake traditionally made from grated tapioca (cassava), sugar, coconut milk, and optional flavourings or ingredients such as pandan or yellow food colouring. It is often rectangular in shape, and is cut into small cuboid pieces for serving.
Words.Example: Making kueh bengka ubi is incredibly easy. The main ingredients are grated tapioca, eggs, sugar and coconut milk. Just mix everything thoroughly and bake. It’s as easy as a box cake, but the results are way more delicious.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: kuih + dadar from malay kuih small snack cakes, biscuits, confectioneries etc. ← hokkien (poj) 粿 kóe steamed cake made from rice flour or glutinous rice flour + malay dadar thin omelette or pancake; crepe
Words.Definition: a snack consisting of a thin pandan-flavoured crepe (usually coloured green from the pandan) made from flour, eggs, and coconut milk, rolled around a filling of grated coconut and gula melaka

Words.English Translation: → Malay: kuih + dodol from malay kuih small snack cakes, biscuits, confectioneries etc. ← hokkien (poj) 粿 kóe steamed cake made from rice flour or glutinous rice flour + malay dodol sweet, sticky confection made from glutinous rice flour, jaggery or gula melaka, and coconut milk ← old javanese dwadal sweet, sticky confection made from rice flour and brown coconut sugar
Words.Definition: a sweet, sticky confection made from glutinous rice flour, jaggery or gula melaka, and coconut milk

Words.English Translation: → Malay: kuih + jongkong from malay kuih small snack cakes, biscuits, confectioneries etc. ← hokkien (poj) 粿 kóe steamed cake made from rice flour or glutinous rice flour + malay jongkong bullion; ingot; lump of metal, dinghy; dugout canoe
Words.Definition: a sweet confection made from glutinous rice flour, sugar and/or gula melaka, pandan, coconut milk, and water. It is usually pressed into a small, oblong, ingot-like shape, wrapped in a banana leaf, and steamed. It is typically drizzled with or dipped in gula melaka before eating.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: kuih + kapit from malay kuih small snack cakes, biscuits, confectioneries etc. ← hokkien (poj) 粿 kóe steamed cake made from rice flour or glutinous rice flour + malay kapit clamp; pinch or squeeze on both sides; support; stand beside; accompany
Words.Definition: a brittle waffle biscuit made by pressing a batter of flour, eggs, sugar, and coconut milk in a special decorated iron to form a thin, flat, patterned layer, which is usually then folded into a quarter-circle or rolled into a tube around 2 cm in diameter. It is popularly eaten during festive seasons such as Chinese New Year.It is derived from the Dutch kniepertje, a thicker version which is often also rolled into tubes, and likely entered Singaporean cuisine via Indonesia; compare other very similar North Germanic snacks such as the Norwegian krumkake, which is almost identical to kueh kapit except that it uses cream instead of cocnut milk.
Words.Example: Making Kuih Kapit was an all-day event, almost like a celebration in itself. The front porch was cleared out to make room for the charcoal brazier on the cement floor ... Way before that, big Milo tins were gathered and saved for the occasion. Each Milo tin can store up to 100 pieces of Kuih Kapit.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: kuih + koci from malay kuih small snack cakes, biscuits, confectioneries etc. ← hokkien (poj) 粿 kóe steamed cake made from rice flour or glutinous rice flour + malay koci wrapped glutinous rice snack dumpling with a sweet coconut filling ← hokkien (poj) 裹 kó/kó͘ wrap; bind + hokkien (poj) 糍 chî glutinous rice cake or dumpling
Words.Definition: a small snack dumpling made from glutinous rice (or a dough of glutinous rice flour) stuffed with grated coconut and gula melaka, usually wrapped using a piece of banana leaf into a tetrahedron or square pyramid. The rice may come in various colours, such as green (from pandan), blue (from the butterfly pea flower), or black to dark purple (from using black glutinous rice).
Words.Example: She improvised the recipes, churned out tray after tray of cakes such as kueh lapis ... kueh koci ... and kaya ... and sold them for 30 to 50 cents each. For kueh koci, she used tapioca flour instead of rice flour.

Words.English Translation: → Baba malay: kueh + kosui from baba malay kueh small snack cakes, biscuits, confectioneries etc. ← hokkien (poj) 粿 kóe steamed cake made from rice flour or glutinous rice flour + baba malay kosui type of sweet steamed kueh ← hokkien (poj) Dubious or unconfirmed 碱水 鹼水 kiⁿ-chúi/súi alkaline water; lye water
Words.Definition: a type of small, soft Nyonya kueh made from a mixture of rice or tapioca flour flavoured with gula melaka and pandan, topped with grated coconut. It can be made with alkaline water (gan sui) to attain a more chewy, bouncy texture. Because of the gula melaka and pandan, they are usually brown or green in colour. Each kueh is traditionally steamed in an individual Chinese teacup, but they can also be made in any other small mold, or cut from a larger cake into bite-sized pieces.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: kuih + lapis from malay kuih small snack cakes, biscuits, confectioneries etc. ← hokkien (poj) 粿 kóe steamed cake made from rice flour or glutinous rice flour + malay lapis layer; row; stratum
Words.Definition: a cake with thin alternating light and dark layers of cake, each of which are made by repeatedly laying a layer of batter over the previous layer, baking it from above in an oven until set, then taking the cake out of the oven to put down a new layer. It has origins in colonial Dutch-Indonesian cuisine, and is known as spekkoek in Dutch and lapis legit in Indonesia.
Words.Example: Eating more protein during breakfast may help to keep you full for longer, say experts. That, hopefully, would help you stop after your third slice of kueh lapis.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: kuih + lopes/lopis from malay kuih small snack cakes, biscuits, confectioneries etc. ← hokkien (poj) 粿 kóe steamed cake made from rice flour or glutinous rice flour + malay lopes/lopis confection of glutinous rice, coconut, and gula melaka
Words.Definition: a Malay confection of glutinous rice, grated coconut, and gula melaka, typically flavoured with pandan, which may be steamed or boiled. It is usually shaped into a triangle and wrapped in a piece of banana leaf, and eaten with sugar syrup.
Words.Example: ... go Nyonya all the way with homemade kuehs ... The selection includes ondeh ondeh, kueh lopis ... and kueh sarlat ...

Words.English Translation: → Malay: kuih + Baba malay: pai or English: patty/pasty from malay kuih small steamed cake ← hokkien (poj) 粿 kóe steamed rice cake + baba malay pai pie ← english pie pastry with a crust and filling or english patty/pasty folded and pleated pastry with filling
Words.Definition: A bite-sized snack of Peranakan origin, consisting of a thin, crispy fried tart shell with a filling of shredded jicama (bangkuang) and other small shredded or diced ingredients, including black fungus, carrots, hard-boiled eggs, and prawns. It is commonly topped with kicap manis and chilli sauce. Believed to have derived as a snack-sized version of popiah.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: kuih + pulut from malay kuih small snack cakes, biscuits, confectioneries etc. ← hokkien (poj) 粿 kóe steamed cake made from rice flour or glutinous rice flour + malay pulut glutinous rice
Words.Definition: a Malay or Peranakan steamed confection of glutinous rice, coconut milk, and white (or brown) sugar, usually steamed in a foil tray or saucepan to form a round cake, but which is often sectioned into wedges before serving

Words.English Translation: → Malay: kuih + Likely, but other possible etymologies exist selat from malay kuih small snack cakes, biscuits, confectioneries etc. ← hokkien (poj) 粿 kóe steamed cake made from rice flour or glutinous rice flour + malay Likely, but other possible etymologies exist selat strait
Words.Definition: a steamed Malay and Peranakan confection consisting of a kaya-like layer of pandan custard over glutinous rice, with both layers infused with coconut milk
Words.Example: Or kueh salat—the moist rice scrolled with dark blue dye from the pea flower complementing the rich kaya perfectly.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: kuih + seri + muka from malay kuih small snack cakes, biscuits, confectioneries etc. ← hokkien (poj) 粿 kóe steamed cake made from rice flour or glutinous rice flour + malay seri glory; splendour; beauty; radiance; vibrant ← sanskrit श्री śrī́ glory; splendour; beauty; holy; sacred + malay muka face ← sanskrit मुख múkha mouth; face
Words.Definition: a steamed Malay and Peranakan confection consisting of a kaya-like layer of pandan custard over glutinous rice, with both layers infused with coconut milk

Words.English Translation: → Malay: kuih + talam from malay kuih small snack cakes, biscuits, confectioneries etc. ← hokkien (poj) 粿 kóe steamed cake made from rice flour or glutinous rice flour + malay talam tray without legs; platter ← tamil தட்டம் taḷam porringer; deep plate for eating
Words.Definition: a sweet steamed Malay confection consisting of a white top layer of rice flour and coconut milk over a bottom layer usually coloured and flavoured with either pandan or gula melaka, traditionally made in a large tray and cut into smaller slices for serving
Words.Example: Finally, I turn to my favourite kueh talam, the top half white with coconut milk and the bototm half a dark green. The aroma of the pandan leaves hits my nose as I take deep, joyous breaths. An older lady standing next to me tells me that the kueh seller, Haji Noh, with his white cap and shirt and green sarong, is particularly proud of his kueh talam.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: kuih + Likely, but other possible etymologies exist putu from malay kuih small snack cakes, biscuits, confectioneries etc. ← hokkien (poj) 粿 kóe steamed cake made from rice flour or glutinous rice flour + malay Likely, but other possible etymologies exist putu South Indian cylindrical steamed rice cake with grated coconut ← tamil புட்டு puṭṭu cylindrical steamed rice cake with grated coconut
Words.Definition: a Singaporean Chinese kueh made from finely-pounded rice flour with a filling of grated coconut with gula melaka or ground peanuts, steamed in a flower-shaped mould, and finally served on a square of pandan leaf.[1] It is possibly based on the South Indian snack known as puttu.
Words.Example: Ask a Chinese Singaporean to name the kueh and chances are he'd tell you it's kueh tutu. Ask a Peranakan and the answer will likely be kueh kutu. But doesn't kutu refer to lice? "Yes, it does," laughed a Nyonya colleague. "It doesn't make sense, but we've always been using kutu for putu. Don't ask me why, but we also call putumayam, kutumayam."

Words.English Translation: → Malay: kuih + wajik from malay kuih small snack cakes, biscuits, confectioneries etc. ← hokkien (poj) 粿 kóe steamed cake made from rice flour or glutinous rice flour + malay wajik diamond-shaped confection of glutinous rice, coconut milk, and sugar
Words.Definition: a traditional diamond-shaped Malay confection of glutinous rice, coconut milk, brown sugar, and often gula melaka

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 鸡饭 雞飯 poj: koe-pn̄g from hokkien (poj) 鸡饭 雞飯 koe-pn̄g chicken rice ← hokkien (poj) 鸡 雞 koe chicken + hokkien (poj) 饭 飯 pn̄g rice ↻ hainanese Possible, but not certain 鸡饭 雞飯 kɔi1 ʔbui1 chicken rice
Words.Definition: Hokkien term for Hainanese chicken rice, one of the national dishes of Singapore
Words.Example: ... for 252 days, at the time of this article, an Instagram account called Kuey.Png has been painstakingly uploading pictures of chicken rice onto his account.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: kuih + dahlia from malay kuih small snack cakes, biscuits, confectioneries etc. ← hokkien (poj) 粿 kóe steamed cake made from rice flour or glutinous rice flour + malay dahlia plant in the genus Dahlia, esp. its flower ← english dahlia plant in the genus Dahlia, esp. its flower ← swedish Dahl surname of botanist Anders Dahl ← swedish dal valley; dale ← old norse dalr valley; dale
Words.Definition: a custard butter cookie traditionally enjoyed during Hari Raya, made in the shape of a piped star, and often decorated with a small cube of cherry in its centre. It is named after its similarity in appearance to a dahlia flower.
Words.Example: Kuih dahlia displays a gorgeous floral detail that is attributed to its fitting name. Decorated with a single placement of cubed cherry, this crowd favourite is well-known for a deliciously crumbly texture that melts in the mouth upon first bite.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: kuih + semperit from malay kuih small snack cakes, biscuits, confectioneries etc. ← hokkien (poj) 粿 kóe steamed cake made from rice flour or glutinous rice flour + malay semperit extruded; piped ← malay Likely, but other possible etymologies exist sempit tight; narrow
Words.Definition: a custard butter cookie traditionally enjoyed during Hari Raya, made in the shape of a piped star, and often decorated with a small cube of cherry in its centre
Words.Example: Kuih Semperit is Malaysia’s answer to the Scottish butter cookie. It is usually shaped into either the dahlia flower pattern or round biscuits with a ridged, serrated surface.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 咕咕 咕咕 poj: ku-ku from hokkien (poj) 咕咕 咕咕 ku-ku (childish) penis, especially that of a young boy ✂ hokkien (poj) 咕咕鸟 咕咕鳥 ku-kú-chiáu (childish) penis, especially that of a young boy ← hokkien (poj) 咕咕 咕咕 ku-ku (onom.) dove or other bird's cry + hokkien (poj) 鸟 鳥 chiáu bird
Words.Definition: (childish, vulgar) a penis, especially that of a young boy

Words.English Translation: → Malay: kuping + gajah from malay kuping ear + malay gajah elephant; giant ← sanskrit गज gaja elephant
Words.Definition: a hard, mildly savoury biscuit with a cupped or shell-like shape made from wheat and/or soya bean flour, often with a spiral pattern, said to resemble an ear

Words.English Translation: → Malay: kurang ajar from malay kurang ajar insolent; impolite; poorly brought up ← malay kurang less; lacking + malay ajar teach; guide ← sanskrit आचार्य ācārya teacher; guide
Words.Definition: poorly brought up; uncouth; impolite; insolent; disrespectful
Words.Example: Just because these people may not agree with the Mufti, or the Islamic authorities, does not mean they should use rude and abusive language against them. I find that very saddening - kurang ajar.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: kurang manis from malay kurang manis less sweet ← malay kurang less; little ← malay manis sweet
Words.Definition: (drink ordering) less sweet; with less sugar
Words.Example: My workday often ended with a jog inside the station ... To warm down, a teh halia, kurang manis.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: kuti-kuti from malay kuti-kuti children's game played with small, brightly-coloured plastic pieces ← malay kuti tear or pull into tiny pieces
Words.Definition: a small, brightly-coloured plastic game piece, often molded in the shape of an animal, used in the traditional children's game kuti-kuti

Words.English Translation: → Malay: kuti-kuti from malay kuti-kuti children's game played with small, brightly-coloured plastic pieces ← malay kuti tear or pull into tiny pieces
Words.Definition: a traditional children's game played with small, brightly-coloured plastic game pieces (often molded in the shape of animals), where the objective is to flip one's own pieces such that they land on top of an opponent's piece. When successful in doing so, a player gets to keep their opponent's piece for themself.For want of the traditional playing pieces, children often may substitute any small, light, readily available objects such as bottlecaps or rubber bands instead.[1]

Words.English Translation: → Malay: kutuk from malay kutuk curse; damn; condemn; criticize
Words.Definition: to condemn; to criticize; to denounce; to speak out harshly and openly against
Words.Example: 181cm - 260 pounds reporting in ... before y'all kutok me i got go gym on every weekends hor

Words.English Translation: → Teochew: 粿汁 peng'im: guê2 zab4 from teochew (peng'im) 粿汁 guê2 zab4 flat rice noodle sheets in a soya sauce broth with mixed pork offal, pork belly, and other meats and ingredients ← teochew (peng'im) 粿 guê2 steamed cake made from rice flour or glutinous rice flour + teochew (peng'im) 汁 zab4 sauce; juice
Words.Definition: a Teochew dish of flat rice noodle (kway teow) sheets in a soya-sauce-based broth (the chap), served with mixed pork offal, pork belly, and other meats and ingredients such as tau kwa and hard-boiled eggs. It is usually served with a sourish chilli particular to the dish.
Words.Example: They served only one dish: a bowl of wide rice noodles in a savoury dark broth redolent of cinnamon and star anise, piled high with braised duck meat, pig intestines and other viscera Jess couldn't identify ... She was busy glaring at the people lining up at the stall, as though she suspected them of having designs on her kway chap.

Words.Word: kway teow /ˌkweɪ ˈtjaʊ/ 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Hokkien / teochew: 粿条 粿條 poj: kóe-tiâu from hokkien / teochew (poj) 粿条 粿條 kóe-tiâu flat rice noodle ← hokkien / teochew (poj) 粿 粿 kóe steamed cake made from rice flour or glutinous rice flour + hokkien / teochew (poj) 条 條 tiâu long item; strip; long piece
Words.Definition: a flat rice noodle originally used in Hokkien and Teochew cuisine, but now widely used among other local cuisines; the Cantonese equivalent of kway teow
Words.Example: Like “mue”, kway teow is an indispensable part of the Teochew culinary make-up and it forms the basis of many popular hawker foods like fried kway teow, beef kway teow and fishball kway teow.
Related: or ya peh ya som balik ah roti prata char kway teow

Words.Word: kway teow goreng 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Hokkien / teochew: 粿条 粿條 poj: kóe-tiâu + Malay: goreng from hokkien / teochew (poj) 粿条 粿條 kóe-tiâu flat rice noodle ← hokkien / teochew (poj) 粿 粿 kóe steamed cake made from rice flour or glutinous rice flour + hokkien / teochew (poj) 条 條 tiâu long item; strip; long piece + malay goreng fried
Words.Definition: a Malay term for char kway teow

Words.English Translation: → Mandarin: 可以吗 可以嗎 pinyin: ké yǐ mā from mandarin (pinyin) 可以吗 可以嗎 ké yǐ mā can or not? ← mandarin (pinyin) 可以 ké yǐ can; able to + mandarin (pinyin) 吗 嗎 mā qn. particle
Words.Definition: used to ask for the opinion or validation of others, especially on something one would 'rate highly' oneself
Words.Example: Lai experts my today's brunch kym? Haha

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: kym + English: thread from singlish kym used to ask opinion, esp. if others find sb. sexually attractive ← mandarin (pinyin) 可以吗 可以嗎 ké yǐ mā can or not? ← mandarin (pinyin) 可以 ké yǐ can; able to + mandarin (pinyin) 吗 嗎 mā qn. particle + english thread string; line, (Internet) series of messages replying to a post
Words.Definition: a post in an online forum or social media (especially Hardwarezone) featuring one or more photos or videos of a person, where the poster asks if others find said person sexually attractive, and commenters give their opinions on or fantasize about the subject of the post
Words.Example: last night my kym thread is gone too ... not sure why? has here become Shao Lin Temple?

Words.English Translation: → English: -ly from english -ly suffix to form an adverb from an adjective or noun
Words.Definition: used to form an adverb from any word, including words that are already adverbs

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 抐 poj: lā + 咖啡 poj: ko-pi from hokkien (poj) 抐 lā stir; mix + hokkien (poj) 咖啡 ko-pi coffee ← malay kopi coffee ← dutch koffie coffee ← italian caffè coffee ← ottoman turkish قهوه kahve coffee ← arabic قَهْوَة qahwa coffee
Words.Definition: (literal) to stir coffee
Words.Example: It will be just a la kopi session at any hawker/kopitiam so it's cheap and easy to fit in 20 people unless someone wanna sponsor a place?

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 啦啦 poj: la-la from hokkien (poj) 啦啦 la-la clam ← hokkien (poj) 蜊蜊 lâ-lâ clam ⇇ hokkien (poj) 蜊 lâ clam
Words.Definition: any clam of the genus Veneridae, also known as Venus clams, marine bivalve molluscs commonly found on sandy and rocky shores around Asia. There are several different species native to Singapore's shores. They are a popular seafood item, eaten with e.g. sambal, curry, or as an ingredient in other dishes.
Words.Example: The humble la la is a ubiquitous sight on Singapore’s shores ... they are widely harvested on the strand, from Pasir Ris to Pasir Panjang. Puny size notwithstanding, their plump flesh and subtle umami entice even the most exacting clam connoisseur.

Words.English Translation: → Mandarin: 拉面 拉麵 pinyin: lā miàn from mandarin (pinyin) 拉面 拉麵 lā miàn Chinese hand-pulled noodles ← mandarin (pinyin) 拉 拉 lā pull + mandarin (pinyin) 面 麵 miàn wheat noodles
Words.Definition: Chinese hand-pulled noodles

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien / teochew: 抐屎 poj: lā sái from hokkien / teochew (poj) 抐屎 lā sái stir shit; create trouble; deliberately provoke ← hokkien / teochew (poj) 抐 lā mix; stir; provoke; agitate + hokkien / teochew (poj) 屎 sái faeces; poop; (vg.) shit
Words.Definition: (slightly vulgar) stir shit; create trouble; deliberately provoke

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 抐 poj: lā + 茶 poj: tê from hokkien (poj) 抐 lā stir; mix + hokkien (poj) 茶 tê tea; drink made by infusing leaves of Camilla sinensis in water
Words.Definition: (literal) to stir tea
Words.Example: i grew up la teh la kopi at kopitiam, play block catching, hantam bola...

Words.English Translation: → Malay: lagi from malay lagi again; more; in addition
Words.Definition: more; in addition
Words.Example: "I challenge the PAP candidate to do more. If he says 'yes', lagi better. Whoever wins serves you!" he told residents.

Words.English Translation: → Min nan / cantonese: 啦 poj/poj / jyutping: --la/--lah / laa1 + Malay: lah from min nan / cantonese (poj/poj / jyutping) 啦 --la/--lah / laa1 sentence-final particle used to convey dissatisfaction, affirmation, request, etc. + malay lah sentence-final particle used to convey emphasis or reassurance, form an imperative, etc.

Words.Example: During my time, we also kena pulled ears and knuckle-rapped and niam by our teachers.

Words.English Translation: → Min nan: 念经 念經 poj: liām/niām-keng from min nan (poj) 念经 念經 liām/niām-keng recite scriptures; chant sutras ← min nan (poj) 念 念 liām/niām read; recite; chant + min nan (poj) 经 經 keng sacred texts; classics
Words.Definition: (idiom, intransitive) to repeat instructions, especially when unnecessary; to nag
Words.Example: said once - oksaid twice - ok we heard yousaid many times - nag nag nag like niam keng

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 莲 蓮 poj: liân from hokkien (poj) 莲 蓮 liân Ah Lian; stereotypically common female given name
Words.Definition: an Ah Lian
Words.Example: Often labelled as Bengs and Lians, they howl in Hokkien and gesture in unison while dancing to Euro-trance.

Words.English Translation: → Min nan: 了 poj: liáu from min nan (poj) 了 liáu particle indicating perfective aspect or change of state; already; (approximately) past tense marker
Words.Definition: indicating perfective aspect (completion of an action)
Words.Example: Finish liao, time to pang kang.

Words.English Translation: → English: like + that from english like just as; such as; similar to + english that used to indicate sth. further from the speaker than 'this'
Words.Definition: like that; in such a manner; like so; that way
Words.Example: Wah! Susah leh (very stressful). Liddat how to friend you? So sensitive!

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: liddat + also can from singlish liddat that way; like so ← english like just as; such as; similar to + english that used to indicate sth. further from the speaker than 'this' + singlish also can be fine as well; work too; permissible as well ← english also in addition; as well + singlish can affirmative particle; able to; permitted to ← english can able to; may; be possible; permitted
Words.Definition: used as a sarcastic remark when something that ought not to be passable or allowed manages to pass
Words.Example: They also did not credit me bonus interest on a promotional fixed deposit acc , only after I called to remind, they say they overlooked.... Like that also can leh 🙄

Words.English Translation: → English: like + this from english like just as; such as; similar to + english this used to indicate sth. closer to the speaker than 'that'
Words.Definition: like this; in such a manner; like so; this way
Words.Example: Liddis cannot one lah.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: lidi from malay lidi spine of a coconut leaf; rachis
Words.Definition: the rachis (“midrib” or “spine”) of a coconut leaf, or a stick made from this part
Words.Example: For coconut palms, the leaves were gathered for weaving into ketupat (rice cakes) cases or for wrapping otak-otak ... The spines of the fronds, lidi, had multiple uses too: they were mainly used as skewers for sate (satay), and could also be bundled together to form an egg-beater or even a broom if longer fronds were used.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: lidi + English: broom from malay lidi spine of a coconut leaf; rachis + english broom tool used for sweeping
Words.Definition: a domestic implement made by binding several long coconut leaf rachises (sticks made from the hard midrib of the frond) at one end, used for sweeping
Words.Example: 😂 The little boy with the lidi broom what he trying to sweep away

Words.English Translation: → English: lightbulb + Cantonese: 电灯泡 電燈泡 jyutping: din6 dang1 paau1 from english lightbulb sealed glass container containing a vacuum and a filament which glows when heated by electricity to produce light + cantonese (jyutping) 电灯泡 電燈泡 din6 dang1 paau1 lightbulb; third wheel; third party accompanying a couple on a romantic date
Words.Definition: (metaphor) a third wheel; an uninvited third party accompanying a couple on a romantic date

Words.English Translation: → English: like + dog from english like just as; such as; similar to + english dog Canis lupus familiaris
Words.Definition: (simile) continuously; without a break
Words.Example: 2011 I go Thailand for reservist was 35 degrees. Sweat like dog. Today I stay at home also same. Sweat like dog.

Words.Word: like free one 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → English: like + free + Singlish: one from english like as if + english free at no cost; complimentary + singlish one see one ← english one pro-form (used as a substitute word for a noun or pronoun understood in context) ← general chinese (poj/pinyin) 个/的* 個/的* ê/de possessive particle; nominalizer; emphasis, etc. (*etc.; non-exhaustive)
Words.Definition: (simile) in a large or excessive quantity
Words.Example: This kopi the sugar like free one sia, so sweet until my teeth gg to drop out.

Words.English Translation: → English: like + real from english like as if + english real actual; genuine; true ← old french reel real ← latin reālis real
Words.Definition: ‘as if!’; ‘yeah, right’; used to express doubt; incredulity; etc. at something one feels is highly unlikely

Words.English Translation: → Min nan / hakka: 啉 poj: lim from min nan / hakka (poj) 啉 lim drink
Words.Definition: to drink

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien / hakka: 啉酒 poj: lim-chiú from hokkien / hakka (poj) 啉酒 lim-chiú drink alcohol ← hokkien / hakka (poj) 啉 lim drink + hokkien / hakka (poj) 酒 chiú alcohol
Words.Definition: to drink alcohol
Words.Example: Go there to lim chiu not jiak. River area gotch a lot of nice eateries and also chop carrot ones..just avoid the seafood places can liao.........

Words.English Translation: → Min nan: 啉 poj: lim + 咖啡 poj: ko-pi from min nan (poj) 啉 lim drink + min nan (poj) 咖啡 ko-pi coffee ← malay kopi coffee ← dutch koffie coffee ← italian caffè coffee ← ottoman turkish قهوه kahve coffee ← arabic قَهْوَة qahwa coffee
Words.Definition: to drink coffee
Words.Example: The characters Ning creates are so interesting I want to lim kopi with them ...

Words.English Translation: → Min nan: 啉 poj: lim + 茶 poj: tê from min nan (poj) 啉 lim drink + min nan (poj) 茶 tê tea; drink made by infusing leaves of Camilla sinensis in water
Words.Definition: to drink tea

Words.English Translation: → Malay: limau from malay limau citrus; lemon
Words.Definition: citrus fruit; any member of the genus Citrus, especially lemons and limes

Words.English Translation: → Malay: limau kasturi from malay limau kasturi Citrus × microcarpa, or its edible fruit ← malay limau citrus; lemon + malay kasturi musk ← sanskrit कस्तूरी kastūrī musk
Words.Definition: the plant Citrus × microcarpa, or its edible fruit. As a kumquat hybrid, the plant is sometimes sold as an ornamental, especially during the Chinese New Year season. The fruit resembles a spherical lime, and is yellow-orange in colour on the inside. It is used in many traditional dishes, often as a season or garnish, and is also popular for its juice. It is also known as calamansi.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: limau nipis from malay limau nipis Citrus × aurantiifolia, or its edible fruit ← malay limau citrus; lemon + malay nipis thin; delicate; not thick
Words.Definition: the plant Citrus × aurantiifolia or its edible fruit, also known as the Key lime. The fruit is spherical and between 2.5 - 5 cm in diameter, and its thin skin turns from green to yellow as it ripens. It is popular for its fresh, distinct flavour.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 恁母 poj: lím-bú from hokkien (poj) 恁母 lím-bú your mother
Words.Definition: (condescending or humorous) I; me
Words.Example: Lim bu ka li kong, you better listen.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 恁爸 poj: lím-pē from hokkien (poj) 恁爸 lím-pē your father
Words.Definition: (condescending or humorous) I; me
Words.Example: 恁爸是我; 我是恁爸！(Limpeh si wa; wa si Limpeh!)

Words.Word: limpeh ka li kong 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 恁爸共汝讲 恁爸共汝講 poj: lím-pē kā lí kóng from hokkien (poj) 恁爸共汝讲 恁爸共汝講 lím-pē kā lí kóng limpeh tell you; 'now listen here' ← hokkien (poj) 恁爸 恁爸 lím/lín-pē (lit.) your father, (fig., condescending or humorous) I; me; 1p. sing. pronoun + hokkien (poj) 共 共 kā to; with; at + hokkien (poj) 汝 汝 lí you; 2p. sing. pronoun + hokkien (poj) 讲 講 kóng speak; talk; say
Words.Definition: (condescending or humorous) used at the start of a sentence to call attention to something one is about to say; used to indicate one is about to give their opinion, give advice, explain something, share their thoughts etc.; 'look here'; 'listen here'
Words.Example: Limpeh ka li kong, the greatest wealth is health.

Words.Word: limpeh tell you 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 恁爸共汝讲 恁爸共汝講 poj: lím-pē kā lí kóng from hokkien (poj) 恁爸共汝讲 恁爸共汝講 lím-pē kā lí kóng limpeh tell you; 'now listen here' ← hokkien (poj) 恁爸 恁爸 lím/lín-pē (lit.) your father, (fig., condescending or humorous) I; me; 1p. sing. pronoun + hokkien (poj) 共 共 kā to; with; at + hokkien (poj) 汝 汝 lí you; 2p. sing. pronoun + hokkien (poj) 讲 講 kóng speak; talk; say
Words.Definition: (condescending or humorous) used at the start of a sentence to call attention to something one is about to say; used to indicate one is about to give their opinion, give advice, explain something, share their thoughts etc.; 'look here'; 'listen here'
Words.Example: Limpeh tell you, don’t let your dreams be dreams.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 恁老母 poj: lín-lāu-bú from hokkien (poj) 恁老母 lín-lāu-bú your (old) mother ← hokkien (poj) 恁 lín you; your (pl.) + hokkien (poj) 老母 lāu-bú mother
Words.Definition: (condescending or humorous) I; me
Related: kan ni na bu chao chee bai
kan ni na chao chee bai
ni ma ma mei you mao

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 恁老兄 poj: lín-lāu-hiaⁿ from hokkien (poj) 恁老兄 lín-lāu-hiaⁿ your older brother, (vg.) damn ← hokkien (poj) 恁 lín you; your (pl.) + hokkien (poj) 老兄 lāu-hiaⁿ older brother; term of respectful address for a man of similar age, (vg.) damn
Words.Definition: (slightly vulgar) 'damn'; 'damn it'; exclamation of surprise, frustration, displeasure, etc.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 恁老爸 poj: lín-lāu-pē from hokkien (poj) 恁老爸 lín-lāu-pē your father; your old man
Words.Definition: (condescending or humorous) I; me

Words.English Translation: → Cantonese: 莲蓉 蓮蓉 jyutping: lin4 jung4 from cantonese (jyutping) 莲蓉 蓮蓉 lin4 jung4 lotus
Words.Definition: lotus paste, a sweet paste made from lotus seeds and sugar that is mainly used as a filling for pastries and snacks such as pau or mooncakes
Words.Example: For dessert the Chinese pancake stuffed this time with "lin yoong", instead of the usual "tau sar," created a lighter and smoother ending to an interesting meal.

Words.Word: lin zor ma 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 恁祖妈 恁祖媽 poj: lín-chó͘-má from hokkien (poj) 恁祖妈 恁祖媽 lín-chó͘-má (vg.) I; me, (lit.) your great-grandmother ← hokkien (poj) 恁 lín you; your (pl.) + hokkien (poj) 祖妈 祖媽 chó͘-má paternal grandfather's mother
Words.Definition: (humorous or condescending; possibly vulgar) I; me
Words.Example: lin zor ma is proud to be an army gal✌️😉 #reminiscing #armylife #bmt #cheongswa

Words.Word: ling ling long long 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 轮轮珑珑 輪輪瓏瓏 poj: lin-lin-long-long + 铃铃隆隆 鈴鈴隆隆 poj: ling-ling-long-long + General chinese: 玲玲珑珑 玲玲瓏瓏 pinyin: líng líng lóng lóng from hokkien (poj) 轮轮珑珑 輪輪瓏瓏 lin-lin-long-long (onom.) sound of bells; emphasising adv. or adj. ⇇ hokkien (poj) 轮珑 輪瓏 lin-long (onom.) sound of bells; emphasising adv. or adj. + hokkien (poj) 铃铃隆隆 鈴鈴隆隆 ling-ling-long-long (onom.) sound of bells; making a lot of noise ⇇ hokkien (poj) 铃隆 鈴隆 ling-long (onom.) sound of bells + general chinese (pinyin) 玲玲珑珑 玲玲瓏瓏 líng líng lóng lóng (onom.) sound of precious objects chiming or clinking ⇇ general chinese (pinyin) 玲珑 玲瓏 líng lóng (onom.) sound of precious objects chiming or clinking
Words.Definition: (onomatopoeia) the sound of objects clinking, jangling, chiming, etc.
Words.Example: - Eh this keychain you buy from where one?- Pasar malam lor. Got one stall sell a lot this kind of ling ling long long, I see nice then buy for you.

Words.English Translation: → English: little + red + dot from english little small; tiny; insignificant + english red colour on the lower frequency range before orange on the visible light spectrum + english dot small spot; point; speck
Words.Definition: (metaphor) Singapore

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: lan lan suck thumb from singlish lan lan suck thumb grudgingly bear with sth. unpleasant or unfavourable without complaint ← singlish lan lan indifferently; resignedly; grudgingly ⇇ singlish lan (vulgar) penis; the fuck; the hell ← min nan / cantonese (poj) 𡳞 lān (vulgar) penis; the fuck; the hell; used to express disgust + singlish suck thumb bear with sth. unpleasant or unfavourable without complaint ← english [to] suck [one’s] thumb put one’s thumb in one’s mouth, often seen as a childlike action ← english suck draw into one’s mouth by creating a region of lower pressure + english thumb short, thick, opposable digit of each hand
Words.Definition: abbreviation of lan lan suck thumb

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 啰 囉 poj: --lo͘/--lo͘h from hokkien (poj) 啰 囉 --lo͘/--lo͘h already; particle used at the end of a sentence to exp. finality or completion
Words.Definition: already; used at the end of a sentence to denote finality or completion

Words.English Translation: → Cantonese: 捞起 撈起 jyutping: lou1 hei2 from cantonese (jyutping) 捞起 撈起 lou1 hei2 pull up and mix; toss yu sheng ← cantonese (jyutping) 捞 撈 lou1 dredge; fish up; pull up; mix + cantonese (jyutping) 起 起 hei2 up; go up
Words.Definition: a salad dish popularly eaten to celebrate Chinese New Year, developed in either Singapore or Malaysia from a tradition of either Teochew or other Guangdongese origin (though unlike the modern salad, the original dish essentially only consisted of sliced raw fish).It is often the centrepiece of a reunion dinner, where the salad is placed in the centre of a table and communally tossed with chopsticks by all present. Tossing the salad as high as possible while noisily shouting out auspicious greetings, and the big mess that often results, is considered a key part of the festivities.It consists of raw fish (in modern times, usually salmon), julienned vegetables such as carrot, turnip, and capsicum, and often the flesh of fruits such as pomelo or mandarin orange. Before tossing, it is topped with a variety of ingredients, each traditionally paired with an auspicious saying. This usually includes ground peanuts, sesame seeds, honey, sesame oil, pok chui crackers, plum sauce, and five spice powder.

Words.English Translation: → Cantonese: 老鼠粉 jyutping: lou5 syu2 fan2 from cantonese (jyutping) 老鼠粉 lou5 syu2 fan2 bee thai bak; rat tail noodles; short, thick noodles made of rice flour and cornstarch ← cantonese (jyutping) 老鼠 lou5 syu2 rat; mouse + cantonese (jyutping) 粉 fan2 flour; powder; noodles
Words.Definition: Cantonese term for bee thai bak

Words.English Translation: → Malay: lubang from malay lubang hole; opening
Words.Definition: an opportunity; a good deal; a source; a tip; an opening
Words.Example: Of course, we hope we will get more lobang in the form of recording deals and performing events.

Words.Word: loh gai yik 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Cantonese: 卤鸡翼 滷雞翼 jyutping: lou5 gai1 jik6 from cantonese (jyutping) 卤鸡翼 滷雞翼 lou5 gai1 jik6 dish of chicken wings and other ingredients braised in a nam yu-based sauce ← cantonese (jyutping) 卤 滷 lou5 braised in soya sauce; thick gravy + cantonese (jyutping) 鸡翼 雞翼 gai1 jik6 chicken wing ← cantonese (jyutping) 鸡 雞 gai1 chicken + cantonese (jyutping) 翼 翼 jik6 wing
Words.Definition: a Cantonese dish of chicken wings (and often an eclectic mix of various other ingredients) braised in a sauce based on red fermented beancurd (nam yu)
Words.Example: Lo Kai Yik's heydays were in the 1960s but it gradually faded away. Cantonese immigrants who came to Singapore from Guangdong, China in the 1820s - 1930s brought the comfort dish with them. Today, Lo Kai Yik is rarely made at home and only two hawker stalls still sell it in Singapore.

Words.English Translation: → Possible, but not certain Hokkien: 落佝 poj: lo̍k-kok from hokkien (poj) Possible, but not certain 落佝 lo̍k-kok sloppy; shabby; run-down; dilapidated
Words.Definition: sloppy; old; shabby; run-down; dilapidated
Words.Example: Wait till u visit Kaohsiung.. more lok kok than old Jalan Besar or South Bridge Road. really like old prewar Sungei Road shophouses.

Words.English Translation: → Cantonese / hakka: 渌渌 淥淥 jyutping / pinfa: luk6 luk6 from cantonese / hakka (jyutping / pinfa) 渌渌 淥淥 luk6 luk6 street food of skewers served steamboat-style ⇇ cantonese / hakka (jyutping / pinfa) 渌 淥 luk6 / lug6 scald
Words.Definition: a style of meal involving skewers of various foods such as meats, vegetables, fishballs, tofu, sausages, etc. which are cooked steamboat-style by dipping them in a boiling broth before eating. It was traditionally sold as a street food from carts or stands, which had an open display of skewers that customers could choose from.
Words.Example: ... taking up a third of the round tables with their specially designed "lok lok" facilities — namely a pot of bubbling hot water in which to dip stick after stick of fresh and exotic seafood in. The current anchor stall is an evolution from four generations of Teochews of selling "lok lok" from the first family mobile stall.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 老君 poj: ló-kun from hokkien (poj) 老君 ló-kun doctor ← malay dukun shaman; witch doctor
Words.Definition: a doctor

Words.English Translation: → English: long + No. 4 from english long extended; lengthy + english No. 4 (mil.) abbreviation of 'Number 4', the designation of the camouflaged combat uniform of the SAF
Words.Definition: (military) a variant of the No. 4 uniform worn by soldiers with the sleeves let down and the cuffs done up. It is used in most cases when wearing the uniform in of a combat or training situation.

Words.Word: long chiam pas 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Possible, but not certain English: roshambo from english Possible, but not certain roshambo scissors paper stone ← japanese Possible, but not certain じゃんけんぽん じゃん拳ぽん jankenpon scissors paper stone
Words.Definition: scissors paper stone; a game played by making hand signs of either scissors, paper, or stone, used in selection or tiebreaking

Words.English Translation: → Min nan / hakka / min: 拢总 攏總 poj: lóng-chóng from min nan / hakka / min (poj) 拢总 攏總 lóng-chóng totally; all; altogether; entirely
Words.Definition: totally; all; altogether; entirely
Words.Example: Remember all those Ah Bengs park like their grandfather road near our house last night? Turns out the whole jin gang long zong tio saman. Orbi quek!

Words.Word: long zong thia 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Min nan: 拢总 攏總 poj: lóng-chóng + 疼 poj: thiàⁿ from min nan (poj) 拢总 攏總 lóng-chóng totally; all; altogether; entirely + min nan (poj) 疼 thiàⁿ painful; sore; aching
Words.Definition: everything hurting; having pain everywhere; aching all over
Words.Example: When you ask the ah mah to point to where it hurts ... Process sped up 100x. “Long zhong tia” happens too often ...

Words.English Translation: → Cantonese: 龙眼 龍眼 jyutping: lung4 ngaan5 from cantonese (jyutping) 龙眼 龍眼 lung4 ngaan5 Dimocarpus longan or its edible fruit ← cantonese (jyutping) 龙 龍 lung4 dragon + cantonese (jyutping) 眼 眼 ngaan5 eye
Words.Definition: the tree Dimocarpus longan or its edible fruit, which are spherical and around 2 - 3 cm in diameter with a thin, firm, leathery, yellow-brown skin and translucent white, mildly sweet flesh. The skin splits open along a longitudinal line when squeezed, while the centre of the fruit contains a single large black seed. This gives it the appearance of an eye, with the skin being the eyelids and the flesh and seed being the sclera and iris respectively. It is related to the lychee, rambutan, and pulasan.
Words.Example: Jackfruit, for example, is churned into ice cream and covered in a disarrayed dune of young coconut mousse, fresh longan and shards of almond ginger cake.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: longkang from malay longkang drain ← hokkien (poj) 垄江 壟江 lóng-kang drain in a field; furrow; irrigation ditch ← hokkien (poj) 垄 壟 lóng raised path between fields; ridge + hokkien (poj) 江 江 kang river
Words.Definition: drain; ditch
Words.Example: My Nani didn't let me play in the longkang. Actually, it was mostly boys and some of the more daring girls who liked to climb down the steps at the side of the longkang to play and catch fish. They even played catching on the concrete floor of the longkang because the longkang was really very big, you know, and it would be dry enough.

Words.English Translation: → Indonesian / malay: lontong from indonesian / malay lontong compressed rice cylinder
Words.Definition: compressed rice cakes traditionally made by rolling banana leaves into a cylinder, filling it with uncooked rice, sealing it closed, then boiling or steaming the whole roll. Modern versions may use a cylindrical mold lined with banana leaves instead. A finished cylinder is usually sliced transversely into small pucks before serving.
Words.Example: I eat lontong every day, because it's full of vegetables, and I eat lontong without rice. So it's like I get to have coconut and spice but I'm only having vegetables, and maybe an egg for protein.

Words.English Translation: → General chinese: 看看 pinyin: kàn kàn from general chinese (pinyin) 看看 kàn kàn take a look around; have a look-see; make a brief inspection ⇇ general chinese (pinyin) 看 kàn see; look
Words.Definition: to have a gander; to take a quick peek around; to make a brief inspection
Words.Example: Here got any ATM anot? Wait ah, I go have one look look see see.

Words.English Translation: → General chinese: 看看 pinyin: kàn kàn from general chinese (pinyin) 看看 kàn kàn take a look around; have a look-see; make a brief inspection ⇇ general chinese (pinyin) 看 kàn see; look
Words.Definition: to have a gander; to take a quick peek around; to make a brief inspection
Words.Example: - Eh? Never see you at Holland V before. You come here do what?- Dunno, look see look see nia.

Words.English Translation: → Cantonese / hokkien: 啰 囉 jyutping / poj: lo1 / --lo͘ from cantonese / hokkien (jyutping / poj) 啰 囉 lo1 / --lo͘ used to express obviousness, logical connection, impatience, etc.
Words.Definition: used to point out that something is obvious, self-evident, or must logically follow from a previous condition
Words.Example: He is definitely the louder, funnier one. If I need to tell him to shut up, I'll just tell him to shut up, lor!

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien / teochew: 卤鸭 滷鴨 poj: ló͘-ah from hokkien / teochew (poj) 卤鸭 滷鴨 ló͘-ah braised duck ← hokkien / teochew (poj) 卤 滷 ló͘ thick gravy; braised in soya sauce + hokkien / teochew (poj) 鸭 鴨 ah duck
Words.Definition: a Hokkien and Teochew dish of duck braised in soya sauce with several aromatics and spices, often with other ingredients such as hard-boiled eggs, tau pok, or tau kwa. The duck is often cut into bite-sized pieces and served on a platter with the other ingredients.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien / teochew: 卤肉 滷肉 poj: ló͘-bah from hokkien / teochew (poj) 卤肉 滷肉 ló͘-bah braised or stewed meat ← hokkien / teochew (poj) 卤 滷 ló͘ thick gravy; braised in soya sauce + hokkien / teochew (poj) 肉 肉 bah meat; flesh; pork
Words.Definition: a Hokkien and Teochew dish of meat (usually pork) braised in soya sauce with several aromatics and spices, often with other ingredients such as hard-boiled eggs, mushrooms, or tau kwa. The meat is usually cut into bite-sized pieces and served on a platter with the other ingredients, or alternatively may be cubed or finely diced before braising.
Words.Example: Lor bak isn’t a hawker dish. Unlike braised duck, it is also less likely to be found on the menus of restaurants. Still, it touches an emotional chord with many Singaporeans who encounter it at economic rice stalls or Teochew porridge stalls, if they are not lucky enough to enjoy it at home.

Words.Word: lor bak png 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 卤肉饭 滷肉飯 poj: ló͘-bah-pn̄g from hokkien (poj) 卤肉饭 滷肉飯 ló͘-bah-pn̄g braised pork with rice ← hokkien (poj) 卤肉 滷肉 ló͘-bah braised or stewed meat ← hokkien (poj) 卤 滷 ló͘ thick gravy; braised in soya sauce + hokkien (poj) 肉 肉 bah meat; flesh; pork + hokkien (poj) 饭 飯 pn̄g rice
Words.Definition: a Hokkien dish of diced or minced meat (usually pork) braised in soya sauce with several aromatics and spices served over rice, originating from southern Fujian but popularized in Taiwan

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 老枯 poj: ló͘-ko͘/kho͘ from hokkien (poj) 老枯 ló͘-ko͘/kho͘ tough; chewy; stringy ← hokkien (poj) 老 ló͘ overcooked; tough; chewy; stringy + hokkien (poj) 枯 ko͘/kho͘ fibrous; tough; stringy; dry
Words.Definition: (of food, especially fish or other seafood) tough; chewy; stringy; overcooked; rubbery
Words.Example: Not everything is perfect though. Our Turbot Fish is actually hard, rubbery and stiff (Lor Kor) so it is really an unfortunate event ...

Words.Word: lor mai gai 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Cantonese: 糯米鸡 糯米雞 jyutping: no6 mai5 gai1 from cantonese (jyutping) 糯米鸡 糯米雞 no6 mai5 gai1 steamed glutinous rice with chicken ← cantonese (jyutping) 糯米 糯米 no6 mai5 glutinous rice + cantonese (jyutping) 鸡 雞 gai1 chicken
Words.Definition: a Cantonese dish of glutinous rice topped with chicken, and sometimes other ingredients such as mushrooms or lup cheong, traditionally wrapped in a lotus leaf and steamed. It is a common breakfast and dim sum dish.
Words.Example: Often a local coffee shop ... will have, alongside its drinks store, an electronic steamer with requisite hot items such as char siew bao (roast pork bun), chee cheong fun (steamed rice rolls) and lor mai gai (leaf wrapped glutinous rice) ready to be served immediately.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 卤面 滷麵 poj: ló͘-mī from hokkien (poj) 卤面 滷麵 ló͘-mī noodles in thick soya sauce gravy ← hokkien (poj) 卤 滷 ló͘ thick gravy; braised in soya sauce + hokkien (poj) 面 麵 mī wheat noodles
