Words.Definition: a Hokkien dish of wheat noodles in a thick, starchy, soya-sauce-based gravy with a variety of toppings such as egg, sliced pork, ngo hiang, fish, fishcake, etc. It is often garnished with minced raw garlic, vinegar, sambal, and sliced chilli to taste. It is likely to be the predecessor of Hokkien mee, a popular Singaporean stir-fried noodle dish.
Words.Example: Where I grew up, in Sims Drive, there was an incredible lor mee stall that sold a version of lor mee that offered the option of mee pok, which accompanied the crispy freshly fried fish impeccably. I've not been able to find lor mee pok since.

Words.English Translation: → Cantonese / hokkien: 啰嗦 囉嗦 jyutping: lo1 so1 from cantonese / hokkien (jyutping) 啰嗦 囉嗦 lo1 so1 long-winded; verbose, troublesome; hasslesome ← cantonese / hokkien (jyutping) 啰/唠 囉/嘮 lo1/lou6 nag; prattle; yap; chatter
Words.Definition: long-winded; verbose
Words.Example: Her reputation for being so lor sor meant that few people actually read her emails in full.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: lorong from malay lorong lane; alley; street
Words.Definition: a lane or alley

Words.English Translation: → General chinese: 丟臉 丢脸 pinyin: diū liǎn + English: lose face from general chinese (pinyin) 丟臉 丢脸 diū liǎn embarrass or disgrace oneself; lose one's dignity or reputation + english lose face embarrass or disgrace oneself; lose one's dignity or reputation ← english lose stop having; be unable to keep + english face face; reputation; public image; dignity ↻ general chinese (pinyin) 面子 miàn zi face; reputation; public image; dignity
Words.Definition: to lose one's dignity or reputation; to be disgraced or embarrassed; to be publically humiliated
Words.Example: The authorities should take tougher action against these ofenders. Singaporeans do not like to lose face, so maybe publishing their photographs would send a message to drivers that they are being watched.

Words.English Translation: → English: lose/lost from english lose/lost be unable to find sth.; go astray
Words.Definition: to lose; to misplace; to be unable to find something that one once had
Words.Example: This is my one, I lend you first. Don’t lost it hor!

Words.English Translation: → English: lotus + root ↻ General chinese: 莲藕 蓮藕 pinyin: lián ǒu from english lotus aquatic plant in the genus Nelumbo ← latin lōtus Egyptian water lily ← ancient greek λωτός lōtós name of various unrelated plants, including the white lotus + english root part of a plant that absorbs water and nutrients from a substrate ↻ general chinese (pinyin) 莲藕 蓮藕 lián ǒu lotus root
Words.Definition: the edible rhizome of Nelumbo nucifera, also known as the sacred lotus, which has holes running lengthwise through its structure. When used in Chinese cuisine, the rhizome is usually sliced transversely, resulting in round wheel-like cross-sections.

Words.English Translation: → English: lotus + seed ↻ General chinese: 莲子 蓮子 pinyin: lián zǐ from english lotus aquatic plant in the genus Nelumbo ← latin lōtus Egyptian water lily ← ancient greek λωτός lōtós name of various unrelated plants, including the white lotus + english seed fertilized ovule of a plant ↻ general chinese (pinyin) 莲子 蓮子 lián zǐ lotus seed
Words.Definition: the edible seeds of plants in the genus Nelumbo (collectively known as lotuses), particularly N. nucifera, used in Chinese cuisine and desserts as well as in traditional Chinese medicine

Words.English Translation: → English: love letter from english love letter letter written about the writer's love for the receiver ← english love deep affection, care, romantic feelings, etc. for another + english letter written or printed missive ← old french letre letter (printed character) ← latin littera letter (printed character) or piece of writing
Words.Definition: a brittle waffle biscuit made by pressing a batter of flour, eggs, sugar, and coconut milk in a special decorated iron to form a thin, flat, patterned layer, which is usually then folded into a quarter-circle or rolled into a tube around 2 cm in diameter. It is popularly eaten during festive seasons such as Chinese New Year.It is derived from the Dutch kniepertje, a thicker version which is often also rolled into tubes, and likely entered Singaporean cuisine via Indonesia; compare other very similar North Germanic snacks such as the Norwegian krumkake, which is almost identical to kueh kapit except that it uses cream instead of cocnut milk.
Words.Example: Chinese New Year is just around the corner, and if you're a seasoned festive shopper, your larder is probably already bursting with a plethora of typical treats, such as cookies, love letters and bak kwa ...

Words.English Translation: → English: low + SES from english low reduced; not high + english SES initialism of 'socioeconomic status' ← english socioeconomic status social and economic standing of an individual, group, class, etc. ← english socioeconomic of or relating to both social and economic factors ← english socio- relating to society and social factors ← middle french social allied; social ← latin sociālis of or relating to allies, companionship etc; social + english economic of or relating to an economy; the study of money ← middle french œconomique household management; of or relating to household management ← latin oeconomicus economic; household management ← ancient greek οἰκονομικός oikonomikós of or relating to household management + english status standing; position ← latin status position; rank; standing
Words.Definition: of or having a relatively poor and unprestigious social and economic standing, such as in terms of educational background and access to education, wealth, family and occupational prestige, and other economic and subjective social factors which may lead to different experiences and social perceptions.[1]

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 乱 亂 poj: loān from hokkien (poj) 乱 亂 loān disorderly; confused; haphazard
Words.Definition: disorderly; confused; haphazard

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 乱 亂 poj: loān + 拂 poj: hut + 刜 poj: hut/phut from hokkien (poj) 乱 亂 loān anyhow; disorderly; chaotic; wild; as one pleases + hokkien (poj) 拂 hut act recklessly; disregard everything; do without care for the consequences + hokkien (poj) 刜 hut/phut strike forcefully; hit; do recklessly without care for the consequences
Words.Definition: to do recklessly and blindly; to disregard everything and do as one pleases; to do without care for the consequences
Words.Example: Else if you dunno clarify all these, luan luan hoot tikum tikum based on intuition or rumour, sure backfire.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: lucu from malay lucu funny; hilarious; cute
Words.Definition: funny; hilarious
Words.Example: I sibeh suka how these 2 zou stead gin na are so endearing and lucu and on point man.

Words.Word: lui cha fan 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Hakka: 擂茶饭 擂茶飯 pfs: lùi-chhà-fan from hakka (pfs) 擂茶饭 擂茶飯 lùi-chhà-fan ground tea rice (Hakka dish) ← hakka (pfs) 擂茶 擂茶 lùi-chhà ground tea (Hakka ingredient made of tea, grains, herbs, and other ingredients ground into a powder ← hakka (pfs) 擂 擂 lùi grind + hakka (pfs) 茶 茶 chhà tea + hakka (pfs) 饭 飯 fan rice
Words.Definition: a Hakka dish made of ground tea powder (tea leaves ground with herbs, seeds, grains etc. into a fine powder) cooked together with rice

Words.English Translation: → Cantonese: 论尽 論盡 jyutping: leon6 zeon6 from cantonese (jyutping) 论尽 論盡 leon6 zeon6 clumsy; careless; ungainly
Words.Definition: clumsy; careless; ungainly

Words.English Translation: → Mandarin: 罗汉 羅漢 pinyin: luó hàn from mandarin (pinyin) 罗汉 羅漢 luó hàn clipping of arhat ← mandarin (pinyin) 阿罗汉 阿羅漢 ā luó hàn arhat (Buddhist monk who has achieved Nirvana) ← pali 𑀅𑀭𑀳𑀦𑁆𑀢𑁆 अरहंत् arahant arhat; majestic; honourable ← sanskrit अर्हत् arhat arhat; venerable; honourable; deserving; celebrated
Words.Definition: the flowerhorn cichlid, an ornamental aquarium fish that is a hybrid of various cichlid species, particularly Amphilophus labiatus (the red devil cichlid) and Amphilophus trimaculatum (the three spot cichlid), and which can grow to a size of around 50 - 60 cm. It has a distinctive, prominent forehead protuberance known as a nuchal hump, an asesthetic feature which is highly prized by many aquarium hobbyists in Singapore and Malaysia.

Words.Word: luo han fish 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Mandarin: 罗汉鱼 羅漢魚 pinyin: luó hàn yú + English: fish from mandarin (pinyin) 罗汉鱼 羅漢魚 luó hàn yú flowerhorn cichlid ← mandarin (pinyin) 罗汉 羅漢 luó hàn clipping of arhat ← mandarin (pinyin) 阿罗汉 阿羅漢 ā luó hàn arhat (Buddhist monk who has achieved Nirvana) ← pali 𑀅𑀭𑀳𑀦𑁆𑀢𑁆 अरहंत् arahant arhat; majestic; honourable ← sanskrit अर्हत् arhat arhat; venerable; honourable; deserving; celebrated + mandarin (pinyin) 鱼 魚 yú fish + english fish animal which lives in water
Words.Definition: the flowerhorn cichlid, an ornamental aquarium fish that is a hybrid of various cichlid species, particularly Amphilophus labiatus (the red devil cichlid) and Amphilophus trimaculatum (the three spot cichlid), and which can grow to a size of around 50 - 60 cm. It has a distinctive, prominent forehead protuberance known as a nuchal hump, an asesthetic feature which is highly prized by many aquarium hobbyists in Singapore and Malaysia.
Words.Example: Mr Yap also allayed concerns that the company's earnings would be affected in case the bubble bursts on the current luo han fish fad. These fishes account for only two per cent of the company's total turnover, said Mr Yap.

Words.Word: luo han guo 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Mandarin: 罗汉果 羅漢果 pinyin: luó hàn guǒ from mandarin (pinyin) 罗汉果 羅漢果 luó hàn guǒ monkfruit, the edible fruit of Siraitia grosvenorii ← mandarin (pinyin) 罗汉 羅漢 luó hàn clipping of arhat ← mandarin (pinyin) 阿罗汉 阿羅漢 ā luó hàn arhat (Buddhist monk who has achieved Nirvana) ← pali 𑀅𑀭𑀳𑀦𑁆𑀢𑁆 अरहंत् arahant arhat; majestic; honourable ← sanskrit अर्हत् arhat arhat; venerable; honourable; deserving; celebrated + mandarin (pinyin) 果 果 guǒ fruit
Words.Definition: monkfruit, the edible fruit of Siraitia grosvenorii, an apple-sized, yellowish-brown round fruit which is usually dried to form a thin, hard, brittle shell for sale. It is used by the Chinese to make sweet drinks and as herbal medicine. It is also popularly used as a zero-calorie sweetener, due to it containing the natural noncaloric sweetening compounds known as mogrosides.
Words.Example: Formulated with black garlic, monk fruit (also known as luo han guo) and wolfberries, this ready-to-drink supplement is 100-percent natural and refreshing.

Words.English Translation: → Cantonese: 腊肠 臘腸 jyutping: laap6 coeng4-2 from cantonese (jyutping) 腊肠 臘腸 laap6 coeng4-2 Chinese sausage ← cantonese (jyutping) 腊 臘 laap6 cured or dried meat + cantonese (jyutping) 肠 腸 coeng4-2 intestine; sausage
Words.Definition: a hard, red, Chinese sausage made from pork and pork fat, which is seasoned, smoked, waxed, and dried, used widely as an ingredient in Cantonese and other Chinese cuisines
Words.Example: My grandmother can converse in Hokkien and Cantonese, and makes good fried rice with lap cheong (sausage) which I loved eating as a child.

Words.English Translation: → General chinese: 嘛 pinyin: ma from general chinese (pinyin) 嘛 ma used to point out sth. obvious
Words.Definition: used to point out that a reason is obvious, self-evident, or must logically follow from a previous condition
Words.Example: - Why we must wait here so long?- The light still red ma.

Words.English Translation: → Mandarin: 麻烦 麻煩 pinyin: má fan from mandarin (pinyin) 麻烦 麻煩 má fan troublesome; hasslesome; annoying
Words.Definition: troublesome; hasslesome; annoying
Words.Example: ... having a child on your own, single mother, very ma fan leh, get a dog. Fish even better, no need to clean poo. Ma fan doesn't even begin to cut it ...

Words.Word: ma lai gou 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Cantonese: 马拉糕 馬拉糕 jyutping: maa5 laai1 gou1 from cantonese (jyutping) 马拉糕 馬拉糕 maa5 laai1 gou1 steamed dim sum sponge cake ← cantonese (jyutping) 马拉 馬拉 maa5 laai1 of or relating to the Malays ← english Malay of or relating to the Malays ← malay Melayu Malay + cantonese (jyutping) 糕 糕 gou1 cake
Words.Definition: a soft, fluffy steamed sponge cake, commonly flavoured with brown sugar, coconut milk, or honey, and served as a dim sum dish
Words.Example: ... and test your chopstick skills on ma lai gou, a soft steamed sponge cake, sipping tea throughout.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 嘛是三箍 poj: mā-sī saⁿ kho͘ from hokkien (poj) 嘛是三箍 mā-sī saⁿ kho͘ it will still/also be three dollars (no matter how hard you work) ← hokkien (poj) 嘛是 mā-sī also be; nevertheless be ← hokkien (poj) 嘛 mā also; nevertheless + hokkien (poj) 是 sī be + hokkien (poj) 三 saⁿ three + hokkien (poj) 箍 kho͘ unit of money (dollar, etc.)
Words.Definition: (NS, aphorism) used to express that no matter what, one's pay will still be the same pitifully small amount at the end of the day, and thus there is no need to put in too much effort and hard work

Words.English Translation: → Malay: mabuk from malay mabuk drunk; inebriated
Words.Definition: drunk; inebriated
Words.Example: Requiem is so potent in its effecting the hell of addiction that it lulls us into the characters' same dreamy drugged-out state through such insiduous repetitions. And that is mind-blowing. You might well stagger out from the cinema a little mabok (drunk) yourself.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: macam from malay macam like; similar to
Words.Definition: like; similar to
Words.Example: Aiyoh! Don't call me that lah. Macam ... pensioner lah. The reality of it being 20 years hasn't really sunk in yet. I still feel very young.

Words.English Translation: → German: Maggi from german Maggi brand of food products including sauces, instant noodles, and instant soups ← german Maggi last name of Julius Michael Johannes Maggi, a Swiss entrepreneur and founder of Maggi
Words.Definition: instant noodles
Words.Example: moi put chili insai moi maggie ... harvest some ghost chili ... put half insai noodles ... crying liao bery hot

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: maggi1 + Malay: goreng from singlish maggi1 instant noodles ← german Maggi brand of food products including sauces, instant noodles, and instant soups ← german Maggi last name of Julius Michael Johannes Maggi, a Swiss entrepreneur and founder of Maggi + malay goreng fried
Words.Definition: a Malay or Indian-Muslim variant of mee goreng using instant noodles as the noodles, which are stir-fried together with other ingredients, such as seasoning powder from the instant noodle packets, soya sauce, chilli, sambal, vegetables, egg, meat, prawns, tomato ketchup, etc.
Words.Example: That often leaves her enough time to grab a quick fix of hearty murtabak or maggi goreng with a milo dinosaur from her favourite prata haunts ...

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: maggi1 + mee from singlish maggi1 instant noodles ← german Maggi brand of food products including sauces, instant noodles, and instant soups ← german Maggi last name of Julius Michael Johannes Maggi, a Swiss entrepreneur and founder of Maggi + singlish mee noodles ← hokkien (poj) 面 麵 mī wheat noodles
Words.Definition: instant noodles
Words.Example: But should you still crave your maggi mee, there's bound to be a mamak stall offering fried maggi mee, with a fried egg on top, just round the corner.

Words.English Translation: → Baba malay: mah mee from baba malay mah mee dish of yellow noodles with prawn stock and meat ← hokkien (poj) 肉面 肉麵 mah-mī dish of noodles with meat ← hokkien (poj) 肉 肉 mah/bah esp. pork and shrimp/prawn + hokkien (poj) 面 麵 mī meat
Words.Definition: a Peranakan dish of yellow noodles stir-fried with prawns, pork, vegetables, garlic, shallots, chilli, tau cheo, and other ingredients in a prawn-based stock. It was likely derived from the Hokkien dish Hokkien mee.
Words.Example: The finished Nyonya Mah Mee should be deliciously moist with the noodles fluffed up and succulent after soaking in the sauce and all its lovely flavours but still maintaining its springy textures.

Words.English Translation: → Min nan: 莫 莫 poj: mài from min nan (poj) 莫 莫 mài not want; contraction of 毋愛 ← min nan (poj) 毋爱 毋愛 m̄-ài not want
Words.Definition: to not want (something)
Words.Example: Mai, last time so embarrassing, I don't want try again lah.
Related: khiang tioh ho, mai keh khiang
mai la mai la, wa mai

Words.English Translation: → Min nan: 莫 莫 poj: mài + 莶 薟 poj: hiam from min nan (poj) 莫 莫 mài not want; contraction of 毋愛 ← hokkien (poj) 毋爱 毋愛 m̄-ài not want + min nan (poj) 莶 薟 hiam spicy
Words.Definition: (food ordering) non-spicy; without chilli or other spicy ingredients
Words.Example: Uncle, one wantan mee mai hiam.

Words.Word: mai hiam buay pai 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Min nan: 莫 莫 poj: mài + 嫌 poj: hiâm + 𫧃歹 𣍐歹 poj: bōe-pháiⁿ from min nan (poj) 莫 莫 mài not want; contraction of 毋愛 ← hokkien (poj) 毋爱 毋愛 m̄-ài not want + min nan (poj) 嫌 hiâm fed up with; dislike; complain; criticize + min nan (poj) 𫧃歹 𣍐歹 bōe-pháiⁿ not bad; pretty good ← hokkien (poj) 𫧃 𣍐 bōe not; cannot + hokkien (poj) 歹 歹 pháiⁿ bad; evil
Words.Definition: 'don’t complain or criticize, it’s not that bad'; 'don’t be too picky and choosy'
Words.Example: - Walao eh. I got this suit for $180, but Arif told me he got lobang in Bangkok that can do better one for $100.- Ok but still not bad what… Mai hiam buay paĩ.

Words.English Translation: → Min nan: 莫 莫 poj: mài + 啦 poj/poj: --la/--lah from min nan (poj) 莫 莫 mài not want; contraction of 毋愛 ← hokkien (poj) 毋爱 毋愛 m̄-ài not want + min nan (poj/poj) 啦 --la/--lah sentence-final particle used to convey emphasis, request, etc.
Words.Definition: 'come on, I don't want it'; 'no thanks'; 'please no'; used to reject something firmly but contritely and politely
Related: mai la mai la, wa mai

Words.Word: mai la mai la, wa mai 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Min nan: 莫 莫 poj: mài + 啦 poj/poj: --la/--lah + 莫 莫 poj: mài + 啦 poj/poj: --la/--lah + 我 poj: óa + 莫 莫 poj: mài from min nan (poj) 莫 莫 mài not want; contraction of 毋愛 ← min nan (poj) 毋爱 毋愛 m̄-ài not want + min nan (poj/poj) 啦 --la/--lah sentence-final particle used to convey emphasis, request, etc. + min nan (poj) 莫 莫 mài not want; contraction of 毋愛 ← min nan (poj) 毋爱 毋愛 m̄-ài not want + min nan (poj/poj) 啦 --la/--lah sentence-final particle used to convey emphasis, request, etc. + min nan (poj) 我 óa I; me; my + min nan (poj) 莫 莫 mài not want; contraction of 毋愛 ← min nan (poj) 毋爱 毋愛 m̄-ài not want
Words.Definition: 'no, no thanks, I don't want it'; used to reject something unequivocally and outright
Words.Example: Duh ... Of course accept la ... Cannot be say "mai la mai la wa mai"

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 莫躇了 poj: mài-tû/thû--liáu from hokkien (poj) 莫躇了 mài-tû/thû--liáu don’t hesitate;; don’t dilly-dally ← hokkien (poj) 莫 mài don’t; do not + hokkien (poj) 躇 tû/thû hesitate; be indecisive + hokkien (poj) 了 liáu already
Words.Definition: ‘don’t hesitate’; ‘don’t dilly-dally’; ‘act now’; ‘delay no more’
Words.Example: This wan lah mai tu liao ... If money no issue this wan very tokong

Words.English Translation: → English: mainstream + -er from english mainstream common; of the general population; ordinary ← english main primary; most extensive or sizeable + english stream division of a school batch based on ability (usu. academic) + english -er suffix used to form a demonym
Words.Definition: (derogatory) a student in one of the normal divisions of the Singaporean educational system, typically referring to any stream other than the GEP (Gifted Education Programme)

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: maintain balan from singlish maintain balan relax; chill out; don't worry ← english maintain preserve; keep up ← old french maintenir maintain ← late latin manūteneō support; maintain + english balance harmony; calmness ← old french balance weighing scales ← late latin bilancia that which is two-scaled
Words.Definition: 'relax'; 'keep it together'; 'stay cool', used to encourage a person to calm down and stay composed, especially in a stressful situation
Words.Example: Maintain leh, otter fans. Give otters the space they need.

Words.English Translation: → English: maintain + balance from english maintain preserve; keep up ← old french maintenir maintain ← late latin manūteneō support; maintain + english balance harmony; calmness ← old french balance weighing scales ← late latin bilancia that which is two-scaled
Words.Definition: 'relax'; 'don't panic'; used to encourage a person to calm down and stay composed, especially in a stressful situation

Words.English Translation: → Cantonese: 妈姐 媽姐 jyutping: maa2 ze2 from cantonese (jyutping) 妈姐 媽姐 maa2 ze2 Shunde maidservant ← cantonese (jyutping) 妈 媽 maa2 mother + cantonese (jyutping) 姐 姐 ze2 older sister
Words.Definition: any of the women from Shunde, Guangdong, who travelled overseas to places such as Southeast Asia in the early 20th century to seek work as maidservants. They typically wore a black-and white samfu, and were often indentured to serve a single household and never marry for their entire lives.
Words.Example: I never wandered beyond the watchful, guarding eyes of my majie ...

Words.English Translation: → Malay: mak + kau + hijau from malay mak mother ✂ malay emak mother + malay kau (familiar) 2p. sing. pron. ✂ malay engkau (familiar) 2p. sing. pron. + malay hijau green
Words.Definition: (juvenile, offensive, sometimes jocular) expression of contempt; used to insult a person’s mother, or by extension insult or provoke said person themself, by insinuating that their mother is 'green'
Related: ni ma ma mei you mao

Words.English Translation: → Malay: makan from malay makan eat; consume
Words.Definition: to eat
Words.Example: Cycling brings people together, and not only do we cycle, we have very regular makan trips, our kids play together in our estate, we try each other's cooking, we go for movies together.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: makan angin from malay makan angin (fig.) take a walk to get some fresh air; sit around silently passing the time ← malay makan eat; consume + malay angin wind
Words.Definition: (idiom) to go on holiday; to gallivant; to go for a joyride

Words.English Translation: → Malay: makan gaji from malay makan gaji work for salary ← malay makan eat; consume + malay gaji wages; salary ← dutch gage wages; salary ← middle french gage wages; salary; deposit
Words.Definition: (idiom) to work to earn a living; to work just for the pay
Words.Example: … to hold a job and to mine it for all it’s worth constructively requires something more than just the air of makan gaji.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: makan + Singlish: kaki1 & Malay: makan + kaki ↻ Likely, but other possible etymologies exist Cantonese: 饭脚 飯腳 jyutping: faan6 goek3 from malay makan eat; consume + singlish kaki1 friend; buddy; companion or partner who one does a shared activity with ← malay kaki sb. who is fond of or good at sth.; lover of sth.; leg; foot &/or singlish ka ki nang one of us; one of our own; people in one's circle; friends and family ← teochew / hainanese / min nan (peng'im) 家己侬 家己儂 ga1 gi7 nang5 one of us; one of our own; close companions; sb. in one's circle & malay makan eat; meal; food + malay kaki sb. who is fond of or good at sth.; lover of sth.; leg; foot ↻ cantonese (jyutping) Likely, but other possible etymologies exist 饭脚 飯腳 faan6 goek3 lunch buddy; sb. who one dines out with[1] ← cantonese (jyutping) 饭 飯 faan6 food; meal; cooked rice + cantonese (jyutping) 脚 腳 goek3 sb. who joins in an activity; leg; foot
Words.Definition: a group of close companions with whom one regularly gets meals; lunch buddies
Words.Example: I quickly conveved a meeting of makan kakis, and we got to work. (I really mean makan kakis. Our first editorial meeting was at a café in Holland Village. Our second was at Sakunthala's on Race Course Road. And so on...)

Words.English Translation: → Malay: makan + English: session from malay makan eat; consume + english session period of time dedicated to an activity ← old french session session; sitting ← latin sessiō session; sitting
Words.Definition: a meal with others, especially one planned beforehand as a social gathering
Words.Example: If ending each workout with a makan session sounds like your idea of fun, this is the running group to join.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: makan + ular ↻ Min nan: 食蛇 poj: chia̍h-chôa from malay makan eat + malay ular snake ↻ min nan (poj) 食蛇 chia̍h-chôa slack off; skive; play truant; take time off work ← min nan (poj) 食迣 chia̍h-chōa clipping of 偷食迣 ← min nan (poj) 偷食迣 thau-chia̍h-chōa (lit.) slyly take trips or runs; (fig.) skive; sneakily slack off; slyly take time off work ← min nan (poj) 偷食 thau-chia̍h slyly eat; sneakily take (food, etc.) + min nan (poj) 迣 chōa (measure word) trips; runs; frequency of occurrences
Words.Definition: to slack off; to skive; to take time off work; to play truant
Words.Example: The new intern didn't last long after being caught trying to makan ular several times.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: makcik from malay makcik aunt ← malay mak mother + malay cik miss; term of address for an unmarried woman ✂ malay Likely, but other possible etymologies exist encik mister; term of respectful address for an older man ← hokkien (poj) 引叔 ín-chek dear uncle ← hokkien (poj) 引 ín dear; honorific prefix + hokkien (poj) 叔 chek uncle; father's younger brother
Words.Definition: aunt; auntie; term of address or endearment for an aunt
Words.Example: macik see me liao tao hin hin, bak chew huay huay ... then count salah

Words.English Translation: → Cantonese: 马骝 馬騮 jyutping: maa5 lau4-1 or Hokkien: 麻粩 poj: mâ-láu from cantonese (jyutping) 马骝 馬騮 maa5 lau4-1 monkey or hokkien (poj) 麻粩 mâ-láu fried puffed rice snack with maltose, sesame seeds, and crushed peanuts
Words.Definition: (military, derogatory) a Taiwanese person

Words.English Translation: → Cantonese: 马骝 馬騮 jyutping: maa5 lau4-1 or Hokkien: 麻粩 poj: mâ-láu + 兵 poj: peng from cantonese (jyutping) 马骝 馬騮 maa5 lau4-1 monkey or hokkien (poj) 麻粩 mâ-láu fried puffed rice snack with maltose, sesame seeds, and crushed peanuts + hokkien (poj) 兵 peng soldier; warrior; army
Words.Definition: (military, derogatory) a Taiwanese soldier

Words.English Translation: → Malay: malu from malay malu embarrassed; shy
Words.Definition: embarrassed; shy; ashamed
Related: giah lam pa chut lai tom toh teng

Words.English Translation: → Malay: malu + English: -ate from malay malu embarrassed; shy + english -ate suffix used to form a verb from a stem
Words.Definition: to embarrass; to shame; to humiliate
Related: giah lam pa chut lai tom toh teng

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: maluate + English: -ed from singlish maluate embarrass; shame; humiliate ← malay malu embarrassed; shy + english -ate suffix used to form a verb from a stem + english -ed suffix used to form past tense or past participles of verbs
Words.Definition: embarrassed; shy; ashamed; humiliated
Words.Example: It’s a bit cheem (difficult, confusing) and we’re feeling a bit maluated (embarrassed) at our lack of knowledge.
Related: giah lam pa chut lai tom toh teng

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: maluate + English: -ing from singlish maluate embarrass; shame; humiliate ← malay malu embarrassed; shy + english -ate suffix used to form a verb from a stem + english -ing suffix used to form present participles of verbs
Words.Definition: embarrassing; shameful; humiliating; disgraceful
Words.Example: Im suppose t sit at table 29 and ended up sitting at table 26. Dang maluating please!
Related: giah lam pa chut lai tom toh teng

Words.English Translation: → Tamil: மாமா māmā + English: shop from tamil மாமா māmā maternal uncle + english shop stall where goods are sold
Words.Definition: a small, local sundry or general goods stall, usually owned and operated by one stallholder, and located in a HDB estate or in the void deck of a HDB block
Words.Example: Childhood snacks can transport you back to a simpler time when winning the most number of goli (marbles) made you the happiest and most popular kid on the block. Those were the days when going to the mamak shop was like entering the wonderful world of Willy Wonka.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: mamak from malay mamak Tamil Muslim; stall selling Tamil Muslim cuisine, or the cuisine itself ← malay mamak maternal uncle; uncle &/or tamil மாமா māmā maternal uncle
Words.Definition: a Tamil Muslim (usually male)
Words.Example: Every afternoon my friends and I always looked forward to the mamak bread man who arrived on his motorcycle at 5pm on the dot. We would hear his bell ringing and run out to buy snacks.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: mamak + English: stall from malay mamak Tamil Muslim; stall selling Tamil Muslim cuisine, or the cuisine itself ← malay mamak maternal uncle; uncle &/or tamil மாமா māmā maternal uncle + english stall small shop where goods are sold
Words.Definition: a stall, eatery, or restaurant selling Tamil Muslim and/or Malay cuisine
Words.Example: Another from Tamil Nadu, Murthi, and I used to have conversations about family, food, and relationships during that earlier period, often while he was off work and enjoying his late evening meal at a mamak stall, which I would always buy him in exchange for the conversations.

Words.English Translation: → Malay / baba malay: mampat from malay / baba malay mampat compressed; tightly packed; compact, very good; beautiful; excellent; thumbs up
Words.Definition: (especially of a woman’s clothing or buttocks) tight

Words.English Translation: → Malay: mampus from malay mampus die; pass away
Words.Definition: done for; finished; dead meat; screwed
Words.Example: If you make a scene, you yell and shout, then, he has an excuse to get angry! "Oh, my wife is such a shrew. No wonder I can't stay with her!" Mampus, you're finished!

Words.English Translation: → English: man + mode from english man (mil.) soldier who is not a non-commissioned oficer or officer + english mode state of mind or being; setting ← old french mode manner; method; mood ← latin modus manner; method; mood
Words.Definition: (military) a state of mind induced in soldiers as a result of extreme physical or mental fatigue, uncaringness, etc. where they cluelessly follow behind others and make no effort or contribution to the group other than the bare minimum
Words.Example: Went to a specialist course and regretted it like crazy not just opting to be a man. Just man mode and do something useful with the extra free time

Words.English Translation: → Malay: mana from malay mana where
Words.Definition: where

Words.Word: mana eh sai 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: mana poj: ma-na + 会使 會使 poj: ē-sái from hokkien (poj) mana ma-na where; (rhet.) how ← malay mana where + hokkien (poj) 会使 會使 ē-sái can; may; be allowed to
Words.Definition: how can it be; since when is it allowed; in what situation is it possible; in what world would this do or suffice; how is this fair
Words.Example: But how in God's name could it be her? I looked at the girl again, praying I was mistaken."Mana eh sai!" Mu said, his voice ragged. "I don't believe it".

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien / teochew: 芒加跤 poj: mâng-ka-kha from hokkien / teochew (poj) 芒加跤 mâng-ka-kha historical area around Whampoa, Boon Keng Road, Bendemeer Road, and Balestier Road ← hokkien / teochew (poj) 芒加 mâng-ka jackfruit (Artocarpus heterophyllus) ← malay nangka jackfruit (Artocarpus heterophyllus) + hokkien / teochew (poj) 跤 kha foot; leg; base
Words.Definition: a historical area in Singapore roughly corresponding to the region around Whampoa, Boon Keng Road, Bendemeer Road, and Balestier Road
Words.Example: The vernacular parlance for many places is fading in the nation's memory — Tua Po, Siew Po, Mang Ga Kah, Sa Koh Jio, all alien to the younger generation, a result of the ferociously conducted 'Use Mandarin' campaign, which discouraged the use of Chinese dialects.

Words.English Translation: → Cantonese: 𤷪𤺧 jyutping: mang2 zang2 from cantonese (jyutping) 𤷪𤺧 mang2 zang2 irritable; easily annoyed; snappy
Words.Definition: irritable; easily annoyed; anxious; snappy; on edge
Words.Example: So now ah, limbu got no US dorrar to take taxi to the hotel. So mang zang leh!

Words.English Translation: → English: Bengali from english Bengali of or relating to Bengal or the Bengalis ← sylheti ꠛꠦꠋꠉꠟꠤ beṅgoli of or relating to Bengal or the Bengalis or bengali বাঙ্গালী baṅgali of or relating to the Bengalis
Words.Definition: (derogatory) a person of Indian or other South Asian descent

Words.English Translation: → Malay: mangkuk from malay mangkuk bowl
Words.Definition: (NS, metaphor) 'empty-head'; term of insult or address for a vacuous, stupid, or silly person
Words.Example: Eh mangkok, so slow for what?

Words.English Translation: → English: mango + pomelo + sago from english mango Mangifera indica and its edible fruit ← portuguese manga mango ← malay mangga mango ← tamil மாங்காய் māṅkāy unripe mango &/or malayalam മാങ്ങ māṅṅa mango + english pomelo Citrus maxima and its edible fruit ← english pampelmoes pomelo ← french pamplemousse pomelo ← dutch pompelmoes grapefruit; pomelo ← dutch Possible, but not certain pompen pumpkin or dutch Possible, but not certain pompel swollen; big; thick + dutch Possible, but not certain limoes citrus; lemon ← portuguese limões lemons ← arabic لَيْمُون laymūn lemon ← persian لیمو limu lemon; lime ← sanskrit निम्बू nimbū lemon; lime + english sago starch of sago palms, plants of the species Metroxylon esp. M. sagu ← malay sagu sago palms, plants of the species Metroxylon esp. M. sagu, and their edible starch
Words.Definition: a cold dessert made with diced mango, mango purée, sago pearls, pomelo, and coconut milk or milk. It was invented in the 1980s in Singapore by a chef from Hong Kong, who sought to create a dish with the characteristics of Cantonese tong sui desserts but using local ingredients.

Words.English Translation: → English: mango + sago from english mango Mangifera indica and its edible fruit ← portuguese manga mango ← malay mangga mango ← tamil மாங்காய் māṅkāy unripe mango &/or malayalam മാങ്ങ māṅṅa mango + english sago starch of sago palms, plants of the species Metroxylon esp. M. sagu ← malay sagu sago palms, plants of the species Metroxylon esp. M. sagu, and their edible starch
Words.Definition: a cold dessert made with diced mango, mango purée, sago pearls, and coconut milk or milk. It was invented in Singapore in the 1980s by a chef from Hong Kong, who sought to create a dish with the characteristics of Cantonese tong sui desserts but using local ingredients.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: manis from malay manis sweet
Words.Definition: (taste) sweet

Words.English Translation: → Malay: manja from malay manja spoilt; pampered; coddled, friendly; gentle; affectionate
Words.Definition: to spoil; to pamper; to coddle; to adore
Words.Example: I don't really like Nicole (my roommate) very much, but she's very sociable and well-liked and manja.

Words.English Translation: → Mandarin: 慢摇 慢搖 pinyin: màn yǎo from mandarin (pinyin) 慢摇 慢搖 màn yǎo (music) low-tempo; (genre) downtempo
Words.Definition: a genre of downtempo Mandarin EDM or house music, commonly enjoyed by YPs and heard at Thai discos (siam dius) and karaokes
Words.Example: The typical zh’nged look can best be described as café racer meets fixie meets The Fast and The Furious circa 2001. Think lowered handlebars, cut frames, custom fairings, blindingly bright LED lights, and obnoxiously loud Bluetooth speakers often blasting a tacky Mandarin eurodance genre known as Manyao.

Words.Word: Mao Shan Wang 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Mandarin: 猫山王 貓山王 pinyin: māo shān wáng + Singlish: Musang King from mandarin (pinyin) 猫山王 貓山王 māo shān wáng Musang King ← mandarin (pinyin) 猫 貓 māo cat + mandarin (pinyin) 山 山 shān mountain + mandarin (pinyin) 王 王 wáng king + singlish Musang King cultivar of durian originating in Gua Musang, Kelantan, Malaysia ← malay [Gua] Musang district in Kelantan, Malaysia where the cultivar was discovered ← malay musang Asian palm civet (Paradoxurus hermaphroditus); civet cat + english king (usu. male) the ruler of a monarchy; a powerful or preeminent person ↻ malay Raja [Kunyit] original name of the variety of durian from which Musang King was developed; (lit.) Turmeric King ← malay raja king; monarch ← sanskrit राजन् rājan king; prince
Words.Definition: a cultivar of durian originating in Gua Musang, Kelantan, Malaysia, prized for its texture and flavour
Words.Example: Look out for their new offering of crystal durian mini mooncake — the brand's 2016 creation that features a creamy mix of D24 and Mao Shan Wang durian filling encased in a tender, see-through crystal skin.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: mari kita from malay mari kita let us ← malay mari come on; come + malay kita we; us; our (1p. pl. inclusive pronoun)
Words.Definition: to stand upright; to stand at attention
Words.Example: ah meng got marikita bo

Words.English Translation: → General filipino: Maria from general filipino Maria female given name ← spanish María female given name ← latin Marīa female given name ← ancient greek Μᾰρῐ́ᾱ(μ) Maríā(m) female given name ← aramaic מרים maryām female given name & biblical hebrew מִרְיָם miryám female given name
Words.Definition: (possibly racist, derogatory) a Filipino maid
Words.Example: I already gave her discount in housework cuz I wash my own clothes, fold n iron my own clothes, clean my own room ... Now cooking also I do? ... I might as well sack her n I become the Maria

Words.English Translation: → English: market from english market system of trading and demand ← latin mercātus trade; market
Words.Definition: (betting) betting odds

Words.English Translation: → English: marketing from english marketing (arch.) trading at a market ← english market set place for trade of goods ← latin mercātus trade; market + english -ing suffixed to a verb to form a noun or its gerund form
Words.Definition: shopping; buying goods at a market
Words.Example: Geylang Serai is a lively place where Malays, even those who live elsewhere in Singapore, love to go marketing, dining, shopping, or simply to hang out.

Words.English Translation: → English: money from english money cash; currency; legally accepted means of quantifying and exchanging wealth ← anglo-norman muneie money; coins ← latin monēta mint; money; coins ← latin Monēta Italian goddess of the mint
Words.Definition: (usually ironic) money
Words.Example: Our cpf marnee is to kua sah to our chewren hokay
Related: see no touch, touch no see, see and touch, pay money

Words.English Translation: → Malay: masak-masak from malay masak-masak cook; play-cooking ⇇ malay masak cook
Words.Definition: play-cooking, an activity done by children where they pretend to cook using toy ingredients and utensils
Words.Example: During my childhood, I was contented to play "masak-masak" using shredded recycled paper. After tearing the paper into shapes to represent different food items, I "cooked" them in a "wok" and served them to my doll. Any toy more than this was a luxury to me.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: masuk from malay masuk enter; come in; join
Words.Definition: to enter; to go in

Words.English Translation: → Malay: mat from malay mat (slang) guy; dude; John Doe ← malay Ahmad popular Muslim male given name ← arabic أَحْمَد ʔaḥmad popular Arabic male given name + malay Muhammad* extremely popular Muslim male given name ← arabic مُحَمَّد muḥammad prophet of Islam; extremely popular Arabic male given name, (lit.) praised; exalted; extolled ← arabic حَمِدَ ḥamida thank; praise; exalt
Words.Definition: (chiefly of a male Malay person) a guy; a dude; a John Doe; a generic name for an anonymous or unknown male person
Words.Example: In its purest form, “sial” means “jinx” but mats have refined the art of using the word to include it at the end of their every sentence.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: mat + motor/moto from malay mat (slang) guy; dude; John Doe ← malay Ahmad popular Muslim male given name ← arabic أَحْمَد ʔaḥmad popular Arabic male given name + malay Muhammad* extremely popular Muslim male given name ← arabic مُحَمَّد muḥammad prophet of Islam; extremely popular Arabic male given name, (lit.) praised; exalted; extolled ← arabic حَمِدَ ḥamida thank; praise; exalt + malay motor/moto motor; sth. powered by a motor, e.g. a motorcycle or car ← english motor device which converts energy into mechanical energy ← latin mōtor sth. which moves sth.
Words.Definition: a subculture consisting of (usually Malay) people who have a strong interest or passion about motor vehicles, especially motorcycles
Words.Example: Recently, Federal Territories Minister Datuk Seri Tengku Adnan Tengku Mansor suggested that motorcycle race tracks be provided in certain areas of the capital to meet the needs and interests of young people known as mat moto.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: mat + rempit from malay mat (slang) guy; dude; John Doe ← malay Ahmad popular Muslim male given name ← arabic أَحْمَد ʔaḥmad popular Arabic male given name + malay Muhammad* extremely popular Muslim male given name ← arabic مُحَمَّد muḥammad prophet of Islam; extremely popular Arabic male given name, (lit.) praised; exalted; extolled ← arabic حَمِدَ ḥamida thank; praise; exalt + malay rempit motor; sth. powered by a motor, e.g. a motorcycle or car ← english Possible, but not certain ramp increase rapidly; fire up + english Possible, but not certain it impersonal pron.
Words.Definition: a subculture consisting of (usually Malay) people who participate in illegal street racing, performing motorbike stunts, and other petty criminal activities
Words.Example: Weekends and holidays attract many to enjoy the city's sights and sounds, but they're also attracting another crowd that's young and dangerous.The Mat Rempit menace is back in the heart of the city.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: mat + English: reputation from malay mat (slang) guy; dude; John Doe ← malay Ahmad popular Muslim male given name ← arabic أَحْمَد ʔaḥmad popular Arabic male given name + malay Muhammad* extremely popular Muslim male given name ← arabic مُحَمَّد muḥammad prophet of Islam; extremely popular Arabic male given name, (lit.) praised; exalted; extolled ← arabic حَمِدَ ḥamida thank; praise; exalt + english reputation image; public standing or perception; clout; what one is known for ← latin reputationem thinking over; reflection; consideration
Words.Definition: (derogatory) a young, delinquent Malay man, often associated with negative stereotypes such as smoking, drinking, truancy, lepaking, low education, and a certain style of dress such as tapered jeans and wearing trucker caps intentionally adjusted such that they sit too high on the head
Words.Example: “[When] mat reps fight, their language is coarse, but the delivery is beautiful. They use a lot of rhythm that is found in pantun [a Malay poetic form],” she explains.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: mat + rok from malay mat (slang) guy; dude; John Doe ← malay Ahmad popular Muslim male given name ← arabic أَحْمَد ʔaḥmad popular Arabic male given name + malay Muhammad* extremely popular Muslim male given name ← arabic مُحَمَّد muḥammad prophet of Islam; extremely popular Arabic male given name, (lit.) praised; exalted; extolled ← arabic حَمِدَ ḥamida thank; praise; exalt + malay rok rock (music genre) ← english rock music genre ✂ english rock and roll music genre
Words.Definition: a subculture consisting of Malay men and youth who listen to hard rock and heavy metal, and accordingly dress like metal fans or rock stars, with long hair, leather or denim jackets, and ripped jeans. It is often associated with antiestablishmentism, delinquency, and social deviance, but also provides an identity and community for the displaced, misunderstood, and neglected of society.
Words.Example: Immediate post independence stereotypes of Malay deviancy--the school drop out, the drug taker and the indolent musician were invariably masculine. However, Mat Rock today no longer holds the same connotations of deviancy with the greater social space given to the performing arts.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: mat + rok + English: -er from malay mat (slang) guy; dude; John Doe ← malay Ahmad popular Muslim male given name ← arabic أَحْمَد ʔaḥmad popular Arabic male given name + malay Muhammad* extremely popular Muslim male given name ← arabic مُحَمَّد muḥammad prophet of Islam; extremely popular Arabic male given name, (lit.) praised; exalted; extolled ← arabic حَمِدَ ḥamida thank; praise; exalt + malay rok rock (music genre) ← english rock music genre ✂ english rock and roll music genre + english -er suffix used to form a noun which performs the action of the root verb
Words.Definition: a Malay man or youth who listens to hard rock and heavy metal, and accordingly dresses like metal fans or rock stars, with long hair, leather or denim jackets, and ripped jeans, traits overall referred to as the mat rok subculture
Words.Example: The Mat Roker of the eighties wore almost skin tight jeans that came in all shades and were adorned with embroidered patches of heavy metal symbols. Hair was always kept long, sometimes past the waist. This was a direct affront to the government's policy on long hair.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: mat salih from malay mat salih white person; British person ← malay mat (slang) guy; dude; John Doe ← malay Ahmad popular Muslim male given name ← arabic أَحْمَد ʔaḥmad popular Arabic male given name + malay Muhammad* extremely popular Muslim male given name ← arabic مُحَمَّد muḥammad prophet of Islam; extremely popular Arabic male given name, (lit.) praised; exalted; extolled ← arabic حَمِدَ ḥamida thank; praise; exalt + malay salih unusual; standing out; different from the others
Words.Definition: a white person; a person of European descent, especially a British person
Words.Example: As I stepped out of the shower, the little white rodent scurried across the floor and I scurried out into the lodge. Housemaids were treated to the sight of a soaking wet mat salleh, shouting: "There's a mouse in my house!"

Words.English Translation: → Min nan / cantonese: 马打 馬打 poj: má-tâ from min nan / cantonese (poj) 马打 馬打 má-tâ police; policeman ← malay mata-mata police ⇇ malay mata eye
Words.Definition: a policeman; a police officer

Words.English Translation: → Malay: mata kucing from malay mata kucing Dimocarpus longan subsp. malesianus and its edible fruit ← malay mata eye + malay kucing cat
Words.Definition: Dimocarpus lichi (sometimes considered a subspecies of the longan, D. longan subsp. malesianus) or its edible fruit, which are spherical and around 2 - 3 cm in diameter with a firm, leathery, warty yellow-brown skin and translucent white, sweet flesh. The fruits come in large bunches. The skin splits open along a longitudinal line when squeezed, while the centre of the fruit contains a single large black seed. This gives it the appearance of an eye, with the skin being the eyelids and the flesh and seed being the sclera and iris respectively. It is closely related to and resembles the longan, but its flesh is sweeter and firmer and its skin is warty instead of smooth.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: mata-mata from malay mata-mata police; spy ⇇ malay mata eye
Words.Definition: a policeman; a police officer
Words.Example: Hawksworth and his men were not liked by anyone — neither by the local populace nor by their fellow uniformed constables. The locals referred to them as mata-mata, the Malay word for 'eyes'. They were not to be trusted, the people had decided ...

Words.English Translation: → Malay: matau from malay matau (slang) pool money, esp. to purchase a pack of cigarettes for sharing
Words.Definition: to pool money, especially to purchase a pack of cigarettes for sharing

Words.English Translation: → Malay: mati from malay mati die; dead
Words.Definition: to die; to pass away
Words.Example: There were red scrawls on the vehicle, including the word "mati" ...
Related: you die, I die, everybody die

Words.English Translation: → Malay: mati + susah from malay mati die; dead + malay susah difficult
Words.Definition: exclamation of woe or despair
Words.Example: Alamak! Forgot to off the oven. Mati susah!

Words.English Translation: → Malay: mati + terus from malay mati die; dead + malay terus directly; straight away; immediately
Words.Definition: to be screwed; to be done for; to be dead meat
Words.Example: sekali kena orchid cucuk..mati terus.
Related: you die, I die, everybody die

Words.English Translation: → English: to the max from english to the max to the utmost degree; extremely ← english maximum greatest amount ← french maximum maximum ← latin maximum maximum
Words.Definition: (postpositive) to the utmost degree; to the greatest extent; extremely
Words.Example: You friend very anal. Confirm buy smallest hdb and kiam siap max. Better unfriend him because he won’t be nice to you.

Words.English Translation: → English: medical certificate from english medical certificate doctor's note; validated statement from a healthcare professional on a patient's situation ← english medical of or relating to medicine and/or healthcare + english certificate document attesting to a statement or evidence of sth.
Words.Definition: a doctor's note; a validated statement from a physician or other healthcare professional on a patient's medical situation based on their evaluation
Words.Example: When in doubt, doctors are advised to review a patient's MC record, and if there are concerns of malingering – deliberately feigning symptoms – doctors will refer a patient for an in-person assessment.

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: MC + king from singlish MC initialism of 'medical certificate' ← english medical certificate doctor's note; validated statement from a healthcare professional on a patient's situation ← english medical of or relating to medicine and/or healthcare + english certificate document attesting to a statement or evidence of sth. + singlish king (suffix, usu. sarcastic or pejorative) the epitome of sth. ← english king (usu. male) the ruler of a monarchy; a powerful or preeminent person
Words.Definition: someone who is always taking MCs at the slightest sickness or injury; a serial malingerer
Words.Example: The scheme encouraged “MC kings and queens” who used to take medical leave “as and when they like” not to do so anymore, said Mr Lim.

Words.English Translation: → English: Mc[Spicy] + Min nan: 落屎 poj: làu-sái from english Mc[Spicy] spicy chicken burger sold by McDonald’s ← english Mc[Donald’s] American fast food chain started by the brothers McDonald ← scots gaelic mac [Dhòmhnaill] Scottish surname, (lit.) ‘son of Dhòmhnaill’ ← scots gaelic mac patronymic prefix; son of ← middle irish mac patronymic prefix; son of; son ← primitive irish ᚋᚐᚊᚊᚔ maqqi son of + min nan (poj) 落屎 làu-sái have diarrhoea ← min nan (poj) 落 làu leak; have diarrhoea + min nan (poj) 屎 sái faeces; poop; excrement
Words.Definition: (humorous) the McSpicy, an extremely popular McDonald’s menu item consisting of a deep-fried piece of spicy boneless chicken thigh between two toasted sesame seed burger buns
Words.Example: Ever since the McLaoSai exploded onto McDonald’s menus, Singapore has been split into two polarised groups: Those who love it and those who refuse to touch the damn thing with a laundry pole for fear of its powerful laxative effects.

Words.English Translation: → English: measure + road ↻ Mandarin: 量马路 量馬路 pinyin: liáng mǎ lù from english measure determine a quantity or amount; evaluate ← old french mesure measure; measurement ← latin mēnsūra measure + english road path for travelling ↻ mandarin (pinyin) 量马路 量馬路 liáng mǎ lù measure the road; (fig.) have nth. to do; do nth. ← mandarin (pinyin) 量 量 liáng measure; evaluate + mandarin (pinyin) 马路 馬路 mǎ lù road
Words.Definition: (idiom) to have nothing to do; to be idle and unoccupied

Words.English Translation: → English: Mediacorp + corpse from english Mediacorp Singaporean government-owned media conglomerate ← english media pl. of 'medium' ← english medium means of communication and broadcasting of information ← latin medius middle; central + english corp abbr. of 'corporation' ✂ english corporation legal entity or body distinct from its members ← late latin corporatio incarnation; taking on of a body + english corpse dead (usu. human) body ← old french cors body ← latin corpus body
Words.Definition: (pejorative) Mediacorp, the government-owned media conglomerate of Singapore
Words.Example: MediaCorpse says their radio stations remain as favourite radio stations in Singapore! JOKE!

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 面 麵 poj: mī from hokkien (poj) 面 麵 mī wheat noodles
Words.Definition: noodles
Words.Example: Residents of Singapore often eat mah-mee and Hokkien mee, but few observe the mee manufacturer at work.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: mee/mi + goreng from malay mee/mi noodles ← hokkien (poj) 面 麵 mī wheat noodles + malay goreng fried
Words.Definition: a Malay or Indian-Muslim dish of yellow alkaline egg noodles (mee) stir-fried together with other ingredients, such as soya sauce, chilli, sambal, vegetables, egg, meat, prawns, seasoning powder, tomato ketchup, etc.
Words.Example: Those who have always wanted to whip up mee goreng or chicken rice will be able to learn from the masters from May.

Words.Word: mee goreng mamak 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Malay: mee goreng + mamak from malay mee goreng Malay or Indian-Muslim fried noodle dish ← malay mee/mi noodles ← hokkien (poj) 面 麵 mī wheat noodles + malay goreng fried + malay mamak Tamil Muslim; stall selling Tamil Muslim cuisine, or the cuisine itself ← malay mamak maternal uncle; uncle &/or tamil மாமா māmā maternal uncle
Words.Definition: Indian-Muslim-style mee goreng, usually sold at a mamak stall

Words.Word: mee hoon kueh 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 面粉粿 麵粉粿 poj: mī-hún-kóe from hokkien (poj) 面粉粿 麵粉粿 mī-hún-kóe rectangular handmade noodles ← hokkien (poj) 面 麵 mī flour; wheat noodles + hokkien (poj) 粉 粉 hún powder; flour + hokkien (poj) 粿 粿 kóe steamed cake made from rice flour or glutinous rice flour
Words.Definition: a type of handmade Hokkien noodle made by pinching and tearing flat, roughly rectangular pieces off a sheet of dough, or alternatively slicing rectangular pieces with a knife, resulting in flat noodles measuring roughly 2 cm by 4 cm and 2 mm thick. It is made of the same dough as pan mee and you mee.
Words.Example: Mee hoon kueh was one of the few things I was allowed to help make as a kid. These are handmade noodles, done without any of the faff of a pasta machine or even a rolling pin ... To make them, you simply tear off a piece of dough, crudely flatten it in between floury palms, and toss it into the boiling pot.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 面囝 麵囝 poj: mī-kiáⁿ from hokkien (poj) 面囝 麵囝 mī-kiáⁿ thin, slender alkaline egg noodles ← hokkien (poj) 面 麵 mī wheat noodles + hokkien (poj) 囝 囝 kiáⁿ baby; child; dimin. suffix
Words.Definition: a type of slender alkaline egg noodle made of wheat flour with a springy, firm texture and characteristic yellow colour, commonly used in Hokkien and Teochew dishes. It is made of the same dough as mee pok.
Words.Example: Also recommended is the Kao Soi Kai ($7.50) with mee kia and chicken chunks smothered in a curry richly flavoured with coconut milk.

Words.English Translation: → Baba malay: mee + nyonya from baba malay mee noodles ← hokkien (poj) 面 麵 mī wheat noodles + baba malay nyonya female Peranakan or descendant of Peranakans; honorific term for a non-Malay but Straits-born woman ← portuguese Possible, but not certain dona lady; term of address for a middle-aged or older lady ← latin domna/domina lady; madam or hokkien (poj) Possible, but not certain 娘 niû/niô͘/niâ woman; lady; girl
Words.Definition: a Peranakan dish of yellow noodles stir-fried with prawns, pork, vegetables, garlic, shallots, chilli, tau cheo, and other ingredients in a prawn-based stock. It was likely derived from the Hokkien dish Hokkien mee.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 面薄 麵薄 poj: mī-po̍h from hokkien (poj) 面薄 麵薄 mī-po̍h thin, flat egg noodles ← hokkien (poj) 面 麵 mī wheat noodles + hokkien (poj) 薄 薄 po̍h (of thickness) thin
Words.Definition: a type of thin, flat alkaline egg noodle made of wheat flour with a springy, firm texture and characteristic yellow colour, commonly used in Hokkien and Teochew dishes. It is made of the same dough as mee kia.
Words.Example: So popular are eggs that we have seen Japanese-styled ni-tamago appear in traditional dishes such as mee pok ...

Words.English Translation: → Malay: mee/mi + rebus from malay mee/mi noodles ← hokkien (poj) 面 麵 mī wheat noodles + malay rebus boil; boiled
Words.Definition: a Malay dish of yellow noodles in a thick, spiced gravy based on sweet potato, tau cheo, and/or prawn stock, usually topped with sliced chilli, fried shallots, meat, a hard-boiled egg halved lengthwise, tau kwa, etc. and a slice of limau kasturi (calamansi lime) to be squeezed over the dish before eating
Words.Example: When it comes to hawker food, Singaporeans appear to have no qualms about paying more for quality mee rebus and chicken rice, according to the results of the "Really Worth It!" Hawker List released yesterday ...

Words.English Translation: → Malay: mee siam from malay mee siam noodle dish consisting of bee hoon in a sweet, sour, and savoury gravy ← malay mee/mi noodles ← hokkien (poj) 面 麵 mī wheat noodles + malay Siam former name of Thailand; Thai; Siamese ← thai สยาม sà-yǎam former name of Thailand
Words.Definition: a noodle dish consisting of bee hoon with a sweet, sour, and savoury gravy of rempah (a spice mix), assam (tamarind), and tau cheo. It is usually topped with a hard boiled egg sliced in half lengthwise, a meat such as chicken or prawns, and vegetables.
Words.Example: But the mee siam made me swallow my sneer. It was boldly flavoured and perfectly balanced between sweet, sour, and savoury. The fresh king prawns on top brought their own sweetness to the dish, while the noodles were slippery without being too soggy. Its generous portion sealed the deal.

Words.Word: mee siam mai hum 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Malay: mee siam + Min nan: 莫 莫 poj: mài + Min nan / cantonese: 蚶 poj: ham from malay mee siam noodle dish consisting of bee hoon in a sweet, sour, and savoury gravy ← malay mee/mi noodles ← hokkien (poj) 面 麵 mī wheat noodles + malay Siam former name of Thailand; Thai; Siamese ← thai สยาม sà-yǎam former name of Thailand + min nan (poj) 莫 莫 mài not want; contraction of 毋愛 ← hokkien (poj) 毋爱 毋愛 m̄-ài not want + min nan / cantonese (poj) 蚶 ham ark clam, any marine bivalve mollusc in the family Arcidae
Words.Definition: mee siam without cockles

Words.English Translation: → Malay: mee/mi + soto from malay mee/mi noodles ← hokkien (poj) 面 麵 mī wheat noodles + malay soto traditional spiced soup ← hokkien (poj) 牛草肚 gû-chháu-tō͘ beef tripe
Words.Definition: a dish of yellow noodles in a spiced chicken soup (soto ayam), usually topped with hard-boiled eggs, fried shallots, shredded chicken, etc. The soup has a characteristic yellowish colour due to the use of turmeric as a key ingredient, and originates from Indonesian cuisine.
Words.Example: One particular event htat sealed our relationship was a dinner date at the Kopi-House just outside the old National Library at Stamford Road. The mee soto and the teh tarik were just incredible. My wife and I still talk about that dinner date ...

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: mee + soup from singlish mee noodles ← hokkien (poj) 面 麵 mī wheat noodles + singlish soup (of noodles) w/ soup served as part of the main dish instead of on the side ← english soup liquid-based dish with water or stock and other ingredients; broth ← french soupe soup
Words.Definition: any of various dishes of noodles served in soup

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 面线 麵線 poj: mī-sòaⁿ from hokkien (poj) 面线 麵線 mī-sòaⁿ thin, slender, salted wheat noodles ← hokkien (poj) 面 麵 mī wheat noodles + hokkien (poj) 线 線 sòaⁿ string; line
Words.Definition: a type of thin, slender, salted noodle with a very soft texture made of wheat flour, commonly used in Hokkien dishes. It is similar to bee hoon, except that it is made of wheat instead of rice flour.
Words.Example: The wide selection includes handmade dim sum and signatures such as ... its stewed mee sua with oyster in a crab roe gravy.

Words.English Translation: → Cantonese: 咩 jyutping: me1 from cantonese (jyutping) 咩 me1 used to impart a doubtful, questioning, or surprised tone to a qn.
Words.Definition: (high tone) used to impart a doubtful, questioning, or surprised tone to a question
Words.Example: HR asked why I was going for a diploma position when I could go for something higher. Wake up lah. You think it's so easy to find a job nowadays meh?

Words.English Translation: → Mandarin / hakka: 梅菜 pinyin: méi cài from mandarin / hakka (pinyin) 梅菜 méi cài dried, preserved mustard greens ← mandarin / hakka (pinyin) 霉菜 méi cài dried, preserved mustard greens ← mandarin / hakka (pinyin) 霉 méi moldy; mold; bacteria + mandarin / hakka (pinyin) 菜 cài vegetable
Words.Definition: a Hakka condiment of dried, preserved mustard greens (Brassica juncea)
Words.Example: For an East-meets-West option, the hotel's Festive Baked Turkey with Angelica Root (S$165, about 5kg) is marinated with an angelica root powder rub and stuffed with sweet corn, preserved mei cai and Chinese blood sausage.

Words.English Translation: → Mandarin / hakka: 梅菜扣肉 pinyin: méi cài kòu ròu from mandarin / hakka (pinyin) 梅菜扣肉 méi cài kòu ròu dish of braised pork belly with mei cai ← mandarin / hakka (pinyin) 梅菜 méi cài dried, preserved mustard greens ← mandarin / hakka (pinyin) 霉菜 méi cài dried, preserved mustard greens ← mandarin / hakka (pinyin) 霉 méi moldy; mold; bacteria
Words.Definition: a Hakka dish of pork belly braised with mei cai (dried, preserved mustard greens)

Words.English Translation: → Mandarin: 妹妹 pinyin: mèi mei from mandarin (pinyin) 妹妹 mèi mei younger sister
Words.Definition: younger sister; term of address for a younger sister

Words.English Translation: → Mandarin: 美女 pinyin: měi nǚ from mandarin (pinyin) 美女 měi nǚ beautiful woman; pretty girl; term of address for a young girl or woman ← mandarin (pinyin) 美 měi beautiful; pretty + mandarin (pinyin) 女 nǚ woman; girl; female
Words.Definition: a young and pretty girl; a beautiful woman

Words.English Translation: → English: remember from english remember recall
Words.Definition: to remember
Words.Example: Last time we tried food here we all lao sai non-stop for a week, member anot?

Words.English Translation: → Malay: membodek from malay membodek (vg.) suck up; bootlick; brownnose ← malay me[m]- prefix used to form an action + malay bodek (vg.) scrotum; male genitalia, (slang) suck up to; bootlick
Words.Definition: (vulgar, idiom) to suck up to someone; to use obsequious flattery and perform favours to gain privileges from someone; to bootlick; to brownnose
Words.Example: I have seen people with no real talent whatsoever except membodek reached the pinnacle of their organisation....and of course eventually screwed things up ... Sometime I felt like vomiting blood watching the way they membodek their leaders.

Words.English Translation: → Translingual: meow from translingual meow (onom.) sound made by a cat
Words.Definition: (cutesy or childish) a cat (Felis catus)

Words.English Translation: → Malay: merah from malay merah red
Words.Definition: red

Words.English Translation: → Malay: merepek from malay merepek prattle; yap; talk incessantly ← malay merepet prattle; yap; talk incessantly ← malay me- prefix used to form an action + malay repet prattle; yap; talk incessantly
Words.Definition: to prattle; to yap; to talk incessantly
Words.Example: I gave up worrying about what people are going to write about me. Some magazines even wrote about me when they didn't even interview me, merepek (rubbish) only ...

Words.English Translation: → English: mer- + lion from english mer- of or relating to the sea; prefix used to form a being that is partly a sea creature + english lion Panthera leo ← old french lion lion ← latin leō lion ← ancient greek λέων léōn lion
Words.Definition: a national symbol of Singapore, a mythical creature with the head of a lion and body of a fish
Words.Example: Instead, we got ourselves comfortable seats and drowned our livers in liquor, after which we'd hug the toilet bowl, vomit like the Merlion and then go back for more.

Words.English Translation: → English: Michael Jackson from english Michael Jackson ’King of Pop’; extremely famous pop artist
Words.Definition: a drink made by mixing equal parts of chin chow and tau huay chui (soya bean milk)

Words.English Translation: → English: Milo + Singlish: dinosaur from english Milo Nestlé chocolate-flavoured malted drink and drink powder product ← ancient greek Μῆλος Mêlos Milo of Croton, six-time Olympic wrestling champion who competed between c. 540 - 512 BC + singlish dinosaur iced, and topped with a scoop of the drink’s powder ← english dinosaur (technically) any member of the clade Dinosauria; (colloq.) only the large, extinct animals extinct living around 230 - 65 mya, incl. those not in the clade Dinosauria ← ancient greek δεινός deinós terrible; fearful; marvelous + ancient greek σαῦρος saûros lizard
Words.Definition: a drink of iced Milo topped with a scoop of Milo powder
Words.Example: He is also a professional bartender and will make you any cocktail you could possibly want, so don't let him down by asking for a Milo dinosaur.

Words.English Translation: → English: Milo + Singlish: Godzilla from english Milo Nestlé chocolate-flavoured malted drink and drink powder product ← ancient greek Μῆλος Mêlos Milo of Croton, six-time Olympic wrestling champion who competed between c. 540 - 512 BC + singlish Godzilla iced, with a scoop of ice cream or whipped cream, and topped with a scoop of the drink’s powder ← english Godzilla kaiju from Godzilla (1954) and the following film series ← japanese ゴジラ gojira Godzilla, a kaiju from Godzilla (1954) and the following film series ← japanese ゴリラ gorira gorilla ← english gorilla gorilla ← ancient greek Γόριλλαι Górillai tribe of hairy women + japanese 鯨 クジラ kujira whale
Words.Definition: a drink of iced Milo with a scoop of ice cream or dollop of whipped cream, and topped with a scoop of Milo powder. Equivalent to a Milo dinosaur with the addition of the cream or ice cream.

Words.English Translation: → English: Milo + Singlish: King Kong from english Milo Nestlé chocolate-flavoured malted drink and drink powder product ← ancient greek Μῆλος Mêlos Milo of Croton, six-time Olympic wrestling champion who competed between c. 540 - 512 BC + singlish King Kong iced, with two scoops of ice cream or whipped cream, and topped with a scoop of the drink’s powder ← english King Kong eponymous character in the 1933 film King Kong and resulting media series + english King title given to a male monarch; ruler ← english Kong name coined for the 1933 movie King Kong
Words.Definition: a drink of iced Milo with two scoops of ice cream or dollops of whipped cream, and topped with a scoop of Milo powder. Equivalent to a Milo dinosaur with the addition of two scoops of cream or ice cream.

Words.English Translation: → English: Milo + Singlish: T-Rex from english Milo Nestlé chocolate-flavoured malted drink and drink powder product ← ancient greek Μῆλος Mêlos Milo of Croton, six-time Olympic wrestling champion who competed between c. 540 - 512 BC + singlish T-Rex iced, with a scoop of ice cream or whipped cream, and topped with a scoop of the drink’s powder ← english T-Rex large carnivorous dinosaur ← translingual Tyrannosaurus rex large carnivorous dinosaur ← translingual Tyrannosaurus genus of dinosaurs in the family Tyrannosauridae ← ancient greek τῠ́ρᾰννος túrannos tyrant; despot; absolute ruler + ancient greek σαῦρος saûros lizard + latin rēx king; ruler; tyrant
Words.Definition: a drink of iced Milo with a scoop of ice cream or dollop of whipped cream, and topped with a scoop of Milo powder. Equivalent to a Milo dinosaur with the addition of the cream or ice cream.

Words.English Translation: → English: Milo + Singlish: -cino from english Milo Nestlé chocolate-flavoured malted drink and drink powder product ← ancient greek Μῆλος Mêlos Milo of Croton, six-time Olympic wrestling champion who competed between c. 540 - 512 BC + singlish -cino made w. a base of milk, or condensed milk and water, w. the preceding drink layered on top ✂ italian cappuccino espresso coffee with steamed or frothed milk, so named due to dark brown colour resembling Capuchin monks' habits ← german Kapuziner Capuchin (monk of the Capuchin order) ← italian [frate] cappuccino Capuchin (monk of the Capuchin order) ← italian cappuccio hood; monk's cowl ← italian -ino suffix used to indicate a profession or form a diminutive
Words.Definition: a drink made with a base of milk, or condensed milk and water, with Milo layered on top in a milk-Milo ratio of around 1:1. The drink is served with the layers of milk and Milo not fully mixed.

Words.Word: min chiang kueh 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Teochew: 面煎粿 麵煎粿 peng'im: min7 ziang1 guê2 from teochew (peng'im) 面煎粿 麵煎粿 min7 ziang1 guê2 type of sweet pancake with peanut filling ← teochew (peng'im) 面 麵 min7 flour; wheat flour + teochew (peng'im) 煎 煎 ziang1 pan-fry + teochew (peng'im) 粿 粿 guê2 kueh
Words.Definition: a type of sweet pancake with a fluffy, moist, elastic, and chewy texture (though it is often also pan-fried until a crispy exterior is achieved). It is folded over in half and filled with some filling, most typically crushed peanuts and sugar, but sometimes other flavours such as sweetened grated coconut, kaya, tau sar, etc.

Words.English Translation: → Likely, but other possible etymologies exist Tamil: மீனாட்சி mīṉāṭci from tamil Likely, but other possible etymologies exist மீனாட்சி mīṉāṭci common female given name ← tamil மீன் mīṉ fish + sanskrit अक्षी ákṣī -eyed
Words.Definition: a Tamil or other South Indian girl or woman; term of address for such a person
Words.Example: Some minachi want high standard guy. Speak good english. All my english teacher in school is minachi all of them single.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: minah from malay minah gal; dudette; Jane Doe ← malay Aminah popular Muslim female given name ← arabic أَمِينَة ʔamīna popular Arabic female given name ← arabic أَمِين ʔamīn archangel Gabriel; faithful; loyal; reliable; trustworthy
Words.Definition: (chiefly of a female Malay person) a girl; a gal; a dudette; a Jane Doe
Words.Example: If you are insulted that you are labelled a Minah just because you are a Malay girl, then you should think twice about labelling that girl who sat across you in the train a Minah just because she dresses like what you think 'a Minah' dresses like. Who's labelling who now?

Words.English Translation: → Malay: minah + English: reputation from malay minah gal; dudette; Jane Doe ← malay Aminah popular Muslim female given name ← arabic أَمِينَة ʔamīna popular Arabic female given name ← arabic أَمِين ʔamīn archangel Gabriel; faithful; loyal; reliable; trustworthy + english reputation image; public standing or perception; clout; what one is known for ← latin reputationem thinking over; reflection; consideration
Words.Definition: (derogatory) a young, delinquent Malay woman, often associated with negative stereotypes such as smoking, drinking, truancy, lepaking, low education, and a certain style of dress; often also a girlfriend of a mat rep or a regular female companion of a group of mat reps.

Words.English Translation: → English: Ministry + of + Defence from english Ministry government department led by a minister ← old french menistere government department led by a minister ← latin ministerium government department led by a minister ← latin minister waiter; servant; slave + latin -ium suffix used to form a noun + english of used to denote origin, relation, or belonging + english Defence protection from attack or danger ← old french defense defence; protection ← latin dēfēnsa defence; protection
Words.Definition: (abbreviation) the government ministry in charge of Singapore's national defence

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien / teochew: 密司 poj: mi-si from hokkien / teochew (poj) 密司 mi-si female nurse ← english missy term of address for a young girl or woman ← english miss female equiv. of 'master'/'mister' ✂ english mistress term of respectful address for a young (usu. unmarried) woman + english -y dimin. suffix
Words.Definition: a female nurse; term of address for a female nurse

Words.English Translation: → English: men + in + white from english men people + english in wearing; dressed with + english white bright and colourless; diffusely reflecting a mixture of all colours in the spectrum of visible light
Words.Definition: (metonym) the PAP
Words.Example: why alot of ah beng they dont support oppo party but they support the miw? ... i talk to a few of my ah beng friend some got go in squat before ... they tend to support miw than oppo leh ... how come arh?

Words.Word: mixed vegetable rice 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → English: mixed + vegetable + rice ↻ Hokkien: 杂菜饭 雜菜飯 poj: cha̍p-chhài-pn̄g from english mixed assorted; combined together + english vegetable edible plant used as a culinary item ← old french vegetable plant; vegetable ← latin vegetābilis able to grow; enlivening + english rice edible seeds, used as a food grain, of the Oryza sativa cereal crop ↻ hokkien (poj) 杂菜饭 雜菜飯 cha̍p-chhài-pn̄g economy rice ← hokkien (poj) 杂 雜 cha̍p mixed; assorted + hokkien (poj) 菜 菜 chhài vegetable + hokkien (poj) 饭 飯 pn̄g cooked rice; meal; food
Words.Definition: white rice with portions of assorted dishes, typically a selection or combination of vegetable dishes and meat or fish dishes chosen by the customer from a display
Words.Example: What started as a humble Chinese mixed vegetable rice stall in Bedok is now a sprawling food and beverage conglomerate with 24 firms, an international footprint, and a spanking new S$60 million headquarters facility with a production line that can cook 40,000 portions of rice a day.

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: min jiang kueh from singlish min jiang kueh type of sweet pancake with peanut filling ← teochew (peng'im) 面煎粿 麵煎粿 min7 ziang1 guê2 type of sweet pancake with peanut filling ← teochew (peng'im) 面 麵 min7 flour; wheat flour + teochew (peng'im) 煎 煎 ziang1 pan-fry + teochew (peng'im) 粿 粿 guê2 kueh
Words.Definition: abbreviation of min jiang kueh.
Words.Example: They offer a free mjk for a five star review. That’s why. But they are certainly known as the best mjk or at least the most innovative in sg. No other places come close. Mjk was on the verge of going extinct before this.

Words.English Translation: → General chinese: 呣/唔/嗯 pinyin: m/ḿ/m̀ from general chinese (pinyin) 呣/唔/嗯 m/ḿ/m̀ used to exp. agreement, acknowledgement, surprise, curiosity, contemplation, etc.
Words.Definition: used to express acknowledgement; 'OK'; 'noted'
Words.Example: Mm, can, I do for you later.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 毋 poj: m̄ + Teochew: 唔 peng'im: m6 + Min nan: 着 著 poj: tio̍h from hokkien (poj) 毋 m̄ not + teochew (peng'im) 唔 m6 not + min nan (poj) 着 著 tio̍h correct; right; then
Words.Definition: incorrect; wrong; false

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 毋知 poj: m̄-chai from hokkien (poj) 毋知 m̄-chai not know; don’t know ← hokkien (poj) 毋 m̄ not; do not + hokkien (poj) 知 chai know; comprehend
Words.Definition: to not know; to not understand

Words.Word: mo far kor 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Cantonese: 无花果 無花果 jyutping: mou4 faa1 gwo2 from cantonese (jyutping) 无花果 無花果 mou4 faa1 gwo2 fig ← cantonese (jyutping) 无 無 mou4 no; don't have + cantonese (jyutping) 花 faa1 flower + cantonese (jyutping) 果 gwo2 fruit
Words.Definition: a snack made from long strips of dried, preserved fruit sweetened with sugar
Words.Example: Merry Christmas! Struggling for a creative Christmas present? Why not gift a handy snack like Mo Far Kor? It’s tasty, nostalgic and healthy, the perfect little package.

Words.Word: mo tak teng 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Cantonese: 冇得顶 冇得頂 jyutping: mou5 dak1 ding2 from cantonese (jyutping) 冇得顶 冇得頂 mou5 dak1 ding2 best; incomparable; unbeatable; superb ← cantonese (jyutping) 冇得 冇得 mou5 dak1 unable to; cannot + cantonese (jyutping) 顶 頂 ding2 exceeding; above; on top; go against; replace; rebut
Words.Definition: the very best; incomparable; unbeatable; superb
Words.Example: BEST kway teow thnng ever .mo tak teng ... Their fish balls are mostly fish, not flour or any other fillers ... Theit soup is simply awesome. [sic]

Words.English Translation: → French: moi from french moi me; 1p. sing. obj. pron. ← latin mē me; 1p. sing. obj. pron.
Words.Definition: (humorous, ironic) I; me; the first-person singular personal pronoun
Words.Example: after 1 month moi boss come tell moi why chiu tis level want do this low level contract? come moi promote and convert chiu to perm lamoi mix feeling leh moi just want to chill lax after taking a long break

Words.Word: mong cha cha 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Cantonese: 蒙查查 矇查查 jyutping: mung4 caa4 caa4 from cantonese (jyutping) 蒙查查 矇查查 mung4 caa4 caa4 blurry; foggy; muddleheaded; absentminded; clueless
Words.Definition: muddleheaded; absentminded; clueless
Words.Example: I get so disoriented all the time. When I exit the new TEL MRT station ah, I was so mong cha cha I went the wrong way.

Words.English Translation: → English: ROD + mood from english ROD init. of Run-Out Date ← english run out come to an end; be finished ← english run proceed; persist; last + english out to the end; into non-existence or non-operation + english date point in time + english mood feeling; mental or emotional state; atmosphere
Words.Definition: (NS, dated) an older term for ORD mood
Words.Example: - Are you gonna start on your project today?- See my mood later how lor.

Words.English Translation: → General chinese: 月饼 月餅 pinyin: yuè bǐng from general chinese (pinyin) 月饼 月餅 yuè bǐng baked pastry with sweet filling eaten during the Mid-Autumn Festival ← general chinese (pinyin) 月 月 yuè moon + general chinese (pinyin) 饼 餅 bǐng biscuit; pastry
Words.Definition: a baked Chinese pastry consisting of a soft, tender skin with a sweet filling typically made of lotus seed paste (or sometimes red bean or green bean paste), usually pressed using a mold to form a round shape decorated with patterns and words. The filling may also contain other ingredients, such as salted egg yolks and crushed nuts, or in modern times novelty flavourings such as durian or lychee. They are traditionally eaten during the Mid-Autumn Festival, and have also been commercialized into expensive, luxury business gifts in Singapore.

Words.English Translation: → English: mooncake + biscuit from english mooncake Chinese pastry with a sweet lotus paste or other filling, traditionally eaten during the Mid-Autumn Festival ↻ mandarin (pinyin) 月饼 月餅 yuè bǐng pastry with a sweet lotus paste or other filling, traditionally eaten during the Mid-Autumn Festival ← mandarin (pinyin) 月 月 yuè moon + mandarin (pinyin) 饼 餅 bǐng pastry; cookie; biscuit + english biscuit small baked item; cookie ← old french bescuit twice-baked bread ← latin biscoctus twice-cooked ← latin bis twice; two times + latin coctus cook
