Words.Definition: messed up; gone out of hand; in a state of havoc

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: rabz + English: kebab + Singlish: -z from singlish rabz messed up; gone out of hand; terrible; poor; bad ← malay rabak torn; in tatters; ripped + singlish -z colloquializing suffix; used to add a quirky, silly, cool, or cute twang ← english -z (urban slang) suffix used to add a quirky, silly, cool, or cute twang + english kebab dish of skewered roasted meat ← arabic كَبَاب kabāb dish of skewered roasted meat + singlish -z colloquializing suffix; used to add a quirky, silly, cool, or cute twang ← english -z (urban slang) suffix used to add a quirky, silly, cool, or cute twang
Words.Definition: messed up; gone out of hand; in a state of havoc

Words.English Translation: → Malay: raja + kampung from malay raja king; monarch ← sanskrit राजन् rā́jan king; prince; sovereign + malay kampung village; community; hometown
Words.Definition: (sports, pejorative) a team or player that can only win at home
Words.Example: This has led to critics labelling the Lions "Raja Kampung". It means they are kings at home and paupers away. They need to beat Pahang if they hope to prove the critics wrong.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: rambai from malay rambai Baccaurea motleyana or its edible fruit
Words.Definition: the tree Baccaurea motleyana or its edible fruit, which grow in clusters off the tree’s branches or trunk. The fruit is brown- to cream-coloured, slightly acidic in taste, and around 3 cm in diameter. The tree is classified as a critically endangered species in Singapore.[1]

Words.English Translation: → Malay: rambutan from malay rambutan Nephelium lappaceum or its edible fruit ← malay rambut hair + malay -an suffix attached to a verb to form a noun related to it
Words.Definition: the edible fruit of the tree Nephelium lappaceum, which has sweet, translucent white flesh and a thick, red and yellow skin covered in characteristic hair-like protrusions. It is a close relative of the less common pulasan, and also more distantly related to the lychee and longan.
Words.Example: Quirky offerings bode well for the adventurous diner, though the more conservative would probably blanch at appetisers such as the Whacky Rambutan ($8.90).

Words.English Translation: → Malay: Ramly bin Mokni + English: burger from malay Ramly bin Mokni founder of Ramly Food Processing Sdn. Bhd. + english burger rebracketed clipping of 'hamburger' ✂ english hamburger ground meat patty between two halves of a sliced bun ✂ english Hamburger steak ground meat patty ← german Hamburg city-state in Germany + german -er suffix used to form a demonym + english steak thick slice of meat (usu. beef) ← old norse steik roast; roasted meat
Words.Definition: a type of halal burger with a patty wrapped in an omelette, and topped with any of various sauces such as tomato sauce, chilli sauce, mayonnaise, barbecue sauce, etc.

Words.English Translation: → English: range from english range location for shooting practise ← old french rengier line up in ranks; order
Words.Definition: a session of target shooting practice at a firing range

Words.English Translation: → Malay: Hari Raya from malay Hari Raya holiday or festival; Eid ← malay hari day + malay raya big; great
Words.Definition: ellipsis of Hari Raya

Words.English Translation: → English: recce from english recce (mil.) scout unit; scout; scout work; scout ahead ✂ english reconnaissance scouting ← french reconnaissance recognition ← latin recognōscere recognition; knowing; acknowledgment
Words.Definition: (military) to reconnaitre; to scout ahead

Words.English Translation: → English: red + bean ↻ General chinese: 红豆 紅豆 pinyin: hóng dòu & Malay: kacang merah from english red colour on the lower frequency range before orange on the visible light spectrum + english bean plant of the family Fabaceae producing edible seeds, or the seeds thereof ↻ general chinese (pinyin) 红豆 紅豆 hóng dòu Vigna angularis and its edible bean ← general chinese (pinyin) 红 紅 hóng red + general chinese (pinyin) 豆 豆 dòu bean & malay kacang merah Vigna angularis and its edible bean ← malay kacang bean + malay merah red
Words.Definition: the bean plant Vigna angularis and its edible red-coloured beans, which are used in several local dishes in Singapore

Words.Word: red bean soup 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Singlish: red bean + English: soup from singlish red bean Vigna angularis and its edible bean ← english red colour on the lower frequency range before orange on the visible light spectrum + english bean plant of the family Fabaceae producing edible seeds, or the seeds thereof ↻ general chinese (pinyin) 红豆 紅豆 hóng dòu Vigna angularis and its edible bean ← general chinese (pinyin) 红 紅 hóng red + general chinese (pinyin) 豆 豆 dòu bean + english soup liquid-based dish with other ingredients ↻ general chinese (pinyin) 汤 湯 tāng soup
Words.Definition: a soup made by boiling red beans (Vigna angularis) and other optional ingredients in water, usually sweetened (traditionally with rock sugar or gula melaka) and served as a cold or warm dessert.
Words.Example: The silk bean curd with cream of red bean ($2.60) is an interesting blend of flavour and texture, with the sweetness of the red bean soup complementing the understated flavour of the smooth bean curd.

Words.English Translation: → English: referee + Malay: kayu from english referee umpire; game official ← old french referer speak about; talk about ← latin referō judge; refer to; reply + malay kayu wood
Words.Definition: used to berate or deride a referee (especially in football/soccer) for being stupid, missing important game events, being intentionally biased, or generally making decisions that are unfavourable for the team one is supporting
Words.Example: My sister loved her first night in Singapore at the country's first neighbourhood sports complex ... She joined in with the chanting (once she had learned "de-fend, clear the ball" and "referee kayu", she had pretty much exhausted our repertoire).

Words.English Translation: → Malay: rehatkan + diri from malay rehatkan rest; relax ← malay rehat rest ← arabic راحة rāḥa rest; leisure; confort; ease + malay -kan suffix used to form a transitive imperative verb + malay diri stand
Words.Definition: (military) a standing position even further relaxed as compared to senang diri, where soldiers are allowed to make small adjustments such as wiping their sweat and stretching
Words.Example: The CDS allowed his platoon to rehatkan diri while they waited for the rest of the company to fall in.

Words.English Translation: → English: relax from english relax calm down; destress; reduce tension ← old french relaxer relax ← latin relaxāre loosen; slacken; open; relax
Words.Definition: to relax; to loosen up; to chill out
Words.Example: Opened two years ago, Pondok Selera, which means "delicious hut" in Malay, is the perfect neighbourhood eatery for its avid regulars to makan and relak.

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: relak + English: one + corner from singlish relak relax; calm down; chill out ← english relax calm down; destress; reduce tension ← old french relaxer relax ← latin relaxāre loosen; slacken; open; relax + english one a; a given thing + english corner secluded or out-of-the-way place
Words.Definition: to relax somewhere quiet, secluded, or out of the way; to withdraw oneself and chill out; idle around
Words.Example: I reassured Satiman by asking him to "relak ... in one corner". And so he did, as he took off his socks.

Words.English Translation: → French: remisier from french remisier type of middleman between a client and a stockbroker ← french remise hand over; remit + french -ier suffix used to form a job
Words.Definition: a type of middleman trader who takes orders from clients and transmits them to a stockbroker, in return for a cut of the brokerage fee

Words.English Translation: → Malay: rempah from malay rempah spice
Words.Definition: a ground spice mixture, especially in Malay and Peranakan cuisine
Words.Example: Suprisingly, the beef rendang — cubes of Wagyu braised until meltingly tender in a lovely pineapple-spiked rempah (spice mix) — was the highlight of our meal.

Words.English Translation: → Baba malay: rempah udang from baba malay rempah udang snack of glutinous rice with a filling of hae bee hiam wrapped in a pandan or banana leaf and grilled ← malay / baba malay rempah spice; ground spice mixture + malay udang prawn
Words.Definition: a traditional Peranakan kueh consisting of an oblong-shaped roll of glutinous rice with a filling of hae bee hiam, wrapped in a pandan or banana leaf and grilled. The rice is mixed with coconut milk and salt and is often mottled with a striking blue colour extracted from the blue pea flower. It is similar to the Indonesian lemper.
Words.Example: Rempah udang means spices and prawns. So what's rempah udang if it does not have enough of either rempah or udang? Making it at home is the only way to ensure that you have plenty of both.

Words.English Translation: → Malay / indonesian: rendang from malay / indonesian rendang type of dry curry; rich, spicy stew- or curry-like dish with meat
Words.Definition: a rich, spicy, slow-cooked stew- or curry-like dish with cubes of diced meat (usually beef) and a base of coconut milk. The gravy uses a mixture of spices including galangal, lemongrass, chilli, ginger, turmeric, shallots, garlic, and other spices, fried in oil. The spice mix and beef are slow-cooked in coconut milk until the curry is almost dry and the ingredients have absorbed the liquid in the dish, resulting in a remarkably rich, complex, and flavourful curry. It is typically served with rice.The dish supposedly originated in Minangkabau cuisine. While beef rendang is the most famous form of rendang, other meats can be used, such as in rendang ayam and rendang kambing.
Words.Example: There are several dishes that define Hari Raya – lemang, ketupat and, of course, rendang.But for Nora’shah Ibrahim and her family in Kuala Kangsar, rendang is more than just a Raya tradition: it’s also how she keeps her late mother’s legacy alive.

Words.English Translation: → Malay / indonesian: rendang ayam from malay / indonesian rendang ayam rich, spicy stew- or curry-like dish with chicken meat ← malay / indonesian rendang type of dry curry; rich, spicy stew- or curry-like dish with meat + malay / indonesian ayam chicken
Words.Definition: a variant of rendang using chicken (ayam) as the meat
Words.Example: To wrap up the series for this Ramadan month, today I’ll be sharing a dish that’s often enjoyed during Hari Raya (Eid Al-Fitr) in Malaysia. It’s the classic rendang ayam.

Words.English Translation: → Malay / indonesian: rendang daging from malay / indonesian rendang daging rich, spicy stew- or curry-like dish with meat (usu. beef) ← malay / indonesian rendang type of dry curry; rich, spicy stew- or curry-like dish with meat + malay / indonesian daging meat; beef
Words.Definition: a rich, spicy, slow-cooked stew- or curry-like dish with cubes of diced beef and a base of coconut milk. The gravy uses a mixture of spices including galangal, lemongrass, chilli, ginger, turmeric, shallots, garlic, and other spices, fried in oil. The spice mix and beef are slow-cooked in coconut milk until the curry is almost dry and the ingredients have absorbed the liquid in the dish, resulting in a remarkably rich, complex, and flavourful curry. It is typically served with rice.The dish supposedly originated in Minangkabau cuisine. While rendang daging is the most famous form of rendang, other meats can be used, such as in rendang ayam and rendang kambing.
Words.Example: The main dishes include rendang daging, sayor lodeh and other traditional favourites.

Words.English Translation: → Malay / indonesian: rendang kambing from malay / indonesian rendang kambing rich, spicy stew- or curry-like dish with mutton ← malay / indonesian rendang type of dry curry; rich, spicy stew- or curry-like dish with meat + malay / indonesian kambing goat; mutton
Words.Definition: a variant of rendang using mutton (kambing) as the meat
Words.Example: I liked the rendang kambing best. The mutton did not have the usual offensive odour; instead, it was spiced fragrantly and had a sweet flavour.

Words.English Translation: → Malay / indonesian: rendang sapi from malay / indonesian rendang sapi rich, spicy stew- or curry-like dish with meat (usu. beef) ← malay / indonesian rendang type of dry curry; rich, spicy stew- or curry-like dish with meat + malay / indonesian sapi zebu; cattle; cow
Words.Definition: a rich, spicy, slow-cooked stew- or curry-like dish with cubes of diced beef and a base of coconut milk. The gravy uses a mixture of spices including galangal, lemongrass, chilli, ginger, turmeric, shallots, garlic, and other spices, fried in oil. The spice mix and beef are slow-cooked in coconut milk until the curry is almost dry and the ingredients have absorbed the liquid in the dish, resulting in a remarkably rich, complex, and flavourful curry. It is typically served with rice.The dish supposedly originated in Minangkabau cuisine. While rendang daging is the most famous form of rendang, other meats can be used, such as in rendang ayam and rendang kambing.
Words.Example: Here, you can savour familiar dishes such as ... the popular rendang sapi (beef cubes in a sweet, spicy curry), accompanied by nasi kuning and the essential belacan dip.

Words.English Translation: → English: re- + service + reservist from english re- again ← old french re- again ← latin re- again; back + english service subordination; work as a member of the military ← old french servise service ← latin servitium slavery; servitude; service + english reservist trained soldier not on active military duty but held in reserve ← english reserve kept or held for future use + english -ist suffix used to denote sb. who does sth.
Words.Definition: variant form of reservist, regular annual training cycles, each lasting between one week to 40 days, that men who have served NS are required to go through
Words.Example: I propose a six-month NS in the medical field for females at age 18 and a six-month re-service duration, which may be completed in part or in full by age 30. Women who give birth would be exempt from reservice ...

Words.English Translation: → English: reservist from english reservist trained soldier not on active military duty but held in reserve ← english reserve kept or held for future use + english -ist suffix used to denote sb. who does sth.
Words.Definition: a man who has completed his national service (and thus ORDed) but is still obligated to serve in annual training cycles, inform the government when he leaves the country for longer than a given period, be available for regular manning periods, and be mobilised for action when necessary

Words.English Translation: → English: revert from english revert go back to a previous state, (India) reply; respond ← old french revertir return ← latin revertō return; turn back
Words.Definition: reply; respond (to a correspondence)

Words.English Translation: → Malay: rewang from malay rewang random; spread out; always changing, (slang, of cigarettes) shared
Words.Definition: (of cigarettes) shared; free to be taken by anyone who wants one

Words.English Translation: → General chinese: 饭碗 飯碗 pinyin: fàn wǎn from general chinese (pinyin) 饭碗 飯碗 fàn wǎn (lit.) rice bowl, (fig.) livelihood; living; job; career ← general chinese (pinyin) 饭 飯 fàn cooked rice + general chinese (pinyin) 碗 碗 wǎn bowl
Words.Definition: (metaphor) livelihood; means of making a living; job; career
Words.Example: ... Lee had "clearly played an active role as she had deliberately manipulated the quotations in order to protect her own rice bowl".

Words.English Translation: → English: running + marching + jumping from english running activity of 'to run' ← english run move at a speed faster than walking, with both feet leaving the ground at regular intervals + english -ing suffixed to a verb to form a noun or its gerund form + english marching activity of 'to march' ← english march orderly, rhythmic, ceremonial gait used esp. by soldiers ← middle french marcher walk + english -ing suffixed to a verb to form a noun or its gerund form + english jumping activity of 'to jump' ← english jump spring up; leap; propel oneself momentarily airborne + english -ing suffixed to a verb to form a noun or its gerund form
Words.Definition: (military) initialism of running, marching, and jumping

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: rilak one corner from singlish rilak one corner relax somewhere quiet, secluded, or out of the way; withdraw oneself and chill out; idle around ← singlish rilak relax; calm down; chill out ← english relax calm down; destress; reduce tension ← old french relaxer relax ← latin relaxāre loosen; slacken; open; relax + english one a; a given thing + english corner secluded or out-of-the-way place
Words.Definition: Initialism of rilak one corner.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: rock + kapak from malay rock rock (music genre) ← english rock music genre ✂ english rock and roll music genre + malay kapak alteration of 'carpark' ← english carpark open, cleared area of land with space to leave vehicles ← english car automobile; wheeled automotive land vehicle ← anglo-norman / old french carre cart; wagon ← latin carrus cart; wagon + english park large open area ← old french parc fenced-off area for livestock; pen ← latin parricus fenced-off area; pen; fence; enclosure
Words.Definition: a subgenre of rock and metal music, usually with vocals in Malay, inspired by genres such as glam metal, hard rock, and power ballads. It is typically associated with a correspondingly inspired subculture and fashion, including long hair, leather or denim jackets, and ripped jeans.
Words.Example: hey guys, keep the sharing of rock kapak albums here ah! gerek siol!

Words.English Translation: → English: run out + date from english run out come to an end; be finished ← english run proceed; persist; last + english out to the end; into non-existence or non-operation + english date point in time
Words.Definition: (NS, dated) an older term for ORD

Words.English Translation: → English: ROD + mood from english ROD init. of Run-Out Date ← english run out come to an end; be finished ← english run proceed; persist; last + english out to the end; into non-existence or non-operation + english date point in time + english mood feeling; mental or emotional state; atmosphere
Words.Definition: (NS, dated) an older term for ORD mood

Words.English Translation: → Malay: rojak from malay rojak salad dish of bite-sized pieces of fruit, vegetables, and fritters with a sweet, tangy dressing ← javanese ꦫꦸꦗꦏ꧀ rujak salad dish of bite-sized pieces of fruit, vegetables, and fritters with a sweet, tangy dressing; mix; blend
Words.Definition: a salad dish of bite-sized pieces of fruit, vegetables, and fritters (such as tau pok or you tiao) with a sweet, tangy dressing made of ingredients such as chilli, belacan, hae ko, ground peanuts, assam, etc. It has origins in ancient Javanese cuisine.
Words.Example: What I like most about the rojak is the viscous savoury-sweet prawn paste sauce.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: rokok from malay rokok cigarette ← dutch roken smoke; produce smoke
Words.Definition: to smoke a cigarette
Words.Example: Bapa told me before he died never to forget to place kopi-o and rokok at the offerings.

Words.English Translation: → English: registry + of + marriage[s] from english registry record; database; account ← medieval latin regesterium register; record; archival list + english of used to denote origin, relation, or belonging + english marriage[s] wedding; social and legal union of two people ← old french mariage marriage; wedding ← old french marier marry ← latin marītō marry + old french -age suffix to form a noun for the result or state of sth. ← latin -āticum suffix to form a noun for relation to or the result or state of sth.
Words.Definition: (abbreviation) the government ministry in charge of all marriages in Singapore, and which solemnizes civil marriages
Words.Example: Bee we together so long already... Ai ROM mai?

Words.English Translation: → Malay: rosak from malay rosak (of a mechanism, machine, etc.) broken; spoiled; not working
Words.Definition: broken; spoiled; not working
Words.Example: Aircon remote rosak already... need to buy new one.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: rotan from malay rotan rattan, any palm in the genus Calamus; cane made of rattan; cane ← malay raut trim; whittle; pare + malay -an suffix used to form a noun
Words.Definition: a cane, traditionally made of rattan, used to cane criminals or other offenders as punishment
Words.Example: Besides sparing him the rotan, Chief Justice Yong also reduced his two-year jail term to the original nine months.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: roti from malay roti bread ← tamil ரொட்டி roṭṭi bread ← sanskrit रोटिका roṭikā bread
Words.Definition: bread
Words.Example: Desserts like the mango sticky rice or banana roti will be a sweet treat for kids.
Related: or ya peh ya som balik ah roti prata char kway teow
or ya peh ya som balik ah roti prata chai tow kway

Words.English Translation: → Malay: roti [canai/prata] + banjir from malay roti [canai/prata] bread [Indian flatbread influenced by paratha] ← malay roti bread ← tamil ரொட்டி roṭṭi bread ← sanskrit रोटिका roṭikā bread + malay banjir flood ← javanese ꦧꦚ꧀ꦗꦶꦂ banjir flood
Words.Definition: a variation of roti prata where the plain flatbread is roughly chopped up or torn into bite-sized pieces and served on a dish “flooded” with various curry sauces, chilli or sambal, and sometimes dal. It is often topped with one or more fried or soft-boiled eggs.
Words.Example: 9KG Roti Banjir. One man. This Mamak will be telling stories about me for generations 🤣

Words.English Translation: → Malay: roti + Possible, but not certain canai from malay roti bread ← tamil ரொட்டி roṭṭi bread ← sanskrit रोटिका roṭikā bread + malay Possible, but not certain canai to roll, stretch, or sculpt e.g. dough or pastry
Words.Definition: the Malaysian term for roti prata, a type of local flatbread with influence from Indian paratha.
Words.Example: Despite being considered as a variation of the paratha, the dish does not exist in India; the closest to roti canai is believed to be the Malabar or Kerala paratha.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: roti + jala from malay roti bread ← tamil ரொட்டி roṭṭi bread ← sanskrit रोटिका roṭikā bread + malay jala cast net for fishing ← sanskrit जाल jālá net; web; any woven or lattice structure
Words.Definition: a traditional Malay pancake with a characteristic lace or net shape, which is made by letting the pancake batter stream onto a flattop griddle from holes in the bottom of a special cup, while moving the cup around in a circular pattern. It is usually eaten with curry and other traditional gravy-based dishes, or sometimes with sweet accompaniments as a dessert food.It is believed to have originated in India, and bears several similarities to putu mayam or idiyappam.
Words.Example: Roti jala looks beautiful and tastes even better. This classic lacy pancake is every bit as tasty as it is festive-looking ... What makes for great roti jala is plenty of good chicken curry gravy. The better the curry, the better the roti jala. The lacy texture of the roti jala enhances further the flavour of the curry.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: roti + English: John from malay roti bread ← tamil ரொட்டி roṭṭi bread ← sanskrit रोटिका roṭikā bread + english John common male given name; anonymous man ← latin Iōhannēs John (Hebrew male given name) ← koine greek Ἰωάννης Iōánnēs John (Hebrew male given name) ← hebrew יוֹחָנָן Yōḥānān male given name; ‘God is gracious’
Words.Definition: a sandwich made with a loaf of “French-style” bread (i.e. any long or oblong bread loaf, such as a baguette, batard, sub roll, large hot dog bun, etc.) fried on a flattop griddle with an omelette made of eggs, minced meat, onions, etc. It is topped with tomato and chilli sauce and sometimes cheese, then folded and chopped transversely into roughly three to five pieces before serving.It is believed to be based loosely on a hamburger or some other similar Western sandwich. The dish originated in Singaporean cuisine, but has become popular throughout neighbouring countries like Malaysia and Indonesia.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: roti + kok from malay roti bread ← tamil ரொட்டி roṭṭi bread ← sanskrit रोटिका roṭikā bread + malay kok (onom.) sound made when eating a hard and crunchy biscuit
Words.Definition: a snack made from stale slices of bread that are buttered and sprinkled with sugar, cut into quarters, then baked or toasted in an oven until dry and crispy
Words.Example: What to do with half a loaf of white bread 🍞. Sayang to throw away. So making Roti Kok is the only thing that came to my mind.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: roti + Perancis from malay roti bread ← tamil ரொட்டி roṭṭi bread ← sanskrit रोटिका roṭikā bread + malay Perancis France; French ← portuguese francês French ← latin francēnsis French
Words.Definition: a French-style crusty bread, usually served with Malay cuisine in food such as sup kambing, roti john, and kacang pool

Words.English Translation: → Malay: roti + Tamil: பரோட்டா parōṭṭā from malay roti bread ← tamil ரொட்டி roṭṭi bread ← sanskrit रोटिका roṭikā bread + tamil பரோட்டா parōṭṭā paratha; type of Indian flatbread
Words.Definition: a type of local flatbread with influence from Indian paratha. It is usually served with curry, sugar, or dhal.
Words.Example: What are you guys waiting for? Grease your palms with ghee and get to flippin’ today! The workshop is also applicable for those of you who have always aspired to open up your very own roti prata joint but never knew how to go about doing so.
Related: or ya peh ya som balik ah roti prata char kway teow
or ya peh ya som balik ah roti prata chai tow kway

Words.English Translation: → English: RSM + -'s + hotel from english RSM (mil, init.) regimental sergeant major ← english regimental sergeant major (mil.) most senior warrant officer in a battalion ← english regimental (mil.) of or relating to a regiment ← middle french régiment regiment ← latin regimentum government; rule + english -al suffix to form an adj. pertaining to sth. ← latin -ālis suffix to form an adj. pertaining to sth. + english sergeant major (mil.) appointment given to the most senior NCO in a unit, usu. held by a warrant officer ← english sergeant (mil.) the ranks between corporal and warrant officer; soldier holding such a rank ← old french sergeant/serjant sergeant; servant ← medieval latin serviens servant; soldier; vassal ← latin serviō serve; be a slave to + english major of greater rank or prominence ← latin maior elder; greater; more important + english -'s possessive suffix + english hotel establishment offering lodging, meals, and services to travelers ← french hôtel hotel; townhouse ← latin hospitālis of or pertaining to hosting or hospitality
Words.Definition: (military, euphemism) detention barracks, or any other facility where soldiers who have committed crimes or transgressions are held and confined

Words.English Translation: → English: rubberband + noodles from english rubberband elastic ring made of rubber ← english rubber highly elastic material made from the sap of the rubber tree, or any synthetic material with similar properties; eraser ← english rub press one object against another and move it to and fro with friction + english -er suffix used to form a noun which performs the action of the root verb + english band ring; long strip of material + english noodles long, thin strings of cooked dough ← german Nudel pasta; noodle
Words.Definition: a Cantonese-style alkaline thin egg noodle, enjoyed for its firm bite and highly springy texture

Words.English Translation: → Malay: rugi from malay rugi lose out; suffer a loss ← sanskrit Possible, but not certain रोग róga loss of strength; infirmity; disease
Words.Definition: to lose out; to suffer a loss
Words.Example: Owning car in Singapore si peh bo hua... buy $70k, sell $5k, end up you rugi only.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien / teochew: 走私 poj: cháu-sai + 狮 獅 poj: sai from hokkien / teochew (poj) 走私 cháu-sai smuggle, (slang) elope; cheat; commit adultery ← hokkien / teochew (poj) 走 cháu run; run away; leave + hokkien / teochew (poj) 私 sai secretly; stealthily; private; selfish + hokkien / teochew (poj) 狮 獅 sai lion
Words.Definition: to cheat on a partner; to be romantically unfaithful; to commit adultery
Words.Example: Better she run lion now than get married with such kind...
Related: tiong sim is a lie, hongster never die

Words.English Translation: → English: rush from english rush hurry; make haste
Words.Definition: tight (on time); at too short notice; sudden; soon
Words.Example: Friday a bit rush for me leh... Next Wednesday how?

Words.English Translation: → English: -z from english -z (urban slang) suffix used to add a quirky, silly, cool, or cute twang
Words.Definition: colloquializing suffix, normally used to create a slang term with a quirky, silly, cool, cute etc. twang from another word, e.g. popular → pops or bo pian → bopes

Words.English Translation: → English: -ster from english -ster sb. who does or is associated with sth.
Words.Definition: someone who does or is associated with something

Words.English Translation: → English: Singapore from english Singapore island city-state in South-East Asia, officially known as the Republic of Singapore ← malay Singapura Singapore ← sanskrit सिंहपुर siṃhá-pura Singapore ← sanskrit सिंह siṃhá lion + sanskrit पुर pura city
Words.Definition: (abbreviation) Singapore

Words.English Translation: → English: Singaporean from english Singaporean Singaporean; of or pertaining to Singapore; a Singaporean ← english Singapore island city-state in South-East Asia, officially known as the Republic of Singapore ← malay Singapura Singapore ← sanskrit सिंहपुर siṃhá-pura Singapore ← sanskrit सिंह siṃhá lion + sanskrit पुर pura city + english -an suffix used to form an adjective describing sth. of or pertaining to a noun
Words.Definition: (abbreviation) Singaporean; of or pertaining to Singapore

Words.English Translation: → English: sabotage from english sabotage purposely damage, tamper with, destroy, obstruct etc. sth. to hinder or prevent its success ← french sabotage sabotage
Words.Definition: to sabotage; to purposely damage, tamper with, destroy, obstruct etc. something to hinder or prevent someone or something’s success

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: sabo + king from singlish sabo sabotage ← english sabotage purposely damage, tamper with, destroy, obstruct etc. sth. to hinder or prevent its success ← french sabotage sabotage + singlish king (suffix, usu. sarcastic or pejorative) the epitome of sth. ← english king (usu. male) the ruler of a monarchy; a powerful or preeminent person
Words.Definition: a person who is always sabotaging others, whether intentionally or unintentionally

Words.English Translation: → Malay: sachek from malay sachek (f.) pretty; good-looking; beautiful
Words.Definition: (of a male person) handsome; good-looking; suave
Words.Example: Most malay are happy to serve in SPF and SCDF. We look more sachok in those uniform, that's how we attract dem minahs.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: sachok from malay sachok (m.) handsome; good-looking; suave
Words.Definition: (of a male person) handsome; good-looking; suave
Words.Example: Most malay are happy to serve in SPF and SCDF. We look more sachok in those uniform, that's how we attract dem minahs.

Words.English Translation: → English: sago + Malay: gula melaka from english sago starch of sago palms, plants of the species Metroxylon esp. M. sagu ← malay sagu sago palms, plants of the species Metroxylon esp. M. sagu, and their edible starch + malay gula melaka palm sugar; palm jaggery ← malay gula sugar ← sanskrit गुल gula unrefined sugar; raw sugar; molasses + malay Melaka a state in Malaysia (aka Malacca) or its capital city ← sanskrit आमलकी āmalakī Phyllanthus emblica, aka the Indian gooseberry tree, whose fruits can be eaten, or used in cooking and Ayurvedic medicine
Words.Definition: a sweet dessert soup consisting of boiled sago pearls (soft, chewy balls around 3 - 5 mm in diameter made from sago starch) in chilled coconut milk, sweetened with gula melaka
Words.Example: Particularly enjoyable were the lychee pannacotta (S$8) with tropical fruit coulis and the coconut pudding (S$8) stuffed with sago pearls and drizzled with palm sugar — a modernised sago gula melaka indeed.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 屎 poj: sái from hokkien (poj) 屎 sái faeces; poop; excrement; bodily secretion; (vg.) shit; lousy; useless
Words.Definition: faeces; poop; excrement

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 屎工 poj: sái-kang from hokkien (poj) 屎工 sái-kang undesirable and unpleasant work or tasks ← hokkien (poj) 屎 sái faeces; bodily excrement; shit ← hokkien (poj) 工 kang work
Words.Definition: undesirable, unpleasant, boring, or menial work or tasks; dirty work

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 屎工 poj: sái-kang + English: warrior from hokkien (poj) 屎工 sái-kang undesirable and unpleasant work or tasks ← hokkien (poj) 屎 sái faeces; bodily excrement; shit ← hokkien (poj) 工 kang work + english warrior fighter; soldier; active combatant ← anglo-norman werreur fighter; combatant ← old french guerroiier fighter; combatant; wage war
Words.Definition: a person who excels at doing, or is very often made to do, undesirable, unpleasant, or boring work or tasks, especially when doing so stoically and without complaint

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 司奶 poj: sai-nai from hokkien (poj) 司奶 sai-nai spoilt; childish; petulant; acting cutesy
Words.Definition: spoilt; childish; acting like a spoilt child; cutesy; emotionally sensitive
Words.Example: wow ... she so sweet so sai nai ... no cry no cry, moi sayang sayang .

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 三跤 poj: saⁿ-kha + Possible, but not certain Malay: sakar from hokkien (poj) 三跤 saⁿ-kha suck up to sb.; booklick; brownnose, (lit.) three legs ← hokkien (poj) 三 saⁿ three + hokkien (poj) 跤 kha leg; foot + malay Possible, but not certain sakar sugar; cane sugar ← persian شکر šakar sugar ← sanskrit शर्करा śarkarā gravel; small stone; ground sugar
Words.Definition: to flatter; to compliment; to butter up, often with the implication of doing so for some motive or agenda
Words.Example: Maybe sakar her a bit and she’ll be more amenable to approving your leave.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: sakit from malay sakit pain; painful; sick
Words.Definition: painful
Words.Example: - What if I press here?- Eh! Sakit!

Words.English Translation: → Malay: salah from malay salah wrong; false
Words.Definition: wrong; false; erroneous
Words.Example: Your answer all salah lah, no wonder fail so badly.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 三六九 poj: saⁿ-la̍k-káu from hokkien (poj) 三六九 saⁿ-la̍k-káu numbers 3, 6, 9
Words.Definition: An infamous gang operating in Singapore. Associated with violent gangsterism, delinquency, criminals, and low-class behaviour.

Words.English Translation: → English: saliva + conscious from english saliva spit; enzymatic liquid produced by glands in the mouth ← latin salīva saliva; spit + english conscious sensitive of; aware of ← latin cōnscius aware of; conscious
Words.Definition: uncomfortable with exchanging saliva with others, either directly, or indirectly through food, beverages, eating utensils, straws, water bottles, etc.
Words.Example: Hello. I'm extremely saliva conscious and I am wondering for other fellow saliva conscious people out there, how do you kiss??A light peck seems okay but, the thought of french kiss creeps me out. How do I overcome this fear?

Words.English Translation: → English: saltish from english saltish slightly or somewhat salty ← english salt crystals mainly composed of of sodium chloride, used as a condiment and ingredient + english -ish used to form an adj. from a noun or adj., meaning ‘rather; somewhat’
Words.Definition: salty
Words.Example: Alamak. This tau yu a bit too saltish.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: saman from malay saman fine; monetary penalty ← english summons legal notice requiring sb. to appear in court or pay a fine
Words.Definition: a fine or monetary penalty
Words.Example: If you've never received a speeding summons or saman, as we like to call it, that plain envelope marked 'On Government Service' looks innocuous. You might even think it's from HDB or CPF.

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: saman + auntie from singlish saman fine; monetary penalty ← malay saman fine; monetary penalty ← english summons legal notice requiring sb. to appear in court or pay a fine + singlish auntie term of address for a woman of an older generation than the speaker, regardless of relation ← english auntie dimin. of aunt (female relative of the same generation as one's parent) ↻ asian languages "auntie" equivalent of "auntie" in various languages and cultures; woman of older generation than oneself
Words.Definition: a female parking warden or enforcement officer who issues parking tickets to illegally parked vehicles at public carparks
Words.Example: Ah, the 'saman aunty'... Clad in her iconic blue-and-white uniform and armed with an evil calculator-looking device, this legendary makcik is the stuff Singaporean nightmares are made of.

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: saman + uncle from singlish saman fine; monetary penalty ← malay saman fine; monetary penalty ← english summons legal notice requiring sb. to appear in court or pay a fine + singlish uncle term of address for a man of an older generation than the speaker, regardless of relation ← english uncle male relative of the same generation as one's parent ↻ asian languages "uncle" equivalent of "uncle" in various languages and cultures; man of older generation than oneself
Words.Definition: a male parking warden or enforcement officer who issues parking tickets to illegally parked vehicles at public carparks
Words.Example: “Saman uncle” takes abuse in his stride ... He’s been railed at, offered bribes and even been hit by angry motorists.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: sambal from malay sambal paste or relish made from chilli and other spices or ingredients ← javanese ꦱꦩ꧀ꦧꦼꦭ꧀ sambel sambal ← tamil Likely, but other possible etymologies exist சம்பால் campāl kind of savoury dish or seasoning ← sanskrit सम्बार sambāra spices
Words.Definition: a paste or relish made from chilli and other spices or ingredients, such as ginger, garlic, lime juice, small shrimp, shrimp paste, etc. It probably originated in Javanese cuisine, and is now an integral part of the cuisines of many South-East Asian cultures. It comes in many forms and is often tailored to specific uses and dishes, such as a mostly sweet, smooth, low-pungency (spiciness) version for nasi lemak and a coarser, more chilli-centric version for ayam penyet.
Words.Example: … most fishermen beyond our shores consider this fish an unwanted catch. But for us Singaporeans, BBQ sambal stingray is a need to have at supper tables.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: sambal + belacan from malay sambal paste or relish made from chilli and other spices or ingredients ← javanese ꦱꦩ꧀ꦧꦼꦭ꧀ sambel sambal ← tamil Likely, but other possible etymologies exist சம்பால் campāl kind of savoury dish or seasoning ← sanskrit सम्बार sambāra spices + malay belacan a Malay fermented shrimp paste
Words.Definition: a sambal made primarily using chillies mixed with toasted belacan, traditionally pounded together in a mortar with a small amount of limau kasturi juice and sugar.
Words.Example: Thank you for your warmth and kindness, sending my father (and me) your special sambal belacan all these years!

Words.English Translation: → English: same from english same alike; equal; equivalent; not different
Words.Definition: 'there’s no difference'; 'it’s all the same'; expressing that something is equivalent or just like another thing
Words.Example: - Can lend me $3?- Na, take.- This is a RM10 note bro…- Same same what.

Words.English Translation: → English: same + but + different from english same alike; equal; equivalent; not different + english but contrary to the previous statement; however; nevertheless + english different not the same; unlike; separate
Words.Definition: expressing that something is nearly equivalent or quite similar to another thing, but not exactly
Words.Example: One is liao (already), one is liao (filling; condiments). Same same, but different.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: sampai + tua from malay sampai until; reach; arrive; achieve + malay tua old (age)
Words.Definition: (military) having no further prospects of career advancements or promotions
Words.Example: After the armskote debacle, he knew he’d be a sampai tua if he stayed on in the army.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: sampan from malay sampan small wooden rowboat ← hokkien (poj) 舢板 sam-pán small wooden rowboat
Words.Definition: a small wooden rowboat
Words.Example: Mr Lee said the Republic is a small country and while it may have progressed from being a "sampan" to a safer boat with a motor, "the seas are unpredictable".

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 三八 poj: sam-pat from hokkien (poj) 三八 sam-pat (lit.) 3 8, (hum.) woman who behaves irrationally and is slightly crazy; having traits associated with such women e.g. unreasonable, frivolous, immodest, unabashed, gossipy, etc.; silly; stupid; foolish
Words.Definition: (euphemistic, humorous) a woman (usually) who behaves irrationally and is slightly crazy, and has traits such as being unreasonable, frivolous, immodest, unabashed, gossipy, acting wacky, etc.
Words.Example: She thinks she's being even more quirky by suddenly becoming bi out of nowhere ah. AA only, what a little sampat.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 三牲 poj: sam-seng from hokkien (poj) 三牲 sam-seng (lit.) three domestic animals (pig, sheep, cattle), oft. used for sacrifices; (slang) gangster
Words.Definition: gangster; hooligan; ruffian
Words.Example: Samseng roamed the streets stoning pedestrians, bicycles, and hackney carriages.

Words.English Translation: → Cantonese: 三水 jyutping: saam1 seoi2 from cantonese (jyutping) 三水 saam1 seoi2 name of a district in Guangdong, China ← cantonese (jyutping) 三 saam1 three + cantonese (jyutping) 水 seoi2 water; waters
Words.Definition: a district in Guangdong, China where the majority of Samsui women hailed from

Words.English Translation: → Cantonese: 三水 jyutping: saam1 seoi2 + English: chicken from cantonese (jyutping) 三水 saam1 seoi2 name of a district in Guangdong, China ← cantonese (jyutping) 三 saam1 three + cantonese (jyutping) 水 seoi2 water; waters + english chicken member of the subspecies Gallus gallus domesticus
Words.Definition: a dish of steamed chicken marinated in soya sauce, sesame oil, and generous amounts of ginger, and served with a ginger-based dip. Similar in flavour profile to the Hainanese steamed chicken used in chicken rice.
Words.Example: Apparently, the samsui chicken is real in that the chicken is prepared and cooked in the samsui way (i.e., ginger etc). But when I asked if it was true that samsui women only ate samsui chicken once a year like during Chinese New Year, Hoi Yin said no, not even once a year.

Words.English Translation: → Cantonese: 三水 jyutping: saam1 seoi2 + English: woman from cantonese (jyutping) 三水 saam1 seoi2 name of a district in Guangdong, China ← cantonese (jyutping) 三 saam1 three + cantonese (jyutping) 水 seoi2 water; waters + english woman adult female person
Words.Definition: any of the women, mostly hailing from Samsui in Guangdong, China but also other regions such as Fujian and Chaozhou, who came to Singapore during the 1920s to 1940s to work as manual labourers, most often in the construction industry. They were usually distinguished by their trademark outfit of a stiff square bright red cloth hat and a dark blue samfu (a traditional Chinese blouse).Samsui women often lived hard lives and earned barely enough to get by on a simple lifestyle. They have often been recognised for their important role in Singapore’s early development.
Words.Example: Recently, a Chinatown shophouse mural by Sean Dunston depicting a samsui woman with a cigarette has become the centre of a heated debate.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: sangkut from malay sangkut snag; entangle; hook onto
Words.Definition: to snag; to entangle

Words.English Translation: → Malay: santan from malay santan coconut milk; coconut cream ← old javanese santěn coconut milk ← sanskrit सार sāra essence
Words.Definition: coconut milk; coconut cream; the liquid pressed from the scraped-out inner flesh of a coconut

Words.English Translation: → Malay: sapu from malay sapu broom; sweep; wipe clean; clear out (a room)
Words.Definition: to completely finish a meal; to eat something all up
Words.Example: The chai tow kway here was so good, I sapu the whole large portion by myself and still wanted to get another.

Words.English Translation: → Urdu: شربت sharbat + English: stall from urdu شربت sharbat sweet West and South Asian drink from flower petals or malay serbat sweet drink made with water, ginger, sugar, etc.; sweet West and South Asian drink ← persian شربت šarbat sweet West and South Asian drink from flower petals ← arabic شَرْبَة šarba drink + english stall small shop where goods are sold
Words.Definition: a drink stand traditionally set up at roadsides and run by Pakistani immigrants, which offer a variety of local drinks from the traditional teh tarik and eponymous teh sarabat (teh halia) to more modern innovations such as a Neslo Godzilla
Words.Example: The resident philosopher, Mohideen the sarabat stall owner, wiped his hands on the tea towel and flashed a smile that sent 1,001 fireflies into ecstasy.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: sarjan from malay sarjan (mil.) sergeant ← english sergeant (mil.) the ranks between corporal and warrant officer; soldier holding such a rank ← old french sergeant/serjant sergeant; servant ← medieval latin serviens servant; soldier; vassal ← latin serviō serve; be a slave to
Words.Definition: (military, when qualified) any sergeant rank; the ranks between corporal and warrant officer
Words.Example: Sarjen Greg, tonight can order in anot?

Words.English Translation: → Malay: sarung from malay sarung traditional lower garment worn in various forms by South-East and South Asians, usu. a light, decoratively-printed cloth tied around the waist
Words.Definition: a garment traditionally worn in South and South-East Asia, which is usually a light, decoratively-printed cloth wrapped around the waist or sometimes under the armpits
Words.Example: I grew up in a world of sarongs. Grandma wore colourful, crisp sarongs, starched till they could function as mini changing rooms when left to stand on their own. My mother had a wider range — sarong kebaya or cheongsam for formal functions and celebrations, cotton blouses with sarong or pants for informal wear. Grandfather was always in cool, checked sarongs whenever in relaxation mode.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: sarung + kebaya from malay sarung traditional lower garment worn in various forms by South-East and South Asians, usu. a light, decoratively-printed cloth tied around the waist + malay kebaya traditional light blouse ← arabic قَبَايَة/قَبَاء qabāya/qabāʔ type of long-sleeved garment; gown ← middle persian kabāh cloak; garment
Words.Definition: a traditional outfit formed by the combination of the sarong, a long cloth wrapped around the waist or under the armpits, with the kebaya, a light upper garment or blouse, worn over it
Words.Example: The nyonya sarong kebaya is not complete unless worn with jewellery, beaded shoes, silver belt and a silver or beaded bag.

Words.English Translation: → English: sarong party + girl from english sarong party party for expatriates, usually well-off Western professionals, where guests dress up in sarongs ← malay sarung traditional lower garment worn in various forms by South-East and South Asians, usu. a light, decoratively-printed cloth tied around the waist + english party social event or gathering for fun and entertainment ← anglo-norman partie part; section ← latin partīta part; division + english girl young female human
Words.Definition: (derogatory) an Asian girl who goes to parties and other social events with the intention of hooking up with white expatriate men or other non-Asian foreigners; an Asian girl who dates a white expatriate man or other foreigner, especially if said girl is perceived to be attracted to their supposed racial or socioeconomic privilege
Words.Example: Maureen was a vivacious, totally dolled-up lady and the dream woman of every hot-blooded ang moh. She was the foremother and immeasurably higher-class version of the sarong party girl.

Words.English Translation: → English: support from english support prop up; back; help ← old french supporter support ← latin supportō carry; bear; bring
Words.Definition: to support
Words.Example: Pls sarpork Singapore Children's Society Fundraising!

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 杀 殺 poj: sat from hokkien (poj) 杀 殺 sat clipping of 杀气/殺氣 ✂ hokkien (poj) 杀气 殺氣 sat-khì (lit.) cold, bloodthirsty mood; killer's aura, (slang) awesome; cool ← hokkien (poj) 杀 殺 sat kill; murder; slay + hokkien (poj) 气 氣 khì air; breath; mood; character
Words.Definition: cool; trendy; awesome; hip
Words.Example: Aiseh, the teh tarik uncle damn sard sia.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 杀气 殺氣 poj: sat-khì from hokkien (poj) 杀气 殺氣 sat-khì (lit.) cold, bloodthirsty mood; killer's aura, (slang) awesome; cool ← hokkien (poj) 杀 殺 sat kill; murder; slay + hokkien (poj) 气 氣 khì air; breath; mood; character
Words.Definition: cool; awesome
Words.Example: How come when the policemen wear tight shorts they look so sat ki, but when I wear I look so buaya.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: sate/satay from malay sate/satay grilled, spiced meat on skewers served with peanut sauce ← javanese ꦱꦠꦺ saté satay ← tamil சதை catai flesh
Words.Definition: charcoal-grilled, spiced meat, usually mutton (kambing), chicken (ayam), or beef (variously sapi, lembu, or daging) on bamboo skewers (traditionally coconut leaf stems). It is usually served with a peanut sauce (kuah) in a bowl for dipping, with raw cucumber and onion as well as cubed ketupat on the side. Variants include a Chinese version which uses pork and a tablespoon of puréed pineapple in each bowl of sauce.It traces its history back to similar Arab skewered meat dishes like shish kebab. The version known today which uses characteristic local spices like turmeric and ginger likely originated in Java, from where it then spread to the rest of Indonesia and Malaysia. The Singaporean version is smaller than the Indonesian version, possibly to increase the surface area to volume ratio of each piece to maximize the ratio of seasoning and desirable charred outer layer to meat.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: sate/satay + Hokkien: 米粉 poj: bí-hún from malay sate/satay grilled, spiced meat on skewers served with peanut sauce ← javanese ꦱꦠꦺ saté satay ← tamil சதை catai flesh + hokkien (poj) 米粉 bí-hún rice vermicelli; rice flour ← hokkien (poj) 米 bí rice + hokkien (poj) 粉 hún flour; powder
Words.Definition: a dish of bee hoon fried with various ingredients such as seafood and kangkong and topped with a spicy peanut-based sauce very similar to satay sauce. It is an original Singaporean fusion of local Malay/Javanese and Teochew/Hokkien culinary cultures.
Words.Example: That evening ... Meng and I go out to dinner at Ang Mo Kio Central, where we could have our favourite satay bee hoon.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: sate/satay celup from malay sate/satay celup Melaka dish of raw skewers served with boiling satay sauce for dipping and cooking ← malay sate/satay grilled, spiced meat on skewers served with peanut sauce ← javanese ꦱꦠꦺ saté satay ← tamil சதை catai flesh + malay celup dip into liquid; submerge
Words.Definition: a Melakan dish of raw skewers (of seasoned meat, seafood, fishballs, etc.) served with a pot of thick, boiling satay sauce, into which the skewers are dipped to cook before eating. It is similar in concept to a steamboat.
Words.Example: Satay celup or steamboat satay is the dish where customers would dip their raw skewers of meat into a steaming pot of satay soup/gravy ... When Chinese food sellers appropriated satay or satay celup, pork was included in the dish.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: sate/satay + English: sauce from malay sate/satay grilled, spiced meat on skewers served with peanut sauce ← javanese ꦱꦠꦺ saté satay ← tamil சதை catai flesh + english sauce gravy; thick liquid condiment
Words.Definition: a thick, brown gravy made of both powdered and ground roasted peanuts with spices such as chilli, assam, shallots, garlic, lemongrass, galangal, and sugar, mixed together in a base of oil. Its composition may differ across cuisines and regions; for example, the Chinese version often includes a dollop of pineapple sauce. It is most often eaten as an accompaniment to satay, but is also used in other dishes such as satay bee hoon.
Words.Example: 'There's satay sauce in the cupboard,' you say.'Satay sauce is everywhere.'Maria doesn't know the origin of satay sauce, but she knows that the Dutch like to mix it into food.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: sate/satay + English: stick from malay sate/satay grilled, spiced meat on skewers served with peanut sauce ← javanese ꦱꦠꦺ saté satay ← tamil சதை catai flesh + english stick long piece of wood or other material
Words.Definition: a wooden skewer used to skewer satay, traditionally made from the hard midrib of coconut palm leaves, but in modern times (and as commercially sold) more often from bamboo
Words.Example: Ollivadai eventually picked out a satay stick from a shelf at the side of the shop, and pased it to Harris. "Twenty-one centimetres, was used for chicken satay. Hmm. Give it a wave."

Words.English Translation: → English: save + Singlish / english: lose face + General chinese: 面子 pinyin: miàn zi from english save preserve; conserve; prevent from losing; keep; spare + singlish / english lose face embarrass or disgrace oneself; lose one's dignity or reputation ← general chinese (pinyin) 丢脸 丟臉 diū liǎn embarrass or disgrace oneself; lose one's dignity or reputation + general chinese (pinyin) 面子 miàn zi face; reputation; public image; dignity
Words.Definition: to preserve one's dignity or reputation; to spare from embarrassment or disgrace
Words.Example: Keeping the South China Sea issue out of ASEAN discussions may help China to save face, but this diplomatic victory comes at the high strategic cost of driving the claimant states closer to the US and Japan.

Words.English Translation: → English: say ↻ General chinese: 讲 講 pinyin: jiǎng from english say speak; talk ↻ general chinese (pinyin) 讲 講 jiǎng say; speak; talk about; lecture; badmouth; gossip; complain about
Words.Definition: to blame; to assign fault to; to make allegations against
Words.Example: Eh that one really not me ah! Don't anyhow go and say people!

Words.English Translation: → English: say + first from english say tell; speak sth. + english first before continuing with other things
Words.Definition: used to coax someone into revealing or saying something, especially when they are hesitant to do so for fear of consequences, backlash, embarrassment, etc.
Words.Example: Eh say first lah, anything happen we won’t pau toh you one.

Words.Word: say people say yourself 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Singlish: say + Hokkien: 有喙讲别人，无喙讲家己 有喙講別人，無喙講家己 poj: ū chhùi kóng pa̍t-lâng, bô chhùi kóng ka-kī from singlish say blame; scold; complain about; badmouth ← english say speak; pronounce; tell ↻ general chinese (pinyin) 讲 講 jiǎng say; speak; talk about; lecture; badmouth; gossip; complain about + hokkien (poj) 有喙讲别人，无喙讲家己 有喙講別人，無喙講家己 ū chhùi kóng pa̍t-lâng, bô chhùi kóng ka-kī (idiom) have a mouth to talk about others, yet no mouth to talk about oneself ← hokkien (poj) 有 有 ū have + hokkien (poj) 喙 喙 chhùi mouth + hokkien (poj) 讲 講 kóng speak; say; talk about; talk + hokkien (poj) 别人 別人 pa̍t-lâng other people; others + hokkien (poj) 无 無 bô not have; no; don’t + hokkien (poj) 家己 家己 ka-kī oneself; of one’s own
Words.Definition: (idiom) the pot calling the kettle black; pointing out the flaws or shortcomings of others while lacking the self-awareness to recognise the same faults in oneself. Used to imply that a criticism levied upon somebody by the idiom’s addressee is just as, if not more, applicable to themself.
Words.Example: - Haha Lilian wear today like so auntie sia.- Say people say yourself, obiang queen.

In Singaporean Peranakan cuisine, compressed rice cylinders called lontong or nasi impit are often added to it, to create a dish that is also referred to as lontong.

Words.English Translation: → English: scissors paper stone from english scissors paper stone game played by making hand signs of either scissors, paper, or stone, used in selection or tiebreaking ← english scissors tool with crossed blades attached at a pivot used for cutting or shearing thin material + english paper sheet made from, used for writing, wrapping objects, etc. + english stone piece of rock

Words.English Translation: → English: scissors paper stone + leg + stretch from english scissors paper stone game played by making hand signs of either scissors, paper, or stone, used in selection or tiebreaking ← english scissors tool with crossed blades attached at a pivot used for cutting or shearing thin material + english paper sheet made from, used for writing, wrapping objects, etc. + english stone piece of rock + english leg (in humans) one of the lower limbs of the body, used primarily for locomotion e.g. walking + english stretch extend; reach out with
Words.Definition: a game played between two players who start off facing one another, with one foot in front of the other and the tip of the forward foot touching the opponent’s. They then play scissors paper stone, with the winner of each bout putting their forward foot behind their back foot (toe-to-heel). Their opponent then has to stretch out their forward foot until it once again touches the now-forward foot of the winner, while keeping their back leg in place. The game continues until one player is physically unable to stretch to reach their opponent’s foot, or falls over or unplants their back leg in the process of trying, at which point their opponent is declared the winner.
Words.Example: The kids were late for class because they had gotten too absorbed in a particularly hard-fought game of Scissors Paper Stone Leg Stretch.
