Words.English Translation: → Vietnamese: Việt + Hokkien: 母 poj: bú from vietnamese Việt Vietnamese; Vietnam ← old chinese (pinyin) 越 yuè Vietnam; Vietnamese; beyond ← old chinese (pinyin) 戉 yuè type of ancient battleaxe + hokkien (poj) 母 bú mother; female
Words.Definition: (derogatory) a Vietnamese girl; a woman of Vietnamese nationality, ethnicity, etc., especially a young and attractive one
Words.Example: Viet bu kpkb Ah Pek for standing near her in the MRT.

Words.English Translation: → English: virus from english virus infectious particle consisting of a DNA or RNA packet surrounded by a protein coat, often causing disease ← latin vīrus venom; poison
Words.Definition: a game similar to catching where a specified 'infected' player chases the other players around with the goal of touching any part of their body with their hand, while the other players attempt to run away and avoid being touched. However, unlike catching (where the role of 'catcher' is transferred away to the caught player), when a player is touched by an 'infected' player, they are both then 'infected' for the rest of the round, and as such must both chase down the 'uninfected' players. Hence, the number of 'infected' players always increases as the game progresses. The game usually continues until every player has been infected, or a certain time limit has been reached.

Words.English Translation: → English: void + deck from english void empty; unoccupied; containing nothing ← old french vuit empty ← latin vacuus empty; vacant + english deck flat floor or surface for walking on ← middle dutch dec/decken roof; cover
Words.Definition: an unoccupied common area found at the ground floor of almost every HDB block, sometimes used for social functions, gatherings, and events including weddings or funerals, and often containing e.g. seating areas, community facilities, bicycle parking, and sometimes even small sundry shops known as mama shops.
Words.Example: In contrast to the safe and regulated space of the flat, the void deck is seen as a permissive and carnivalesque space, where the margins and interstices of dominant state discourses ... come to the fore.

Words.English Translation: → English: vomit + blood ↻ Hokkien: 吐血 poj: thò͘-huih & Cantonese: 呕血 嘔血 jyutping: au2 hyut3 from english vomit regurgitate; throw up ← latin vomitāre vomit + english blood bodily fluid conveying oxygen and nutrients ↻ hokkien (poj) 吐血 thò͘-huih (lit.) vomit blood; (fig.) be infuriating or exasperating; angry; frustrated; shocked ← hokkien (poj) 吐 thò͘ vomit; spit + hokkien (poj) 血 huih blood & cantonese (jyutping) 呕血 嘔血 au2 hyut3 (lit.) vomit blood; (fig.) be angry, frustrated, exhausted etc. ← cantonese (jyutping) 呕 嘔 au2 vomit + cantonese (jyutping) 血 血 hyut3 blood
Words.Definition: (figurative) to become overwhelmed by extreme frustration, infuriation, shock, aggravation, etc.
Words.Example: Kani nah. Just thinking about Ah Long coming back and getting to sit in some air-con office, planning the family business's future while Ah Meng sweated his balls off at the kelong, made him want to vomit blood.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 我 poj: óa/góa from hokkien (poj) 我 óa/góa I; me; my
Words.Definition: I; me; my

Words.Word: wa bo kia 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Latin: Wolbachia + Hokkien: 我 poj: óa + 无 無 poj: bô + 囝 poj: kiáⁿ from latin Wolbachia type of male mosquitoes infected with the Wolbachia parasite, rendering them effectively sterile ← latin Wolbachia (taxonomy) genus of bacteria which acts as a parasite in many arthropod species ← german Wolbach family name of Simeon Burt Wolbach + latin -ia suffix used to form abstract nouns; (esp. in taxonomy) suffixed to a name or word to form a genus name + hokkien (poj) 我 óa I; me + hokkien (poj) 无 無 bô no; not have; don't + hokkien (poj) 囝 kiáⁿ children; kids
Words.Definition: (humorous) a type of male mosquito infected with the Wolbachia parasite, rendering them effectively sterile. They are released in several estates in Singapore as a biological agent to control the population of mosquitoes, and thus reduce the spread of mosquito-borne diseases such as dengue fever.
Words.Example: Gahmen release so many wa bo kiãs, I dunno which one is the real dengue mozzie so end up I just whack all anyway.

Words.Word: wa ka li kong 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 我共汝讲 我共汝講 poj: oá kā lí kóng from hokkien (poj) 我共汝讲 我共汝講 oá kā lí kóng [let] me tell you; 'listen here' ← hokkien (poj) 我 我 oá I; me; 1p. sing. pronoun + hokkien (poj) 共 共 kā to; with; at + hokkien (poj) 汝 汝 lí you; 2p. sing. pronoun + hokkien (poj) 讲 講 kóng speak; talk; say
Words.Definition: used at the start of a sentence to call attention to something one is about to say; used to indicate one is about to give their opinion, give advice, explain something, share their thoughts etc.; 'look here'; 'listen here'
Words.Example: Wa ka li kong, use olive oil on your hair it will stay black black one, no need dye. My friend tell me one!

Words.English Translation: → Mandarin: 哇靠 pinyin: wà kào from mandarin (pinyin) 哇靠 wà kào holy crap; damn; oh my god
Words.Definition: my goodness; holy crap; damn; oh my god

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 碗糕 poj: óaⁿ-ko/ko͘ from hokkien (poj) 碗糕 óaⁿ-ko/ko͘ a traditional steamed rice cake, (slang) the heck; what on earth ← hokkien (poj) 碗 óaⁿ bowl; rice bowl + hokkien (poj) 糕 ko/ko͘ cake
Words.Definition: (slightly vulgar) the hell; (what) on earth
Words.Example: People say si mi wã ko you also will believe meh?

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 碗糕粿 poj: óaⁿ-ko/ko͘-kóe from hokkien (poj) 碗糕粿 óaⁿ-ko/ko͘-kóe a traditional steamed rice cake, (slang) the heck; what on earth ← hokkien (poj) 碗 óaⁿ bowl; rice bowl + hokkien (poj) 糕 ko/ko͘ cake + hokkien (poj) 粿 kóe kueh
Words.Definition: a traditional Hokkien steamed rice flour cupcake, which is soft, fluffy, and sweet. It is traditionally leavened with baking soda instead of yeast. The cakes are usually coloured in a variety of pale shades, such as pink, green, brown, and blue, but this usually has no bearing on the individual cakes' flavours (though some bakers may incorporate flavours, such as pandan or gula melaka in green- or brown-coloured cakes respectively). Very similar to ma lai gao and huat kueh, the latter of which is often just used as a synonym, though they are often differentiated as being somewhat larger and less colourful than wã ko kueh.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 我 poj: óa + Min nan: 莫 莫 poj: mài from hokkien (poj) 我 óa I; me + min nan (poj) 莫 莫 mài not want; contraction of 毋愛 ← hokkien (poj) 毋爱 毋愛 m̄-ài not want
Words.Definition: 'I don’t want (it/to/that etc.)'

Words.English Translation: → General chinese: 哇 pinyin: wā + Hokkien: 我 poj: óa/góa + Cantonese: 哗 嘩 jyutping: waa3 from general chinese (pinyin) 哇 wā woah!; wow!; exclamation of surprise, shock, amazement, etc. + hokkien (poj) 我 óa/góa I; me; my (part of interjectional phrases) + cantonese (jyutping) 哗 嘩 waa3 woah!; wow!; exclamation of surprise, shock, amazement, etc.
Words.Definition: woah!; wow!; oh my; exclamation of surprise, shock, amazement, etc.
Related: mai la mai la, wa mai

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 我𡳞 poj: óa lān from hokkien (poj) 我𡳞 óa lān (vg.) oh my God; for goodness' sake; (lit.) 'oh/my cock' ← hokkien (poj) 我 óa I; me; my + hokkien (poj) 𡳞 lān (vg.) penis; cock
Words.Definition: (vulgar) oh my God, man; for goodness' sake; oh cock; exclamation of frustration, shock, anger, disbelief, distress, surprise, etc.
Words.Example: "Wah lan! I organized this specially for you, and you're not staying?" Bernard sounded frustrated.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 我𡳞欸 poj: óa lān--eh from hokkien (poj) 我𡳞欸 óa lān--eh (vg.) oh my God, man; for goodness' sake; (lit.) 'oh/my cock' ← hokkien (poj) 我 óa I; me; my + hokkien (poj) 𡳞 lān (vg.) penis; cock + hokkien (poj) 欸 --eh general intensifying particle; used to exp. surprise, shock, get attention, etc.
Words.Definition: (vulgar) oh my God, man; for goodness' sake; oh cock; exclamation of frustration, shock, anger, disbelief, distress, surprise, etc.
Words.Example: I said wah l** eh! I thought it was just an expression like wah lau eh and didn't know what it actually meant. Now I know that it means man's best friend and I am not referring to his dog.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 我老 poj: óa lāu from hokkien (poj) 我老 óa lāu oh my God; oh my goodness; for goodness' sake; wow ← hokkien (poj) 我 óa I; me; my + hokkien (poj) 老 lāu old; elderly; respectful or familiar prefix
Words.Definition: oh my God, man; oh my goodness; for goodness' sake; exclamation of frustration, incredulity, disbelief, shock, anger, distress, surprise, etc.
Words.Example: Wah lao! That musical was so bad, pay me money also I will never watch again!

Words.Word: wah lao eh 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 我老欸/个 我老欸/個 poj: óa lāu--eh/--ê from hokkien (poj) 我老欸/个 我老欸/個 óa lāu--eh/--ê oh my God, man; oh my goodness; wow; woah ← hokkien (poj) 我 我 óa I; me; my + hokkien (poj) 老 老 lāu old; elderly; respectful or familiar prefix + hokkien (poj) 欸 欸 --eh general intensifying particle; used to exp. surprise, shock, get attention, etc. or hokkien (poj) 个 個 --ê possessive particle
Words.Definition: oh my God, man; oh my goodness; for goodness' sake; exclamation of frustration, incredulity, disbelief, shock, anger, distress, surprise, etc.
Words.Example: Low laughed loudly. "Wah lao eh, that really is your bloody catchphrase eh?"

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 我迸 poj: óa piàng from hokkien (poj) 我迸 óa piàng oh my God; oh my goodness; wow ← hokkien (poj) 我 óa I; me; my + hokkien (poj) 迸 piàng 'oh no'; 'what a disaster'
Words.Definition: oh my God; oh my goodness; wow; exclamation of surprise, shock, amazement, etc.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 我迸欸 poj: óa piàng--eh from hokkien (poj) 我迸欸 óa piàng--eh oh my God, man; oh my goodness; wow; woah ← hokkien (poj) 我 óa I; me; my + hokkien (poj) 迸 piàng 'oh no'; 'what a disaster' + hokkien (poj) 欸 --eh general intensifying particle; used to exp. surprise, shock, get attention, etc.
Words.Definition: oh my God, man; oh my goodness; my God; for goodness' sake; exclamation of shock, dread, distress, frustration, disbelief, etc.
Words.Example: "Wah piang eh, why y'all don't believe me? ... You have it all wrong and you're wasting time, okay?"

Words.English Translation: → Mandarin: 哇塞 pinyin: wā/wà sèi/sài from mandarin (pinyin) 哇塞 wā/wà sèi/sài oh my goodness; oh wow ← hokkien (poj) 我使 óa sai (vg.) 'fuck me'; 'I fuck'; excl. of frustration, consternation, shock, surprise, etc. ← hokkien (poj) 我 óa I; me; my + hokkien (poj) 使 sai do; make; effect; (vg.) fuck
Words.Definition: my goodness; wow; exclamation of surprise, shock, amazement, admiration, etc.
Words.Example: "Wah seh!" Ping exclaimed. "That's got to be the richest sample we've ever found at our touchdown site."

Words.English Translation: → English: wait + General chinese: 等 pinyin: děng from english wait delay action, proceeding, etc. until something occurs + general chinese (pinyin) 等 děng wait; when
Words.Definition: (usually, but not always, of an undesirable, unpleasant, or problematic outcome) when; supposing; lest; what if
Words.Example: Don’t stack liddat lah. Wait the whole thing really topple, then you know.

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: wait + later from singlish wait (usu. or an undesirable outcome) when; what if; lest ← english wait delay action, proceeding, etc. until something occurs + general chinese (pinyin) 等 děng wait; when + singlish later used to introduce a consequence or continuation; what if ← english wait at a future point in time + general chinese (pinyin) 等一下 děng yí xià wait one moment; later
Words.Definition: (usually, but not always, of an undesirable, unpleasant, or problematic outcome) when; supposing; lest; what if
Words.Example: Later your parents find out how?

Words.English Translation: → English: wait + long ↻ Hokkien: 等久久 poj: tán-kú-kú from english wait delay action, proceeding, etc. until something occurs + english long of an extended duration ↻ hokkien (poj) 等久久 tán-kú-kú used to exp. that sth. has a very low chance of happening; 'in your dreams'; 'not in a million years' ← hokkien (poj) 等 tán wait + hokkien (poj) 久久 kú-kú ages; for a long time ⇇ hokkien (poj) 久 kú (of time) long
Words.Definition: used to express that something has a very low chance of happening, and that hoping upon it is a futile endeavour; 'in your dreams'; 'not in a million years'
Words.Example: "That guy?" She smiled slightly. "Damn ngeow, ah. I always say — want to wait for him to buy something for me also must wait long long!

Words.Word: wait until neck long 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → English: wait + until + neck + long ↻ Cantonese: 等到颈都长 等到頸都長 jyutping: dang2 dou3 geng2 dou1 coeng4 from english wait delay action, proceeding, etc. until something occurs + english until up to; to the point that + english neck body part connecting the head and torso + english long extended; lengthy ↻ cantonese (jyutping) 等到颈都长 等到頸都長 dang2 dou3 geng2 dou1 coeng4 wait a very long time ← cantonese (jyutping) 等 等 dang2 wait + cantonese (jyutping) 到 到 dou3 until; to the point that + cantonese (jyutping) 颈 頸 geng2 neck + cantonese (jyutping) 都 都 dou1 also; even; as well + cantonese (jyutping) 长 長 coeng4 long
Words.Definition: (idiom) to wait or have been waiting for a very long time
Words.Example: Seletar line got news bo, wait until neck long long still feasible studee

Words.English Translation: → English: wake up + idea from english wake up awaken from sleep, (fig.) become more aware of or focused on the current situation; stop daydreaming ← english wake stop sleeping; arouse + english up aspect marker for completion of an action + english idea notion; thought; clue ← latin idea idea; notion ← ancient greek ἰδέα idéa idea; notion
Words.Definition: to stop daydreaming; to become more focused on and aware of the current situation; to get back in touch with reality
Words.Example: Then my father switched over to scolding me in English ... "Wake up your idea, man, Hafiz! Wake up your funny idea!"

Words.English Translation: → English: walk around + look + important from english walk around wander about aimlessly; meander ← english walk locomote by stepping one foot in front of the other while keeping the other planted on the ground + english around to various places; in a general circle + english look appear; seem + english important significant; valuable; crucial ← medieval latin importāns importing; causing
Words.Definition: (military) to hang around an area while pretending to do some serious work, while actually having little or nothing to do; to act like one is doing more than one is busy with

Words.English Translation: → English: walk + some more + Singlish: some more from english walk locomote by stepping one foot in front of the other while keeping the other planted on the ground + english some more further; in addition ← english some few; unspecified amount of anything ← english more additional; greater than + singlish some more in addition; on top of that; moreover; 'what’s more' ← english some few; unspecified amount of anything ← english more additional; greater than
Words.Definition: (military, sarcastic) used to chide someone who is walking slowly and taking their time when they ought to be hurrying somewhere else with haste

Words.English Translation: → English: want + to ↻ Min nan / hakka: 爱 愛 poj: ài + Mandarin / cantonese: 要 pinyin: yào + Hokkien / hainanese / hockchew: 欲 poj: beh from english want desire; wish for + english to inf. marker ↻ min nan / hakka (poj) 爱 愛 ài want to; about to; going to + mandarin / cantonese (pinyin) 要 yào want to; about to; going to + hokkien / hainanese / hockchew (poj) 欲 beh want to; about to; going to
Words.Definition: about to; going to; will be
Words.Example: This kind of companies (or rather startups) want to toh is pretty fast. I have seen two toh liao.

Words.English Translation: → Cantonese: 云吞 雲吞 jyutping: wan4 tan1 from cantonese (jyutping) 云吞 雲吞 wan4 tan1 Chinese dumpling with a filling of seasoned meat and vegetables ← cantonese (jyutping) 馄饨 餛飩 wan4 tan4-1 Chinese dumpling with a filling of seasoned meat and vegetables ← general chinese (pinyin) 混沌 混沌 hùn dùn primordial chaos
Words.Definition: a Chinese dumpling consisting of a thin dumpling skin wrapped around a filling of seasoned meat (such as pork or prawns) and vegetables, usually such that there is a sizeable frill or flap of skin adorning the dumpling. It is commonly prepared either boiled or deep-fried, and eaten in soup or with noodles.

Words.English Translation: → Cantonese: 云吞 雲吞 jyutping: wan4 tan1 + Hokkien: 面 麵 poj: mī from cantonese (jyutping) 云吞 雲吞 wan4 tan1 Chinese dumpling with a filling of seasoned meat and vegetables ← cantonese (jyutping) 馄饨 餛飩 wan4 tan4-1 Chinese dumpling with a filling of seasoned meat and vegetables ← general chinese (pinyin) 混沌 混沌 hùn dùn primordial chaos + hokkien (poj) 面 麵 mī wheat noodles
Words.Definition: a dish of wantan served with Cantonese-style thin egg noodles (or sometimes other types of noodle), also known as rubberband noodles or simply wantan noodles, and various other toppings such as steamed bok choy, slices of char siew, chilli, fried shallots, etc. It may be served as soup or dry with the soup on the side.
Words.Example: We could not even tell if we would have our next bowl of wantan mee or plain rice with canned hot chilli prawn paste, which we fondly called hei bee hiang.

Words.English Translation: → Cantonese: 云吞 雲吞 jyutping: wan4 tan1 + English: noodles from cantonese (jyutping) 云吞 雲吞 wan4 tan1 Chinese dumpling with a filling of seasoned meat and vegetables ← cantonese (jyutping) 馄饨 餛飩 wan4 tan4-1 Chinese dumpling with a filling of seasoned meat and vegetables ← general chinese (pinyin) 混沌 混沌 hùn dùn primordial chaos + english noodles long, thin strings of cooked dough ← german Nudel pasta; noodle
Words.Definition: a dish of wantan served with Cantonese-style thin egg noodles (or sometimes other types of noodle), also known as rubberband noodles or simply wantan noodles, and various other toppings such as steamed bok choy, slices of char siew, chilli, fried shallots, etc. It may be served as soup or dry with the soup on the side.
Words.Example: This week I start my diet ... This means no hamburgers, chicken rice, wantan noodles and basically everything else worth eating.

Words.English Translation: → Cantonese: 云吞 雲吞 jyutping: wan4 tan1 + English: soup from cantonese (jyutping) 云吞 雲吞 wan4 tan1 Chinese dumpling with a filling of seasoned meat and vegetables ← cantonese (jyutping) 馄饨 餛飩 wan4 tan4-1 Chinese dumpling with a filling of seasoned meat and vegetables ← general chinese (pinyin) 混沌 混沌 hùn dùn primordial chaos + english soup liquid-based dish with water or stock and other ingredients; broth ← french soupe soup
Words.Definition: a dish of wantan dumplings served in a savoury soup, often topped with white pepper and chopped spring onions
Words.Example: Ever eaten in a Chinatown restaurant abroad? You've probably puzzleed over what long soup and short soup were on the menu ... Long soup is wantan soup with noodles. Short soup is an abbreviated version, minus the long noodles.

Words.English Translation: → English: wasp from english wasp any member of the paraphyletic group of the suborder Apocrita but excluding bees and ants, sometimes having a sting
Words.Definition: wasp (any member of the paraphyletic group consisting of the suborder Apocrita but excluding bees and ants, sometimes having a sting)

Words.English Translation: → English: warrant officer from english warrant officer (mil.) officer who is not commissioned but holds a warrant ← english warrant authorization; certification; sanction; guarantee ← anglo-norman warant authorization; assurance; guarantee; witness; protector ← old french guarant authorization; assurance; guarantee; witness; protector + english officer sb. w. a position of authority or holding a rank or office, (mil.) commissioned officer ← anglo-norman officer officer ← old french officer officer ← latin officiārius officer
Words.Definition: (military) a warrant officer; an officer who is not commissioned but holds a higher rank and office than specialists or other non-commissioned officers by virtue of having a warrant
Related: confirm plus guarantee times 2 with 3 year warranty

Words.English Translation: → English: wash from english wash clean with water or other liquid; (photog.) remove
Words.Definition: to develop photographs or photographic film

Words.English Translation: → English: water + parade from english water clear liquid (at room temperature and pressure) with the chemical formula H2O + english parade (mil.) organized procession involving soldiers marching in formation; soldiers composing the procession; general show or display of military force or drills ← french parade military display; ostentatious procession ← italian parata military parade; preparation; ostentatious display
Words.Definition: (military) a mandated and organized ceremony in which soldiers are made to drink a given amount of water (usually 500 ml or 1 litre) to prevent dehydration, especially just before or after some physical activity or exercise
Words.Example: The water parade was held at 2030, the earliest ever. Lights-out was at 2200.Water parades are meant to ensure we're hydrated, but forcing down a full liter of water can be difficult. Thanaraj can verify that. While trying to finish his bottle, he threw up.

Words.English Translation: → Malay: wayang from malay wayang Javanese shadow play performance or puppet ← javanese ꦮꦪꦁ wayang shadow play performance or puppet
Words.Definition: to act; to pretend, especially to be busy doing work when one is not; to put on a perfunctory display
Words.Example: A person's character is not determined from distorted media reports or from some wayang show.
Related: khiang tioh ho, mai keh khiang

Words.English Translation: → English: wet from english wet covered or soaked in a liquid
Words.Definition: (of food, usually noodles) served in a sauce or gravy

Words.English Translation: → English: wet + market from english wet covered or soaked in a liquid, esp. water + english market set place for trade of goods; set or demographic of customers for a product or industry ← latin mercātus trade; market
Words.Definition: a market located in a complex with several stalls selling a variety of fresh produce such as vegetables, fish, meat, and fruits which is usually sourced from more local or regional sources as compared to supermarkets. They are often located next to or within a contiguous complex with hawker centres, as many hawkers source their ingredients from there. Stalls usually only operate during the morning or daytime.
Words.Example: Even while he was working as a consultant, Tan began a Facebook business to take small orders and deliveries. But he always knew he wanted to be in a wet market to "retain the tradition and show that a fish stall can be clean and appealing" ... "We should feel confident about our Asian wet markets and find new ways to innovate to be relevant. It would be sad if we were to lose this wet-market culture.

Words.English Translation: → English: whack from english whack hit; beat; smack ↻ hokkien (poj) 拍 phah (lit.) hit; (generally) do or perform an action; used to verbify a noun & hokkien (poj) 拂 hut act recklessly; disregard everything; do without care for the consequences & hokkien (poj) 刜 hut/phut strike forcefully; hit; do recklessly without care for the consequences & malay gasak hit; beat; whack & malay hentam hit; beat; do sth. flagrantly with no regard for consequences
Words.Definition: to attack; to beat up
Words.Example: The driver drew out his toolbox and handed me a long spanner. ‘Eh signaller, for you to whack the pai nang.’ ‘Thanks, but if I kena whack, I’ll still rely on your Shaolin wushu to help me.’

Words.English Translation: → English: what from english what (dated) tag question used to await agreement of the preceding statement; 'isn’t it?'
Words.Definition: used to indicate the preceding statement’s contradiction or disagreement with the listener’s point of view or belief, which the speaker holds to be obviously false, unreasonable, ridiculous, etc.
Words.Example: - I’m lazy to walk there lah, damn far; let’s take bus.- It’s only a few hundred metres away what…

Words.English Translation: → English: what + talking + you from english what used to ask a question; which thing + english talking saying; speaking + english you 2p. sing. & pl. pronoun
Words.Definition: expression of confusion, doubt, incredulity, disagreement, etc., especially in response to someone saying something confusing, nonsensical, irrelevant, ridiculous, or untrue
Words.Example: " ... You're going to participate?""We're already participating! What talking you? ..."

Words.English Translation: → English: what + thing ↻ Hokkien / cantonese / teochew / general chinese: * various: (see details) from english what used to ask a question; which thing + english thing entity; being; object; concept, etc. ↻ hokkien / cantonese / teochew / general chinese (various) * (see details) 'what thing'
Words.Definition: 'what is it?'; 'what's the matter?'; used to curtly ask someone to get to the point, or speak their mind
Words.Example: "Hey Jacky, what do you see?" I asked."What thing?""Look around you."

Words.Word: what time already 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → English: what + time + Singlish: already ↻ General chinese: 几点了 幾點了 poj: kúi-tiám-liáo from english what used to ask a question; which thing + english time duration that has passed in a given day + singlish already particle indicating perfective aspect or change of state ← english already completed or happened by the present or specified time ↻ min nan (poj) 了 liáu particle indicating perfective aspect or change of state; already; (approximately) past tense marker ↻ general chinese (poj) 几点了 幾點了 kúi-tiám-liáo 'what time is it now?'
Words.Definition: (rhetorical) 'hurry up'; ‘what’s taking so long'; 'stop taking your own sweet time'; used to express impatience and annoyance at a delay or a person’s lateness
Words.Example: But that wasn't all Jaspers' smart home had to offer. When he announced his return home, the lights went on as the same robotic voice nagged: "Now then come back, what time already ah?" … "What time already, now then you sleep?" The device would say when Jaspers wished it good night. … Conversely, when Jaspers wished it a good morning, it replied: "What time already, now then you wake up?"

Words.English Translation: → English: WhatsApp from english WhatsApp (brand name) phone messaging app ← english what's up friendly or casual greeting + english app application, esp. for a smartphone or mobile device ✂ english application packaged computer program or software ← old french aplicacion applying of sth. ← latin applicationem applying of sth.; attachment
Words.Definition: WhatsApp, a phone messaging app now owned by Meta
Words.Example: I can't receive Whatapps at work; Tele me instead.

Words.Word: when policemen wear shorts 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → English: when + policemen + wear + shorts + Hokkien: 马打 馬打 poj: má-tâ + 穿 poj: chhēng + 短裤 短褲 poj: tér-khò͘ from english when at the time of; during the time + english policemen police officers + english wear don; put on; dress oneself with + english shorts pants that end above the knees + hokkien (poj) 马打 馬打 má-tâ police; policeman ← malay mata-mata police ⇇ malay mata eye + hokkien (poj) 穿 chhēng wear; put on (clothes); have (clothes) on + hokkien (poj) 短裤 短褲 tér-khò͘ shorts ← hokkien (poj) 短 短 tér short + hokkien (poj) 裤 褲 khò͘ trousers; pants
Words.Definition: (metaphor) a bygone era before the modernization of Singapore; back in the day; a different era; a long time ago, especially when irrelevant to the present or the current situation
Words.Example: Triple science is more of a prestige option, a legacy leftover from the days when policemen wear shorts.

Words.English Translation: → English: where + Singlish: can ↻ Hokkien: mana poj: ma-na + 会使 會使 poj: ē-sái from english where at what place; in what situation + singlish can affirmative particle; able to; permitted to ← english can able to; may; be possible; permitted ↻ hokkien (poj) mana ma-na where; (rhet.) how ← malay mana where + hokkien (poj) 会使 會使 ē-sái can; may; be allowed to
Words.Definition: since when is it allowed; in what situation is it possible; in what world would this do or suffice; how is this fair
Words.Example: Where can?! Come back here before you kena!

Words.English Translation: → English: where + Singlish: got from english where at what place; in what situation + singlish got have; exists; has happened ← english got received; obtained, (with have) possess
Words.Definition: used to express doubt about or question when or whether something is (or was), existed, happened, got done, etc.
Words.Example: For a little more than the price of a top-of-the-line steak lunch, diners get to enjoy all the red, white, and pink (raw) meats he or she can stomach. Where got bad?

Words.Word: where got can 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → English: where + Singlish: got + can ↻ Hokkien: mana poj: ma-na + 会使 會使 poj: ē-sái from english where at what place; in what situation + singlish got have; exists; has happened ← english got received; obtained, (with have) possess + singlish can affirmative particle; able to; permitted to ← english can able to; may; be possible; permitted ↻ hokkien (poj) mana ma-na where; (rhet.) how ← malay mana where + hokkien (poj) 会使 會使 ē-sái can; may; be allowed to
Words.Definition: since when is it allowed; in what situation is it possible; in what world would this do or suffice; how is this fair
Words.Example: Where got can?! Dun bedek lah!

Words.English Translation: → English: where + Singlish: got + English: time from english where at what place; in what situation + singlish got have; exists; has happened ← english got received; obtained, (with have) possess + english time duration
Words.Definition: used to express that while the idea of something is nice, it is not worth the time or effort to make the time it would require
Words.Example: I'm just proposing that the happiness, the satisfaction, or even, the self-actualization, that we seek may very well lie in day-to-day living, in its many simple pleasures, like nurturing a meaningful relationship or appreciating nature in a leisurely garden walk. Of course, you might retort: "Where got time?"

Words.English Translation: → English: white + fungus from english white bright and colourless; diffusely reflecting a mixture of all colours in the spectrum of visible light + english fungus a member of the kingdom Fungi ← latin fungus mushroom; fungal infection
Words.Definition: Tremella fuciformis, a fungus which grows edible frilly, translucent white fruiting bodies. When cooked, it has a desirable gelatinous texture, and is believed to have medicinal benefits in traditional Chinese medicine. It is popularly used in sweet desserts or soups in Chinese cuisine.
Words.Example: ... guests can also enjoy a one-time serving of chef's specials comprising braised shark's fin soup with white fungus and crabmeat, mussels in spicy chilli, wok-fried scallops with capsicum and pine nuts, ...

Words.English Translation: → English: white + gold ↻ Hokkien: 白金 poj: pe̍h-kim from english white bright and colourless; diffusely reflecting a mixture of all colours in the spectrum of visible light + english gold valuable heavy metal, chemical symbol Au ↻ hokkien (poj) 白金 pe̍h-kim white gold; platinum ← hokkien (poj) 帛金 pe̍h-kim money given at funerals as condolences for the bereaved + hokkien (poj) 帛 pe̍h silk ← hokkien (poj) 金 kim gold
Words.Definition: money given at wakes and funerals as condolences for the bereaved
Words.Example: Asking people to attend the funeral is 1 to let the people who know him send him off, 2 to collect white gold to recoup the losses incurred by the funeral. FYI funeral not cheap hor ...

Words.English Translation: → English: white + horse ↻ General chinese: 白马王子 白馬王子 pinyin: bái mǎ wáng zǐ from english white bright and colourless; diffusely reflecting a mixture of all colours in the spectrum of visible light + english horse Equus ferus, a domesticated hoofed animal used for work, riding, transport, racing, etc. ↻ general chinese (pinyin) 白马王子 白馬王子 bái mǎ wáng zǐ Prince Charming (fairytale character), (lit.) white horse prince ← general chinese (pinyin) 白 白 bái white + general chinese (pinyin) 马 馬 mǎ horse + general chinese (pinyin) 王子 王子 wáng zǐ prince; king's child
Words.Definition: (military) a soldier whose parents or family are from a highly wealthy or influential background. Such soldiers are usually given preferential treatment and far less strict orders, and their entire company often reaps benefits such as much more conscientious adherence to safety standards, lax book-in timings, allowance of time for recreational activities, and other such welfare liberties. To notify commanders of their status, their personnel dockets used to be stamped with a special mark (which may or may not have literally been in the shape of a horse), though this practice has supposedly been discontinued since the 2000s.
Words.Example: If I can, may I ask the Minister whether medical dockets continue to be stamped today with the "white horse" stamp, in view of his comments on equity in National Service?

Words.English Translation: → English: white + spider from english white bright and colourless; diffusely reflecting a mixture of all colours in the spectrum of visible light + english spider any member of the order Araneae
Words.Definition: a colourless soft drink, usually Sprite, topped with a scoop of ice cream; a Sprite float
Words.Example: Iced White Spider: This delightful beverage combines creamy vanilla ice cream with the crisp effervescence of soda, served over ice for a refreshing and satisfying drink that's sure to please.

Words.English Translation: → English: whole + day from english whole entire; all of + english day set 24-hour calendar period
Words.Definition: all day long; the entire time; constantly; incessantly
Words.Example: She whole day complaining about ST for so long liao, now then stop?? Is like those people whole day complaining about PAP but still vote for them.

Words.English Translation: → English: whole jingbang/jimbang + gang from english whole jingbang/jimbang (Scottish/US slang) whole bunch; unspecified entire lot of sth; shebang + english gang group or company of people; (pej.) criminal or delinquent group
Words.Definition: an entire group or bunch of people
Words.Example: Oi, I tell y’all one at a time lah, not the whole jin gang try to go at once!

Words.English Translation: → English: whole + Malay: kampung ↻ Possible, but not certain Cantonese: 成/全村人 jyutping: seng4/cyun4 cyun1 jan4 from english whole entire + malay kampung village; community; hometown ↻ cantonese (jyutping) Possible, but not certain 成/全村人 seng4/cyun4 cyun1 jan4 large group of people; everyone ← cantonese (jyutping) 成 seng4 entire; whole; all or cantonese (jyutping) 全 cyun4 entire; whole; all + cantonese (jyutping) 村 cyun1 village + cantonese (jyutping) 人 jan4 people
Words.Definition: an entire group or bunch of people
Words.Example: Don't shout so loud. Later the whole kampung knows you're here!

Words.English Translation: → English: why + you + so + Singlish: liddat from english why for what reason + english you 2p. sing. & pl. pronoun + english so to the extent that; very + singlish liddat that way; like so ← english like just as; such as; similar to + english that used to indicate sth. further from the speaker than 'this'
Words.Definition: 'why are you this way?'; 'what's wrong with you?'; used to express disapproval, disappointment, or frustration at a person's behaviour, decisions, antics, etc.
Words.Example: " ... Irving is right. Why you so liddat one? Drinking hot gelato."... "It's really good, Chia Ying, you want to try?""Yucks no ... "

Words.English Translation: → English: win from english win become victorious; triumph
Words.Definition: (ditransitive, sometimes transitive) to defeat; to outdo; to best, e.g. in an argument, game, or contest
Words.Example: I never win him at bowling before; he damn pro cos he played CCA in primary school.

Words.Word: win liao lor /ˈwɪn˦ ljaʊ˨˩ ˌlɔː˦/ 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → English: win + Singlish: liao + lor from english win become victorious; triumph + singlish liao particle indicating perfective aspect or change of state; already; (approximately) past tense marker ← min nan (poj) 了 liáu particle indicating perfective aspect or change of state; already; (approximately) past tense marker + singlish lor particle indicating obviousness, suggestion, resignation, begrudgement, emphasis, etc. ← hokkien / cantonese (jyutping) 啰 囉 lo1 particle indicating obviousness, suggestion, or completion
Words.Definition: expression of grudging and reluctant resignation, e.g. admitting defeat in an argument, or conceding that something unwelcome has happened but one can do nothing about it
Words.Example: He told me he wear red underwear, that's why he strike Toto... This kind of logic, OK lah, win liao lor.

Words.English Translation: → General chinese: 风 風 pinyin: fēng from general chinese (pinyin) 风 風 fēng rheumatism ← general chinese (pinyin) 风湿 風濕 fēng shī rheumatism ← general chinese (pinyin) 风 風 fēng wind; one of the disease-causing Six Excesses in TCM ← general chinese (pinyin) 湿 濕 shī wet
Words.Definition: rheumatism; pain or disorder of the muscles, tendons, joints, bones, etc.
Words.Example: Stimulate body warmth and reduces aching in joints, draws out impurities, and get rid of excess wind and water retention.

Words.English Translation: → Cantonese: 镬气 鑊氣 jyutping: wok6 hei3 from cantonese (jyutping) 镬气 鑊氣 wok6 hei3 desirable char or sear and its flavour on food cooked in a wok ← cantonese (jyutping) 镬 鑊 wok6 wok + cantonese (jyutping) 气 氣 hei3 breath; air; smell; essence; spirit
Words.Definition: the desirable char or sear, and its resulting flavour, that is produced on food that has been cooked in a well-seasoned wok over a fierce fire
Words.Example: A simple dish of fried mee sua ($16/small) was surprisingly enjoyable — silky in texture and smoky with the perfume of wok hei.

Words.English Translation: → English: slow from english slow late; taking a long time
Words.Definition: slow; late, especially with regard to being caught up with news, current events, popular culture, etc.
Words.Example: happening again. loading damn wols ... is it because of an excess in overseas site visitors?

Words.English Translation: → English: won't + die ↻ Hokkien: 𫧃死 𣍐死 poj: bōe-sí from english won't will not ← english wonnot contraction of 'will not' ← english will aux. future tense marker + english not adverb used to negate sth. + english die become dead; stop living ↻ hokkien (poj) 𫧃死 𣍐死 bōe-sí won’t/doesn’t die ← hokkien (poj) 𫧃 𣍐 bōe won’t; doesn’t; isn’t + hokkien (poj) 死 死 sí die; dead
Words.Definition: ‘no harm trying’; ‘it won’t kill you’; ‘it’s worth a shot’; used to reassure someone that attempting something is not too risky or has manageably low consequences
Words.Example: Why you so scared to try stinky tofu? Try a bit won't die one la.

Words.Word: wong tong gou 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Cantonese: 黄糖糕 黃糖糕 jyutping: wong4 tong4 gou1 from cantonese (jyutping) 黄糖糕 黃糖糕 wong4 tong4 gou1 brown sugar sponge cake ← cantonese (jyutping) 黄糖 黃糖 wong4 tong4 brown sugar ← cantonese (jyutping) 黄 黃 wong4 yellow + cantonese (jyutping) 糖 糖 tong4 sugar + cantonese (jyutping) 糕 糕 gou1 cake
Words.Definition: brown sugar sponge cake, a steamed Chinese cake made from a fermented batter of rice flour, brown sugar, water, and a leavening agent. It is normally portioned into triangular or cuboid slices for serving. If made with white sugar instead, it is known as bak tong gou.

Words.English Translation: → Cantonese: 㖞 喎 jyutping: wo3 from cantonese (jyutping) 㖞 喎 wo3 used to emphasize, indicate realization or sarcasm, etc.
Words.Definition: used at the end of a sentence to indicate realization or understanding
Words.Example: Oh, is liddat wor…

Words.Word: wu eh bo eh 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 有个无个 有個無個 poj: ū--ê-bô--ê from hokkien (poj) 有个无个 有個無個 ū--ê-bô--ê nonsense; trifling matters; drivel ← hokkien (poj) 有 有 ū have + hokkien (poj) 个 個 ê possessive particle; one + hokkien (poj) 无 無 bô not have + hokkien (poj) 个 個 ê possessive particle; one
Words.Definition: nonsense; trifling matters; meaningless drivel
Words.Example: youngester nowadays too much money and time, thats why they got the spare time to think about other wu eh, bo eh stuff and feel the stress.
Related: talk cock sing song play ping pong

Words.English Translation: → Min nan: 有划 poj: ū-hôa from min nan (poj) 有划 ū-hôa worth it; value for money ← min nan (poj) 有 ū have + min nan (poj) 划 hôa profitable; a good deal
Words.Definition: worth it; being a good deal; worthwhile; value for money
Words.Example: Eat there is the most wu hua. Got soup, no need to wash utensils, food is warm and fresh. Last but not least, no need to pay 30 cents more
Related: ai pee ai chee ai tua liap nee

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: xiao di di from singlish xiao di di little boy; immature young boy ← mandarin (pinyin) 小弟弟 xiǎo dì di little brother; little boy
Words.Definition: a boy or young man who is or appears immature but tries to act mature for their age, is physically small, and is often associated with xiao mei meis or older girls
Words.Example: Those xdd that sell ice-cream from door to door, so lucrative meh? ... How come they don't want to do food deliveries? Sell ice cream more lucrative ah?

Words.English Translation: → Mandarin: 香蕉人 pinyin: xiāng jiāo rén from mandarin (pinyin) 香蕉人 xiāng jiāo rén (pej.) Chinese person who is overly Westernized ← mandarin (pinyin) 香蕉 xiāng jiāo banana + mandarin (pinyin) 人 rén person
Words.Definition: (pejorative) a person of Chinese descent who speaks English well but has poor skills in Chinese languages, is only in touch with Western culture, and lives a Western lifestyle

Words.English Translation: → Mandarin: 小 pinyin: xiǎo from mandarin (pinyin) 小 xiǎo little; small
Words.Definition: (before an adjective) low-key; kind of; rather
Words.Example: Why she trying to act step? She think she xiao cool ah.

Words.English Translation: → Mandarin: 小弟弟 pinyin: xiǎo dì di from mandarin (pinyin) 小弟弟 xiǎo dì di little younger brother; little boy
Words.Definition: a little boy
Words.Example: Georgette Chen affectionately called me xiao di-di (little brother) because of my young age and to me she was more like a mother than a teacher in the classroom.

Words.English Translation: → Mandarin: 小妹妹 pinyin: xiǎo mèi mei from mandarin (pinyin) 小妹妹 xiǎo mèi mei little younger sister; little girl
Words.Definition: a little girl
Words.Example: I thought I might cope with a flirty xiao mei mei shouting "hi, ham-sum" across a bak kut teh stall.

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: xiao mei mei from singlish xiao mei mei little girl; pretty, youthful-looking girl ← mandarin (pinyin) 小妹妹 xiǎo mèi mei little younger sister; little girl
Words.Definition: a pretty, young, and very youthful-looking girl, especially one that acts naive, spoilt, and fragile to attract attention
Words.Example: The XMM, it seems, is at least partially defined by a state of mind ... Like our beloved ‘ah lian’, female counterpart to the ‘ah beng’, people don’t seem to like the XMM very much. XMMs are described as naive, cringy, and immature.

Words.English Translation: → English: yeah/yea & Malay: ya from english yeah/yea yes; expn. of acknowledgement & malay ya yes; expn. of confirmation or acknowledgement ← dutch ja yes
Words.Definition: yes; expression of acceptance, agreement, or acknowledgement

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: ya + Cantonese / hokkien: 啰 囉 jyutping / poj: lo1 / --lo͘ from singlish ya yes; expn. of acknowledgement ← english yeah/yea yes; expn. of acknowledgement & malay ya yes; expn. of confirmation or acknowledgement ← dutch ja yes + cantonese / hokkien (jyutping / poj) 啰 囉 lo1 / --lo͘ used to express obviousness, logical connection, impatience, etc.
Words.Definition: 'yeah, exactly'; 'I know, right?'; 'that's what I'm saying'; used to indicate agreement, commiseration, etc.
Words.Example: Ya lor! He talk only what and you all jump on him like dat! So unfair one ah!

Words.English Translation: → Cantonese: 饮胜 飲勝 jyutping: jam2 sing3 from cantonese (jyutping) 饮胜 飲勝 jam2 sing3 ← cantonese (jyutping) 饮 飲 jam2 drink + cantonese (jyutping) 胜 勝 sing3 completely; entirely; victory; success
Words.Definition: 'cheers!'; 'bottoms up'; phrase said as a toast when drinking
Words.Example: It's a raucous, friendly contest at most wedding dinners, but this time, toasters will be competing to set a Guinness World Record for the longest yam seng cheer ever made.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 缘投 緣投 poj: iân-tâu from hokkien (poj) 缘投 緣投 iân-tâu handsome
Words.Definition: handsome
Words.Example: Everyone in the room couldn't help but notice the new intern, who was not only skilled at his job but also quite the 'yandao'.

Words.English Translation: → Min / hakka: 枵鬼 poj: iau-kúi from min / hakka (poj) 枵鬼 iau-kúi gluttonous; stingy; (Budd.) preta; hungry ghost ← min / hakka (poj) 枵 iau hungry; starving + min / hakka (poj) 鬼 kúi ghost; demon; evil spirit
Words.Definition: a glutton; a gourmandizer

Words.English Translation: → Min nan: 夭寿 夭壽 poj: iáu-siū from min nan (poj) 夭寿 夭壽 iáu-siū die young; short-lived; damn; wretched ← min nan (poj) 夭 夭 iáu die young; die early + min nan (poj) 寿 寿 siū longevity; long life; old age
Words.Definition: (vulgar) 'damn it!'; exclamation of frustration, anger, outrage, exasperation, etc.
Words.Example: My employer's mother stays with us occasionally. When she talks on the phone, I always hear her say "yao siu." ... I asked my employer's son what the words meant. He told me it means "hello." ... One day, my employer sent me to buy something from the shops, where I met my employer's friend. I put on a sweet smile and greeted her: "Yao siu, maam."

Words.Word: yao siu kia 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Min nan: 夭寿 夭壽 poj: iáu-siū + 囝 poj: kiáⁿ from min nan (poj) 夭寿 夭壽 iáu-siū die young; short-lived; damn; wretched ← min nan (poj) 夭 夭 iáu die young; die early + min nan (poj) 寿 寿 siū longevity; long life; old age + min nan (poj) 囝 kiáⁿ son; child; dimin. suffix
Words.Definition: (vulgar) damned kid; an wretched child; an insufferable brat
Words.Example: If know who is the father, his boss better sack the father! Let him spend more time disciplining his yao siu kia and also make the family get into financial difficulties so that yao siu kia cannot have any material comforts and don’t have so much time to hang around void decks and bully people

Words.English Translation: → Dubious or unconfirmed Malay: yang-yang or Dubious or unconfirmed yakin or Dubious or unconfirmed Old javanese: jâjâ or Dubious or unconfirmed Hokkien: 厌 厭 poj: ià from malay Dubious or unconfirmed yang-yang god; deity; god of gods or malay Dubious or unconfirmed yakin confident; certain ← arabic يَقِين yaqīn certain or old javanese Dubious or unconfirmed jâjâ father or hokkien (poj) Dubious or unconfirmed 厌 厭 ià fed up with; have enough of; cannot tolerate; grow tired of
Words.Definition: arrogant; conceited; stuck-up; boastful
Words.Example: Sometimes, when you meet people like that, the first meeting doesn’t go so well. Like, ‘Why did she make fun of me?’ But there’s just something that still attracts you to that person. Maybe because she’s just so yaya — that’s why I like her ...

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: yaya + king from singlish yaya arrogant; conceited; stuck-up; boastful ← malay Dubious or unconfirmed yang-yang god; deity; god of gods or malay Dubious or unconfirmed jâjâ father or hokkien (poj) Dubious or unconfirmed 厌 厭 ià fed up with; have enough of; cannot tolerate; grow tired of + singlish king (suffix, usu. sarcastic or pejorative) the epitome of sth. ← english king (usu. male) the ruler of a monarchy; a powerful or preeminent person
Words.Definition: a constant show-off; someone who is always being arrogant, boastful, and conceited
Words.Example: You know a Singaporean is worth his or her salt when they hear, "eh that guy so stylo milo (trying too hard to be stylish)" and replies, "yeah he think he some yaya papaya (someone who thinks he or she is very important)"

Words.English Translation: → Singlish: yaya + English: papaya from singlish yaya arrogant; conceited; stuck-up; boastful ← malay Dubious or unconfirmed yang-yang god; deity; god of gods or malay Dubious or unconfirmed jâjâ father or hokkien (poj) Dubious or unconfirmed 厌 厭 ià fed up with; have enough of; cannot tolerate; grow tired of + english papaya Carica papaya or its edible fruit ← spanish papaya edible fruit of the tropical evergreen Carica papaya tree ← lokono papáia papaya
Words.Definition: arrogant; conceited; show-offy; boastful
Words.Example: You know that feeling of being oddly attracted to that "yaya papaya" girl? The one who lives "east side on the green line" and tells you you’re late when you’re on time?Of course you do.

Words.English Translation: → Dubious or unconfirmed Malay: yeh-yeh from malay Dubious or unconfirmed yeh-yeh game played by jumping over a rubberband chain set at increasing heights
Words.Definition: a game played by linking rubber bands into a chain or rope, which is then set at a certain height that players must jump over. After players have cleared the chain at a given height, the height is then increased until only one player can make it over, at which point the player (or team of players) with the most points is declared the winner. Players shout out their score when jumping over the chain, with the first jump being “zero point”, then the next being “one point”, and so on.
Words.Example: To play zeropoint, we first need a "yay-yay" or a rubber rope. To make one, you need to collect as many rubber bands as possible. Sometimes you can buy a whole packet of them in the shops.

Words.English Translation: → English: yellow + noodles from english yellow colour between orange and green on the visible light spectrum, approx. 560 - 590 nm in wavelength + english noodles long, thin strings of cooked dough ← german Nudel pasta; noodle
Words.Definition: yellow alkaline egg noodles slightly thicker than spaghetti, often used in Hokkien cuisine but also now common in other local and regional cuisines. They are usually sold fresh, rather than dried. The use of a carbonate salt (typically sodium or potassium carbonate) gives the noodles a unique taste and springy texture, as well as causing their distinctive bright yellow colour.
Words.Example: The mixture of yellow noodles and coarse bee hoon are al dente without beign too soggy or overcooked.

Words.English Translation: → Hainanese: 薏粑 hrs: i4 ʔbua3 from hainanese (hrs) 薏粑 i4 ʔbua3 steamed glutinous rice kueh with sweet filling
Words.Definition: a traditional Hainanese steamed kueh consisting of an outer skin of glutinous rice flour, stuffed with grated coconut, gula melaka (though traditionally sugar and candied winter melon), sesame seeds, and crushed peanuts. It is steamed in a cup made of folded banana or coconut leaves, and typically marked with a red dot of food colouring on top.

Words.Word: yo ah yo 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Min nan: 摇啊摇 搖啊搖 poj: iô--a-iô from min nan (poj) 摇啊摇 搖啊搖 iô--a-iô shake; sway ← general chinese (pinyin) 摇啊摇 搖啊搖 yáo ā yáo shake; sway
Words.Definition: to sway; to shake, often to music

Words.English Translation: → Min nan / hakka: 药 藥 poj: io̍h from min nan / hakka (poj) 药 藥 io̍h medicine
Words.Definition: medicine

Words.Word: yong tau foo 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Min nan / cantonese: 酿豆腐 釀豆腐 poj / jyutping: iōng-tāu-fū / joeng6 dau6 fu6 from min nan / cantonese (poj / jyutping) 酿豆腐 釀豆腐 iōng-tāu-fū / joeng6 dau6 fu6 originally Hakka dish of tofu, vegetables, mushrooms, etc. stuffed with a mixture of ground pork and/or fish paste ← hakka (pinfa) 酿豆腐 釀豆腐 ngiong4 têu4 fu4 Hakka dish of tofu stuffed with ground pork and fried or braised ← hakka (pinfa) 酿 釀 ngiong4 stuff a filling into sth. and cook; ferment + hakka (pinfa) 豆腐 豆腐 têu4 fu4 tofu
Words.Definition: a dish originally from Hakka cuisine, consisting of various items such as tofu, vegetables, mushrooms, etc. stuffed with a mixture of ground pork and/or fish paste. In Singapore, items are usually chosen from a display at a yong tau foo stall, and often include a number of other items, such as fried wontons, sausages, sotong, noodles, rice, etc. The chosen items are then cooked in one of various styles, such as dry, soup, in a laksa broth, with curry, etc., and served with a sweet bean sauce and chilli.
Words.Example: Yong tau foo is a Hakka dish that has become ubiquitous with the office lunch crowd and tables “choped” (or reserved) with tissue packets and umbrellas.

Words.Word: you ask me, I ask who 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → English: you + ask + me + I + ask + who ↻ General chinese: 你问我，我问谁 你問我，我問誰 pinyin: nǐ wèn wǒ, wǒ wèn shéi from english you 2p. sing. or pl. pron. + english ask pose a question + english me 1p. sing. obj. pron. + english I 1p. sing. pron. + english ask pose a question + english who which or what person ↻ general chinese (pinyin) 你问我，我问谁 你問我，我問誰 nǐ wèn wǒ, wǒ wèn shéi 'how would I know' ← general chinese (pinyin) 你 你 nǐ you; 2p. sing. pronoun + general chinese (pinyin) 问 問 wèn ask + general chinese (pinyin) 我 我 wǒ I; me + general chinese (pinyin) 我 我 wǒ I; me + general chinese (pinyin) 问 問 wèn ask + general chinese (pinyin) 谁 誰 shéi who
Words.Definition: 'how on Earth would I know'; 'hell if I know'; used to exasperatedly or incredulously express that there was no point in asking one a question, as one has not got the faintest idea about it
Words.Example: "When they need you, like during exam time, they run to you ... When the exams are over and they don't need you, they run away from you. Why, ahh?"Like they say on the streets: You ask me, I ask who?

Words.English Translation: → Min nan: 油炸粿 poj: iû-chā-kóe from min nan (poj) 油炸粿 iû-chā-kóe Chinese deep-fried puffed dough baton ← min nan (poj) 油 iû oil + min nan (poj) 炸 chā deep-fry + min nan (poj) 粿 kóe kueh
Words.Definition: a Chinese deep-fried puffed dough baton. It is usually dipped into a sauce or liquid like milk and eaten, or cut into slices and eaten as part of dishes like rojak or tau suan.

Words.Word: you die, I die, everybody die
Words.English Translation: → English: you + I + everybody + die from english you 2p. sing. & pl. pronoun + english I 1p. sing. pronoun + english everybody everyone; all people + english die become dead; stop living
Words.Definition: used to express that the consequences of a situation will be dire, terrible, and disastrous
Related: you think, I thought, who confirm

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 幼面 幼麵 poj: iù-mī from hokkien (poj) 幼面 幼麵 iù-mī thin egg wheat noodles ← cantonese (jyutping) 幼面 幼麵 jau3 min6 thin egg wheat noodles ← cantonese (jyutping) 幼 幼 jau3 thin; fine + cantonese (jyutping) 面 麵 min6 wheat noodles
Words.Definition: a type of thin egg noodle made of wheat flour, commonly used in Cantonese dishes. It is made of the same dough as pan mee and mee hoon kueh.

Words.English Translation: → English: you + say + Singlish: leh from english you 2p. sing. or pl. pron. + english say speak; talk + singlish leh particle used for emphasis, questioning, etc. ← hokkien (poj) 咧 --leh particle used for emphasis, questioning, etc.
Words.Definition: (rhetorical, sarcastic) 'duh'; 'if not, what?'; used in retort to a question that the speaker feels the answer to is obvious
Words.Example: - Ohh, isit the space too less that’s why we shift to this room ah?- You say leh?

Words.English Translation: → General chinese: 你才是 pinyin: nǐ cái shì from general chinese (pinyin) 你才是 nǐ cái shì (contrary) ‘you are the one’; ‘it’s you who is’
Words.Definition: (contrary) ‘you are the one’; ‘it’s you who is’; ‘look who’s talking’; ‘you’re one to talk’; used to assert that the listener is being hypocritical in criticising and badmouthing someone else, because they themself are the one actually guilty of that very fault
Words.Example: You then lah! He was the one doing it correctly, bodoh.

Words.Word: you think, he thought, who confirm
Words.English Translation: → English: you + think + he + thought + who + Singlish: confirm from english you 2p. sing. & pl. pronoun + english think ponder; reckon; be of the opinion; presume + english he 3p. sing. m. pronoun + english thought past tense of ‘think’ + english who which or what person + singlish confirm for sure; guarantee ← english confirm ensure the truth or accuracy of a statement ← old french confermer confirm ← latin cōnfirmō confirm
Words.Definition: (rhetorical) used to chastise or rebuke someone who has made hasty conclusions and assumptions without properly ensuring the facts of the situation, especially after the consequences of their negligence have come to pass
Related: you think, I thought, who confirm

Words.English Translation: → Mandarin: 油条 油條 pinyin: yóu tiáo from mandarin (pinyin) 油条 油條 yóu tiáo Chinese deep-fried puffed dough baton ← mandarin (pinyin) 油 油 yóu oil + mandarin (pinyin) 条 條 tiáo long item; strip; long piece
Words.Definition: a Chinese deep-fried puffed dough baton. It is usually dipped into a sauce or liquid like milk and eaten, or cut into slices and eaten as part of dishes like rojak or tau suan.

Words.English Translation: → English: your + head ↻ Cantonese: 你个头 你個頭 jyutping: nei5 go3 tau4 & Malay: kepala otak kau from english your 2p. sing. & pl. possessive pron. + english head part of the body containing the brain and several sensory organs ↻ cantonese (jyutping) 你个头 你個頭 nei5 go3 tau4 'my ass'; 'my foot'; 'as if' ← cantonese (jyutping) 你 你 nei5 you; 2p. sing. pronoun + cantonese (jyutping) 个 個 go3 (dial.) possessive particle + cantonese (jyutping) 头 頭 tau4 head & malay kepala otak kau 'my ass'; 'my foot'; 'as if' ← malay kepala otak (derog.) head; brain ← malay kepala head ← sanskrit कपाल kapā́la skull; cranium + malay otak brain + malay kau (familiar) 2p. sing. pron.
Words.Definition: (rude) 'my ass'; 'my foot'; 'as if'; expression of disbelief, disagreement, disdain, disapproval, doubt, etc., used as a retort to something one thinks is highly exaggerated, unlikely, or untrue
Words.Example: Not so ex your head lah bodoh, the satay cost $4 per stick!

Words.English Translation: → English: young + punk from english young youthful; not old; at an early age + english punk young delinquent; thug
Words.Definition: a young delinquent who is associated with a subculture of dressing in street fashion, smoking and/or vaping, riding e-scooters, wearing sling bags, and general gangsterism, hooliganism, troublemaking, and rebellious behaviour; a Gen Z Ah Beng

Words.English Translation: → English: yong tau foo from english yong tau foo originally Hakka dish of tofu, vegetables, mushrooms, etc. stuffed with a mixture of ground pork and/or fish paste ← min nan / cantonese (poj / jyutping) 酿豆腐 釀豆腐 yōng-tāu-fū / joeng6 dau6 fu6 originally Hakka dish of tofu, vegetables, mushrooms, etc. stuffed with a mixture of ground pork and/or fish paste ← hakka (pinfa) 酿豆腐 釀豆腐 ngiong4 têu4 fu4 Hakka dish of tofu stuffed with ground pork and fried or braised ← hakka (pinfa) 酿 釀 ngiong4 stuff a filling into sth. and cook; ferment + hakka (pinfa) 豆腐 豆腐 têu4 fu4 tofu
Words.Definition: abbreviation of yong tau foo.

Words.English Translation: → Mandarin: 鱼生 魚生 pinyin: yú shēng from mandarin (pinyin) 鱼生 魚生 yú shēng raw fish; sashimi ← mandarin (pinyin) 鱼 魚 yú fish + mandarin (pinyin) 生 生 shēng raw; fresh
Words.Definition: a salad dish popularly eaten to celebrate Chinese New Year, developed in either Singapore or Malaysia from a tradition of either Teochew or other Guangdongese origin (though unlike the modern salad, the original dish essentially only consisted of sliced raw fish).It is often the centrepiece of a reunion dinner, where the salad is placed in the centre of a table and communally tossed with chopsticks by all present. Tossing the salad as high as possible while noisily shouting out auspicious greetings, and the big mess that often results, is considered a key part of the festivities.It consists of raw fish (in modern times, usually salmon), julienned vegetables such as carrot, turnip, and capsicum, and often the flesh of fruits such as pomelo or mandarin orange. Before tossing, it is topped with a variety of ingredients, each traditionally paired with an auspicious saying. This usually includes ground peanuts, sesame seeds, honey, sesame oil, pok chui crackers, plum sauce, and five spice powder.

Words.English Translation: → English: yuck + Singlish: -s from english yuck expression of disgust + singlish -s colloquializing suffix
Words.Definition: 'ew'; 'yuck'; expression of disgust
Words.Example: My chicken pox has become worse. Yucks (10x)! It makes my body look like a toad —disgusting!! I hate chicken pox!!!

Words.English Translation: → English: -z from english -z (urban slang) suffix used to add a quirky, silly, cool, or cute twang
Words.Definition: colloquializing suffix, normally used to create a slang term with a quirky, silly, cool, cute etc. twang from another word, e.g. boom → boomz or rabak → rabz

Words.English Translation: → Cantonese: 揸弗 jyutping: zaa1 fit1 from cantonese (jyutping) 揸弗 zaa1 fit1 take charge; lead; give orders; drive
Words.Definition: to take charge; to give orders; to lead
Words.Example: Ah Loong now no Acting PM, SG no zaa fit guy!!!

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 才 poj: châi + 在 poj: chāi from hokkien (poj) 才 châi talent; ability; talented or gifted person + hokkien (poj) 在 chāi steady; solid, confident, and collected under pressure; skilled
Words.Definition: extremely skilled; talented; of exceptional ability; outstanding; highly capable
Words.Example: White people—even those in our country—rarely make an effort to speak or understand Singlish in a manner comparable to the proficiency with which Singaporeans speak and understand English. When a white person does learn to speak a modicum of Singlish, it is amazing—wah! dis angmoh damn zai!—because he has gone out of his way.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 𫏐 蹔 poj: chàm from hokkien (poj) 𫏐 蹔 chàm step hard; stomp with great force; trample
Words.Definition: to step hard; to stomp with great force
Words.Example: coz singapore road too pack... u change lane liao.. suddenly the 2 car distance in front zham brake, u zham brake.

Words.English Translation: → Min nan: 走 poj: cháu from min nan (poj) 走 cháu run; flee
Words.Definition: to run; to flee; to make a hasty getaway
Words.Example: Before I could ask what he needed my NRIC number for, he zao already.

Words.English Translation: → Likely, but other possible etymologies exist Hokkien: 走虎 poj: cháu-hó͘ from hokkien (poj) Likely, but other possible etymologies exist 走虎 cháu-hó͘ impressive, (lit.) running tiger ← hokkien (poj) 走 cháu run + hokkien (poj) 虎 hó͘ tiger
Words.Definition: impressive

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 走光 poj: cháu-kng from hokkien (poj) 走光 cháu-kng be exposed
Words.Definition: to be exposed; to accidentally expose oneself; to have a wardrobe malfunction
Words.Example: Tell CFO that car with bodykit and not lowered is like women sitting with their legs open when wearing a miniskirt..... will zao kng one.... hahaha.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 走 poj: cháu + 兵 poj: peng from hokkien (poj) 走 cháu run; flee + hokkien (poj) 兵 peng soldier; army
Words.Definition: a deserter; a soldier who goes AWOL (absent without official leave)
Words.Example: Soldiers who chau peng tend to be privates and low in IQ and educational profile. By contrast, more intelligent and better-educated men and officers tend not to chau peng or go AWOL: but they skive or jiak zua.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien / teochew: 走私 poj: cháu-sai from hokkien / teochew (poj) 走私 cháu-sai smuggle, (slang) elope; cheat; commit adultery ← hokkien / teochew (poj) 走 cháu run; run away; leave + hokkien / teochew (poj) 私 sai secretly; stealthily; private; selfish
Words.Definition: to cheat on a partner; to be romantically unfaithful; to commit adultery
Words.Example: u sure or not? ... after u tender say today (1 month notice), u can just zao sai one meh? ... don't chut pattern ... wait reputation tio burn
Related: tiong sim is a lie, hongster never die

Words.English Translation: → Min nan: 走声 走聲 poj: cháu-siaⁿ from min nan (poj) 走声 走聲 cháu-siaⁿ go off tune; voice crack ← min nan (poj) 走 走 cháu run away; leave + min nan (poj) 声 聲 siaⁿ voice; sound
Words.Definition: to go off-tune when singing
Words.Example: i will zao sia at times esp when tired ... got one time, i go to chalet and play through whole nite and go jamming the next day, veri tiring... no energy to sing. keep zao sia through out all songs

Words.English Translation: → English: zap from english zap sound of electric arc; electric shock
Words.Definition: to poke somebody with a finger in ticklish or sensitive areas, especially with the intent of tickling them

Words.English Translation: → Cantonese: 执笠 執笠 jyutping: zap1 lap1 from cantonese (jyutping) 执笠 執笠 zap1 lap1 (mph.) close down a business; go bankrupt ← cantonese (jyutping) 执 執 zap1 pick up; gather; clean out; tidy up + cantonese (jyutping) 笠 笠 lap1 woven basket
Words.Definition: (idiom, of a business) to close down; to go out of business; to go bankrupt
Words.Example: last time joo chiat area got one shop selling this kind of curry puff, even got rendang beef filling. super shiok but tiagong zhup lup oredi

Words.English Translation: → English: zero + point from english zero 0; nothing ← french zéro zero ← italian zero zero ← medieval latin zephirum zero ← arabic صِفْر ṣifr zero; empty; void ↻ sanskrit शून्य śūnya zero; empty; void; blank + english point unit of score in a sport or game
Words.Definition: a game played by linking rubber bands into a chain or rope, which is held at each end at a certain height which players must jump over. The height is subsequently increased as players clear successive heights. Players shout out their score when jumping over the chain, with the first jump being “zero point”, then the next being “one point”, and so on.
Words.Example: One of the more modern games played in the school playground is zero point, popular among girls. A series of elastic bands strung together make a long flexible "rope". A child holds each end, while a third makes skillful manuevers across the bands as they are raised gradually from ankle height to head height.

Words.English Translation: → Dubious or unconfirmed Mandarin / cantonese: 乍 pinyin: zhà + Dubious or unconfirmed 诈 詐 pinyin: zhà from mandarin / cantonese (pinyin) Dubious or unconfirmed 乍 zhà suddenly; extend out + mandarin / cantonese (pinyin) Dubious or unconfirmed 诈 詐 zhà bluff; feign
Words.Definition: a turn-based finger game played between two (or sometimes more) players. Players may choose between three different symbols made with the hands, which are called by various names, but always include: two fingers held together pointing upwards (‘man’), two fingers held together pointing away from oneself (‘plane’), and a closed fist (‘rock’), with ‘man’ beating ‘rock’, which beats ‘plane’, which beats ‘man’.At the beginning of the game, players hold up their hands in the ‘man’ position, and play e.g. scissors paper stone to decide who goes first. On their turn, a player shouts ‘zha!’ and changes their hands to show their choice of hand symbol, while the opponent does the same; if any of their symbols beats any of the opponent's, the opponent's corresponding hand is ‘knocked out’ for the rest of the game. The winner is the player who ‘knocks out’ both their opponent's hands first.

Words.English Translation: → Dubious or unconfirmed Mandarin / cantonese: 乍 pinyin: zhà + Dubious or unconfirmed 诈 詐 pinyin: zhà + English: boom from mandarin / cantonese (pinyin) Dubious or unconfirmed 乍 zhà suddenly; extend out + mandarin / cantonese (pinyin) Dubious or unconfirmed 诈 詐 zhà bluff; feign + english boom (onom., intj.) a loud, explosive sound; sth. sudden happening
Words.Definition: a variant of zha where players shout 'zha-BOOM!' instead of 'zha' on their turn for emphasis

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 装 裝 poj: chng from hokkien (poj) 装 裝 chng dress up; decorate; refurbish; adorn; pimp up

Words.Definition: exact; certain; spot-on; accurate

Words.Definition: ‘are you sure?’; ‘is that right (or not)?’; used to question the accuracy of, or confidence in, a statement

Words.Definition: to kiss

Words.English Translation: → Cantonese: 啜啜 jyutping: zyut3 zyut3 from cantonese (jyutping) 啜啜 zyut3 zyut3 kiss; suck (reduplicated), (onomatopoeic) kissing or sucking noise ← cantonese (jyutping) 啜 zyut3 kiss; suck

Words.Example: The two young lovebirds met at the staircase after school to zhut-zhut and fool around.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 煮炒 poj: chír-chhá from hokkien (poj) 煮炒 chír-chhá assorted Chinese food consisting of mostly fried or stir-fried dishes sold at small restaurants, kopitiams, or hawker centres ← hokkien (poj) 煮 chír cook + hokkien (poj) 炒 chhá stir-fry
Words.Definition: a style of Chinese food consisting of assorted, mostly fried or stir-fried dishes, usually with a relatively large selection and variety. Usually sold at small restaurants, kopitiams, or hawker centres.
Words.Example: Chin Yan celebrated his retirement with small gathering of old work friends over zi char and a few rounds of Tiger beer.

Words.English Translation: → General chinese: 自动 自動 pinyin: zì dòng from general chinese (pinyin) 自动 自動 zì dòng of one's own accord; automatically ← general chinese (pinyin) 自 自 zì own; oneself; self + general chinese (pinyin) 动 動 dòng move; act
Words.Definition: to take initiative; to do of one's own accord
Words.Example: They know I'll like to manage a small wedding, hence they also "zi dong". My parents have offered to return us the ang baos for the 4th table. That's what families are for, I feel, you "zi dong" a bit, I "zi dong" a bit.

Words.English Translation: → Min nan: 做 poj: chò from min nan (poj) 做 chò be; do
Words.Definition: (usually in compounds) to be

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 做无 做無 poj: chò-bô from hokkien (poj) 做无 做無 chò-bô do nothing; loaf or laze around; idle ← hokkien (poj) 做 做 chò do + hokkien (poj) 无 無 bô nothing; not have
Words.Definition: to do nothing; to loaf or laze around; to be unproductive; to idle

Words.Word: zo bo lan 简 繁
Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 做无 做無 poj: chò-bô + 𡳞 poj: lān or 懒 懶 poj: lán from hokkien (poj) 做无 做無 chò-bô do nothing; loaf or laze around; idle ← hokkien (poj) 做 做 chò do + hokkien (poj) 无 無 bô nothing; not have + hokkien (poj) 𡳞 lān (vulgar) penis; the fuck; the hell; used to express disgust or hokkien (poj) 懒 懶 lán lazy; idle
Words.Definition: (vulgar) to do fuck-all; to loaf or laze around; to be unproductive; to idle
Words.Example: who here got a zhuo bo lan job? ... Can share what job is it ... What is the salary ... Why the company is willing to hire you and pay you salary when you are zhuo bo lan?

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 做戏 做戲 poj: chò-hì from hokkien (poj) 做戏 做戲 chò-hì act; pretend; feign, (lit.) put on a play ← hokkien (poj) 做 做 chò do; make + hokkien (poj) 戏 戲 hì play; performance; movie
Words.Definition: to put on an act; to pretend; to feign or deceive
Words.Example: Zo Hee (Make Movie), the sequel to Zo Gang, features cameo appearances by local film personalities, including Tan Pin Pin.

Words.English Translation: → Min nan: 做侬 做儂 poj: chò-lâng from min nan (poj) 做侬 做儂 chò-lâng behave properly; conduct oneself well ← min nan (poj) 做 做 chò be; do + min nan (poj) 侬 儂 lâng person; human
Words.Definition: to behave properly; to conduct oneself well; to have integrity and ethics
Words.Example: This guy jin jialat. Looks like he made enemies everywhere. Zo lang can zo until so cham.

Words.English Translation: → Hokkien: 做歹侬 poj: chò pháiⁿ-lâng from hokkien (poj) 做歹侬 chò pháiⁿ-lâng be the bad guy; sb. who does bad or evil things ← hokkien (poj) 做 chò do + hokkien (poj) 歹 pháiⁿ bad; evil + hokkien (poj) 侬 lâng person; man; human
Words.Definition: to have to be the bad guy or villain, e.g. when one has to delegate people to do an undesirable task

Words.Definition: taking up or wasting space; blocking the way; hindering
